We booked a 'City Queen' room with Tokyo Tower views - what a sight when we checked in after a long trip, well worth the extra i think.We could not fault the room in any way - we thought it was spacious and clean, had views to die for, staff were impeccably polite and friendly, location was perfect as we only had a few days here (Fall out of bed and you are in Shiodome station - its literally on the door step, 5-10 minute walk to Shimbashi for the JR line), and of course it had the all singing and dancing loos!Sadly breakfast was not included and we thought the hotel continental prices were a bit steep so we opted for a couple of local cafes/bakeries - there is one on the ground floor (Hotel reception starts on the 25 floor) that does a simple coffee and outrageous doorstep toast (with salad?!). Its not open at weekend though.There is also one (Excelsior cafe) close to the crazy clock - you'll know what i mean when you see it! - 5 mins walk away on the 3rd level (walk way).

In a reasonable location near Shiodome and is cheaper than some of its nearby competitors but is a pretty tired hotel, with small rooms and fairly basic amenities. the price is probably "what you get" but has the feeling of somewhere you don't want to spend time in your room.

I stayed at this hotel with a friend for 3 nights. The hotel is OK for Tokyo. Small, not much room for 2 people. The bed to me more on the hard side. The room is quiet, so you get good sleep. The breakfast buffet was good. The service prompt and efficient, as most of the hotels in Tokyo. This was my second visit of Tokyo, so I opted this hotel knowing its location would be convenience. Subway right underground the hotel, bus station across the street. Lots of restaurants/stores underground the hotel, as well. Our room has a view of Tokyo tower.

V clean.. Nice breakfast choice, nice ambience, v helpful staff. Is good for a stay. Has all the standard prerequisites of a big city hotel. location is v accessible with train stations and Ginza close by.

Good balance between price and quality. Good positioning for using public transportation and going all around Tokyo. Good choice also if you travel with children and need more space in the room without booking 2 rooms.

We stayed at the Hilton hotel Tokyo last year and the Grand Bach in Kyoto this year. The Park Hotel was our choice for Tokyo. There were no frills at this hotel and a beer in the bar cost over £7. We paid about £168 pounds a night for a view of the Tokyo sky tree but I could not see it when sitting in my bed . The staff were mediocre and nowhere near as friendly as the other two hotels. Difficult to find from Shimbashi station and about a 10 min brisk walk. Shimbashi is on the Yamanote line which is very convenient for most sights. The hotel is nearer to the Shiodome line but this underground station is not as convenient.Many shops and bars in the underground walkways. We did not eat at the hotel as it was too expensive.

Hotel was less than 20 minutes drive from haneda airport. The subway was within 5 minutes walk, in fact it is in the actual building of this hotel, so VERY convenient. The rooms were a good size, clean and comfy. Plus they had those awesome Japanese type toilets! Hairdryer was provided as well as toiletries and tea and coffee making set. Breakfast was not included in our accommodation but if you wanted it cost around £12-15 per person i think. For breakfast they had a wide variety of food and traditional Japanese breakfast too. This hotel is quiet, so sleeping would not be a problem. They also have a small gym which you can you privately as they have time slots to book you in. Staff are friendly and helpful too. Although if you are on a budget then I wouldn't recommend this hotel.

I stayed at this hotel for four nights. On my first night I had a view of the water but then I realised the city views are better so I asked a different room with views of Tokyo tower and they duly upgraded my room to s bigger and better one. I enjoyed the daytime and night time views it was breathtaking on the 69th floor! Breakfast was good too.

It may be a bit tedious for some since you have to go all the way up to the 25th floor to access the hotel from the ground floor, but as travellers, me and my husband didn't mind at all. the lobby has a great view of the Tokyo Tower and the city, everyone was helpful and warm. Even their practicumer from the Concierge went above and beyond to ensure that we got a cab and that we are well attended to. The room is bigger than the usual Japanese based hotels (like Citadines, Ibis, etc) and has an awesome view of the city and bridge.

Lovely hotel with amazing views of Tokyo, in a great location within easy walking distance to fabulous shopping and dining, and close to all public transportation. All hotel staff were extremely friendly and helpful, from suggesting restaurants to mailing packages to telling us best shops to buy what we were looking for. We had a room facing the Tokyo tower which offered a most incredible view both at night & during the day. Highly recommend taking time to enjoy a beverage at the bar or in the hotel lobby at least once. We also ate at the Japanese restaurant in the hotel which turned out to be our most fabulous meal in Tokyo (also with an amazing view!) We would definitely recommend the Park Hotel to everyone!

I love this place. The views are fabulous (see below) - it is worth paying a little extra for the Tokyo Tower view, the staff are, as I'm coming to expect from here in Japan, impeccably polite, and overall it is very well done. The hotel starts at floor 25 (if you are looking for the lobby) up to the top and it has a big central atrium with gives a personal, indoors-outdoors feel. This is the hotel at which they filmed some of Lost in Translation - there is a Scarlet room, but a different bar and no pool (in case you come expecting a swim).In case you are not coming by taxi and have a JR pass (thoroughly recommended for travelling throughout Japan), catch the JR line down to Shimbasi station and then there is an aerial walkway which connects you to the hotel ... Ok it is not direct and there are a few twists and turns but you'll find it useful rather than traipsing along at street level.On a mundane level they have a coin operated laundry in case you don't want to have to pay for everything to be fully hand washed.A really fantastic base for visiting Tokyo.Room was very good too with all facilities with, of course, heated and all singing all dancing toilet!

The room was immaculate and people who worked there were truly top notch. Not to mention the easy access via subway.And I can't complain about location either. Hamarikyu Gardens really balanced the whole Tokyo experience.Nothing but the best at Park Hotel Tokyo.

The Park Hotel is a very modern "art" hotel. The location was great with easy access to the Tokyo JR line and the Tokyo Metro. The rooms are very clean and very modern. The hotel is not huge but it does offer a fantastic view from the main lobby which is located on the 25th floor. Our room faced west so that you could get the best evening views of both the city and the sunset.Rooms are not as large when compared to a pure western style room but the spaces was comfortable. The service and the staff were all top of the line and we were treated by name and given our room even though we checked in a bit early. Once again shopping and dining are all close by and easy access. I would stay here again in the future.

Clean, functional rooms. Friendly staff. Great city views. Airport hotel ambience. Drinks and food at the restaurants within the hotel are outrageously expensive. Better to use the concierge service to visit one of the many really good local restaurants..

I've stayed here quite a few times now over the last 5 years, and it is always great service and an enjoyable stay.The rooms are a good size for Tokyo, the beds comfortable and its always clean and beautifully presented. The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor and the rooms above. The hotel has had art collections in the lobby area for a long time, but now have "Art Rooms". Individually designed rooms with a story, along Japanese themes, I chose the "100 poems room" which is a lovely room.Staff are helpful and speak English, check in and check out is always quick and efficient.

We started our trip to Japan at the Park Hotel and were really impressed.Situated on the upper floors of the Shiodome media tower, the views from our room were amazing.Access was good as its situated close to several subway lines.The staff were very courteous and helpful and really worked hard to make our stay enjoyable.Breakfast was by good and is taken in a beautiful area full of modern art and with uninterrupted views up to the top of the building.Can't fault anything about the stay. The air con was the best I've experienced. Very quiet and very good.Full marks from me.

Location and the size of the facility were perfect Service was outstanding , particularly Concierge with fine Restaurant recommendations, House keeping service was prompt and efficient , amenities top qualityLobby furnishings comfortable and pleasing

Great location for seeing the city.Initially have to get your bearings to find your way. Friendly and efficient as ever. Lot of tourists some work going on remodelling the rooms which causes some noise. Best view is city then bay side.. They were incredibly polite and helpful. Beautiful rooms with the art and good spec as opened in 2014.

For a 4-star hotel at its price range and location, it's hard to beat Park hotel. The hotel is nearly brand new. It sits atop a mixed office-hotel building.Fixtures and amenities are class leading. Rooms are relatively specious, considering Tokyo standard. Bathrooms, while of a typical modular design, are very well put together and very well designed. A case in point, lots of small bathrooms in tokyo hotels with poor lighting makes showering feel like you are doing it in a cave. Park hotel puts lighting fixture above the bath tub giving the bathroom an airy feel.Location-wise, it is 6 to 10 mins away from metro and train stations. The closest train station is Shimbashi. It is all connected via underground passageway. Overall, Park hotel deserves its accolade and is highly recommended.

When the bus or the taxi drops you off in front of an office tower, don't worry. The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor. Though the check-in process can be slow, particularly after a long flight, don't worry. Just make sure they know you are there, then sit down and wait.The rooms are clean and comfortable. Try to get one with a view of the old Tokyo Tower.The lobby staff is very friendly and accommodating and that makes up for the somewhat limited lobby menu should you wish a light dinner before getting needed sleep.

The location of the hotel is superb--there is a subway station underneath the hotel and it is in walking distance to both the Fish Market and the Ginzo quarter (shopping!). The hotel is quite modern and has a quite modern architecture (e.g. featuring a huge lobby over 9 floors, during our stay they projected some modern art on the walls over all 9 floors). The rooms are modern and clean, for Japanese standards even spacious (i.e. you have enough space to open a large suitcase on the floor). The best thing about the park hotel is the view: we hat a room facing the river and we could see airplanes taking off and landing on nearby Haneda Airport. The room has high windows and a window seat for two. We enjoyed sitting there in the evening and watching trains, boats, and airplanes in nightly Tokyo.

This was one of the best places we stayed at during our trip to Tokyo. My favorite part was the view. We had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower from our room on the top floor of the hotel (and of the building). The staff were friendly and helpful. The breakfast buffet was good, but a little pricey at $28/person. We did eat it twice if that tells you anything. They had coin laundry onsite which was helpful for us, but the cycle did take a very long time.Room was comfortable and very clean. The hotel had a great location adjacent to both the Shinbashi and Shiodome stations. Don't accidentally go the the Royal Park Hotel. It's right across the street, and even some of our taxi drivers were confused which was which.

Me & my hubby stayed in few hotels in tokyo But then Park hotel we would rate this at the top! For a very good price you get everything you look for in a hotel ~very clean, amenities like a selection of hot breakfast items and cookies and a very nice lounge area. Room is gorgeous, very creative design,very authentic. Above all, is the very helpful, kind and friendly staff ,can speak english~that greets you wherever you go in the hotel. Definitely will be coming back for next visit.

Location was great for an early trip to the fish markets (only a short walk away). Also convenient to Ginza and imperial palace gardens. We stayed in an artist queen room. Amenities were tired and like an old business hotel. Art was super cute and the only reason to chose this hotel. They were able to provide a cot for baby.

We recently stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for one night during a stopover in Tokyo. Check-in was smooth and pleasant, but our stay experience made a turn for the worse when we arrived at our room. Upon walking into the bathroom we immediately noticed some hairs stuck to the wall in a prominent area just by the door, which suggested that the room had probably not been inspected properly. The design of the room itself was fine, although on the small side, slightly dated and bland - think business hotel - despite the futuristic location in the Shiodome district. As some other reviewers have mentioned, the interior could definitely benefit from a refresh. Meanwhile, our poor experience with the hotel's service continued the next morning, when we called the front desk for help with our luggage and had to wait for quite a long time for the bellhop to show up, so we ended up having to call again. Of note, this was around 10AM, not exactly the peak checkout time for the hotel (which has a 12PM checkout policy). Finally, after checking out and coming back later in the day to collect our luggage, we found the bell desk empty and had to wait until someone showed up 5 minutes later. Unfortunately, nobody at the front desk nearby came to assist us. All in all, despite the generally good reviews that this hotel seems to be receiving, our experience was not as good, and we probably won't be returning.

We loved our stay in an art room, high up, looking out over Ginza. Good sized room, comfy bed, clean bathroom, everything you need. Amazing block out curtains guaranteed a good sleep in. Would stay again. Would be even better with milk in the fridge for coffee.

I LOVE a great hotel room. The view was amazing, with a window seat to really ENJOY the view with your morning coffee; the location sublime; the help, couldn't be more helpful, went above and beyond to find us a place to dress up for the sumo wrestling match (they even got out kimono back to rental place because we had to leave early the next morning); the coffee shop had a breakfast savory treat (pastry-meat-potato) that truly was my favorite thing I ate in Tokyo. The room was on the small side but I'd certainly stay there again. Extremely fond memories, I find I'm smiling as I sit here and write this review

This hotel is worth the money. Perfect location of you want to get around Tokyo! Everyone who works here is beyond amazing. They're kind and beyond helpful! We had an awesome view of the train tracks and a fantastic view of the park right across the way! So great! I cannot say enough good things about this hotel!

We decided to close our 3 weeks trip in Japan by staying the last night in this hotel. Clearly we may say that we made a great decision. The hotel is very nice with amazing views to the Tokyo tower or Odaiba. The lobby is located on floor 25th and rooms are from floor 25th to floor 34th. Rooms size is slightly bigger than other hotels in Japan and all rooms count with a wide window where you may sit down and enjoy the views. Hotel location is great because there are two different JR and subway stations very close to the hotel: Shimbasi and Shiodome. Besides, Ginza area is located 10 muinutes from the hotel by walk.Another aspect we would like to highlight is the staff friendliness and hospitality. Once we arrived to the hotel they explained us the different rooms and views available and after checking our passports they realized that my birthday was one day ago. Due to this during the evening they bring to our room a bottle of champagne which was a very nice surprise after coming back from our visit to Tokyo. The hotel also offers a very comfortable shuttle bus service to Haneda and Narita airports. It is not for free but the price is very convenient.

Upon arriving late into Tokyo and getting lost on the subway - lucky for google maps to direct us to the correct exit. The hotel is located in a convenient location approx 5-10 minutes walk from Shimbashi station. The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor and even arriving at close to midnight the staffs are attentive and welcoming.I stayed on the 32nd floor in the artist room which has nice wall paintings and great view of the city. The room is cosy and could not find any faults with it. There was free WiFi available. There are plenty of restaurants and eateries opened till late around Shimbashi station. Stayed in July for 2 nights on business.

The hotel is located on a convenient location, almost on top of the Subway station Shiodome and at a 5 minute walk from Shimbashi station. The Artist Room Queen was nicely decorated; don't expect a large room though. There was free WiFi available, also a (very) small fitness room. Breakfast was for us the big plus: gluten free bread!! Hard to find in Tokyo as a tourist...the staff was very friendly and did their very best, as they did with the bread. So we had a nice stay; the hotel is highly recommended.

I understood before coming to Tokyo that prices are high, hotel rooms are small, and the breakfasts were not so exciting; however, I wasn't prepared for the fact that our staff doesn't seem to display graciousness. We paid 24 dollars for the breakfast buffet, 12 for our 7 year old. When I saw the very limited options, and didn't like the eggs they served, I was told if I needed to get poached eggs, that would be an extra charge of 10 dollars. I had served myself only a miso soup and a bread roll, and ordered a capuccino. When I asked to be served a la carte, the capuccino and eggs were included and so was the single piece of bread that the head waiter was trying to figure out in the transaction. This is when we are paying 386 US dollars a night per room for the very tiny rooms, which we had to get 2 of because we couldn't possibly fit in one room with our 2 girls.In the end, I was told that the miso soup would be complimentary because it wasn't in the a la carte menu, but my 2 poached eggs, single bread and capuccino came out to 20 us dollars. I think that is ridiculous! When we asked for water to be served we were pointed in the direction of where to serve it ourselves. Just little details like this make it unpleasant to stay here.

We booked a room with a view on Tokyo tower and Mount Fuji which was worth every penny. Absolutely loved the scenery--which was best very early in the morning (we discovered after getting up for our early flight). The location is very convenient as well: close to Ginza and two central subway stations. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Thank you!

This was our first time in Japan, and understanding that compared to US hotel room sizes, it would be smaller including the bed sizes as well, we had two to a room for about 175 usd a night for a slightly small than a US "full" sized bed. Since i have nothing to compare to, take what you will for the size but in terms of the room and lobby and service, that was all top notch. the room is very space efficient, you have ample space in the restroom, nice shower and pressure, and cool sliding windows with a curtain which gives it a very nice traditional Japanese vibe. The front desk was super friendly and even printed out my three reservations for restaurants i asked them to make. one of them was Jiro's son's restaurant and that was a cinch to get a month in advance. you can speak english with them at the front, and prior to arrival over email was fine as well. lastly its literally 5 min from suidobashi subway, which is a good area (close to many major attractions) if you are visiting tokyo. overall i would highly recommend Niwa!

My partner won 3 nights stay at the hotel and their rooms and bathrooms were much bigger than the rooms I'm used to in Japan - Shinjuku Prince etcThe view was beautiful and their breakfast selection was decent for Japan's western hoels' standards. It's abiout 8-12mins pleasant walk from the train station to the hotel - through the underground tunnels etc and certainly not as overwhelming as Shinjuku station. It's a great choice for business and slow travellers who prefer to avoid crowds. I would still prefer to stay in Shinjuku for the sheer convenience and shops/eateries galore!

The hotel gave us a big surprise on our wedding anniversary. Our room was the one with romantic view of Tokyo tower which is very very beautiful especially at night. Hotel staffs are nice and helpful.The hotel is near to JR 新橋 station in about 5-10 mins walking.

Very convenient hotel to explore on foot and by public transport. A bit out of the way but nice rooms, impeccable bathroom and a lovely view at night. Employees were consistently friendly and helpful. Breakfast was a nice mix of western und japanese food and they even offered me gluten free bread. If you have ever stood before a large buffet and wondered what to eat you'll understand

The rooms are great. Folks are very friendly helpful. The Lobby is on the 25th floor. Breakfast is reasonably expensive at the hotel but there are many places down below the hotel at the subway level to get a reasonably priced breakfast. The view from the rooms are fantastic and have good connections for the all the subways and trains.

Easy to locate in Shimbashi train complex the Park provides a haven of luxury in the sky. Reception is on 25th floor and you can see part of the city as you sweep upwards in the lift. Very helpful concierge. Comfortable and functional room with good city view. Heated toilet with bidet in it! Good breakfast. Enjoyable start for a Japanese sojourn.

While in Tokyo I stayed in the Park Hotel Tokyo for a couple of nights, and decided to splurge a little bit extra for a room with a view of Tokyo Tower. Worth it!If you've never visited this hotel before and/or don't speak Japanese very well, it may be a little tricky to find this place as the front desk is located on the 20-something floor of the building. But a little persistence pays off. The hotel layout is stylish and modern, and the staff there are extremely friendly and helpful.As with most Japanese hotels, the room was a little small, but otherwise it was clean, modern and contained all the necessities.Close to public transport, it was easy to navigate Tokyo from this destination. Having major landmarks such as Tokyo Tower nearby also helps.

We stayed there for our honeymoon, for 15 days during xmas vacation. The view from our room was stunning, the hotel itself is clean, modern and very well located. The are is safe and clean, you can walk around the Ginza area, especially when you arrive and you have no idea where to go for the first night. Totally satisfied

Spectacular hotel with lots of interesting art displayed. Forms the top 8 floors of a skyscraper. Great views across Tokyo and internally down to the lobby floor. Rooms small but comfortable. Smoking is the norm in Japan hotels, so all the rooms tend to smell of smoke wherever you go, which is rather off putting. We ate in the restaurant, which served really good steak. Two main courses and two beers £65, which is reasonable for a five star hotel in Japan. Central position. Easy access to subway. Collection point for taxis outside. Bus to airport calls at the hotel.

My wife, two children and I stayed in the Park Hotel for a week (and then one night at the end of our trip) in July when on holiday. We had rooms overlooking the Tokyo tower (worth paying the extra for, we thought) with Mt Fuji visible when the weather was clear). The rooms were reasonably sized for a capital city (although the children's double was a little tight) with good amenities in the bathroom. Some of the rooms have rather funky art -- including the one I stayed in -- which was fun. Other facilities included a communal washing-machine/dryer, a tiny gym (for one person/small group use at a time, bookable in 45min slots -- I never had any difficulty getting in whenever I wanted so suspect not used that much); and vending machines with ice on I think all floors. The Tokyo tower view rooms are above the railway tracks and while a little noisy during the day it wasn't a problem at night; but if you're very sensitive to noise worth bearing in mind.There is a large atrium where breakfast is served along with light evening meals and drinks, and a couple of restaurants and a bars off it. The bar makes good cocktails, priced at upmarket hotel levels. We ate in the French restaurant a couple of times (excellent food, very swiftly served -- they had a special multi-course set menu for guests which was good value). We were less impressed with the breakfast buffet -- all fine but not standout, worth buying as a package rather than pay-as-you go if you can and want a large breakfast).Service was, as might be expected, punctilious and very high quality. It's worth joining the loyalty scheme if staying there a few nights as they give some freebies.The hotel itself is located close to Shimbashi station (for JR trains and the metro) and there are plenty of local restaurants. Ginza is a 10-15 minute walk, ditto the Tsukiji fish market, the Imperial Palace Gardens about 25 and it's generally convenient for the central area's attractions.

We've travelled to Japan on a number of occasions and usually stay in the area adjacent to the main Tokyo station. On this occasion we were travelling with friends who were staying in Ginza so we researched hotels in the Shiodome/Ginza area. The Park Hotel was a reasonably priced quality hotel and we had two rooms with fantastic views of the Tokyo Tower, at night the view was breath taking. Staff were very helpful and went to great lengths to make us feel welcome. Although the location of the hotel seems somewhat out of the way, the location is essentially on top of the subway and not far from the railway station so it is very easy to get around and to access Haneda airport. We walked into Ginza from the hotel on more than one occasion it is only a 10-15 minute stroll, we also spoke to people who had walked to the Tsukiji fish markets from the hotel. I enjoyed our stay, rooms are not huge, but in comparison to other accomodation we've stayed at was at the higher end in terms of space. The buffet breakfast at the hotel was nice and had a good mix of Western and Japanese dishes. Would certainly stay there again.

We had a very convenient stay at this hotel. The view to the city from the reception desk is impressive. Our room was located in the 34th floor and facing the sea. The view from the room was great. Room was convenient, clean and simple but a bit small. Location is very good. Tsukiji market (which is set to move elsewhere in November 2016) and Ginza are within walking distance. Yurikamome takes you to Odaiba. With Yamanote you can reach pretty much everything else. The hotel is only a few steps from Shiodome station, from where you can get into Oedo and Yurikamome lines. It is a bit longer walk to the Shimbashi station (which serves the Yamanote line), takes maybe 10 minutes. The entire walkway is covered but has many stairs so walking can be inconvenient if you have big luggage. There is a very convenient bus service directly from Narita Airport to the front door of this hotel. We found the price we paid very much worth it - hotels just next door charge you 2-3 times more.

We stayed here at the end of our trip to Japan, as a substantially less expensive contrast to the Conrad Hotel (20 second walk away also in Shiodome / Ginza), where we stayed at the beginning of our trip (see my review of the Conrad).At half the price (or less) of The Conrad we found this hotel to be an excellent hotel with excellent value and excellent service. The staff was wonderful, friendly, and absolutely went out of their way to assist us. The room was large and comfortable and well appointed and clean and quiet. The breakfast buffet was probably the best of our entire trip.Here was the best bonus for us. We made a few purchases that did not fit in our suitcase and had set aside a half day to go out and buy boxes / tape or another suitcase. When we asked the bell-lady where we should go, she want to their back room and provided us with fantastic boxes for about $5 US each, and all the wrapping tape and bubble wrap we needed. That simple service was priceless.Bottom line: If you don't need or want (or want to pay for) the super high end luxury, this is a perfect alternative in a great location!

I booked this hotel because it was the best looking option within walking range of Tsukiji, which worked great. The entrance to the hotel is on the second floor of the lobby and it's a bit strange to get to, but there is plenty of signage (in English as everywhere in Tokyo) so it's no that big of a deal, even your first time there.The service was immediate upon entrance, very friendly and quick and capable. The room, while small by US standards, was a nice size and very well done. There was a nice sitting area at our window which overlooked Tokyo Tower- on the first day Mt Fuji was visible in the background which was very nice. The bathroom was nice as well, with a good stock of supplies if you forgot anything.The lobby atrium area is very nice, the ceiling is several stories high and they project art onto one of the walls at night. They have an art display on the ground floor. We did not eat at the hotel, but they did have very good drinks and comfortable seating.They offer a limousine (nice bus) service to the airport which was a great alternative to getting across town to Tokyo Station. Also in the lobby there is a currency changing machine, which was easy to use and offered a 98.-something rate to the dollar (pretty solid) rate. We also used the concierge to make dinner reservations and she was very friendly and accommodating and succeeded both times- the 1st time the restaurant wasn't open during the day and she promptly sent an e-mail update to let us know we were in.We slept great in the hotel and for all the talk I heard about Tokyo being expensive I thought this was a great value.

The rooms offer a phantastic view over Tokyo. The hotel is well located. The breakfast buffet was also a highlight. We will choose the Park Hotel again, when we are in Tokyo again. Last but not least: do not forget to eat at Hanasnshou Restaurant -- great Keiseki set menu.

the room was average size but expensive. Concierge is helpful. Service is good and nice with smile. nice view of tokyo tower at night. But our bathroom had a bad smell the first day we arrive. At first we thought it was bleacher or something so we didnt notify the front desk. but the smell keep showing up occasionally so we had to open the bathroom door every day we leave. No ventilation in bathroom was totally a bad idea. The housekeeper put the towel upside down once. This detail should not be happening in this kind of 4 star or 5 star or such an expensive hotel. subway donwstars is very convenient. food and shopping malls are all near. Good location.

Great hotel and location. Close to trains/subway. Had a JR pass and used the train the whole time. Small rooms so we had to get two rooms for our family of 4. Ask for view of the Tokyo tower-really great view.

We stayed for 3 nights in a room with the Tokyo tower view. The view was great as well as the location. The subway station is location just beneath the hotel. Easy to access from the airport. The staff was really helpful. Would also recommend the breakfast, they had both Japanese and western style. Would love to stay here again!

I was disappointed with this hotel as I paid so much money for what I got! Although the the staff were friendly and the views form the room were amazing the room it self was very small and not very clean. Also not at all sound proof! The room we got was facing the Tokyo tower but was just above the railway lines so you could hear the trains going by. I found it catered to the tourist and found it to be very pretentious!! The building itself was very confusing to get to and from the metro. It is intertwined with other high rise buildings and located very close to where a lot of homeless people are sleeping at night under neath a bridge! So save your money and go stay at the Tobu Levant hotel!!

I recently stayed in this hotel in a double room with a city view. The hotel is conveniently located on top of and with direct access into Shiodome station on the Oedo line. Shimbashi station ( Ginza line and Asakusa line ) is also very near by.The room itself was spacious compared to the business hotels I have stayed in the past in Tokyo with a good view of the cityscape. Candidly I have no real opinion on my stay at this hotel either way it simply meets the criteria of a hotel room, i would not say it is luxury nor basic but rather somwhere in between, lacked complimentary water which surprised me for the price but provided all other basic amenities.Staff were polite and helpful. Whilst the hotel met my basic needs, I would choose to seek somewhere new on my next stay.

My room on the 30th floor had a great panoramic view of Tokyo, I particularly enjoyed being able to look down on the main station and watch the bullet trains.The hotel its self is a treat with well appointed rooms, a breathtaking central atrium, art on the walls and plush breakfast area. The perfect place for my last night in Japan.

We really enjoyed out stay in a Tokyo Tower view room at the Park Hotel. We loved the view & the room, and were also very pleased with the hotel's location and access to public transit. The hotel is right over one station, and you can walk to a station on the main city loop within transfer tunnels & bridges. It seemed everywhere we needed to go was within a few stops of one of these two stations with very little need to transfer. The hotel itself was lovely with spectacular views from their position starting on the 25th floor. Even if you don't have a Tokyo Tower view room, you'll enjoy the views from the lobby. Definitely recommend this hotel for a stay in Tokyo!

Been here in June 2016 for our honey moon.... the hotel is simply amazing...amazing in every single detail and in his beautiful view able to offer.A special thanks to all the staff.Hope to come back from Italy as soon!!Arigato Gozaimas and.... Sayonara! :)

The location is super convenience from the prospective of travelling from the airport (airport bus stop) and going out for sightseeing (two metro lines are just at the doorsteps). Service is good including there are plenty of English speaking staffs so you won't be "lost in tokyo".

We booked this hotel to be close to the Tsukiji fish market. Proximity to the Shiodome subway station makes travel very easy to other neighborhoods such as Shinjuku and Harajuku. Hotel was very clean, we upgraded to the Tokyo Tower view and it was definitely worth it. We could even see Mt Fuji!

We split up our locations in Tokyo and Park Hotel was our 2nd stop. The lobby is beautiful, with high ceilings in the atrium and comfortable areas to relax after a long day. The hotel has sort of a business vibe, something I usually avoid on vacation, but I wouldn't count that as a negative in this case. The rooms are comfortable, clean and normal sized. We opted for a Corner King and the view of Tokyo Tower is really a treat to behold. We dined once in the lobby, pretty average. They do have a very cool whiskey bar with an impressive list. Expensive.

Everyone is super nice! All staff members speak perfect English. The rooms are so beautiful. Modern with a touch a traditional Japan. So, close to the train stations, it's under the building. Close to the fish market and golden gai.

I stayed here with my family including 2 children ages 4 and 6 in a triple room which was a good size. The hotel is in a good location for travel around Tokyo near to subway stations Shiodome and Shimbashi. Hotel itself is clean and efficient, with friendly staff. The hotel seems to have both tourists and business people staying here and I think would be good for either.

We absolutely enjoyed our stay at Park Hotel Tokyo. The room, grounds, and amenities were superb. Clean and beautiful. All of the staff were so friendly and helpful and spoke wonderful English. The hotel is very convenient to the metro, and is in a perfect location for exploring the city. There is also a Family Mart on the premises, which is great! We only wish we could have stayed a couple more days.

We were very pleasantly surprised with the quality of the hotel. Very clean, excellent service and good location. We had a room for 3 which worked out well. Loved the bathroom. Located close to two metro stations and within walking distance of Ginza. We highly recommend and would stay there again.

The Hotel is incapable to change a reservation that due to a typo we made for one day too early - five minutes after making the mistaken booking. Thus we have to pay for the night although we are not staying and won't be staying the night we planned.

Train station, restaurants and shopping adjacent to lovely hotel. The staff wasvery professional, knowledgeable about their city and helpful in writing addressesin Japanese to be used with taxi drivers who often don't speak english.Hotel clean and style very effective. We were grandparents showing two tweensJapan and they loved it.

I stayed at this hotel while on a business trip. It's located right at the Shiodome, and conveniently close to the JR and Metro lines. Check-in was quick and easy and the front desk was friendly and helpful providing me with maps of the metro system, and maps for specific neighborhoods I had asked about. The receptionist even provides me with some helpful suggestions. The room was nice, had great toiletries and was a good size room, for Tokyo standards. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

We enjoyed our stay at this hotel. Very helpful staff. Everyone spoke English. The concierge was very helpful. It is located right next to a subway station. Short walk to ginza shopping district It was a little bit of a pain to have the hotel lobby on the 25th floor but wasn't that big of a problem.

Excellent hotel in great location with fantastic view of the city. Modern, wonderful staff & great place to stay for your Tokyo visit. Comfortable bed with coffee & tea facilities. Room of adequate size.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is in great location in Tokyo. While the hotel isn't cheap, it provides excellent service and you are enables you to get around Tokyo easy with metro stops accessible by underground walkway & access to JR Shimbashi Station. The rooms are well sized and fitted out very well for a short stay. We used the Hotel as a start & finish point for our trip to Japan and can highly recommend the hotel if it is in your price range.

Aloha,Very nice Hotel. The staff was friendly and helpful throughout the stay.Very clean. Great Location.I Highly recommend this hotel for travelers to Tokyo!It was very close to train station. There was a 24 hour store open in basement of hotel.

This is a fantastic hotel! Location is also key with close proximity to the fish markets (if you want a 2:00am walk to line up for the markets). Plenty of choices to eat close by and also the metro. Extremely friendly staff and helpful with directions. We enjoyed the breakfast here with plenty of variety. The room had a beautiful view (worth paying more to enjoy). A very pleasurable stay! Make sure you don't confuse it with the Royal Park Hotel after a late night as we did.

I loved staying at this hotel. Everyone was very friendly, the architecture was modem and all areas of the hotel were spotless. I stayed in the tower view room with an amazing view of Tokyo Tower, which rivaled the views from the observatories in the city. I also went to the spa which was a little small with very limited amenities but the actual massage was great. I did not eat the food but the main restaurant near the lobby always had guests and a casual yet chic ambience. The hotel is very close to a couple of subway stations, Shiodome and Shimbashi, so it's convenient and easily accessible. Loved the artist's work throughout the hotel. Would definitely stay here again!

The service here is excellent, and the view from my room was spectacular. The rate that I got for this hotel made my stay an excellent one. The only issue that keeps me from rating this hotel as outstanding is that I feel that the rooms require a bit of renovation. The decor in my room felt a bit heavy. Other than this, I find the quality to be very high, and if I could get a similar rate, I would stay here again.

We stayed for 2 nights. Staff is great. Hotel is very comfortable. Only complaint - breakfast is expensive but that is across the board in all Japanese hotels I stayed at. Nevertheless I would stay at Royal park hotel next time because it has easier access to the shimbashi train/subway station.

Better than I expected. 2 rooms - small as you'd expect - concierge was very helpful. Breakfast was great if a little expensive. Broadband was super fast even at busy times. Beds were comfortable, 7/11 on basement floor with ATM. Shiodome is a great location. Some excellent little restaurants out past Shimbashi station, and close to Ginza and Tsukuji.

I really love this hotel. The rooms are big and very modern which give you a fantastic view over Tokyo and Tokyo Tower. The staff as all over Japan is very friendly and humble. The location is good and conveniant to go to Ginza for example. Very good hotel for sure.

We had room 3207 one of the best rooms for excellent views of the Tokyo Tower & artwork. Mt Fuji is notoriously 'shy' but this room also afforded us an amazing view of it when the sky cleared. The staff could not be more welcoming or helpful. We were also touched to receive a half bottle of champagne for our wedding anniversary (the main date in our holiday). The laundry service was efficient. The Thann sanctuary massage was very relaxing & the shower gel that smells so nice is also provided for use in the hotel rooms. We would recommend this hotel. You can reach it easily from Shimbashi station, stay underground out of the heat & follow signs to Shiodome where you will find signs to the Park hotel. If coming via taxi they can get confused by Royal Park Hotel but as that is next door you should still get to where you want to. The concierge is very helpful so enlist help to find restaurants directions & in our case we were very happy with the Tokyo bay dinner cruise & teppanyaki restaurants booked for us. the most pleasant building entrances are on levels 1 & 3 although by foot the entrance from station is b2 where the basement aroma was off putting but get past that to hotel entrance & you get the Thann sanctuary very pleasant smell basically don't let b2 entrance put you off - the hotel is lovely. The atrium for breakfast is good too. All in all a good base for a holiday in Tokyo as it is a fantastic location with excellent transport links.

It has been a very nice experience. Hotel is close to Japan Rail station and you can reach all destinations by train or walking. Room are not large but in Tokyo is the right size. It is clise to Ginza and centrally located. Perfect !

I had a room looking directly at the needle and loved it! The customer service was excellent as well. If you plan on taking the metro system the location is really great as well. You are virtually on top of a New York Penn Station like area with an abundance of Eastern and Western restaurants. i can't say enough about this location.The only issue I had was the heat did not work. They did bring a heater but if it were winter (i was there June) I wonder what would have happened. Worth every penny.

Tiny rooms, tiny beds, especially if you don't have an artists room. However, service was fantastic, staff were attentive, polite and helpful! The Japanese restaurant was really good, food was explained carefully so there were no surprises! Also, bar staff carefully explained sake and shochu to us, which was nice. Breakfast was very good, great selection of food, even pizza? There's also a supermarket on the ground floor and good transport links, it's a 15 minute walk to Ginza. Overall, so good we are coming back in two weeks.

Modern trendy hotel, lobby on the 25th floor of a tower in a modern area of Tokyo. Shiodome station in the same building and 7 minute walk to Shimbashi station, which was accessible by a direct train from Haneda Airport. We'd asked for a room on higher floors with a view of the Tokyo tower, and that's exactly the room we got! Highest floor (35th) with fantastic view of the Tokyo tower. Room is not so big but comfy, very good shower and bathroom. Hotel stuff very helpful in giving tips and helping to send our luggage to the next destination. Highly recommended!

Quite nice stylish artist decor concept. Very well located (three main transport options besides taxi), great service culture and quite nice view without being too expensive. Also a very nice breakfast option.

Overall we had a pleasant stay, however two issues did not meet our expectations. 1. Location - we did not feel this was a centrally located hotel, rather a fringe locality of the CBD. 2. We did not enjoy any breakfast during our stay. The choice for a western consumer was very limited and the fact the hotel was seeking an extra ¥600 for personal cooked eggs was totally unacceptable. My husband and I have travelled the world extensively and during my husband's business life, he was a regular traveller staying in high profile hotel chains and this is not the norm for cooked buffets. Whilst ¥600 is not a sizeable amount, there is a principle. The Sheraton Hiroshima and Nikko Princess Kyoto far exceeded your breakfast standards.However the rooms were very comfortable with full amenities and good views. TV for English speaking guests is virtually non-existent. Only BBC News and CNN which a lot of the time was over-dubbed with Japanese. Also no iron provided.

The Park Hotel is a nice option for a short stay in Tokyo. The rooms are generous and accommodate triples. Nice quite air conditioning, and quite room, lovely Thann bath products, and a mini bar fridge that accommodates self purchased beverages. The morning breakfast was fresh and offered new variety each day.

This is quite simply one of the best hotels I've ever stayed in.The location is easily accessible from Haneda and serves as a good base to get to Shinjuku, Shibuya and everywhere else first time visitors would want to go.The service was excellent. I arrived at the hotel at 9am, check in is at 2 pm, they let me in the room at 9:30...now that is service! The rooms themselves were surprisingly spacious and spotless. Cleaned everyday. Toiletries are great and are replenished along with the towels everyday. The lobby provides the best view of Tokyo, in my opinion. There's a floor to ceiling window behind reception that captures the Tokyo tower and its spectacular! All in all if it's your first time in Tokyo, as it was mine, and you want a convenient base with helpful, English speaking staff this is the place for you.

First, the Park Hotel is located in Shiodome, close to the heart of the city and within walking distance of Ginza. The closest rail station, Shimbashi, is a few minutes walk and it's only a five minute ride to Tokyo Station. The nearest metro, the Odeo Line, is basically right out the front door and connects to Roppongi, the popular nightlife district, and Shinjuku, a shopping, eating, and nightlife mecca. You really can't beat the location. For the price, this hotel is really great value. The rooms are well-appointed and clean, although a bit small (like most Tokyo hotel rooms). The staff is incredible. We booked several dinner reservations through the concierge, who emailed us when the reservations were made.To get to the Park Hotel, I would suggest taking a taxi from Tokyo station when you arrive. It's only about $10. Also, try to upgrade to a larger room if you can, since they are a bit small. We had a corner twin, which had an incredible view of the bay. The hotel also has free wifi and laundry facilities.

We were pleasantly surprised with the superior service quality, organization skills, and professionalism of the staff at this hotel. In spite of visiting this hotel at the peak of cherry blossom season when the hotel was at its full capacity, we never found any lack of attention to detail. Right from beginning of making a room reservation, it seemed that the staff accommodated our requests to the greatest possible extent. We felt welcome and cared for. Even when the queues were long, a staff member would approach those waiting in life to inquire if they could help.Our room was sufficient in size, even for a couple travelling with a toddler. The room offered free WIFI. It also had a breathtaking view of the Tokyo skyline by night. The hotel was very conveniently located to the metro, the shopping district as well as the other attractions like Tsujiki fish market. Staying here allowed us to experience authentic Japanese hospitality and kindness. As frequent travellers, we can say this hotel was truly worth the money spent. Adigato to the entire Park Hotel team and a special thanks to Ms. Sugihara and Ms. Shimose for their kind and gracious attitude with guests and for going above and beyond to assist us.

Great hotel - good sized rooms by Japanese standard and toiletries supplied are very good quality. Tokyo tower view, location is fantastic, 15 mins good walking distance to Tsukiji area, another direction will bring you to Ginza area. A big garden close by 10 mins where you can take the water bus to see more of Tokyo and its surrounding areas and amazing bridges. 2 close by subway station Shiodome & Shimbashi accessible by the basement level with a few restaurants, FamilyMart where you can easily get food, Snacks, toiletries everyday necessities etc. Many restaurants, shopping, coffee bars and bakeshops just around the area.

Located on the 25th floor and upwards of the Shidome Media Tower, the hotels rooms have some pretty impressive views out the windows (although you have to pay extra to get the really fancy views). The room we have is a reasonable size with a queen size bed and is pretty nice. The location is excellent, right beside Shimbashi station so it's easy to get out and about, and lots of good eateries on the other side of the station (including good old Starbucks and Subway if you're struggling with Japanese food).The reason it doesn't get a five star rating is that even though we are up 32 floors, we can hear the trains passing by pretty loudly through the window. The bathroom shower is also angled quite horizontally, spraying the entire bathtub and onto the floor (luckily there's a drainage thing next to the bathtub, seems to have been designed this way) which cannot be changed. So smallish things for otherwise a pretty good hotel. The hotel also only has non smoking rooms :)

The hotel is very close to the train station, which makes it very comfortable. The service is very good and the rooms very clean. The Japanese restaurant in the lobby is very good, and the meat delicious!Breakfast is also very good! The hotel is also very close to the Hama-rikyu gardens and the fish market. Very recommendable!!

Stayed a week at Park for a business trip.Park hotel occupied the top 7 floors of a commercial building with the lobby sited on the 26 floors, which gives a great view of the Tokyo tower from the lobby especially in the night. Room wise is rather small, hardly with much space for luggage but they really made good use of space design to provide everything within the limited space given.Love the hotel for its convenient being just next to Shidome station and an easy walk to Shimbashi station, where the working crowd gathers for their Izakaya night out til late. So food is never an issue there. It's also a 15 min stroll to Tsujiki, which mean u can head there for breakfast and back within an hour provided you don't join the queue for the more popular restaurants there. It's also 20 mins to the street of Ginza, and about 3km to the Imperial Palace Garden if you keen to have a run around the park.Overall comfortable stays!

This boutique hotel has everything you are looking for. The location to the metro is great. The view from the room is spectacular. The staff are very helpful. The art displayed throughout the hotel is very nice too.

Located near the Shimbashi Train station, Park Hotel Tokyo is adequate the for the average traveller. The hotel starts from the 25th floor of the building to the 34th floor, so no matter what room you get, you'll probably have a great view of Tokyo. If you can, request them to give you a room facing the Tokyo tower, it lights up at night, giving you quite the view.That being said, I did find the rooms a tad small, and, they don't give out the standard free bottle of water each day. Doesn't matter as since you can drink the tap water, however if you love cold water like I do, you'll have to fill up your own empty bottles and place them in the fridge.It's close to the Shimbashi train station (~500m) and this get useful since the subway is the easiest way to get around Tokyo. The area around the Shimbashi station is packed full of local eating joints and are a delight to visit, highly recommended.

The hotel staff was very welcoming and helpful! Definitely made my stay in Tokyo very nice!Bathrooms were a reasonable size and the room was comfortable. Not much more I could have asked for in a hotel!Room and bathroom was very clean! The view out the window was breathtaking.

This was our favorite hotel in our stay in Japan mostly because it was the most comfortable bed. We got the artist Lucky Cat room and while it didn't have a view of the Tokyo Tower, the hotel's lobby which is on the 25th floor had an amazing view. You could also see Mt. Fuji on clear days from the lobby as well. We also loved the area that the hotel was situated in- a short walk to Shimbashi station where the Yamanote line took us anywhere we needed, and right across from the businesses were lots of small hole in the wall food places to eat. We would absolutely stay here again if we return to Tokyo.

This is a decent and convenient hotel. But if you're used to more upscale hotels (e.g. The W, Fontainebleau, etc.), you will find the hotel's quality below your expectations. I stayed at the hotel for 4 nights at the Tokyo tower view room, and it was very clean and had a comfortable stay. I'd say the room is small and the amenities are limited, but if you're looking for a decent hotel for business and leisure, it will do!

Absolutely spectacular view from the Tokyo Tower view rooms. Location is relatively convenient, with Shimbashi station and therefore the Yamanote line only a few minutes of walking away. Service is top notch and very professional.The room size may be smaller than what one is used to but it is the average for Tokyo. Overall, definitely would recommend this hotel to any travelers going to Tokyo.

This was our first hotel in a 16 day tour of Japan's main island and the best bit was a distant view of Mt Fuji, on a clear day, from the reception areaJapan is an amazing country and we had a wonderful visit. The itinerary from JAL was first class and we got exactly what we had asked for which was detailed support at every transfer and full guidance in EnglishWe were quite nervous about a country with a very different culture, language and script but the reality is that Japan is trying hard to welcome tourists with English signage at train, bus stations and tourist hot spots, indeed it was obvious that additional signage had been added recently. On top of which the people are very welcoming, like to practise their English and respond well to sign language. That said we might not have ventured into some restaurants and local areas without the support of our guides who enabled us to experience the real Japan. Once in a restaurant they really want to help you and most have English and / or pictorial menusThe food was an adventure but there were plenty of Western options if wanted with the ubiquitous MacDonalds, Burger King, KFC and Starbucks in all the cities, plus generic Italian, Thai, Chinese and American restaurants. All our hotels had Western Breakfast options.Smoking was not an issue as it is banned on most city streets and the locals gather obediently to smoke at designated shelters. It is allowed in some small bars and eateries but nearly all bigger ones and those in the stations, where there was a huge choice, were non smoking. Similarly the trains have closed smoking rooms and most carriages are non smoking.The sights are a feast for the imagination with high tec modern buildings and ancient temples side by side. We took long journeys by bus and train but this enabled us to see some spectacular scenery and acres of paddy fields.As the journey progressed we got bolder and took ourselves by train to Osaka and Fushimi from Kyoto, plus twice in and out of Tokyo with just the help of a map. The Tourist Information Offices at many stations have them in English and most tourist spots have leaflets in several languages.All that you have to get your head round is that the stations can be huge with many platforms, department stores, shopping and restaurant malls. The trains run to time and carriages stop on exact markers for each car, staff at the ticket barriers are friendly and helpful.We felt very safe walking around and on all public transport, saw no evidence of crime on the streets and only a very few street sleepers in just a couple of areas although we didn't stay out late because of the time differenceOne of the highlights had to be the many gardens, we had missed the Cherry Blossom but the summer trees and flowers were glorious and, from the pictures that we saw, Autumn must be similarly stunning. I would highly recommend Japan, we would definitely go again and would be confident that we could find our own way around nowAll the hotels had good wifi and there were many free wifi areas in shopping malls as well as in StarbucksJapan isn't expensive if you avoid eating in the hotels and follow the locals who eat mainly in and around the stations and top floors of Department Stores before heading home. Entry fees are reasonable and many smaller temples and shrines are freeThe weather in May/early June was lovely, warm and dry apart from 2 wet days. It had been wet before we arrived and the rainy season starts mid-June however they are well set up for rain and umbrella storage. They also have coin lockers at stations and some tourist spots so you can sight-see without dragging bags around

Even though we had a samll room it had a great view and so well located. Like everywere in japan people were very nice and kind. The bathrooms had Thann products that smelled wonderful and felt great. We didnt have the chance to go to the Thann sanctuary but it looked so nice as well

Room clean but a little worn, everything worked and view breathtaking.Bathroom well stocked. Hospitality amazing: nothing too much trouble, staff incredibly helpful, welcoming and courteous A good base to explore Tokyo but some noise from outside late night and early morning Would be happy to return.

Stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo again in June. As expected the staff were very friendly, spoke very good English and always provided helpful directions regarding places to go.Fantastic view from the 28th Floor. Bakery items delicious. Beds still as hard as ever.Love this hotel for its attention to detail and to their customers.

We found this hotel hard to find but eventually with some good Japanese help we found the reception area at floor 25. The views are spectacular! Our room had a lovely big window with a sitting bench. You can see the Tokyo Skyline, the tower and if she was showing her face Mt Fuji from our room. At night it was a beautiful city view.I must mention here that this part of Tokyo is a concrete juggle so if you want to see the old japan with its beautiful buildings and streets please refer to ASAKUSA. I have heard of people being disappointed because all they see of this city is the jungle.I went to Ginza 40 years ago and i must say I think I preferred it then. Today Ginza is an area for the "beautiful people" with all of the same upmarket expensive shops that you can find in any city. Not my style! The service at the hotel was excellent. All of the restaurants were booked out in Ginza due to it being a Saturday night so we ate at the hotel. We sat in the lobby area and the meal was lovely. Good Aussie steak! This was our last night in Japan after 23 days and we had eaten real Japanese food most of the time.The bathroom was well stocked, the Japanese provide high quality soaps and shampoos in their ryokans and hotels. This is not a complaint just an observation but for such a high end hotel I think they need to start some refurbishment of the carpet as it was showing some wear and tear.Room 2904. We diidnt have breakfast as we had early flight.

The hotel is near JR Station of Shinbashi. Our room was very clean, the view from the room breathtaking, the staff very kind (they speak English well: quit not common, in Japan).The breakfast was good (our cappuccino was really Italian style). I surely recommend it.

Location was nice. Off the train station and a little walk and you're in the hotel elevators. It starts at the 25ths floor. So every room here has a great view. Every staff member has been really friendly and helpful. Stayed here for 3 days. Stayed in the superior rooms. Great size rooms. Hey also have an artist room where the guest would paint the walls. The lobby becomes a lounge in the evening and allow smoking. So that was a minus. It's a short walk away from a huge shopping area. Their gym was a room that was converted to fit an elliptical, stationary bike and home gym with some bands. But the view from the gym is distracting. It's on the 26th floor. You'll ask yourself hundreds of things to do downstairs and you're working out?? They have a laundry room that makes it nice. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone. The price is a little more than my previous hotels. But it was a great experience. Again the staff really made this a great experience.

First off, the hotel is actually located on the 25th Floor of the Shiodome Media Tower. I only booked this hotel purely because of one reason, the view from the Corner Twin Room overlooking Tokyo. It is just magical and gets even better at night.The building features an atrium that begins with the hotel lobby on the building’s 25th floor and extends to the 34th floor, providing panoramic views over Tokyo. Due to it being high, you are away from traffic noise and train noise.Hotel staff are very friendly and helpful, the rooms are clean pleasing to the eye.Close and easy links to transport with access to the station from the hotel. Other stations are short walks away.A possible annoyance for people might be the fact you need to take 2 lifts to get to your room and that as the hotel is situated in the business district, nightlife can be somewhat missed. If you want that then I suggest staying nearer the city center.Overall I loved it, I stayed for 4 nights and would come back to stay again

We stayed at the Park hotel on two separate occasions during a recent trip to Japan. Starting on floor 25 above a media centre, the hotel sits above the usual traffic noise and offers decent views over the City. Well located for the train network and also the glitzy Ginza shopping area as well as the business district. On one side on a clear day Mount Fuji is clearly visible and makes quite an impressive sight. The hotel is based on a triangle footprint creating corner rooms which have the better views over the city.Good staff and service with good English spoken - classic business hotel. The only niggle was the breakfast which was slightly chaotic and the buffet was poorly laid out so guests are falling over each other.

Our stay was 5 nightsFirst good hotel with an excellent staffNice room and we had a great view of Tokyo TowerSubway is in the basement easy to get aroundnow a few things i didn't likekinda far out of the action in the citythe restaurants at night are full of business guys and are very busylate night walks back to the hotel can be long and the night life in the area is not great.Unless you are looking for a late night 'RUB DOWN" I hate that hotel lobby is at the 25 floor and the 2 elevators can be a drag.The price was ok but if you want lots of fun night life stay closer to the core,but you are doing day tours its in a pretty good location When we go back to Tokyo we will try somewhere else..

We stayed here for 3 nights and returned for 1 night prior to flying back to the UK. We didn't have dinner in the restaurant but the breakfast was excellent. Beautifully fresh and continually replenished. Plenty of choice, both Japanese and Western dishes. Our room was spacious,well equipped and super-clean. Had fantastic views as well. We have to say that the very best thing about the Park is the staff. They're exceptional and a credit to the owners. Thankyou to all of them for a lovely stay. We hope to return, (soon!).

An excellent hotel which is able to mix business visitors and travellers well. The staff are extremely helpful and speak excellent English. The rooms are comfortable and have good views of Tokyo (we even saw Mount Fiji from our bed!). Because the hotel starts at the 25th floor, it doesn't have street noise.The breakfasts are a little disorganised and it is difficult to find what there is but have enough variety to suit most tastes. It took us a little time to orientate ourselves to the location, but once we worked out where we were it was easy to get to everywhere in Tokyo that we wanted to go. The subway is very close.

We throughly enjoyed our stay at Park Hotel Tokyo. We opted for the room with a view of the Tokyo tower, which was gorgeous at night. The view was worth the extra money. The size of the room was good. The hotel basement connects to a subway line making it very easy to move around the city. We didn't get a chance to try any of the hotel food, but they do have a food mart in the basement of the hotel building. We also had all of our tours booked and new what were we were going, so didn't get a chance to use the concierge. Check in and check out was easy. The staff was very friendly.

The staff in this hotel are beyong nice and helpful. Theyn helped us organise so much in advance. It is in a slightly quiet business area away from the vibrant areas but Tokyo is not cheap and hard to find space anywhere so this is a good option if you cant get something in the more lively areas. It is also very convenient for Haneda airport. All in all....great staff, nice hotel

We normally stay in the Ginza and Tokyo Station area when we are in Tokyo. So when this hotel came up, we thought it was a bit off the beaten path. Were we mistaken! Shimbashi/Shiodome is at the crossroads of Tokyo just south of Ginza and walkable to all that Ginza and Tsukiji have to offer. In some ways it is more convenient as less busy than crazy Tokyo station and more reachable to the Haneda Airport. Think ANA flights!Staff are friendly and helpful. Prices range from the US$200-300 depending on size of room. We upgraded to the larger 350 square feet suites. We didn't try the restaurant as it only looks average, but for a quality stay at a good pricepoint, you can hardly do better in Tokyo. Any example would be the next door Hilton Conrad Tokyo in the $400-500/night...Good luck and enjoy!

I have searched tripadvisor a lot before I have booked this hotel and I believe this was the best choice for me. The hotel is in a business district which is apparently built not long ago so there are 3 levels of walking area, roads and again walking area. You can use underground walk areas to reach the hotel which is very complicated. I have tried to access train station from outside which was easy since you can see the hotel. Hotel starts at 25th level and I guess goes up to 34. I have paid a bit more and reserve a corner room with a great view. The view was excellent. Everything in the room work perfectly, very silent A/C, there is a best quality air purifier/humidifier, bad was very big and comfortable, room was good size. The bathroom was also excellent with every need you may have. The toilet had a heated seat with lots of features which is usual in Japan. I did not have breakfast in the hotel since it was 22$. There is several cafes (including 2 Starbucks) in a close walking distance. The staff in the reception was extremely helpful and always smiling. Room cost was 270 EUR but this is a normal price for this quality hotel in this location. There is a shuttle bus stopping here from Narita but if you arrive after 19:00 there is no shuttle bus anymore so you need to take train which is complicated. I attached pictures of view from the room and also the hotel corner rooms from outside.

Spent just one night here at the start of our visit to Japan. We flew in early morning and got to the hotel at about 12.30pm, but couldn't get into our rooms until after 3.00pm, which was such a waste of time. We would have so liked to settle, have a refreshing shower and then go out. The situation was saved by my husband who agreed to stay in the reception, whilst the rest of us visited the antique market nearby. Perhaps this hotel needs to understand the needs of international travellers just a little more - the rooms were prepared but the 'check in is at 3.00pm' with no negotiation. The breakfast was ample with lots of choice, although you had to be determined to get a waiter to serve coffee. All in all this hotel could do better for the cost and the location.

We spent 6 nights at the Park Hotel in Shinbashi prefecture at the end of May 2016.We stayed in a twin room and also in a queen size room. The rooms were small but are not considered small byTokyo standards. Everyone we encountered at the hotel was so friendly, courteous, and kind. The hotel is spotlessly clean and well maintained. The hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower. The lobby/reception desk is located on floor 25. Our first room looked into the many skyscrapers located in the Shiodome complex. Our second room faced East with a view of the Sumida River, Tsukiji Market, and the Hama-Rikyu Gardens. The hotel provided everything needed while traveling, including, shower caps, Q-tips, hair bands, shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, loofah washcloth, toothbrush/paste, shaver/shaving cream, hairbrush, drinking glasses, and a hairdryer. The small refrigerator could be used to keep your drinks/food cool. This hotel has a very relaxing lobby, shaped like an atrium, with ample seating, and a buffet restaurant offering breakfast, lunch, and dinner. This became important since our return flight was at 1 a.m. and we checked out of the hotel at noon. We were able to relax comfortably before leaving for the airport. We found the easiest way to exit/enter the hotel was on the 3rd floor by the pedestrian deck. To walk to Ginza you walk towards the Shimbashi station (in the direction of the clock), take exit 1C, a stairway leading down to the street, and then turn right. There is an excellent supermarket located underneath the highway/railway overpass on the right side of the street. Here are the hotel's instructions from the Shinbashi station/JR Line: • Take the Karasumori Exit and turn left out of the ticket gate.• Across from you, go UP the stairs under “Shimbashi Station” sign.• Follow the pedestrian deck until you see a small walkway on the right (this is between two large buildings).• Take the walkway between the buildings. You will see a large clock on the right side building.• Follow the walkway to the large building between the two large buildings, you will find the 3rd floor entrance to Shiodome Media Tower.• Walk through the door and continue along until the elevator of the Park Hotel Tokyo. The other hotel exits include level B1 where the Family Mart is located, offering the best selection of yogurts.The hotel entrance on this level has a small sign in English with the hotel name written over the door in Japanese. There is access to the train/metro station on Level B1 but we found this route very confusing. Level 1/ground floor, the main building lobby, where you are dropped off/picked up by the Limousine Bus. I am including this information since we were unable to determine our direction and spent a lot of time wandering around aimlessly. Also, the Shinbashi station is very large, with several metro/train lines, and its' very crowded. The buildings have no names on them (unless written in Japanese). The TV offered 2 channels in English; CNN and an second channel which showed evening movies. Areas of interest nearby, include, the Panasonic Showroom and the Caretta, a shopping and dining complex, There is an another area if you turn right from the JR Line/Shimbashi station via the Karasumori Exit. I believe this is an older area of Shinbashi with clubs, restaurants, and convenience stores. We found this area rather seedy, but at night, it looked like the set of Blade Runner. This hotel is centrally located; 1 metro stop from Ginza, and 2 train stops from the Tokyo station. The only negative point is the difficulty in reaching the hotel due to the multiple levels and entrances. We landed at the Haneda Airport, took the Hamamatsucho monorail, then the Daimon metro 1 stop to the Shiodome station. This decision was a mistake since it was late at night, after a 14 hour flight, and the stations reguire walking down/up multiple staircases while carrying luggage. Suggestions for the hotel: 1) place a larger sign in English by the B1 hotel entrance 2) add to your Shiodome map the shapes of the buildings if distinguishable. 3) offer the NHK news channel on TV in English. Lastly, upon check out, a very nice young woman inquired about our travel arrangements to the airport. She made reservations for the last Limousine Bus to Haneda Airport, gave us directions, and held our luggage. I love traveling to Japan, mainly, because the people are so courteous, kind, and helpful; the service you receive in Japan is exceptional and unmatched anywhere in the world. We truly enjoyed our stay at the Park Hotel and look forward to staying there again.

Staff were warm, friendly and helpful. Checkout was a breeze. The room was good size for Ginza, and there was ample space to walk around. The hotel locality itself was awesome, located practically in the same building as the Shiodome station and the station for the Yurikame line. Eateries were about 5 minutes walk away, and there was a convenience store located in the basement of the hotel. A very pleasant stay at a lovely hotel

we stayed here 4 nights and found the service excellent.the reception staff are friendly and very helpful. the breakfast is mainly western rooms are clean, spacious with good en suite facility.it is close to two station which is very handy.i would really recommend this hotel is you are staying in Tokyo.the only thing they need to improve on is breakfast boxes for those guests who have to leave for the airport before the breakfast opens at 7am.

We stayed at the Park Hotel on our first stop of a tour of Japan. The rooms were lovely, the restaurant had a delicious buffet breakfast and the one dinner we had was great, the service was impeccable. The location was somewhat away from the center of the city, but the metro stopped footsteps away!

The hotel is excellent, perfectly placed in Ginza and very close to two metro stations, one of them the very big Shimbashi station.The rooms a lovely and perfectly clean, and the staff is helpfull, both during your stay, but also before arrival if you want to book tables at restaurants etc.All in all I highly recommend this hotel.

Park Hotel Tokyo is a hotel with a sense of style. First, you go up, up, up to the 25th floor to the lobby. Beautifully designed, it offers plants, artwork and comfortable seating areas, a splendid bar and restaurant and plenty to enjoy as you savor being in this magnificent, exciting city, We stayed on the art floor, a unique concept in the hotel business. Painters from throughout Japan have been commissioned to create a tableau in each room. It's a wonderful, creative idea. We wrote about it at whereiscookie, and can't say enough about the hotel's unique encouragement of local and regional artists. You can sleep with the fishes, dream with the stars, go back in Japanese history to shogun days, or take a fairy tale ride into Japanese myth. We stayed five nights, and wish it had been ten. Video images of the artwork are projected on the beautiful walls. The hotel hosts receptions and revolving art shows! Rooms look out over Tokyo's bustling streets and soothing parks. And you are staying a few days in a "painting" -- breathtaking. The breakfast, included in the room, is splendid, too, a wonderful blend of east-meets-west. You can have beautiful miso soup, pickles and veggies, smoked salmon or bacon and eggs with gorgeous fruit and healthy cereals, juices and breads. An elegant restaurant offers beautifully presented meals. The bar is welcoming and our bartender was Italian, perfect for an international gathering place. The Park also retains that commendable sense of style for which the Japanese culture is known. Bravo, Park Hotel. We eagerly anticipate our return, and hope other hotels follow suit with the art floor.

The hotel was very clean,staff very helpful and happy ,plenty of maps to help you around Tokyo ,service was of a very high standard,price for accommodation I thought very fair when you compare with other cities,rooms were a good size ,and cleaned every day ,we arrived early and they showed us to room so we could freshen up this is a big plus.

This was our final stay on a two week trip around Japan.Our previous stay in the city had not been in such a central location, so this was exciting. The lobby is on the 25th floor, with the room on floors above that. We were given an "art room" on the 31st floor, making it an even more special stay. The art took some getting used to, but it contrasted with the views over the modern city outside the room window.The taxi driver who brought us from Tokyo Station could not find it, and dropped us at the nearby Royal Park Hotel. But it was just a short walk here, and once checked in and inside our room, we loved the views over the modern city.
