Breakfast is a huge array of continental and Asian fare, and will cost you around USD 52 for 2 persons, not cheap but if you eat a hearty breakfast you may choose to have a snack for lunch. On another positive note, the concierge is very knowledgable and is always willing to suggest good places to eat or make any reservations for you. I can wholeheartedly say that this is one of the most reasonably priced hotels in Tokyo, with a service that's impeccable and a great location to boot.

It is the second time I stay at the Tokyo Park Hotel in a couple of years and I definitely will come back again. The service is very good and the place has a friendly atmosphere. The rooms, especially the corner luxury rooms, are very comfortable. The rooms facing Tokyo Tower, however smaller, have stunning views of the city and, by fine weather, of Mont Fuji.The location, in the Shiodome business district, is excellent, close to Ginza and within a 5' walk to Shimbashi station.

We found this 4 ish star business oriented hotel a very good base for 6 days sightseeing in Tokyo. It is walking distance to some attractions and multiple metro lines and the JR rail system -= it is only 2/3 metro stops to many things. Don't expect a posh 5 star lobby or room and the beds are hard (like most Japanese beds we found) and room on the small side (we had a twin bed as was told this was bigger than a double and the hotel was full at the time so we could not upgrade), however you are not paying 5 star prices either. (On this same trip we spent our last 2 nights in the Hilton Tokyo and paid more for more inconvenience and expense in every way and would go back to the Park over the Hilton). The inhouse Japanese restaurant was very good and reasonable price (approx $130 for a set course menu of 4/5 dishes and a bottle of wine) although there are plenty of restaurants in the Shiodome area both at skyscraper heights and in the extensive underground or office complex areas. We did not have a bad meal on any night (it would be preferable if you like Japanese food), all served wine and the choice was extensive - usual cost was approx $70ish. We ate out for breakfast at Starbucks or other breakfast establishments again all around the Shiodome/Carretta area (although did get a free breakfast for 2 because we stayed 6 nights and joined the Park Hotel club (for free) - thank you to a Tripadvisor tip off before we left - this buffet was very good with a view over the gardens which was pleasant. The only downside for us (which was not a problem but could be for others was our room was on the 26th floor overlooking the train station which made for interesting viewing but there was a slight train noise for all but a few hours in the middle of the night. A major plus was a DYI inhouse laundry (Y200 per load including washing powder) which meant no bathroom washing - which for me puts a damper on my holiday. The concierge was excellent with help to get around, booked our bus trip to Shirakawago which could not be booked until we were in country and provided great maps and the 10 top sights to see (how best to get there, how much on the metro, etc). A transport tip for travellers arriving in Tokyo late (that is around 8pm when the Jetstar flight comes in from Cairns) the direct Park Hotel airport limo bus has stopped so you need to catch the bus to Tokyo Central Station and then a taxi which was not a problem but not expected. As for arriving at this hotel for the first time by train with luggage, I think this would be fairly challenging to find the hotel entrance which although clearly marked needs a bit of experience to negotiate your way through the subway alleys and know how the signage "thinks" and the walk is approximately 1km. Another great plus was a Familymart (aka 7/11) in the basement of the hotel with plenty of choice for snacks, drinks, sushi, sandwiches, toilettry necessities, etc , Chilean wine ($7/bottle and excellent), beer (Japanese and imported - $3 per can).

I stayed here for a week during my stay in Tokyo. The hotel staff were very friendly and helpful. The concierge was able to make some difficult restaurant reservations ex. Jiro. The location is also good as it's close to Ginza and the fish market and is on top of a subway line - though it's about a 5 minute walk to the closest major train station - Shimbashi. I would definitely stay here again in the future.

Perfect location with great views at a very reasonable price. The hotel is located in the ultra modern Shiodome area adjacent to Ginza and the Shinbashi rail station. From the hotel its an easy stroll right into Ginza or to hope on the train and access most of Tokyo within a 30 minute ride. The hotel starts on the 25th floor of the tower so there are great views throughout. From my room I had a panoramic floor to ceiling window view of the Tokyo skyline. The service, as throughout Japan, is wonderful. I had lost my cables for my iPhone and iPad and they were happy to provide replacement/loaner cables. I will certainly look to stay here again when I return to Tokyo.

I just spent 3 nights there and while the location in Shiodome is great for business and leisure (well connected, central and walking distance to Ginza and the fish market), the hotel itself was really not to my expectations, specifically considering the somewhat good reviews it got on TripAdvisor.First of all, the rooms are small and quite basic, although the sleep quality is good. Second, the service is actually not good, particularly for Japanese standard. Finally, it's pretty pricey for what it offers. Finally, this hotel has very limited amenities.With good service, I would have given 3*.

Fantastic views from my room. Very friendly service. This was my first stay at the Park Hotel but I will definitely return again soon. The hotel is very close to the monorail with a direct covered access to the trains.- very handy for the International Exhibition Centre at Tokyo Big Sight. Although the rooms are not very big they are very well appointed with a well stocked toiletry tray in the bathroom. The rooms were very quiet and comfortable.

Location perfect for Ginza, Tokyo sight (Fairs), any metro...Quality of service perfect! (As usual in Japan)Sight breathtaking! Tokyo tower, Fuji mountain, Ginza, Shinbashi...Not expensive at all! Unbeatable ratio quality/price.Great option!

Great service. Good rooms. Incredible view. This is my usual place in Tokyo, 2 or 3 times a year. Never been disappointed. It also very near to great restaurants for all budgets and well connected to airport, Jr and underground.

This is a very modern and beautiful hotel. I found that many of the staff spoke English. The location was especially good. Its in a business district of Tokyo so there were a lot of coffee shops, eateries and train stations close by. I loved the Japanese breakfast buffet that was served daily. It is good to know that it is in the Shiodome Tower and it is on the 25th floor. It can be confusing if you are not aware of this.

This hotel is the best accommodation I have stayed in ten years of traveling the world, from $22 a night motels and hostels to 4/5 star hotelsNormal smallish room but the bed was, oh so comfortable, and bathroom and accessories were 5 star, the breakfast good but pricey if you have to pay for it, try and get included in room cost, I had lunch the first day, tasty and affordableThe foyer and reception were stunning, no problems getting to reception as staff were on hand to assist me from the taxi and whisk me upstairs, I think 25 floorsThe staff were efficient and very helpful, the young chap handling my bag seemed a bit upset that I didn't want it set up, AND wouldn't not accept a tipFor me the location was perfect, two subways within 10 minutes walk, both above and below ground walkways, if you use the underground tunnel, it can be a bit tricky getting up to the hotelOverall, a really fantastic treat to myself after a six week tripI usually do not recommend a lot, I like what I like, but, I would recommend this hotel

As first time visitors to Tokyo we found the Park Hotel to be well located. It sits in the Shiodome business area adjacent to Shimbashi station. It was possible to get to all of the places we wanted to see on the subway or Yamanote line. We requested a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower, and the view was stunning (especially at night). This is also the side of the building alongside the railway line, so light sleepers would not be as impressed by these rooms. Our room was very small, as is often the case in big city hotels. The concierge service was very helpful in booking a couple of tours for us and assisting us when our transfer to Narita airport didn’t arrive (they’d gone to a similarly-named hotel instead). I would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel.

My wife and I had just at the Park Hotel Tokyo for our honeymoon and it was a very enjoyable time. Everyone was very nice and attentive to our needs and any questions we had about getting around. The location was very convenient for getting around Tokyo since it was near 2 metro stations (Shiodome and Shinbashi). We also found that the underground tunnel system to be very convenient as well. One of the nights there was actually a typhoon that hit Tokyo and the tunnels were very useful getting around to the different metro lines without getting soaked by the rain. You can easily walk to Ginza for shopping, restaurants and bars as well. The rooms were very clean but kind of small for the 2 of us. We knew the rooms in Tokyo hotels were going to be smaller in general so we were prepared for it. All and all, we were very happy with our stay and would definitely consider staying there again for our next trip to Tokyo.

This was our first trip to Japan, and this hotel really helped set the tone for a wonderful trip. The staff could not do enough to help us, we had a clean and comfortable room with fantastic views, free wi-fi, and this was the perfect base for exploring the city and transporting 40kg of luggage from the station. When we arrived it was raining heavily, but the hotel employee we met on our way up immediately took our bags from us and then sat us down comfortably in the lobby when we got off the lift. From there we were checked in and allowed in our room ahead of time so that we could change into dry clothes. The same employee pointed out the local landmarks visible from our window (fantastic view of the harbour), and recommended activities for us. We were so pleased with our room and breakfast each morning and would highly recommend it. If you're staying here, you must go and see the Studio Ghibli mechanical clock, up the stairs towards Shidome Centre. I can't comment on value as the stay was organised as part of a package. The hotel restaurants seemed a little pricey, but you're just a few minutes away from lots of local eateries and great bento boxes at the station, or Ginza is close for even more options.

Incredible views, especially from the bathroom. A great base to explore Tokyo and with a suitable dash of electric features on the toilet. Good cocktail bar with views. Some nice hot wings in nearby garage

Out first trip to Tokyo and we think we got lucky landing here. The access to metro lines was great, it was a perfect launch point for exploring the city once we deciphered the myriad train lines. Room was comfortable and clean. Overall the decor could use an upgrade, starting to look tired in spots. Would stay again.

As my son said in the restaurant. "It does't feel like we are in Tokyo any longer. Feels like motel in Germany". Rooms are like okej but not more. Becoming little old. Boring area if your not here in business and need to stay in this area.

This hotel occupies the upper floors of a Tokyo skyscraper. The rooms are set around a central atrium. In each room there is an illustrated floor plan showing the locations of emergency fire exits. Coming from New York, we always check those exits. On the 27th floor, where we stayed, two of three designated emergency fire exits were locked. An exployee told me they would be opened if a fire broke out. I cannot speak as to what Japanese authorities permit, but we do not stay in hotels which lock fire exits. I do not rate room cleanliness, courtesy at the front desk or the food service - none of which are relevant in view of the fire exit issue. This hotel is not acceptable.

Hotel is very nice, part of the Design Hotels group. Rooms compact but comfortable. Connected to Shiodome subway station and on the edge of Ginza shopping district, also not that far from Roppongi. Convenience store and restaurants at the basement level. Great views from the rooms. Chris the British concierge was incredibly knowledgeable and helpful, and all staff were very pleasant. Would stay again.

Nice hotel with a very nice view from the rooms. I was impressed with the interior design. Staff is helpfull and are able to speak english which is rare to find in Tokyo..The location is good and it has an easy access to the metro. It is also very easy to go to the airport with the train.. No need to arrange a limousine bus.

I always stay close to the Shinagawa station when visiting Tokyo and decided to switch to Simbashi. I selected this hotel based on comments from this web site and was not disappointed at all. Great way to walk underground from the train/metro station to the hotel, and walking distance to Ginza. The staff is remarkably helpful. I asked to switch to a room w/view on the park/river and they accommodated my needs right away. Rooms are good size for Japan standard for the price. I'll go back on my next visit.

We chose this hotel as it was a good standard for a good price. My expectations for Tokyo hotel rooms was not that high but this was good. A little small but not so much. It was very well equipped, very clean and gave a stunning view of Tokyo Tower. It was superbly located too. You could easily take several subway lines and easily access the sky walks and the shiodome shops, cafe sand restaurants. We found the Starbucks in the basement particularly useful. The hotel also provided easy access for the detached palace garden and the fish market. The breakfast is also pretty good and the in-house Japanese restaurants is simply stunning and not to be missed. All in all, I recommend this hotel without hesitation.

Very convenient location in the heart of Tokyo. Walking distance to Tsukiji Market and Ginza. Right on top of the subway station which made it extremely convenient. Rooms were clean but small. Staff were very helpful and friendly, able to communicate in english and happy to help make reservations. Hotel is very difficult to find if you are coming from the airport by train!

Our family of 3 stayed in a triple room, which was relatively spacious. Hotel is well located, close to trains and many restaurants. Staff were friendly and helpful. We arrived in the morning after an overnight flight and were able to pay a fee (calculated on an hourly basis) and check into our room early (well worth it!). Will stay here again.

Good location. Central to the city and close to the subway. Room was clean and modern. On the smaller side, but norm for Tokyo. Loved there breakfast!! Their "personal gym" was interesting; only one person can use at a time, consists of a stationary bike, elliptical, and universal weights machine, 500 yen for 45 minutes. It was sufficient and great views (like the rest of the hotel)

We stayed here in July. After researching hotels in Tokyo I found that double rooms can be small so book a twin. I found that the single beds were very wide so was well pleased. The room was equipped with a kettle so we had tea and an excellent tasting coffee. If we wanted more suplies they were quickly brought to our room. The bathroom was lavishly stocked with toiletries and essential toilet items (combs , toothbrushes etc).We had a view over the Hamarikyu gardens and the river.Staff were extremely helpful and courteous. One of the front office managers came originally from Ipswich and he was really helpful, confirming our flights and giving me help for shopping for a certain gift I wanted to buy which was not easily obtainable in Tokyo.We would definitely stay at the Park again and this time we know how to get there through the labryinth of Shimbashi underground station and shopping malls. It is easy when you know how but arriving there with baggage it is not easy. The locals know this and we met some extremely kind people who just came up to us and offered to help as we were looking at our mapT

Located on the top 6 floors of a 31 floor high rise, Park Hotel is quiet, and removed from the busy commerce below. Great views of Tokyo tower and Mt. Fuji from our room. Excellent breakfast buffet with a wide variety of traditional Japanese and western breakfast selection. Staff speaks English and are very accommodation (as are most service oriented businesses in the city.) Very convenient to the myriad of train lines, Ginza shopping and walkable to Fish Market and other must see's in town. Little curb appeal and if you do not know exactly where it is, it's hard to find. Study the train system before you go!

We were booked into the Shiba Park hotel but somehow we were transferred to the Park,and what a bonus that was. The receptionist managed to find us a room overlooking the Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji and looking down onto numerous train tracks criss crossing and at different levels,it was like looking at city of the future! The room,although quite small,was spotlessly clean and well presented with free wifi,tv,coffee and tea. The hi tech toilet and bath/shower were great. The breakfast really good,served in the huge atrium or a side room with views. The staff were friendly and helpful and we really enjoyed our stay. Highly recommended.y

Impressive hotel, as it starts on level 25 of the building. The view was amazing from the room, but a pity the cloud was on the ground for most of the stay. We paid a bit extra for a slightly larger room and Tokyo Tower view, and very glad we did. Staff are friendly, with good English. Location is very convenient for rail access to other parts of Tokyo, particularly Line E that's right next to the hotel. Also only 10 or so minutes walk from the Ginza shopping area. My only criticism is the gym is subject to payment, and you must book in advance... which is a tad inconvenient, and I feel should be included in the room price.

This was an amazing hotel, and the best accommodation I enjoyed whilst travelling in Japan. It has amazing views of the Tokyo skyline, with views to Mt Fuji on a clear day. The service is warm and friendly, the staff speak good English, and the rates are affordable. Whilst it is not located directly within any of the main tourist areas, it is readily accessible to the JR/Metro railways which are within 20 minutes of Roppongi, Shinjuku, Ginza, Sibuya, Harijuku, Odaiba and all the other fun places! I would recommend it highly to any other travellers.

Spent 3 nights here when first arriving in Tokyo and we are going back before the end of our trip. The rooms are spacious for Japanese standards (which is not huge but is bigger than other hotels we have stayed at in Japan). The staff were very polite and helpful. The location is excellent and is right on top of the shiodome subway or a 5 minute walk to the shinbashi (or shimbashi) JR and metro station. If you have a JR pass use the shimbashi station it is a lot easier than it initially appears. 10 minute walk to ginza for shopping and great restaurants. Definitely stay here again and would recommend.

You'd certainly expect more from this kind of price-range property. But first the good things: location is a great plus, Shiodome station being a short 5 minutes walk on an astounding elevated promenade. The view from the right from the room is spectacular. Hotel rooms are high enough (levels 25 and up) that no street-noise will wake you up at wee hours. Breakfast is rich and diverse. This is where the good part ends. There is a gym. postage-stamp sized, and locked at all times. In theory if you make a reservation ( for one hour only) you room key should open the gym door when time comes. In practice you have to parade through the lobby , fetch an assistant - who then needs to check the records- maybe you are a dangerous imposter, after all- upon witch you may get access to the gym, 15 minutes later. The experience is either needlessly-grotesque or funny, depending on your mood. Then there is the stench. Rooms stink. Badly, How on earth is this possible in this class of hotels, god knows. It is probably the aged carpet, saturated with yearly layers of "I-don't-even-want-to-know-what". Sure, you get used to it after about 15 minutes of being in the room, but you wouldn't anticipate the need for olfactory calibration, in a hotel, would you? Management, if you read this, please bite the bullet and renovate..

The Park Hotel Tokyo is a very easy access hotel. It has direct access to the metro station in Ginza area.The lobby is on the 25th floor and we got ourselves perched on the 29th overlooking the Sumida river and the Tsukiji Market with views of Tokyo tower and the Shimbashi station. There is a lot to do around the hotel and walking is easy. The hotel was neat and clean and had recently been renovated.

Location is good, though via the labyrinthine underground tunnels of the area, which makes it not entirely easy to find, and entails a great deal of walking.First impressions were good, check-in excellent, but no drink provided during the process. But the (quite small) room itself had a slightly tired feel, the arms of the chair being grubby and one or two marks were on the carpet. Much the same can be said for the lobby area. Some train noise can be heard. The view was great.But the service was poor. We wanted a drink after a long journey, but no-one noticed us come to sit in the lobby area and ask us what we would like, and after 10 minutes I got up and walked to the pay-desk and asked if anyone was actually serving. In that time we watched the waiters chatting together but not actually serving anyone.And then the whole process was repeated around 9.30pm. We wanted a drink and, yet again, no-one saw us and, again, I went to ask if anyone was actually serving. Only then did we get our drink.The only (quite small) restaurant was booked-up and this reveals the greatest weakness-it's a long walk through the maze of tunnels and walkways until you find a restaurant, and then they are mediocre railway-station-type places, some of which did not open in the evenings. Failing this it's the (very) expensive restaurants high in the nearby tower blocks or a metro journey to find better quality establishments. The hotel desperately needs another all day restaurant without leaving the building, such as in Sheraton Hiroshima.However, in its favour, one member of staff needs great praise. On receiving our luggage from the courier, we found a lock to have been broken and the case part-open. With a flight to the UK first thing next morning, buying a replacement at that time in the evening or next morning was out of the question. At first fazed by my request for help, the night manager, with little English, was only concerned about how it got broken. But then, as we began to panic about the possibility of loading a broken suitcase on to an aircraft, he sent one of his staff out into the night to buy some straps. When the fellow returned, he had two very strong suitcase straps with number code locks. The night-manager would accept no payment, 2000yen each (around £25 total) and was only concerned that they would be up to the job of securing the case, which they did admirably. I can only thank him most sincerely.

It's hard to imagine a nicer, more modern room, in an ideal location, close to transportation, shopping, and wonderful restaurants. The lobby is 25 floors up, atop an office tower, but that places rooms in the center of Tokyo high above the noise of this hustling city, with magnificent views of the harbor, and of the ultra modern trains and pedestrian skyways intertwined below. The heated high tech toilet should have a thick user's manual to use all of its bidet and shower functions. Staff is courteous beyond even Japanese standards. A short ten minute walk to Ginza. Really decent prices for the quality.

Excellent location, in an amazing architecture complex. Near stations, lot of attractions as the fish market and Ginza . The staff is very helpful the room is nice with great view of the city. If you are sensitive - be aware you might hear the trains noise in your room. And you should notice that they Don't have a gym or a swimming pool. Still it was a very good place in a very very good price

We were in Tokyo from 28 Aug - 4 Sep. my hubby was there for business and I was just come along. We like the hotel very much. Stayed in City queen room, at first few night the room with Tokyo tower view were fully booked so we had to changed the room later on but it worth it! The view was stunning... My in room fav was the bathroom amenities from Thann Thailand spa products and Japanese drip on Key coffee plus all the juices selection from Deen&Deluca. Hotel room was small as you can expected from Tokyo but it was not tiny or uncomfortable, we had good sleep the whole week. I tried both in-room breakfast and buffet breakfast at lobby level, I'd give 5 and 6.5 point out of 10 for breakfast. They had Yokai tour exhibition (Japanese Demons) in the hotel during our stay, that was very interesting. The location is excellent, you can excess subway station just by taking the elevator to basement of hotel building. The surrounding also very nice... Plenty of shopping area during the day and very lifely during the night in Shimbashi filled with local restaurant and bars. I must thanks the reception staffs, they were very attentive and helpful, we'll English speaking, we didn't have any problem even though it was our first time in Japan. We will go back and stay there in November!

Beautiful hotel, with amazing staff willing to help you get around. While clean and well maintained, the rooms are small and they don't allow to set up two baby crib (baby cot), so one of our kids need to sleep with us on the bed. They didn't have another room to get two rooms. Food is way too expensive for the quality. The breakfast is OK taking in consideration the cost, is has poor quality and variety. The Japanese restaurant is too expensive and not so good in my point of view. Easy access to underground and to get to Disneyland (which we did with our girls).

Close to Shinbashi station and central station only 2stops away. Hotel staff very helpful and room on 28th had fabulous views. Arrived early and was offered possibility of a corner room (upgrade at a fee) which I took just to benefit from the views. Room good size for Tokyo hotel. High standard and clean. Everything worked well. Would recommend.

My friend and I stayed on two separate occasions within a 4 week time period. We found the rooms on a bit of the small size but they where clean and well keep. The room was modern and comfortable. The best factor was the staff couldn't help you enough and went out of their way to help us in finding things we wanted and how to get to places. Requests to housekeeping was quickly responded too and never a problem. We asked for a few pillows late in the night expecting them the next day...we got them within 10 minutes.The only negative was the location but don't let that put you off we found a short cut a few days before we left. Walk towards the JR but at the big clock take the escalator down and then the next escalator down to Shiodome. Turn left under the pillons walk about 100meters and you'll find the entry to the JR. Use the JR line (green) not the Metro and you'll be fine and location isn't a problem.

We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights,the first night we had a corner room but after asking next day we where moved to a room with a wonderful view of Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower.We never ate in the hotel so cant comment on the food,but for Breakfast we walked thro the underpass and either had a Subway or a McDonalds.10 mins walk away there are several good eating places.The staff were very helpful most of the front desk speaking good englishThe beds where comforable and the bathroom also very good with its Thann toiletries.All in all would defo go back if in Tokyo again.If you intend to travel on the underground and local buses be sure to get a Pasmo card at the local station much easier that paying every time with cash.

This is surely one of the best hotels in Tokyo city...locaed in Shimbashi area and plus the veiws you will get from your room are just amazing. This is surely a place for visitors, business travellers and even for families wanting to come and visit Japan..
user_location: Port Moresby, National Capital, Papua New Guinea

review_body: Stayed 3 nights in September 2013. This was already my third stay at Park Hotel Tokyo. Location is just perfect, easy access to both Shinbashi & Shiodome subway stations. Tsukiji fish market is in walking distance too.Rooms need some update, but clean & tidy anyway. For the booking of three night stay I got free upgrade to a room with the Tokyo Tower view! Fitness room for guests on the 2nd floor is not the largest one, but very functional. Used it every day!Very polite and good service at all the departments. Simply a good hotel with mint location!

Stayed here for five nights in August 2013. 4 people in 2 rooms. We got the 40% discount through their website for staying more than 4 nights. It's convenient from the airport because the airport limo bus stops here. The location is great: a 5-10 minute walk to Ginza, Tsukiji, or subway. I loved staying here, mostly because the staff were unfailingly helpful. The concierge service was excellent. Whatever we needed help with, they were on it. They helped our group with a broad range of requests from restaurant and kabuki reservations to mailing a package. The hotel serves business travellers and tourists. The room was cozy and efficient. We loved the shower, which had fabulous water pressure (we live in Bangkok and the water pressure is never strong). We found the mattress comfortable and slept well. They even have some laundry machines on the 26th floor for people who want to wash their own clothes relatively inexpensively. The breakfast buffet, designed to satisfy foreign and Japanese tastes, offers a number of options, all well prepared or thoughtfully selected (or you can walk 10 minutes to the outer market by Tsukiji and have fresh sushi...). They even have a tiny, little fitness room (for one person at a time) with an elliptical machine and a weight machine. If we can get the same price again, we will definitely be back. (if you find this review helpful, please click 'yes' below)

My husband, 2 children and I stayed here for 5 nights. Within 5 minutes on foot, we were in the middle of Ginza, shops, restaurants and stations, all nearby. Staff is very friendly and helpful. Clean, comfortable, beautiful and reasonable. Last time in Tokyo, we stayed at Excel Hotel in Shibuya, which is really great. However, it cost more than $300 per night during the period we went. This hotel charges significantly lower. We were all happy and would definitely go back. Note: The room and beds are very small for a family of four.

We stayed here for our honeymoon and the hotel is fantastic! Great service, location is the best- has the metro station literally next door, walking distance to several parks and fish market, mall next door with breakfast options and relatively large rooms for Tokyo standards with amazing views! Would definitely recommend when visiting Tokyo!

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for six nights in total in September, with a break to visit Kyoto in the middle. The hotel was excellent, the room was exactly as advertised, queen bed with a view of the Tokyo Tower. As others have mentioned the rooms are on the small size which is typical of Japan, but they were very well appointed and comfortable. The staff were excellent, they looked after our luggage while we went to Kyoto on a tour and when we returned they had already taken the luggage up to our new room.The hotel is in easy walking distance of the Tsukji Fish Market and the Hama Rikyu Gardens and as much shopping as you can manage, if you are into that kind of thing, we aren't, but if you get the chance take the self paced audio tour of the Hama Rikyu Gardens,, it is really beautiful and completely restful, right in the center of Tokyo and it is free. Highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay there again.

Spent 5 nights here, on vacation from the States. Location - Right above Shiodome station and walkable to Shimbashi, both have direct lines to almost everything you might want to visit. A bit far from Shinjuku and Shibuya, but great for visiting Ginza, Tsukiji and close enough to Roppongi.Room - Definitely small, but this was expected. The bed was comfortable and the view (that we had) was insanely good. We arrived at night and i spent the first 30 minutes just staring out the window. I imagine the views from any room are good considering it starts on the 25th floor.Price - Got the multi-day discount and saved >$200/day compared to other hotels. This was the biggest draw and still got a great hotel.Service - Phenomenal. I had a number of requests on calling places for reservations, getting Giants tickets, getting tickets to shows, etc., and the staff were always very enthusiastic to help out, which I appreciated. Will definitely stay here again when we're back in town.

We have enjoyed two visits to this hotel. It scores well on location, price, comfort and service. It is only ten minutes walk to the heart of the Ginza as well as being very close to the JR line and a few subway lines. It is also very close the Fish Markets and a beautiful harbour side park.One of the highlights is the view from the 28th floor reception area which has a view out past Tokyo Tower to Mt. Fuji. Breakfast is good however the highlight is a couple of excellent in house restaurants, however if you want something a bit cheaper there is a plethora of eateries within a fairly short walk.

Park hotel is centrally located, less than a 10 min walk from the famous Ginza shopping district and it sits directly above a subway station (Shimbashi Station if my memory serves me) making it amazingly convenient to travel around all of Tokyo (for very cheap). The hotel is designed for more of a business traveler and not particularly for a family or group of college guys (which was my case). Nevertheless, the concierge was tremendously helpful in planning our tour and journey around Tokyo. He directed us to interesting (age appropriate) destinations around the city, was fluent in both English (as he was originally from the UK) and Japanese and even helped me translate medication that I purchased for my traveler’s stomach. He also pointed us towards the interesting clubs in Roppongi and told us to avoid certain areas as they were notorious for haggling tourists. Since the hotel is located in a business area (surrounded by office buildings), many of the restaurants around are more of the mall restaurants you would find in the US. It is not the ideal Japanese experience I was looking for however, there was an abundant selection of places to eat within 2 min walking distance. We used the subway for most of our day travels and our journeys (which were long an extensive) cost no more than $10/day. We used the taxis to travel around at night (especially to the Roppongi area) and they cost around $20-30 for a one way journey. We had breakfast twice at the hotel. The breakfast provided at Park Tokyo was two steps higher than a continental breakfast yet it cost around $20/person. We were shocked at how expensive the breakfast was but came to realize later on that it was worth the price due to the convenience and the fact that it was all you can eat, helping us to skip on a meal or two in between. The best part by far: the breathtaking views of Tokyo! Upon arriving and seeing the view from the reception desk at the Lobby, we decided to upgrade to a room with the view of the Tokyo tower and I must say, it was the best thing about the room (apart from the great bathrooms and the beds). This hotel was fully worth every dime we spent.

Stayed on the 30th floor of the Park Hotel for three nights. Had a great view of the city, which was spectacular at night. The hotel is comparable to a Hilton in the US, but keep in mind our space standards are a bit different than what I found in hotels in Japan. The room is small and the bathroom very small, but it was clean and for the most part comfortable. I found the beds in Japan to be a lot firmer than in the US, but that could be just me. The lobby was modern and the check-in very easy. Behind the front desk is a great panoramic view of the city. Access to the subway was pretty good from the hotel which made it very convenient to get around. The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor which means that you take a elevator to the lobby and then separate hotel to the floors with the rooms. Breakfast was not included in our room (was in the ANA Intercontinental that we stayed at earlier in the week), but our friends tried it and said it wasn't so great. There are other breakfast places nearby (Momi & Toys Creperie, Starbucks, Tullys, etc.) so we were covered. (Although the best breakfast is a sushi breakfast at the fish market.) As others said, smoking is permitted in the lobby which can be unpleasant when you first walk in. Overall, a good stay and would stay there again.

Spent a long weekend with family, over there for best friend wedding. Room is too small for 2 adults and one kid, and the room is rather basic, in particular the bathroom which would definitely need a refreshment. Location is very good at cross roads of many subway and jr lines, lots of places to eat near shinbashi station also. Service was overall good. One point that surprised us is that the hotel is almost fully smoking area (lobby included) which was not so pleasant.

I made a reservation for a twin room checking in on a Tues night for 4 nights with the 40% off deal. Thanks to TA I found that only Park Hotel's own website offers this special deal. There were no double rooms available but I gambled hoping to get a double at check-in. This turned out to be a smart move because I ended up getting a double room on the top floor with Tokyo tower view!Room: 5/5The view towards the Tokyo tower is just awesome and you can even see Fujisan on a clear day. You also get a good view of Shinkansens running below your feet! They have a bay window with a comfy cushion so you can read/chill out feeling you are on top of Tokyo. The room is spacious by Tokyo standard and the bed is very comfortable. The Wifi connection is fantastic and it's quick and easy to hook up. Everything is nicely laid out and really there's nothing much to complain about. Service: 5/5We wanted to check in some large suitcases a couple of days before check-in date and the hotel duly obliged. In fact they moved them into our rooms before we even arrived. What's more impressive is that we requested a switch from twin to a double room. They told us all the rooms that were available and we ended up trying 2 of the Double room with Tokyo view. We were told these are smoking rooms but they don't smell and suggested we check them out. They are right, the only thing that smells was the corridor, so if you can get past that the room is perfectly fine. They moved our suitcases from the initial room and I just had to tip the guy for their entire service.Convenience 4.5/5The hotel actually sits 1 min walk from Shiodome metro/monorail and 7min walk to Shimbashi metro/JR. The 7min walk is pretty painless as it has a very busy underpass that is fully sheltered with aircon. These stations gives you direct/short journeys to most places in Tokyo and even places further out such as Narita Airport, Gotemba (Outlet mall) and Kamakura/Yokohama. Most tourists will find this hotel a perfect base to explore all parts of Tokyo without the noise in the heart of Tokyo. Japan's google transit is awesome and accurate to the minute for trains/metro. So use that to guage whether this is the right area for you. You got a convenience store at basement level and plenty of local restaurants/shops at Shimbashi station. In fact you can reach the heart of Ginza or Tsukiji Fish Market in less than 20min on foot! (save taxi money if you are going for the tuna auction)Value 5/5With the 40% deal you are looking at around 16000yen for a double room (+2000 for Tower View). In my opinion this is a real steal for such a modern luxurious hotel strategically located near Shimbashi. Can't comment too much on facilities but if you are looking for a bit of luxury in an excellent location without breaking the bank then this is your winner.

Stayed here on business for a week and it was great. The rooms are a good size and it has easy access to public transport. Getting from the airport was a simple bus right to the door and checkout made sure you got the bus in time for your flight.

My hubby and I stayed here for a couple nights during our honeymoon in Japan. It was a great location for going to Tsukiji Market, and some nearby department stores. It was fairly close to a Metro station which helped with going around Tokyo, however, since we didn't stay here for very long, I can't say much in terms of getting around to a lot of the different central hubs. It was a great location for us at the start of our trip however, since we were still jetlagged and woke up early, so we were able to eat sushi at Tsukiji Market when it opened and not have to wait in a ridiculously long line.The hotel itself is extremely thoughtful in service and design. The staff was extremely polite and helpful. When my parents called the hotel just as we were arriving, they told us and held the call, before transferring to our room until they had made sure we had gotten into our rooms. The hotel staff had no problem shipping our luggage to Kyoto when we asked them to, and we received our luggage in Kyoto on time with no complications. We received our phone sim card rental from them with no trouble for using their mailing system. The rooms themselves were fairly spacious for a Tokyo hotel room, with a nice window seat for city viewing. The bed thankfully was a King bed, not two split up twin size beds separated by a bed frame, the latter of which was common outside of Tokyo. The mirrors were completely heated so when you step out of the shower you can see yourself and get ready, as opposed to having steam filled mirrors. The toilet had a dizzying number of options which were fun to try out. All in all, the hotel made for a pleasant and convenient stay for the first leg of our trip.

Reasonably priced hotel for Tokyo! It's not located in the center of things, but the subway is in the basement, so its easy to go anywhere. Also there's a little convenience store on the ground level. The hotel is located on the 26th floor of a building so you're away from the bustle of the street. Extremely quiet.....I'm missing it just writing about it :-)

You moved from one hotel in Tokyo to this hotel as the service we were experiencing at the other hotel in Tokyo was not great. We found this hotel to have excellent size rooms, lots of place to hang cloths and well spaced room. Not as modern a decor as some but functional. Service was excellent, people helping you with bags was also a good surprise after our other hotel in Tokyo. I noted it was very quite even though busy a good sign of good design. Close to trains to every part of Japan, as well as shopping. Food is a given as well as very well positioned for business. Breakfast good though not the best we have had in Tokyo.

We stayed here for a three-day stopover in Tokyo. The hotel is very convenient to Shimbashi station, and you can also get from Narita on the limo bus (though we used the Narita Express train). We had a triple room for two adults and two kids--decent set up that has a sofa bed that was already made up on arrival. Room size was good--no need to squeeze--and it was so wonderfully quiet! The views from the room were amazing--Tokyo Sky Tree in the distance and the Shiodome area with its raised pedestrian walkways down below. The hotel is also convenient to food options at the nearby Carretta mall, which has several floors of restaurants, as well as the basement-level pedestrian walkway eateries. Breakfast at the hotel is very nice, with good, crusty breads, hot Western and Japanese options. The whole place has a subdued hush to it, interesting art exhibits, those awesome silent, speedy elevators. Staff was very helpful with questions throughout, as well as helping out when our return flight was cancelled. They wanted to charge for use of the fitness area, but my husband objected and they let him use it without charge--it is a room with a couple of machines in it. Really, if you are running around Tokyo all day, you may not need the fitness center. I would stay here again without hesitation.

One reason I chose this hotel - aside from the TA reviews and the value for the luxury feel - was the location. I assume, based on my reading and planning, that I would be in a location with reasonable restaurants and walking distance from things. I was walking distance from the expansive underground system - and it's a big underground. Basically, by the time I was done sightseeing, and wanting to go out - I'm into alternative clubbing and Tokyo is great for that - I was too worn out and urm, lazy, to want to get on the subway, or get a cab, all the way to the other side of town for clubs and bars. So, each night I either ate at the hotel or, at a nearby hotel. For that very reason, I would stay else where next time I am in Tokyo. Now, if you are working in the Shiodome region, or you're a family or you are prone to turning in early, then it's a great place for your stay. Beautiful interior, helpful staff, many speak good English (I was greeted by a European at reception, in fact). The contemporary art throughout the property is awesome, and the hotel view gives you that "Lost in Translation" feel without the price of staying at the Hyatt. The bar is cool, but, if you're desiring that view with a drink, visit the Conrad next door. The hotel has a bar that has a view, but, it's staring directly at an office building more than anything else, so check out the Conrad. I ate in the Japanese restaurant the hotel - very contemporary and very formal, but, it was delicious and a great chance to experience contemporary classic Japanese. The courtyard restaurant had OK service but the food left much for me to be desiring. So, the hotel is beautiful, staff is attentive, view is nice, but, the location wasn't compatible with what I was looking for. Overall, a great visit, and my biggest concern is something the hotel can't change!

I had been coming to Tokyo/Shiodome nearly every month for over a year for work, and unhesitatingly came back here. It is a "lesser known" hotel in the area (most taxi drivers mix it up with Royal Park next door), but having stayed at both I fell in love with this one. It is very stylish, clear, and hopefully without sounding overused metaphor... a "zen" refuge.... Little hints: join the hotel membership... you can get automatic benefits (small bottle of champagne, free breakfast, etc.) depending on the number of nights you are staying. The location is great, with plenty of food in the Shiodome area as well as the local restaurants, shopping, nightlife, etc in Ginza or Shinbashi. Fish market, water taxi to Asakusa, and a nice jog along the river (behind the fish market) is all nearby. It is also very well connected with the Tokyo JR and Metro (get a Suica pass at any convenience store to avoid constantly shelling out change for tickets...). The 7-Eleven in the Shiodome shopping area has a Cash Machine that is "friendly" to foreign credit cards (Citibank in Ginza is the only other). And you can catch the evening (6pm) live broadcast of a local Japanese tv show for little kids next to the "other" hotel's main entrance. Alas, the work is finished, but should I ever come back.... you can find me here.

We stayed in the Park Hotel in the middle of July on their "Stay 4 Nights get 40% Off Special". With this special we found the hotel to be a good value. But here's are the most important tips in booking this hotel: (1) Book through the hotel's website, as it is the only way to get the special deals. (2) Be sure to scroll down the entire list of rooms available and read carefully what each has to offer. Further down the list , we found FREE BREAKFAST for 2 included with our room and 40% off for the same price as the 40% offer without breakfast! Rooms were small, yes, but not tiny. Most importantly, they were quiet, with what seems to be good insulated walls. The rooms had new clean carpeting, nice wood furniture, good lighting, and blackout curtains. Bathrooms had a great powerful shower, a nice variety of amenities, and a fancy toilet that Japan is so famous for- heated, etc., although without music. (The last time I was in Japan my hotel toilet played Beethovan's 9th symphony every time I sat down!) The hall carpeting seemed shabby in comparison to the room.If internet hook-up is important to you, then you might have found your hotel. I am giving The Park Hotel the award for the fastest, strongest internet hook-up I have ever experienced in any hotel in the world! Perhaps this is because it's in a building that houses offices and a tv station?The breakfast that is included is adequate. I did not love it, so I can't rave about it. I found enough to eat, but the menu didn't vary during the 4 days we were there. The hotel has a 1 star Michelin rated restaurant, but it only seats about 20 persons and was full every night without reservations. The concierge is an Austalian, so English speaking persons will find this very helpful. Location: Hotel is in a quiet area near Ginza, but more in "central Tokyo" than the other areas. The subway is attached to the hotel, so convienent to all of Tokyo. Don't expect to walk outside the hotel and find a variety of restaurants unless you take a cab, one stop on subway or walk to close-by Ginza district. Each hotel room has a safe in the room- a feature that some of the recommended 3 star hotels in Tokyo did not.View: WOW! If you ask for the view of Mt. Fuji and Tokyo Tower, you will get an added bonus. One can see the same view from the hotel's 25th floor lobby, but why not have the same view from your room, too?

Excellent location, modern and nice rooms (we got two "side-by-side" rooms as we were travelling with kids), very good value for money.The hotel is close to the Shiodome metro station and Shimbashi train station and walking distance to the Ginza district and very close to the Hama Rikyu Garden (worth a visit).

Stayed 9 nights in this hotel. Fully enjoy great services from check in to check out. The staff are very friendly and helpful. The hotel is very closed to Shimbashi station so it is very convenient, also the room has a spectacular view. Overall it is a great experience. Thank you, Park hotel.

stayed here twice during my business trips in 2012. My first trip was not so good as the staff who assisted my check in was discriminating me perhaps due to my age (i look relatively young) and the fact that i wasnt japanese.Nevertheless, the room was nice and clean with a view of tokyo tower.quite convenient if you want to take train and move about. lots of food nearby at the shopping mallsi love the buffet breakfast!wish i cold stay here again

This reviews reflects the views of a family with 2 small children. The Park Hotel is located in a very good central location to access Tokyo and greater Japan. The hotel sits atop multiple metro/subway lines and has quick access to the national rail system via Shimbashi station within walking distance. You need to be comfortable navigating the subway/train system without assistance to get the full benefit.We were able to negotiate a suite that comfortably handled the four of us with ease and had a fantastic view of the city.The hotel does not have as many amenities as some of the larger, flashier hotels - but that was not our need, it is very functional and clean for a family trip. The staff was pleasant and good with our children, English skills were quite sufficient.We did not use the restaurants. The lounge area in the center atrium is pleasant to sit for a while but can get smoky at night.We would not hesitate to stay here again.

Nestled on the top floors of an office building in Shiodome. Close to subway, with access to the elevated Shiodome walkway. A nice walk away to Ginza, a short cab ride to Tsukiji Fish Market. Price was reasonable, though my room was a bit on the small side. Breakfast was simple yet well executed. Free wifi. Money changing machine in the lobby. They had an art exhibit in the lobby during my stay, a little creepy but it was a nice distraction. Willing to stay here again in the future.

This hotel was a very pleasant surprise. It is in a modern development with little street traffic. The location is great--a short walk to 4 subway stations and a JR station, with lots of shops and restaurants. It is an easy walk to the Ginza district. The room was small, but comfortable. The concierge was very helpful in getting us oriented to the area. Another convenience was a bus to Narita stopped at the hotel. Walking around the area can be confusing at first, so it was helpful that we took a taxi there from Tokyo Station when we arrived. Once we explored the area, it was easy to get around. Lovely view from the room. Since the hotel is located on the 25th floor and up, all the rooms have a view.

This was a lovely hotel and good value for Tokyo - but Shinbashi is a business area so humming during the week and very very quiet at weekends. Luckily the metro is right at the doorstep so you can go anywhere on that spectacular piece of infrastructure. Our room was big and comfortable - our daughter was on a fold out bed and there was still plenty of room. Service was good and there was an art installation at the hotel which was a nice touch.

I stayed in the hotel for 6 nights, having a room on 30th floor with a view of the Tokyo tower.Unfortunately, the weather was not clear. Otherwise, they say you can see Mt Fuji from your room, too. So I had no reason to pay the entrance fee for any of the high-rise buildings in town.Everything in the hotel worked out just fine. Direct bus transport from Narita Airport, quick registration, rooms are fine, good beds, etc. Also, the location within walking distance to the Ginza area and the metro system is great, once you find your way - it's a little complicated the first day to find the correct exit!Make sure you eat in the hotel's restaurant called Hanasansyou - they have a "casual dinner" for hotel guests which is absolutely awesome!Also, you should find the tempura restaurant called SUI located in the B2 (basement) of the neighbouring Caretta mall. They make fantastic tempura!I cannot wait until I am back in this inspiring city and I will definitively choose Park Hotel again.

I stayed here with wife and kid for 3 nights, and it was a memorable experience. Firstly, the hotel is very easy to find - we took NEX then switch to Yokosuka line to shimbashi station, from here we had a leisurely walk with luggage in tow (5 min) along the elevated pedestrian walkway to the hotel. Second, the room was very clean and comfortable, and the size was surprisingly spacious, and the view was stunning! We could see Tokyo skytree from our room, and the Tokyo tower from lobby. The vicinity has multiple cafes and restaurants, but my favourites are the Japanese eateries in the train station! Mins walk to the Ginza line which is probably one of the most useful lines for tourists. Great location if you're taking shinkansen, or going to Disneyland. The helpful staff deserves special mention. The moment we stepped into the lobby, someone was there to greet us and help with check-in. If you stay three nights and/or if you are a member (not sure which because I had both), you can choose one of the gifts on offer ( one of which is a Pasmo card worth 1000 yen, great for train travels!), and we were given early check-in due to early arrival time at Narita. I highly recommend this hotel. I suggest studying google map & youtube for this area before arrival if you plan to walk from Shimbashi in order to get your bearings. The hotel provides excellent map on its website, but I feel doing extra homework helps a lot for first-timer. Both above-ground walkway and underground network to/from station are easy to navigate, but I recommend taking the surface route when coming in for first time, then you can explore the underground after check-in. By end of 1st day, you will know it like the back of your hand!

My boyfriend and I stayed here during our stay in Tokyo. We booked this hotel because the location looked good and we received a great rate because we stayed four days. We were going to be in Tokyo for the beginning part and last four days of our trip, and we we would go to different areas for the ten days in between. We only booked the first four days at this hotel initially, but realized quickly we had found a gem of a hotel and booked our final days there as well. The rooms are small, but very modern with a great view of the city! We would suggest skipping the buffet breakfast, even though it's good it's a little overpriced and there are plenty of other options nearby. The hotel staff was in credibly helpful and their is a subway stop right under the hotel. The location made it very easy to get around Tokyo! You will be very happy you stayed at this hotel!

The whole stay was a delightful surprise- from the efficient service provided by different staff to the cleanliness and functionality of the rooms.Like rooms in most other Tokyo business hotels, the room was slightly small. Whatever it lacked in size was more than made up for by the amenities in the room. The modern interior and furnishing was definitely better-designed and pleasant than what we were accustomed to at Royal Park Shiodome across the road.Overall, it's under-rated, but the selfish part of me thinks perhaps best it stays that way!

A high rise hotel with rooms starting on the 25th floor with beautiful views of Tokyo.We took the Narita limo service, And we're left off in front of the hotel. We took the elevator to the 25th floor reception area, and the check in was easy.Having gone on-line to their site I joined their club. As we were staying 4 days I was given a number of benefits.I took the buy 1 get 1 free breakfast buffet.The buffet is pricey at $25, but with the coupon and 20% off guest discount it was only $20 for the 2 of us.The rooms are ample size with a great automatic toilet, and all the essential toiletries.The hotel is right on top of 1 subway line that goes to the fish market, and a 7 minute walk threw an underground passage that goes to Shimbashi station for the Ginza subway and the train stations for trains to anywhere in Japan.There is a McDonalds below the Media tower in which the Park is located, and their are a number of restaurants in city center a 4 minute walk away .The top floor of the center has some higher end expensive restaurants with great views,but we found on the 3 rd floor a number of very good inexpensive oriental restaurants.

A well located, functional and attentive Tokyo hotel. Great views of the skyline from reception and in our room. Breakfast of a good standard and rooms whilst small were well designed. Staff spoke a useful level of English too.

Superb hotel, with excellent location. Located near Ginza shopping area, also to Shinbashi station that connects with many lines. Fantastic view from the hotell. Incredible helpfull staff, and nice, big clean room :) We'll be staying here again for sure!

We enjoyed the stay at the hotel. What impressed us most, were the tremendous views of Tokyo from the hotel rooms and the lobby. Size of the rooms was also great, as compared to Japanese standards.One should also mention that the location of the hotel is extremely convenient - Shiodome and Shimbashi stations are just round the corner. Moreover, a gorgeous park is located within a 5 min walking distance.

Ok so this review is more about how to navigate the hotel and the city than the hotel itself. Let's start off with before even getting to Japan...GETTING TO THE HOTEL: I'm originally from Chicago, but I was visiting Manila in the Philippines before going to Tokyo. Unlike in the Philippines, English speakers are a a bit harder to find in Tokyo (with the exception of hotel staff in my humble opinion). With this in mind I wanted to make sure my husband and I knew exactly where to go, what to do and how to get to the Park Hotel Tokyo the moment we stepped foot off the plane in Tokyo. So we did our research before hand. There are three ways to get to the hotel:1) Taxi: The obvious and most common way to get from an airport to a hotel for someone who is not familiar with an area is to take a taxi, and we could have. Except, after quite a bit of research to figure out how much the taxi trip would be we found out it would be a little over 30,000 Yen!!!! (Roughly $300 USD at the time). There was NO way we were going to pay that much. So we explored our other options. 2) Train: We could have taken a train but it would have required transefering trains and walking the rest of the way by foot to the hotel. Overall it would have taken roughly under 2 hours of transit time. Overall price would have been between $40-$60 USD. Definitely better than ~$300 USD for a taxi ride. But after a 5 hour plane ride from Manila, and also because we didn't want to lug our luggage around in a city that we were unfamilar with for 2 hours we decided to see if there were any other options. 3) "Airport Limosuine": Finally, the last option we stumbled upon was also the best option for us. There is a service called "Airport Limosuine". Essentially this is a shuttle bus from the Narita airport that will take you from the airport to the doorstep of the hotel for 3,000 Yen/$30 USD in under an hour and a half. I believe you can buy tickets online (just google Airport Limosuine, Tokyo), but you can also buy it right at the Narita Airport (Or Haneda Airport) right after baggage claim, before you exit the airport. You cannot miss it. The way it works is that you pay $3000 Yen per person and the shuttle will take you (and any other customers) to the doorstep of the Park Hotel Tokyo, and will possibly make a couple other hotel stops along the way (depending on where the other customers on the bus are staying). When my husband and I went we had one other stop before Park Hotel Tokyo, and it was at the Conrad in Tokyo. All of these hotels are within a 2 minute walking distance from each other so really it was no big deal at all. Overall we chose the "airport limosuine" to take us to the hotel as it was the cheapest, pretty quick and most stress-free option. The shuttle bus was comfortable, AC-ed, and had recliining seats so we could sleep the hour and a half away. This is jumping ahead, but two things to note: (A) you can also pay/arrange to have the Airport Limosuine/shuttle bus drop you back off at the airport whenever you depart. (B) Using this service from the Haneda airport is SIGNIFICANTLY cheaper than Narita-- don't quote me on this (make sure you look it up online), but if I remember correctly it was under 1000 Yen( ~$10 USD) to and from Haneda.AT THE HOTEL: Ok so what you need to know (that tends to confuse most people) is that the hotel itself is between the 25-32nd floors of the Shiodome Media Tower. So, when you get dropped off at the hotel, you may think at first that there was some mistake since as soon as you walk in it looks like a business buliding with no sign of a hotel anywhere. I already knew this walking into the building so I knew what to expect and how to get the hotel. Basically this is how you get to the hotel, its actually quite simple if you read this review first ;): 1) As soon as you walk through the main doors (where your luggage gets dropped off and you get off the bus) take a look to the front and to the right. You will see a florist shop. To the right of the florist shop you'll see glass doors and a sign to the left of it on the floor that says "Park Hotel Tokyo". 2) Go through those glass doors and take any of the elevators up to the 25th floor. This is the main lobby of the Hotel. As soon as you get out of the elevator you should be able to see the check in desk to check into your room :).CHECKING IN THE ROOM: Many other reviewers on Trip advisor suggested asking for an upgrade of room to be able to see Mt. Fiji and Tokyo Tower. We wanted to opt for it but we didnt want to pay the extra 1,000 Yen ($10 USD) for a room that we were basically going to just be sleeping in. We had a standard queen room, and it was a good size for a hotel in Tokyo, but overall small by most standards. It was a comfortable sized room, though my husband felt that the bathroom was quite small. The beds are a little firm. But this is more of a standard find in Asia (It was the same in all of the hotels I was at in the Philippines). There was a mini-bar which we didn't use but emptied out all the beverages so we could use it as a fridge. English was a little bit of a hinderance, but managable in comparison to the rest of Tokyo. Food was expensive at the hotel and portions are already tiny in Tokyo (in comparison to the USA haha), so we only ate at the hotel once. It was for the breakfast buffet in the main lobby that is about 2,100 Yen (~$20 USD) that had a few continental items, and lots of japanese items.A few things to note that I enjoyed: 1) the hotel provides free razors, shavign cream, hair brushes and wash cloths in addition to the standard toothbrushes, toothpaste, soaps, shampoos, conditiors, etc etc. These are replenlished everyday :). 2) REALLY good shower pressure. 3) Their toilets. I LOVED them, as I did most toilets in Tokyo. Each toilet has a seat warmer with adjustable temperatures and bidets/'shower' with adjustable water pressure.4) Take the elevators down to the "Subway" level and walk out and follow the hallways (it doesn't matter if you take the right or left path, they merge anyways). Go through the revolving doors and to your right you will see a "Family Mart". This is a convience store that is very helpful and economical when you don't want to spend $25 for a small room service pizza.GETTING AROUND TOKYO/THE AREA: As mentioned before, English speakers are not that easy to come by in Tokyo, and for the most part, its not too big of an issue so long as you are willing to do a little research on your part before hand. You can ALWAYS ask concierge in the main lobby if you have any questions. They have really helpful maps that are in english (like the train station line). A few things to note:1) if you chose to walk to Ginza (an upscale part of Tokyo that can be compared to Michgan Ave. in Chicago/Magnificent Mile) then take the RIGHT elevator down to the Yurikamome level (3rd). and take the 1C exit down the stairs and walk to your right. This is the main street for the Ginza district and you will find stores llike Burberry, Louis Vuitton, Shiseido. You'll also find stores like H&M and Zara. There are also bakeries and pastry shops that can be found along the way. Sometimes we would get lucky and find some items in these places written in english on the placcards but most of the time we would just point at what we wanted, hold up the number of fingers that was equivalent to how many we wanted of something, and then shortly after an employee would show us a calculator with the total we needed to pay in Yen (helpful note, not all these places take credit card, so always have Yen on you).2) Tax is built into prices. So if something says its 1,000 yen. It's a 1,000 yen. No need to add some sales tax. Also, tipping is not a practice that is normally done in Tokyo. 3) Because a good majority of the places don't have english menus, my husband and I tended to eat a lot at Roppongi area. Specifically Roppongi Hills (Consider it the Rodeo Drive of Tokyo). We didn't plan it on purpose, it just ended up being every restaurant we searched for online that we liked and that had an english menu was in Roppongi Hills. Lots of foreigners tend to go here, and for good reason. You can get all sorts of cuisines here (Italian, French, Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Latin, American, Burgers, Steakhouses, Crepes, Pastries, Pizza, Indian, Mexican, Middle Eastern, etc etc) and they pretty much always offer two menus-- one in Japanese and one in English. Roppongi Hills is surrounded by the Metro Hat, Mori Tower and a few other buildings that have english menu restaurants. I'm pretty sure you can find all of the restaurants/stores within the area in english online-- google is your friend!4) The subways. Your BEST friend. There are mulitiple subway lines that are owned here that owned by different companies (as opposed to Chicago, in which the government owns the train line). As a result of the competition, trains are clean, comfortable, AC-ed, always on time (if not early), and run every 10 minutes MAX. Most everything is within the area, and a one way train ride is anywhere between 160-210 yen (~$1.60-$2.10 USD). They offer one day and two day passes that allows for unlimited rides within the time frame for the train/busses on certain lines (I think it may be 1,000 yen for 1 day? Not sure, make sure you double check!)I think I covered everything I needed to. If not feel free to message me.

Great value for moneyGood locationDo not expect 5 star service. Rooms are average, nothing specialStaff is very helpful and niceThere is free internet. Did not try the food at the hotelConcierge is helpful and trying his best but will not be able to guide you to the latest spots to go to.

Stayed in this hotel for 12 nights in June 2013 and it turned out to be a superb experience. Hotel is very well located near Ginza, Tsukiji market and a short walk from Shimbashi metro and JR station.Rooms are good sized compared to japanese standard and very well equiped and clean.But the best about this hotel is the attention of its staff and, in specific, ms. S. Sugihara, from the front desk/concierge. She is an example of employee all hotels should have with its attention, will to help and sympathy. The only negative aspect to mention is that room service offers a so-called pizza that is really small and is only tomato sauce with some few and small chuncks of cheese on top for USD 20!!! Run from it and get something to eat on the covenient Family Mart on B2F floor.Me and my wife would definitely return to this hotel in the future!

A well appointed hotel with excellent amenities and service. Rooms are adequately spacious and come with great views. Language barrier can be an issue at times. I didn't have a room service menu in the room so I called for one. A staff showed up promptly and attempted to barge into the room despite my protest that he shouldn't since my girlfriend was in bed. He then handed me an old torn up menu and insist that I return it! I asked him to leave since I was annoyed by the episode. I called to speak With the duty manager, who wasn't at his desk. I never got a call back either. Within 10 minutes however, a new menu was slipped under the door.The bar is excellent although expensive. Didn't eat at the hotel since the surrounding options are phenomenal. The lobby in the evenings are a bit silly with 2 projectors steaming some cheaply put together animations on a wall. Should stick to artwork like the rest of the hotel.I am well travelled and work in the hotel business so I am very fussy.Final verdict. Will I stay here again?YES I will, most definitely.

The room was quite small as expected but by no means the smallest room that I have ever had. This was balanced by the amazing views from the 32nd floor. Simply stunning, especially by night. The room was always made up well and completely clean. The bed was comfortable and the shower was powerful.The staff were helpful, polite and always there to assist; typical of Japanese hotel staff.The location is good as it offers nearby transportation (at the Shiodome station or a five minute walk from Shinbashi station) and also a short (twenty minute) walk into the heart of the Ginza area, at the same time as being quiet. The area is quiet at night due to being more of a business area. It was very safe and well lit, no issues with coming or going. It is worth noting that the ‘airport limousine’ service from Narita airport stops at the hotel. This was around 3,500 yen per person and worked out to be a better option than catching the train. I would recommend this hotel as an alternative to a Shibuya / Shinjuku location which we preferred. These areas were easily accessible by the transport available.I did not eat in the hotel so cannot comment although it is worth nothing that due the hotel’s location, there are no food options in the immediate vicinity. This may or may not be an issue depending on the guest’s preference. The hotel had a pleasant large lobby which offered somewhere to relax, have a drink or check e-mail.The hotel has complimentary wifi throughout. There was no swimming pool but a very small gym which was only big enough for one person. I feel that a four star rating is a good representation of this class of hotel. Clean, practical and modern. It ticked all the boxes at this price pioint.

The lobby is located at the 25th floor of one of the skyscrapers as part of the Shiodome / Shinbashi area. The rooms are located between the 26th and 33rd floor and offer a beautiful view over Tokyo!We had a Corner Room, which are bigger and therefore, more comfortable as the regular rooms. Room has been clean and offered enough space to stay there for a week.The front desk staff is usually keen to help you, but it did not work perfectly at our arrival (the room was not ready even it was after the start of the check-in time 2pm - they at least offered a free drink at the lobby...). The restaurants are rather expensive - but quality of food is good...We would again stay at the Park Hotel when we return to Tokyo next time :-)

Thanks to an upgrade we had a view of the Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji on a good day (absolutely stunning). The room was small but comfortable. The breakfast area is disappointing. Most seats are too low and the alternative room with windows was too drafty (A/C). Skip the breakfast as it is too expensive for what you get (even though we got vouchers). There are enough coffe shops (Starbucks, Excelsior etc.) nearby. The location is great, walking distance to Ginza district and trains. There is a family shop open 24 hours for odd things at the bottom floor linking to the underground. The coffee bar open from 9 am on the third floor is good for a snack. We would choose the hotel again. Friendly staff.

My wife and I stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo while traveling on business to Tokyo. We were amazed at the view and the solicitous staff.Park Hotel is in the Shiodome Media Tower, on the 25th floor. You may have a hard time finding it if you are an American accustomed to American hotels. From Shimbashi Station take the Shiodome exit (there are signs reading "To Shiodome") and follow signs. You will be able to take a cab from the station but the roads are kind of roundabout and you'll end up paying around 1000 Yen (ten dollars) to get a quarter mile. We had a lot of bags so we opted for this, but if you are traveling light it is an easy walk. Inside the Shiodome Media Tower, take an elevator to the 25th Floor and you'll walk out into the Park Hotel's lobby.Almost all of the staff, including the trainees (they wear trainee nametags), speak excellent English. Several are native speakers for whom Japanese is a second language. We arrived at nine in the evening and were welcomed by four staff members at the desk. They delivered our luggage to our room, which was a very nice room with a gorgeous view of Tokyo (see pictures).This is truly a world class hotel, and you will be treated accordingly. Every question we had for the staff as to area attractions was answered immediately, thoroughly, and with a map to go along with it. They can tell you where to eat, what to do, what time shops close, anything you need during your stay.The breakfast buffet is well stocked and tasty, though at around 4000 Yen (forty dollars) per person you definitely feel that you're in a hotel for the well-off. Be sure to ask at the desk for any discounts, we were able to save ten dollars per person with "discount coupons." Of course everything can be charged to the room. We only had breakfast at the hotel once, but it was a delicious (if expensive) one. Room service is likewise very expensive and we only did this once as well. I had a bit of an America Attack and wanted a pizza, which at 23 dollars for a cheese pizza the size of a dinner plate I regretted. It was good, but not worth the price. There is a well stocked mini bar in the fridge, with a number of drinks available, though we did not partake of the supplies very often. A vending machine will sell you the same beer for the same price, so the mini bar is not over priced, just superfluous to our needs. You're better off going to a local grocery store and stocking the fridge yourself.TV service is Japanese of course, which was quite entertaining for our being unable to understand it. We caught one game show where contestants make ugly faces for money, and a panel of six judges discussed at length which was the uglier. Japanese TV is inexplicable to American audiences, and not just because of the language barrier. Another game show where a man hides inside of things and jumps out at people was on, but we only caught the end of it. You likely won't be doing much with the TV anyway: get out in Tokyo!The room itself was very nice. The rooms are Western style, so don't expect futons and tatami mats. We had a very comfortable double bed with pajamas provided. One entire wall of the room was a picture window overlooking Tokyo Tower. The room was so nice that we literally called the front desk to make sure we had done the math right on how much the room cost. We called them twice, actually.They will do laundry for you at exorbitant prices, or you can use the laundry machine on site for substantially less. About ten dollars will wash and dry a full load. The machines are all in one: they wash, dry, and add detergent, so you won't need to provide anything but 100 Yen coins.We truly enjoyed our stay at the Park Hotel. We were sad (but ready) to go home at the end of our stay. They provide a shuttle service to the airport with numerous departure times, which at 3000 Yen (thirty dollars) was less than the cost of taking trains and far more comfortable. I don't know that we'll be back in Japan, but if we go back we would definitely stay at the Park Hotel.

Lovely hotel, good location, tasty breakfast and the most welcoming and friendly staff makes me incredibly sad to leave .... I would definitely recommend staying here whether for business or as a couple!
