Convenient location in the Shiodome - Shinbashi location, close to Ginza district. Easy to recognize the triangle shape of the tower building. Direct access to JR and Subway stations underground via B2 with hotel lobby located on the 25th floor. We had a nice view overlooking the gardens on the bay side. Rooms are on the smaller size, but fine enough for us. Very clean. Breakfast is not included, but they give you discount coupons that come out to about $22 per person. A large spread is served in the main lobby area and seemed quite expansive each morning we walked through, although we chose not to eat there. Concierge very helpful and we took advantage of using them to help us make dinner reservations.

Got a great deal for six nights in a comfy hotel that ticks almost all the boxes. The room is pretty small but this is Tokyo and you really shouldn't quibble given the value for money. In the Shiodome media tower, a short walk from Ginza, reception is on the 25th floor and rooms above that - it's certainly quiet enough to sleep, there's plenty of water pressure in the bathroom (although the tub is tiny) and eventually (if you ask about the mysteries of the TV remote) you can find some English language stations on the TV. Chris, the British concierge is a wonderful resource - he knows his way around Tokyo, where to get good food and coffee. Very kindly, he arranged for a half bottle of a lovely champagne to be delivered to our room on my birthday during the stay. The only potential downside of this hotel is that the beds are very hard but that's typical of Tokyo from what I'm told. This is a gem.

My friend and I stayed in the corner twin room. More than big enough, with a very nice bathroom and came with everything I needed. My only complaints are that they need to replace all the carpets and that they let people smoke in the beautiful atrium that you have to walk through. Pricey, but you're paying for the view and convenient location. It's connected to the Shiodome station, but you don't need to pay the extra money to take the train from Shimbashi because you can just walk along the elevated sidewalks directly to the hotel. Shiodome is a very quiet and lovely section of town filled with shiny skyscrapers. The hotel restaurants were too expensive, so we didn't eat in them. My friend loved the spa and got a massage. Glad we didn't pay twice as much to stay in a different area since the trains are so easy to just hop on and go wherever you want. (Get a SUICA train card package if you take the NEX from Narita, it makes it much easier and you can use it to buy stuff in the station shops)

If you are an independent traveler looking for a good place to stay in Tokyo, I'd definitely recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo. There's a basement entrance a short distance from the Oedo subway line. A 5 minute walk underground gets you to the Shimbashi station of the JR line. There's also a nearby monorail station for Odaiba. If you are arriving on subway or train, follow the signs to Shiodome exit A7. My room, though not luxurious, had a comfortable double bed (really queen size), clean bathroom, and a nice view of the Tokyo Tower. The buffet breakfast at $20 had a good selection of Western and Japanese foods. My only complaint is that all the restaurants in the hotel are high end and expensive; even the lounge is rather expensive. You need to leave the hotel to find a simple meal at a reasonable price. However, the French restaurant in the hotel is definitely worth the price.

The location is convenient to go almost directions because Shinbashi JR station is very near from this Hotel. And Ginza town,Tukigi market, Hama datached palace ,Tokyo tower are also near this Hotel. Hotel is not so luxury but casual high class level. There are Simmonds beds, clean carpet and clean bus tub in the room. But I think hospitality is middle class level. The staff of the reception can speak English but they are not so kind. The entrance of this hotel is difficult to find and there is no bell boys almost time . Famous french restaurant is small and very good,especially sommelier .

This hotel, occupying the top 10 or so floors of a high rise building in an upscale business district of Tokyo, offered spectacular views of Tokyo from all the rooms. The rooms, although on the small side, were attractive and modern. There were two expensive restaurants in the hotel and one reasonable one serving food in the lobby lounge. The food and service was good at this restaurant. The only criticisms I had were 1) stained rugs in the room hallways; and 2) lack of good dinner restaurants in the area of the hotel.

This hotel is in a good location for transport links but our taxi driver had never heard of it even when we gave him the location in Japanese. In common with a lot of places in Japan there is no signage. Our flight arrived at a time when there was no limousine bus directly to the hotel from Narita so were advised to take another bus to another hotel nearish toThe Park. Even though we were close to The Park, it was notoriously difficult for a first time visitor to find. However our room was ready and.......it was really boring. You could be anywhere! We did have a view of the tower and the views of the lights at night were great. However it was beige everywhere and just felt a bit tired with a stained table and snagged carpet. You can get CNN and BBC world on the tv in the room - just takes a bit of channel hopping. There is sufficient storage for 1 suitcase but not 2. The bathroom is small with a bath shower curtain. I hate these wet clingy things! However there was plenty of hot water and everything worked efficiently but the bath towel was tiny and there is only one other tiny towel provided. The bathroom was spotless however. Breakfast was included in our rate but this was nothing special. Fruit was ok, prepared pineapple and strawberries but a chopped in half banana was not visually appealing and guests looking forward to an English breakfast would not find the offerings well cooked or appetising either. Croissants and coffee were the best choices by a long way unless you are happy with Japanese. Do not understand why breakfast is in the lobby. Why not make use of the dining room? The lobby is utterly impersonal and, as it is completely self service, if you have a table near the service counters there are a lot of people walking past your table all the time.We used the luggage forwarding service to our next hotel and this is efficient. The hotel staff were pleasant and helpful. Smoking is not banned in the lobby at night and it is noticeable when you walk in. There are many restaurants nearby in Ginza. We found the top floor restaurants in the department stores to be terrific value and full of shoppers. These restaurants had personality too! This hotel has a great location but not 4 star and would not choose to stay here again.

We took the elevator to the 25th floor and was greeted by high ceilings and some light show on the large walls. We arrived very late but the staff was very helpful and energetic, as far as I could see. Unfortunately it seemed that like most hotels, this one also did not have a no smoking policy in the lobby.We were only here for one night and it was because all of the other rooms at other hotels were overbooked due to the holiday (I was there the beginning of May.) The rooms were small and clean. Nothing was luxurious. It was above the bare minimum and had amazing views of the Tokyo Tower. I feel asleep watching the lights. My husband and I woke up to an amazing array of amenities! I think they stocked up the bathroom with anyone one could possibly need in a bathroom. We soon went down to the lobby for the breakfast buffet (which is included, I believe). The food was not bad at all. I enjoyed the croissants the most but they also had a good array of fruits.I only give it a three star because it was really nothing out of the ordinary. It was clean and did its job-we slept fine in a bed with subpar linens and mattress but slept nonetheless; the bathrooms were clean and small, but not too small that it was ridiculous. This hotel wasn't designed to be luxurious so it would be unfair to rate it less for that reason alone but I just cannot give it more than the three stars because there are just so many better hotels out there.

The hotel is a 20-30 mins walk from Shiodome Exit if you're taking the JR Line because of JR Pass. The walk is a bit tiring especially after a long day of touring around Tokyo. Still, the hotel location is very convenient since Shimbashi Station is a few stops away from most of the tourist destinations in Tokyo. Restaurants are very accessible within Shiodome Center where the hotel is located but most open around 11:00 AM and close around 8:00/9:00 PM. You'll always end up having breakfast at McDonalds since it's the closest that opens early.The room is big enough for a family of 4 (2 small kids). We were not able to get the room facing Tokyo tower but the view is still amazing especially at night. The toiletries are replenished everyday regardless if they were used or not. No complimentary drinking water though so be sure to stock up especially if you're staying for a few days. Fast in-room wifi connection.Hotel staff are not that friendly. They will pass by you at the reception or anywhere in the hotel without even smiling or a simple greeting. Check-in and check-out is fast and efficient.Would still consider going back to this hotel.

Arrived very late on a Sunday night after a very long trip, did not feel welcomed when checking in as the front desk staff seemed cold and indifferent. I was informed that there was nothing to eat at that hour within walking distance of the hotel and there was only 4 things available on the late night room service menu, none of which I wanted so I went to bed tired and hungry.The room was clean and had stunning views of the Tokyo Tower, but I was disappointed at the western style bathtub with the shower curtain. I was looking forward to having a bubble bath in a deep soak tub but this hotel didn't have those.Not a single taxi driver I came across knew where the entrance of this hotel is so make sure you get a map from the concierge before heading out, or print out directions before you go there. The complex is quite big with several other hotels in the same area, getting dropped off at the wrong place and running around trying to find the entrance is not something you want to do after a long journey.The day time staff was friendlier and more helpful when I checked out, so that improved my rating a little. But next time I would rather pay a little more and stay at the nearby Imperial Hotel, which has much better service, facilities and in a better location.

As per my title, pros are for sure the location and the staff. In fact, the hotel is perfectly located, very close to Ginza district and to JR and major subway lines. The staff is friendly, eager to help and guide you thru the city map suggesting valuable spots as well as restaurants and street indications. However we were quite disappointed by the rooms and the overall service. Our room was really small, the bathroom was super super tiny, all the bottoms of the walls scratched (I guess luggage passage) and basically not enough space to put both our luggage. The breakfast was decent, but not extroardinary and we needed to wait a while before buffet plates were refilled. The same area converts to the lobby bar after breakfast time (which is not really convenient), and when a late night we came back around 10 asking for something to eat (even a cold dish understanding that the kitchen was maybe already closed) we have been told that only drinks were avaialble. From a 4 stars hotel you at least expect to be served some cold dishes even after 10 pm!!! They are also rated as a Design hotel, but a part from few Floss and Artemide lamps, honestly there is not more than a traditional, minimal Japanese design in it, which we liked, but very common to find in other spots in Tokyo.

We stayed here at the end of April at the conclusion of our tour. The tour group we were part of was small that is no more than 10 people plus the two guides. We were informed that the tour operator had booked the corner rooms which were slightly larger and afforded wonderful views. We duly arrived at our room and thought well this is Tokyo and everything is expensive and space is at a premium.Well within 15 minutes of settling in we were phoned by the tour operator who informed us that the Hotel had allocated the wrong corner rooms.... gee how strange that all 6 rooms were wrong!Subsequently we were reallocated the correct rooms. Sure this is not a big deal but the service in the bar area is slow, the staff seem to be in a tranice. To order coffee you really have to wave to get their attention , rather annoying since the area was never overly crowded.The breakfasts are disappointing. If we returned to Tokyo I would not stay here, the service or lack of, would be the main reason.

I stayed for business trip in Japan, the hotel is location on a very convenience spot,next to the subway and easy to get a taxi,Resonable price and breakfast was good, they provice what you need,lobby and the restaurant very nice and easy to move around.

Finding your way to this hotel was quite easy from Shimbashi Station. The over head walkway is the easiest and quickest for those arriving from Narita and using a JR pass. Catch the Nartia express to Tokyo and then jump on any train heading south, Shimbashi is a major station. The walk was only about five minutes and the elevator to the lobby on the 25th floor was quick.We arrived at the hotel 5 hours before check-in so we couldn't proceed to our rooms. The staff were happy to hold our bags while we explored the area, so we left them behind and went and explored Hama Rikyu Garden which was a short walk away. We visited during the cherry blossom season so the park was beautifully covered in trees of pink, white and purple.The hotel itself is conveniently located in a business park. This means that outside of work hours its quite quiet compared to the rest of Tokyo which can be a welcomed thing given its a city that's always moving. The rooms themselves were very nice, we had rooms that were looking over Tokyo Tower and in the direction of Mt Fuji, however the weather whilst we were staying was cloudy on every day so we didn't get to see the peak from there.Ginza is a short stroll from the hotel, as is the famous Tsukiji Fish Market. The subway to Rappongi is pretty much at the hotel door, as is the elevated bus that goes to Odaiba. Shimbashi itself on a friday night comes alive with Japanese business men who go out and enjoy finishing the working week, lots of restaurants, bars, pubs just on the other side of Shimbashi station made it an interesting place to explore at night.The Food in the lobby did look quite expensive so we never ate there, however being a business hotel its to be expected. There is a Convenience store in the basement as well as a big Hyper Market Chain near by called Don.K. The wireless in the rooms on the first two nights didn't work properly and we had to use the free wireless in the reception, however on subsequent nights it worked fine so not sure if there was something wrong with the signal on our floor or what.Bathrooms where nice, big enough for a week or so stay. Being japan the beds were a bit small but a 6ft tall person can have a comfy sleep. The window sill has a cushion so that you can sit and enjoy the view. Only downside is there are no english tv channels provided, and the intriguing style of Japanese TV can be a bit much for someone who is not used to it. The staff were more than happy to organize our bags to be sent ahead to Kyoto and they were waiting for us at our hotel when we arrived. Overall I highly rate this hotel and will definitely use it again on my next trip which I'm planning for next year.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here and the hotel is fantastic. It's up high and whichever direction your room faces, you get an amazing view of one aspect of Tokyo. Cannot recommend it enough. Rooms and facilities are top notch. Make sure you visit the cocktail bar, where the staff are first class and will make you the best cocktails of your life.Only difficulty we had was negotiating the underground areas between Shiodome and Shinbashi stations. It's a bit of a rat maze. The above-street walkaway is much easier between the hotel and Shinbashi but cold/wet if the weather is bad.

Overall this is a nice hotel. The room was quite small but very comfortable. The food in the main lobby restaurant for dinner was nice, but the buffet breakfast was only OK. The overall service could be improved though - tourist information is not openly displayed and it was only on the 3rd day of a 5 day stay I noticed a one page "Top 10 sight seeing places" with really clear travel directions tucked away in in a plastic folder in the hotel lobby. It would have been really useful be given this at check-in.

We stayed there 4 nights and we found it great. Close to Shinbashi station and 15 minutes walking distance from Fish Market.Tateru Yoshino restaurant (on lobby floor) is highly recommendable as well.There is one side of the building with view of the Moiunt Fuji in clear days. It is worth requesting the room there.

We stayed at The Park Hotel for 3 nights and found it a good choice for Tokyo. It is located above the Shiodome subway station, which was convenient. The bed was fine, nothing extraordinary. The room was a good size and comfortable. We had questions about local dining choices and attractions, and the concierge was very helpful. Overall, a good choice for location and value.

This hotel is actually accessible all the way via undercover passages from Shimbashi station if you're arriving in on the train. There's also Shiodome subway station or the monorail station directly underneath the hotel. The hotel is on the top half of the triangular shaped office block. The hotel is located in the office/business district of Shimbashi (a little bit away from the shops and nightlife) and hence noise wasn't an issue. The staff all spoke English and were very helpful and friendly. The concierge also spoke English and was very helpful as well. The front desk actually looks out towards Tokyo Tower. The rooms were average size according to Japanese standards. They were reasonably clean and comfortable. There are plenty of food outlet options nearby including McDonalds and Subway. In these shopping centres are also 7-11 and their equivalents. I would definitely stay here again on my next visit to Tokyo.

I have stayed at this hotel a number of times over the years and it remains my first choice when visiting Tokyo. The views are wonderful and the hotel is within yards of the Shiodome train station so travel is easy and quick. If you have time to visit local tourist destinations then get down to the fish market early in the morning. It explains why fish is so good in Tokyo.

We stayed here for 4 nights in April 2013. Got a room with a view of Tokyo Tower and the train station. View is amazing and one of the reasons I booked. Hotel is also handy if you plan to visit the fish market as you can walk there. Beds were fine. Pillows were not so great. Bathroom great, apart from the cheap shower curtain. Room smelt stale/sweaty which was a bit annoying but not enough of a problem to complain about. Breakfast is mediocre and expensive. Definitely worst breakfast we had in our 2 week trip. We didn't eat at the hotel or drink in the bar as there are many other better options. Transport connections are good although it took a while to find the right exit from the subway which takes you to the hotel. The area itself is not very interesting and on a short trip to Tokyo I am not sure why anyone would want to explore it. Near to Caretta Shiodome which has more amazing views and a number of restaurants but in my opinion there are way more exciting places to eat. I think I would stay somewhere different if I returned to Tokyo. You can both hear and feel the trains below but this didn't keep me awake.

This was a change-up for me. Normally I stay at the Villa Fontaine Shiodome. It is more reasonably priced. Unfortunately, it was not available. So...The rooms are the same size, but they are nicer at the Park Hotel. The lobby is nicer, too. I enjoyed my stay, but I cannot reconcile the cost difference. I will stay here again if necesary, but I will begrudgingly pay the price.

If you enjoy stained carpet, a moldy shower curtain, and a blue smoke filled lobby then go ahead and stay at the Park Hotel. If however, you desire fresh carpet, a clean bathroom, and a lobby in which you can actually breath then keep looking.

This was our second stay at the Park Hotel after previously staying here once in 2011 and at the Conrad across the road in 2010 and liking the general area. The hotel itself is very comfortable for what it is. Comfortable bed and compact clean bathroom in the rooms. We stayed in two different rooms (with a sidetrip to Hakone in between). The first room on the 32nd floor was facing the bay with a glimpse of the Hama Rikyu Gardens. The second room on the same floor, but on the opposite side of the building faced Ginza and overlooked Shimbashi station and train tracks. You can hear the faint sound of the trains from the room - noticeable for a light sleeper like myself but my wife comfortably slept through it. We also had very weak wifi signal in this room. It must be a known problem as within 5 minutes of us calling staff, they delivered a mini-router. Very handy if you have urgent work to do in your room.Shiodome isn't the most lively of areas but you'll find all you need at the convenience store downstairs and food is plentiful closeby in the Caretta building next door.Location:Tsukiji Fish Market is a pleasant 10 minute walk away as is Shimbashi Station and the Ginza shopping district. You can even walk to Tokyo station / Marunouchi in about 35 minutes. Shiodome station is right under the hotel.One con is the lack of a gym. Apparently they have a "Fitness Room" with 2 exercise machines that you need to book. The weather and traffic outside wasn't the most welcoming for an outdoor run so that was quite disappointing.Another minor incident that happened was the staff revealing the surprise meal I had the concierge book for my wife's birthday. They gave a very handy print out of the restaurant details and map for us - but handed it to me right in front of my wife. Nothing major (it was funny, even), but you have a feeling a more prestigious hotel wouldn't make the same mistake.In summary, I would definitely recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo. For the very reasonable rates you pay, you will experience a very enjoyable stay.

I stayed here with my 8 Year old son for 4 Nights on a recent 2 week trip to Japan.From start to finish it was a most memorable stay.The view overlooking train entrance to Shimbashi station [requested] was perfect for keeping my son occupied during quiet moments.Also view out over Tokyo.The more traditional requested view of Tokyo Tower & Mount Fuji [on a clear day] can be viewed from the lobby and is quite special.The hotel is easy to reach from anywhere in tokyo using either Shiodome or Shimbashi station.We arrived at Narita airport at 08.00 and after passing through immigration and customs we offloaded our main luggage to a courier service for delivery to our Hotel.Took the NEX to Shinjuku station and went to the top observation Level [free] for a wonderful view of Tokyo.After that a stroll in a nearby Park spotlessly clean and safe just beautiful.Then we had a bite to eat at a small Restaurant serving the most wonderful choice of traditional dishes.Only then [mid afternoon]did we head for our hotel.We found this no problem and checked in without a bother,my pre booked mobile wifi was at the hotel reception and shortly after checking in my luggage arrived around 17.00.We had a sleep as we had been travelling for quite some time [2 hr. flight Dublin-Paris and 11.5 hr flight Paris-Tokyo.We woke later that night and went to the Family Mart store located on level B1,there we got some sustainance which they heated up for us in microwave,the store had all the basic needs you could wish for. We then went off to explore our surroundings and even though it was late at night/early morning we felt quite safe strolling around.Back to the hotel slept soundly until next morning,jet lag gone,beds and pillows so comfy it was truly great.It was a rainy day but not to worry as the hotel is directly linked to trains/subway/metro by underground or covered passages.And the hotel insisted we took an hotel brollywith us.There are an amazing choice of Places to eat within 10-15 minutes walk from the hotel so much so that we never did eat at any of the hotel restaurants,these seemed more than good but well when you are spoiled for choice something has to miss out.Room size was more than spacious,and spotless clean.The staff were so friendly helpful and efficient it was a pleasure staying here at the Park Hotel.When it was time to move on from here we again sent the bulk of our luggage by courier, all arranged by the hotel, to our next chosen destination.From start to finish our time at the hotel was simply wonderful. And in case you think we Knew our way around Tokyo from previous trips,NO,this was our first visit it really is so easy to get around and SAFE.Summing up.The Park Hotel,it's staff,it's location and overall is JUST PERFECT. A big thank you to everybody there.Arigatogazaimasu.

We were starting a tour in Japan and decided to spend a couple of days in Tokyo before the tour started. As the group was staying at this hotel we decided to extend our time there. It turned out to be a great location to do some exploring on our own before the tour started. It is situated close to the subway and JR lines and this makes it accessible to all the sights.On our arrival we had been given a twin room instead of double. The only double was on a smoking floor and they tried to deodorise the room for us, but after one night we had to move and we were transferred to another room without a problem. Staff most helpful.The open foyer area served as the breakfast area also. Sometimes it was extremely crowded and they had to overflow into a restaurant area. Also most of the seating was designed for relaxing with a drink in the evening and it was not always comfortable to sit at these tables for breakfast. There was plenty of choice for breakfast and more than enough to eat. The hotel has a couple of restaurants and we tried the French one - excellent. The foyer area served as the bar area at night and the prices were fairly expensive and the Japanese idea of non smoking areas just doesn't work. It made it unpleasant at times to sit and have a drink at the end of the day.

The staff and everyone were extremely helpful and accommodating. Room had spectacular views, Easy to get to from Train station and lots of shopping below. Close to train station and excellent pick up for tours and private shuttle to Narita.Coule not fault this hotel on any means.Will stay again and again!What views of Mt Fuji!!!

After the long flight to Narita from NYC and the almost as long (so it seemed) journey from Narita to the hotel, it was wonderful that it completely met our expectations -it was a big exhale when we walked into the lobby and then our rooms when we immediately knew that everything would be just fine! Comfortable, stylish and spotless rooms with great views of Tokyo Tower (especially at night) and Mt. Fuji on clear days. Yes, walking distance to Tsujiki, but a taxi in a cold morning is much more comfy. The Family Mart in the basement met all of our snacking and even our breakfast and (relax in room) dinner needs. The only downside is that the location is a little squirrelly. Because it's in Shiodome, there's no real street life - however, underground access to shops, restaurants and public transportation is actually quite easy once you figure it out.

Bookad a city double with Tokyo Tower view through their website. Fantastic views over the entire Tokyo downtown area. Hotel room not very big, but comfortable enough for two people. Window has seating, so the entire room is built around the view. Hotel starts at the 20th floor, we stayed on the 27th. Location is very near to some great eating in Ginza, but the Shiodome area itself, where this hotel resides, is very dead. Shinbasi JR-rail station links you easily to everywhere you want to go. Walking distance to the fishmarket. Great place to start you Tokyo adventure! If its views you are after, this place has competition in this price range from Hotel Southern Century Tower where we also stayed, which quite possibly has even better views.

Stayed 2 nights in May 2013. Couldn't fault this hotel in any way which says a lot as I travel frequently and am picky when it comes to hotels. The only minor inconvenience is having to take two elevators to get to the room (the hotel only starts on the 25th floor) but this is more than compensated for by the exceptional views of Tokyo Tower and the bullet train lines.Contrary to popular myth, Shiodome is not souless, the childrens TV station in the very next building to the hotel means that there is always something going on around the hotel and there are plenty of attractions very nearby. Not to mention that Ginza is just a short walk away with all that it has to offer.The hotel was exceptional during our stay and very well priced for this quality.

Was possibly expecting a bit better reading past reviews but overall not that bad. Agree with most very handy for subway to get around Tokyo.The views are amazing was on the 33rd floor overlooking Toyko tower

Everything was great the Park Hotel Tokyo. Rooms were clean and tidy, the toiletries in the bathroom were also great and i loved the view from our room...Rooms were a little small, but that comes with being in Tokyo, since most hotels have small rooms.The only set back was the location of the hotel since its in Shiodome, so its a little far from the center of Tokyo, but the hotel has a subway station right at basement, which made it really convenient to get around.

The hotel is an amazing value for its location in Tokyo.A hidden Jem.Comfortable rooms and attentive service are highlightsHowever its the lobby bar that is truely remarkable!The bar's atmosphere and persobal bartendersMake the experience authentic and notchesAbove any 5 star hotel bar in Tokyo. Try any handcrafted Cocktail here and you will see what I'm talking about!The view of the skyline is also amazing.

The place is so nice. It is located very near the subway metros where majority of your trip around the city starts. Just a few steps from the hotel and you are on your way to your sightseeing destinations Around the hotel are numerous shops and restaurants where you can eat besides what the hotel has to offer The staff is so polite and courteous and is willing to accomodate all your request to make your stay memorable . From the time you check in up to the time you check out everything was so smooth. It is one place me and my family would want to stay again in our next visit to Tokyo.

Everything in this hotel was very good. The breakfast has both local and international options, great fresh fruit and juices, excellent service (although you must remember your breakfast coupon, which I had to go back for almost every morning:). The room was well airconditioned, bed was comfy, lots of pillows to choose from. I especially liked the window sill, placed some pillows in there and did all my work on my computer sitting with the view on one side. And as the hotel only starts from the 25th floor, there is no question of how good the view on Tokyo will be from your window. Mine was on the Tokyo Tower side and already on the first evening, I got the most amazing sunset view ever (see photo). The area is fantastic too - Ginza is walking distance, the Advertising Museum is next door, you can buy all sorts of goods and food from the nearby little shop, there is a tea garden that you would not imagine to find among the sky scrapers etc. The Water Bus also stops at this garden, so you can also use that to get from there to Asakusa or Ryogoku Sumo area. Also the metro station is located right under the hotel (straight from the elevator to the station). Airport transfer and taxi stops in front etc. Very convenient.

We had a lovely stay at this hotel.We spent our 1st few nights here!The Views were amazing! The room was a standard size considering we heard that rooms in Japan were small!The lobby was pretty and had cool artwork!The area was shiodome, we were close to the fish market, Ginza, and a pretty tea garden!The hotel lift went straight down to the subway which was very handy!I definitely recommend this hotel!

What a nice hotel, great views and excellent location. Literally steps away from Shiodome metro station (as in less than 100 feet from entrance), next to Shimbashi station. Minutes away from Ginza shopping area. Great buffet breakfast. Rooms very comfortable. Stayed a week and never had any issues. get a corner room with views of Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji if you can. A few days we were lucky enough to see Mt Fuji in the distance. The Conrad is right next to the hotel but doesn't have the views that the Park has. Restaurants galore all around, and very important also several Starbucks! The WiFi worked great in our room and faster that the one have at home actually. Very reasonably priced also. Very easy to get to Tokyo Disneyland from hotel also, with only 1 metro change, takes about 30 mins to get there.

Description:A lovely hotel located on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower, able to boast easy access for travellers to the Yurikamome Line from the 3rd floor skywalk and the Oedo line from the basement thru the underground passages, its very well located and tourist friendly.Located so high up, the lobby reception has the world famous Tokyo Tower in the background. Stunningly lighting up the tokyo skyline at night, lucky customers may get the same view from their hotel room. On clear days even Mount Fuji can be seen from the hotel.The area around the hotel is quite business like and the artistic 'Big Clock' is right next door where on certain times of the day it putsmon a show for the passerbys.Pros:Location, location, location. Shimbashi and Ginza is definitely walkable but reading previous posts saying its only a 5 minute walk is a bit of an exaggeration. It is still quite a walk away but quite enjoyable especially in the cold weather, making it a kind of adventure for the curious tourists who would like to see the real Tokyo.The hotel goes out of their way to entertain customer requests which in my case was an early check-in after a 10 hour journey. When i wanted to borrow their ironing board, the staff said that the iron was 'out of order' and that i could use the one in the laundry room. Even with the language barrier and improper use of wordings, the staff offered alternatives to try and give acceptable service to the customer.Cons:There does not seem to be a concierge service. Upon my arrival, my wife and i had a number of bags and none of the staff actually came to help but they just stood and smiled. Nothing wrong with that, but some help to hold the elevator door open when we were getting to the elevator and at least holding the door so we could bring in our big bags would've been great. I could have always asked for them to help but seeing how friendly and helpful the people are in Japan, the lack of thoughtfulness from hotel staff actually surprised me.Simple touches need to be done namely -A simple area map in english, locations of the nearest family mart, access to the subway on the 3rd floor and to the Oedo line could be placed in rooms for the convenience of the guests. It took us a couple of days, and a lot of walking to actually realize that the Oedo Line stopped right below the hotel.Non-speaking guests could be provided with small business cards which they can carry around and show to the people and taxis in order to get directions in case they get lost like we did on one night.Summary:A lovely hotel that just needs some simple tweaks and english speaking ready staff available at all times. I would definitely stay there again the next time i go to Japan and hope that the small areas are improved by then.

This hotel has great views over Tokyo, we were lucky enough to have a view of the Tokyo tower. The hotel is at the end one of the main shopping streets in Tokyo so there is easy access to some great shops, bars and restaurants. The only thing I was disapointed about with this hotel was the WIFI connection was really poor, and very slow.

Excellent and calm hotel near Ginza ( 10 min. walk). Fish marked is about cca 800 m. I stayed here 4 nights . Hotel and rooms are clean and nicely furnished. Breakfast is great with good selection. The staff is very helpful and nice. Check in and check out is quick. Airport Limousine bus stops in front of hotel. We had a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower. I recommend this hotel !

Having stayed at this hotel on a number of occasions I can say that it is probably the best (modern) hotel that I have stayed in in Japan. The service is first class, the staff always curtious and very helpful. The hotel itself occupies the upper half of a very modern building in the Shiodome area - 5-10 min walk from JR Shimbashi station. While the area directly around the hotel is rather bland, its is only a 10-15 min walk from Ginza and the area north and west of Shimashi station (many small restaurants etc in that area).Rooms are stylish and very comfortable. Breakfast is very good - Japanese and western styles available.Little to fault, except that on ocassion the price can be a little high.

I stayed here early December with my family( 2 adults/ 2 children) . We didn't get interconnecting rooms ( I don't think they have them) but we did get rooms next to each other. Small ( large by Tokyo standards) rooms , but very tidy and clean. Great views out the windows. Reception has amazing views of Tokyo tower. Reception starts half way up the building( offices below). Restaurant for breakfast downstairs great , mix of western and Japanese. Plenty of options for the kids.Very close walk to Ginza ( 5 to 10 min) and SO close to all the subway train lines. We travelled everywhere with ease from this hotel. Lots of little restaurants downstairs, & a great little supermarket on the lowest level for food/ wine etc .We were at reception when a big earthquake hit( 8.5 I think). The hotel swayed and rocked for a few minutes but staff were very calm and professional. Hotel was locked down for about 5 minutes and everything returned to normal. Comforting that the building handled this earthquake without instance. We felt very comfortable here, staff spoke English and were very helpful.I don't think you could beat the position if you are planning to catch rail. We would happily stay here again.

Hotel is located close to Ginza in central Tokyo, fish market not far away. Room are well equiped with nice furniture. Staff is friendly, good knowledge of english. Hotel is accesible from Shindjuku station located between modern buildings. Hotel is located from 26-th floor with breathetaking view. Breakfast is fine, but bit expensive. Iwould recommend this hotel for good location, good quality and reasonable price.

I stayed here over a weekend bridging two work weeks in nearby areas of Japan. This place was reasonably priced, very clean, and of a decent size by Japan standards for a single room. The new (maybe not so new) trend is to have a high floor lobby with the rooms above. Here, you arrive at floor 1 with the lobby on 25 and the rooms in the 10 floors above. The conceirge here was helpful and the hotel is very accessible to the Uedo subway line and Shimbashi transit point (can pick up JR from here). Also, Tokyo Central is a 10 minute (1200Y) taxi ride away. I would recommend this location for a weekend stay or for those who have business nearby. This area is heavy on office buildings and work week traffic.

My wife and I stayed here for a few nights in February for the Lunar New Year weekend. We're teachers in Seoul and popped over for a quick trip. This hotel is quite nice actually, a little expensive but then again, it's Tokyo. The rooms were quite cozy, comfortable beds, and very nice bathrooms. The shower is awesome as are the products they provide (shampoo & whatnot). The staff were very accommodating and always ready to help - they all seem to speak English to a certain degree. As others mention, it's literally on top of the Shiodome subway station but sometimes it's better to walk over and use Shimbashi for more access. It's a quick jaunt over to Roppongi and other areas near there from Shiodome. One major plus about the location is that it's literally a quick 10 minute walk to the Tsukiji Fish Market ~ amazing sushi! It's nice if you don't want to be in the thick of all the entertainment. So, perhaps choosing a hotel actually in Roppongi or one of those busier areas might be better if that's your thing. Overall, we really loved this hotel and would definitely stay here again in the future!

We enjoyed our stay here very much. Hotel is located in southern part of the city so you can easily get to Ginza in the east or Roppongi/Shinjuku in the west. The hotel is located in this weird office tower complex, but it is connected to many different train lines through underground tunnels. That being said, the immediate neighborhood is a bit corporate and it's not the kind of place you would walk around (not because of safety, but just because there is nothing to see). The staff were excellent and the concierge gave us some amazing local restaurant recommendations. I would not hesitate to stay there again. I did a fair bit of research before selecting the hotel and I think it is an excellent value.

We spent three days at the hotel after our skiing holiday at Hakaba . It was a great location near to Tokyo just two stops away on the train. Hotel rooms were good, staff were helpful. But we thought that the breakfast area was set up in the Guest lounge not so good. Perhaps the breakfast could of done to of had a little more western food to choose from , our grand children went out to eat as there wasn't to much for them to from selection from. We booked in advance to get a better deal

staying at Park Hotel for 4 nights, superb! was reading review about this hotel on here before the trip, knowing there are rooms with the view of Tower of Tokyo, but didn't expect we'd get a room with a view since i'm never lucky, but once we opened the door, boom, the tower is right in front of us! it's even prettier at night when the the lights are on! The next morning we even saw Mount Fuji! really, for the price we paid we didnt expect views like that!!and with the staff, saw people saying they don't speak much English, but i found no trouble at all, and they are all very friendly and polite.the location is very good too, u can actually walk to Tsukiji fish market! and very close to Ginza as well. It's not really right in touristy spots but that means u dont have to fight the crowd after a long day out trying to get back and rest ur legs! oh JR line and subway are just under the hotel building.

This is the third time I've stayed at this hotel so by rights how can I complain but each time it's been for work and this time I took my partner who I finally made me see it through normal eyes which is that its pretty unimpressive. Things were noticed that I always knew but brushed aside as I quite like the weirdness of the location and the price!Good things:The price and little increase you pay for an amazing Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji viewThe view - pay for the view and it is amazingThe bed and linen - perfect, comfy and cleanBathroom toiletries - lovely smelling and plentiful free accessories you may need Annoying things:Poor English from the staff which given how many Europeans were staying here every time, is a surpriseRubbish concierge help - they didn't know where one of the most famous museums was, what time it opened and gave false information regarding a public holiday where all dept stores were closed. They're just pretty unhelpful to be honest. Breakfast - expensive and unfulfilling. Every time I have it I wish I didn't. Nothing exciting or nice or worth £20 per headSmoking - the lobby and main communal parts should NOT be smoke areas. It smelt horrid the minute you arrive Showers - really old school with naff plastic curtains on a pole over the bath. The angle of the shower only has to be slightly wrong and you end up with a wet bathroom floor Hangers and wardrobe - tiny and just 4 hangers! A joke!!!

The Park Hotel Tokyo is one of my favourite hotels in the world. It occupies the 25th to 34th floors of the Shiodome Media Tower and has fantastic views towards the Tokyo Tower and Mount Fuji when the weather is clear. In other directions you can see the Tokyo SkyTree and Tokyo Bay. I could sit in the window and watch the view at night for hours.It is very conveniently located for Shiodome and more usefully Shimbashi stations with the Oedo and Yamanote lines being very useful for getting around Tokyo. There are a number of restaurants in the surrounding area or you can walk to Ginza in about 20 minutes. You can also get to the Odaiba area via the Yurikamome Line quite convenientlyThe hotel was very clean. We had a Premium King which for Tokyo was extremely spacious and had plenty of room for both an extra bed for our daughter and a cot for our baby in a living area off the area where the bed was. This gave us some privacy in the evening from our children. The hotel was very accommodating towards our children and made them feel welcome which isn't always the case in a business hotel. We had very helpful communication via email with the Reservations Department in advance to make sure that everything was fine. We had no problem communicating with anyone in English.My only complaint is that you sometimes have to wait a while for the lift to get down from the 25th floor lobby to the outside world...

This hotel is located in a great position, right on the monorail to Odaiba and close to the Subway and JR lines. The staff were really great, as was the view to the Tokyo tower. The staff sorted us restaurant bookings, Sumo tickets and even a blow-wave. Nothing was too much trouble for them. The room itself was small by Western standards, but more than big enough.

We stayed here at the end of August 2012. Our trip was great but I wish we'd waited about a month because it was very hot and humid. This hotel is in a great location. The train station nearest is rather useless but there's another much bigger station that we always used and it took us pretty much anywhere. Someone described the trains in Japan as an organized bowl or ramen noodles and boy were they right. Back to the hotel. We had the breakfast option and it was well worth it. Because of the time change we were waking up pretty early everyday. It was such a relief to get a big breakfast in the morning before we started our long days of walking, sightseeing, getting lost, etc. The rooms were small (which is normal) but very comfortable. However, there was no top sheet on the beds so if you get hot at night you either have to sleep with nothing to cover you or you have to ask for a sheet from the maid service. I loved that the hotel started on the 25th or so floor. We had great views from our room! I wish we could have stayed longer because I loved it that much!

First, they do not have adequate staff that speaks English. The gentleman who checked us in spoke English great, but he is the only one. The rooms are nice and amenities good, except some soap would be nice instead of the bath gel that looks just like the shampoo.The room service selection is very poor. Even trying to order coffe was difficult. They could not understand artificial sweetener for coffee (after a number of tries, they call it "unsugar sugar". We ate in the lobby restaurant for lunch. They has a bugler for 18,000 yen. We asked to have them cooked medium and was told they were cooked well done and they could not do it any other way. For 18,000 yen and at a hotel of this caliber, I would expect them to cook it any way we wanted.The hotel maid service is horrible. They would. To throw away an empty soda bottle, used tissue or an empty box. They have cups in the bathroom and they would not clean and put them away (I had the cup at bedside with water in it).The wifi would go on and off and she asking about it, they could not understand what we were talking about.When I make may reservation with the concierge for transport to the airport, I mentioned that we were disappointed and he response was a very non caring, "sorry" . He never asked why and did not seem to care one bitFor the price, we just expected more

i really recommended this place because of relaxing atmosfere. they offered a great views from a main reception area. although we get a quite small room but the services that they provided feel us like home.

After a long journey from London via FInland, The Park Hotel picked us up and brought us to a relaxing, well-located retreat. The rooms were generously large for a big city. The hotel is perfectly located to hit the Shijuki Fish Market at 4am.

We stayed 4 nights over Christmas. We liked very much their refined modern design and the beautiful paronamic views at Fuji and Tokyo tower from reception. We would have liked to get these views from the room but although we requested nice views, we werent lucky...:( The staff was very attentive and although some struggled with English, we got very good advise for dinner options. Some customer complaint that entrances arent easy to find but it wasnt our experience. It was close to one JR station which was very convinient but at night, it is quite a lonely area, so you have to walk 20 min until you reach Giza and some restaurants.

Excellent location for visiting Tokyo with easy access to Yamanote line and two metro lines with an extensive underground connexion which was more than helpful in the cold rainy days. Amazing view of Tokyo Tower and the Mt Fuji beyond it. The room was comfortable despite the size and very well kept - we chanced the room we've got for a Tower view one, and the overall impression was that the tower view one was in a much better shape than the other. The first one was a quite doggy. The staff was extremely helpful in all this move - they helped us despise the fact that the hotel was fully booked at the time - around new years eve. The staff was very helpful and very efficient during all the time we stay there, almost two weeks. A great choice for so many reasons.

Has pretensions to be a chic luxury hotel as it is on 25 to 34 floors but doesn't really work. Rooms small (even by Tokyo standards) but clean, buffet breakfast mediocre but main problem is the location - in a business area which is just skyscrapers, nearest restaurant area is Shinbashi which is a bit seedy compared to Shinjuku or Harajuku, on the oedo line but too out of the way to be quickly connected. Staff not particularly friendly or helpful. Ate in the lounge ( drinks very pricy ) and served what we thought would be a vegetarian salad with bacon. Would not recommend.

I enjoyed my stay at the Park hotel very much. It’s located atop a commercial building in Tokyo, and is close to Ginza and many good restaurants. It has stunning views of the “Eiffel Tower” and is very modern. It has a great lounge area in the middle of the lobby which is generally abuzz throughout the day and evening. My room was clean and comfortable, and the noise level was very low. I did seem to have a great deal of internet connectivity troubles in my room, but was able to connect in the lounge without trouble. They offer a shuttle service to Narita airport for 3000 Yen which is much less expensive than a taxi. I will certainly stay at the Park again on my next visit to Tokyo…The exercise room has a charge to use, and consists of an elliptical machine (that's about it). If you're looking for a hotel with an exercise room... this is not the place.

Went for 6 days business tripPositive:-amazing view-quiet room- comfortable and spacious lobby with view- ideal location with lots of metro connectionsNegative:-gym is not free and can't be used anytime. You need to book first. Not ideal when you're jet lagged and want to go for a run middle in the night - rooms are very small compared to the new otami hotel for example-not the more lively area but a 15mn walk will bring you to trendy places so not a big dealWould come again if they sort the gym nonsense

Usually stay at the New Otani when in Japan but because of a large touring party we were booked into the Park Tower and have to say was pleasantly surprised how good it was - rooms were fairly big and very comfortable albeit you have to access via the 25th floor lobby. The breakfast buffet was as good as you can get with a great range of traditional Japanese and western food available - added bonus was that it was well priced and only a short walk from some great bars & restaurants

Me and my friend stayed at the Park Hotel for 11 days in january.The hotel´s facilities are pretty well kept and the rooms are quite nice with amazing views.Service is below average since the english skills of the staff is very poor and they dont make an effort in order to please guests and meet their expectations.Concierge was useless and front desk staff was very slow and confused.If you´re in Tokyo for business, maybe the hotel´s location is ideal for you, but if you´re on leisure I wouldn´t recommend staying in this area.I´m planning on going back to Tokyo next year, but will not stay at the Park Hotel again.

I stayed here last week and was not at all impressed. The room is rather basic the lobby serves breakfast and turns into a bar in the evening. There is simply nothing luxury about this hotel. The room was small but clean. You have to take two lifts, one to get to the lobby and the other to get to the rooms. The area is a bit out of the way and you have to walk a bit to get to Gina. However the subway is just below the hotel and th only good view are the train tracks. I would not come back.

Great value with a friendly and helpful staff. Rooms are clean and quite comfortable. The bed we got was hard to sleep (small and soft), but we're offered an upgrade for a reasonable price. Great location at the Shiodome Media Tower and Shinbashi Station. I would go back!

Quite a lovely hotel, it fills only a few levels of a large new office building. The rooms are large for Japan and have very comfortable beds with soft, western pillows. It's a short walk or 1 stop via the monorail to some very cool nightlife full of salaryman bars and restaurants. The foyer and some rooms have great views of Mt Fuji. Our room didn't look towards Mt Fuji but still had great views over the water and got a lovely morning sun even in winter. The gym is cool too. Just a tiny room that you must book to use but it has an ipod dock to play your music nice and loud, great views, excellent air con and a shower to end with. A well considered hotel.

The views are wonderful (the lobby is on the 25th floor, where the hotel starts). Rooms reasonably sized for Japan, small by US standards. A problems is that it's a little out of the way. You wouldn't think so because it's at a subway stop. It turns out that the station requires quite a bit of walking. Another problem is that it's in a business district and to get to things like restaurants and shops requires a hike. It also means that your meal choices are limited. Eating in the hotel is a ripoff. For example, the breakfast buffet is quite ordinary but costs $23 per person. The alternative is to walk at least 3/4 of a mile one way. Good, professional, helpful English-speaking staff.

I've stayed at this hotel a few times over the past 8 years and it is excellent. Clean, centrally located, great views over Tokyo and staff speak good English. This is my first choice when staying in Tokyo.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is located on the 25th-34th floors of the Shiodome Media Tower, the building is directly connected to the Shiodome subway station, and is also close to Shimbashi station on JR's Yamanote line. We stayed at Tokyo Tower View Room for 8 nights, the room even bathroom is not big, free wifi but not fast, bathroom amenities include the luxurious THANN Aromatic Wood Collection. Don't forget to apply free membership of Shiba Park Hotel Group Members Club when you will stay there, because you can enjoy complimentary bottle of Dean and Deluca mineral water daily (one bottle per day for each room) and 1 hour late checkout. Staff spoke great English and very helpful.

We spent our last night in Japan at the Park Hotel for a last hurrah before flying back home. The room was beautiful, light and well laid out, with a window seat so that you can enjoy the view of Tokyo Tower, and if you're lucky, Mt Fuji. For the train enthusiast, you can look down and see the shinkansen running on the tracks below. If you are a very light sleeper, you may have a problem with the distant sound of the trains, but they didn't bother us in the slightest.We didn't eat in the hotel as it was expensive, but there are several options nearby. The concierge gave us directions to a street full of izakaya next to Shimbashi station, which were quite complicated, so take the map offered. There are several cafes nearby for breakfast.We found the staff to be very helpful, particularly the younger ones who all seemed to have completed their university education in New Zealand or Australia. We don't expect Japanese people to use anything but their own tongue, but English skills shown by the staff were exemplary.NB: The Park Hotel is not a long walk from Shimbashi station. With luggage though, I would recommend arriving via Shiodome monorail, as the exit from the station goes straight past the entrance of the hotel, which is very easy. The neighbourhood was a little confusing to navigate at first.

i recently stayed for four nights at the Park Hotel. The reception is on the 25th floor and there is huge airy atrium where breakfast is held, and which is a bar at night. The restaurant is on the side with the views and there is a bar that overlooks the city. The rooms are of a decent size, with the normal amazing toilets and great views. There was not enough storage space for clothes - and not enough drawers to put stuff in really. but there was tea and really nice coffee in the room. A mini bar stocked with drinks, but no snacks or food. The service was really great with a very helpful concierge, and polite, but not overly in your face waiters and bell boys. I was here for business and would certainly come here again. the only complaint is the fact that people were smoking in the bar - but that applies to every hotel so i cannot hold it against the Park! Oh and one more thing - there is no gym to speak of - just one room you have to book and pay 500 yen for.

Been here 2 times, first time in 2008 and the impression was just marvelous - fantastic building, nice service, international papers every morning in your room. In 2012 no more newspapers and staff is not that friendly as before but still overall impression of the hotel is very good. Sky view of the Tokyo (hotel occupies top part of the Shiodome tower), nice design and very convenient location - just couple of minutes from Yamanote JR line, couple of stops from Ginza shopping area. Breakfast was a bit overpriced but this is Tokyo after all and you always can buy something from 7-11 convenient store downstairs. Highly recommend this hotel. Good discounts for early bird reservations.

We stayed here for 3 nights in early January and loved the hotel. We made our reservations online and the hotel was quick to respond and ready to assist in anyway possible. When we arrived we were overwhelmed with the stunning view from the lobby - just beautiful. The room was clean, well equipped and had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The Assistant Manger went out of his way to give us directions, make dinner reservations and insure we knew where to go and how to get there!! The hotel's location is perfect - walking distance to the Pokemon store (we have 3 kids and THIS was important!), right next door to the train and directly on top of the metro. The price is so much more affordable than most other hotels of this caliber.My only negative comment would be about the breakfast. While the food was very good and the staff attentive, the price is high. We found the dining in Tokyo to be fairly reasonable overall, and were disappointed at the price the hotel charged for a basic, buffet breakfast.

Enjoyed this stay, hotel was in a great location for underground access, room was perfect and i had a fantastic view out towards Mount Fuji in the distance. Small issue with the room smelling of cigarette smoke, i moved rooms and the second one was a little better.

I previously stayed in this hotel about one year ago. At the time, service, rooms and cleanliness were excellent. As such, on my next trip to Tokyo I decided to stay here again. However, this was certainly a mistake. We booked a premium room and upon entering, the smell of urine which had permeated from the bathroom hit our noses. We then asked to change rooms and were put in a new room. Although this room did not smell, the toilet seat had droplets of blood! It seems that the cleaners do not properly clean the rooms, and the bed covers are quite worn.In terms of service, this hotel is a mixed bag. The younger staff all seem very polite and helpful. The front counter staff always seem happy to help and always greet you with a smile. However, older staff are less friendly and less inclined to help. E.g. I tried to book the airport limousine, and when I asked the staff at the desk about what time I should depart from the hotel, I was told that he did not know my flight departure time when I clearly showed him my departure itinerary and also showed him the time of my international departure flight. Perhaps this had to do with the language barrier, however his demeanor was that he did not seem like he wanted to help at all. I did not have an enjoyable stay at this hotel this trip, and I do not feel inclined to try it again.

The hotel is very close to 2 of the nicest places in Tokyo: Ginza neighborhood and tsukiji fish market.Besides that, there is a direct connection to the train and metro stations from the underground of the hotel building, which makes your life really easier.The hotel starts in the 25th floor of a commercial building so all rooms are in the 26th+ floors and have nice views but the best ones are the ´corner rooms´, once the hotel has a triangular format. Breakfast is ok, actually a little expensive for what it offers ( 25 US dolars) but you have many other alternatives in the same building, so this is not an issue at all.Definitely recommend it.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 2 nights at the end of our honeymoon tour of Japan, and booked it on the advice of our travel agent as we wanted a bit of a wow-factor to end our trip on. We had a double room on the 33rd floor and when we walked into our room, absolutely exhausted, at 1am we certainly got it! The enormous window looks out over Tokyo with Tokyo Tower at its centre, beautifully illuminated - a truly awesome view that was even better the next morning when we opened the curtains to see the elusive Mt Fuji just to the right of the tower - perfect photo op from the comfort of our bed! The room itself was comfortable, a good size for a Tokyo hotel, with all the amenities you could need. Breakfast is in the atrium lobby and is a good mix of Western and Japanese buffet. FYI, for smokers, the lobby is the smoking area in the evening, but in the day you will need to go down to the designated area at the subway station. You can take the lift straight from the hotel to the subway - look for the lifts on the right that go to B2 as well as the ground floor - and you will walk out into the enormous Shidome/Shinbashi station complex. It's a bit confusing for the newbie in Tokyo, but look for the big maps on the wall - they have English directions, and once you know what station/line you're after, just follow the signs and you'll be fine. Once of the nice things about this area is that you can catch the subway to Asakusa, then take the boat cruise back to Hama Rikyu gardens - well worth doing, and you can see the hotel from the garden. The area around the hotel is not exactly a wander around and admire area, but it is full of skyscrapers and many shops - for resturants, try the Shidome City Centre building (follow the signs in the subway complex) and go for either the uber-luxurious Sky View places at the top, or the cheerful and good value resturants at the bottom. It's maybe 10 minutes from the hotel, so perfect for when you've already been out all day and just want a quick meal and a couple of drinks. The view from the Sky Bars was, to be honest, less impressive than the view from our very own room!Location tip: the hotel is directly connected to the subway Shidome station - look to the sides as you walk through the pedestrain area, look for the Park Hotel logo (3 tree or plant looking things, look it up on their website) on a board by a doorway and you'll find the lift tucked away. If you have big suitcases though, Shinbashi station is a better bet, and is only a ten minute walk away and there are plenty of taxis if you can't walk anymore - suitcases on the subway is not a good idea, as there are not many lifts but many escalators!

The staff, in my opinion, makes this a 4-star hotel, instead of a 3-star hotel. The staff is as good as any staff at Four Seasons or at similar top-notch luxury brand hotels would be. They are extremely courteous yet professional, and as accommodating! Perfect in my opinion!The view from the lobby is stunning! You can see the snow-capped Mt Fuji though the panoramic window during the day time, and at night time, you can see the majestically lit up Tokyo Tower. The view from my room was good as well...didnt have the direct view of Tokyo Tower or Mt Fuji except for the tall buildings of Tokyo and Shinbashi station.This hotel is one of the best kept secrets in entire Tokyo in terms of location for business travelers or for leisure seekers. Only a 10min walking distance from the famous Ginza district. In my opinion, the location is superbly convenient (Shiodome station for Yamanote Line and JR Trains is right under neath the hotel), shopping, restaurants, and post office all within easy walking/stroll distance.So - why a 4-star not a 5 star?The room is very functional, clean, with a full queen bed and a closet, a desk space, a lounger, and a wet bar completes the room. By Tokyo standards, the room is larger than most 4 or 3 star hotels. But the room still felt like utilitarian to me. I would rate the room a 4-star.The 3 star comes from my room's vantage point (Room 3117). I heard every train, metro subway, the bullet train, loud speakers, and other city noises until very late into the night. For some, the noise level might bother them quite a bit. I had ear plugs, which let me sleep soundly, but I still heard the street and subway/train noise. Ironically, I did not hear any noise coming from my next door neighbors.Other than the noise and with some upgraded amenities, this hotel might be a 4.5 star hotel. Then again, I dont love the high rate of 4.5 or 5 star hotel. That's why I will stay at this hotel.

I was doing business in Guam and wrapped things up a day early, so I decided to spend a day in Tokyo. I had never been to Japan before (except on my connecting flight to Guam), so needless to say I was excited but also nervous for my adventure.I chose the Park Hotel Tokyo based on a recommendation and some online research and I was not disappointed. The lobby is on the 25th floor of the Shidome Media Tower and as you approach the front desk, you are treated to an amazing view of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji compliments of a wall of windows directly behind the front desk.I was greeted with a warm smile by a friendly member of their staff who spoke English which was a very big relief for me since the only words I know in Japanese are konichiwa and arigato. Everything was perfect with my reservation and within minutes I was at the elevator heading up to my Queen City View room on the 29th floor. I was amazed at the speed and quietness of the elevator as I headed upstairs.Entering my room, the first thing I noticed was how clean it was....and then my eyes were quickly diverted to the amazing view of the city that I had out of my window.The room was small compared to comparably priced hotel rooms in the U.S., however, it was very comfortable and had everything that I needed for my one night stay in Tokyo. The highlights of the room were the very comfortable bed/pillows and the Grohe shower with incredibly good water pressure and temperature control.Breakfast was a buffet in the lobby atrium and was above average. I say that only because the selection of items was smaller than I am used to...the food that was offered was very good, with both traditional Japanese offerings and American options.Next stop was the Concierge desk to plan my day. There I spoke with another very friendly woman who also spoke very good english and not only helped me plan my day, but also walked through the currency with me and reviewed the store hours with me so I could strategically plan my morning. At this time I also purchased my bus ticket to the airport....which as a side note I highly recommend using Airport Limosine to/from the airport. Don't be fooled by the name though....it is a bus service that uses very nice coach-style buses with bathrooms on board. They are very clean and prohibit cell phone use which is fantastic!The only negatives that I can offer regarding the hotel are as follows....1. Since I only had one day in Tokyo, I asked for a late check out....2:00 instead of the standard 12:00 check out time. They agreed to my request but at a charge of 3000 yen....or roughly 35 American dollars based on the exchange rate while I was there. Not a big deal but I it would have been nice to get the extra 2 hours at no charge.2. The hotel has a restaurant/lounge in the lobby area that I wanted to go have a beer at before heading to bed. As I started to enter, I was greeted by a sign that said a 1500 yen cover charge would be added to all bills in the lounge...even for hotel guests. If my intent was to spend the evening in the lounge with friends or meeting people, I would have paid it without any hesitation but my intent was to sit for just long enough to have a beer or two by myself and enjoy the view. Instead I ended up walking the equivalent of a few blocks to get my beer at a local pub.Bottom line....the Park Hotel Tokyo is definitely a hotel that I would stay at again.

It was our first time in Tokyo and we came with friends’ warnings that hotel rooms would be cramped and everything would be expensive.Thanks to a little research, we experienced neither.To say that we had the loveliest four days in Park Hotel Tokyo would be an understatement. Let me break it down for you.Location. Park Hotel Tokyo is in the Shimbashi area near Ginza, THE shopping destination. We heard Ginza was a few minutes walk from the hotel but we always took a cab for roughly 900Yen which isn’t a lot. Park Hotel Tokyo is connected to the Shinbashi Train Station where you can catch the JR Train that takes you to Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku, Akihabara, or the Tokyo Station- the drop off point if you want to walk to The Imperial Palace. From the basement of Park Hotel Tokyo, it’s a 300- meter walk to the train station. The underground/basement connection is particularly comforting during winter. Convenience. Whenever a pang of hunger hit, we would just go to Basement 2 of the hotel that houses two restaurants and a sake bar that’s open ‘till the wee hours. A Family Mart sits just outside the revolving door. A machine that converts your dollars to yen is just beside the reception area and is easy to use.Room. We booked late and couldn’t get a double room so we settled for a twin room. Each single bed is adequate, not tiny. I’m 5’2” and my husband is 5’10” and we snuggled in one bed comfortably. The standard twin room is 22 square meters, enough space for two people with a huge suitcase and an extra bag. I’m obsessive about cleanliness and the room passed the test, the heated toilet seats and the toiletries that get replenished daily a huge plus. Housekeeping kept everything neat every single day without the staff moving your personal things.Service. Check-In and Check-Out were efficient. We were early for the 2PM Check-In so we left our bags at the concierge. When we came back, we were ushered to our room where our bags were waiting. Sweet. Before we left, the staff arranged for an early schedule for the Narita Express. The staff was businesslike. It’s a business hotel, after all. They gave us space and were not overly solicitous which we appreciated because we’d rather be left alone. But once approached, the staff members go out of their way to help. In fact, the quick-thinking Japanese manager with a Richard Gere demeanor and looks (in a Japanese way) helped us find my husband’s misplaced wallet so fast we never had time to worry. It’s the kind of service that makes an indelible mark.Park Hotel Tokyo is in a quiet area, far from the madness of the shopping crowd but accessible enough thanks to the underground walkway to the train station. We thought of staying in a hotel in the shopping district of Shibuya but congratulated ourselves for choosing to stay here because we could retreat to a quiet place after the sensory overload that is Tokyo.The hotel rooms begin on the 26th Floor and the reception area is on the 25th Floor. An elevator takes you directly to the 25th Floor with a breathtaking view as you go up. The View. The most stunning thing about Park Hotel Tokyo is the view. A morning treat is having a steaming cup of coffee while staring at snow-capped Mt. Fuji and the arresting presence of Tokyo Tower. The view is even more magnificent at night as the whole city lights up. You drift off to sleep with a night light like no other.To me, the hotel is not just a place to sleep. It’s part of the vacation.

the hotel has a good location and easy access to subway. It's also reachable by bus 8from Naarita). The lobby is located at 30th floor and is very unusual. The restaurant's offer are limited but the bar has a great view especially at night time. Rooms are a little small but are new and efficient. so it's a good hotel

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for about 9 nights in their "Premium-Twin room". Booking the room over the internet with the hotel was quite easy. But changing the room type on the advice of the reservations team was a bit of a hassle as I had to cancel and rebook on my end. In any case, with more time to think, we re-arranged our travel plans to make use of their special internet promotion.We arrived after midnight by cab from Haneda international airport. [Cab drivers are quite familiar with the Park Hotel Tokyo and/or Shiodome Media Centre] Check in was quick and breezy. We then rolled our 2 suitcases and 2 roll-on bags into our room. Our first lot of 4 nights was spent on the 31st floor. Our subsequent 5 nights [after spending 4 nights in Niigata prefecture] was on the 34th floor. Room view was the same, but still mind-blowing to be up so high. In the morning, the view across Tokyo [in the direction of Ginza] was fantastic. I stayed up one night reading and watching the night scene from my bed.The room is quite compact, particularly after the sofa bed was laid open. However, we could still fit in our luggage and by the end of the trip, an extra duffel bag. Rooms come with an attached modern bathroom with a bath-tub. The toiletries are from Haan & Thaan. These are replenished everyday. The shower has good water pressure and certainly helps one to relax after a hard day of sightseeing or shopping.There is a good quality hairdryer provided. However, we had to be careful to not use the hairdryer and kettle at the same time - it trips the power to the room.We found the room to be warm and cosy, more than adequate to for our needs. The room has a large screen TV, WIFI internet connect, the usual tea/coffee making facility, fridge, and an air-purifier. The air purifier helps to filter any of the food, smoke or unsavory smells from the room. There are local and some satellite stations on TV. The mini-laundry room was particularly useful to us. Situated in a corner on the 26th floor, there are 2 washing machines with dryer function. It does a good job of washing and drying most of our clothes.The concierge team are also very helpful, knowledgeable and efficient. We made use of their local knowledge to plan trips around Tokyo and to get another booking with Sukiyabashi Jiro. This is truly an asset to the hotel.Another plus is that the hotel is quite centrally located to the JR and Oedo Metro lines, and in the Shiodome business area. There are plenty of food outlets and mini-marts in the area. Food choice is not an issue. Once we had our bearings to the train stations, we found walking to the trains very easy. The concierge also advised us to use more of the JR lines as it usually takes us to the heart of the area. In this case, we were headed to Shibuya and Shinjuku.Bearings to the train station - We found this the easiest route to the JR line: Walk out of the hotel on the 3rd floor, head towards the feature clock tower in a westerly direction, take the escalators down 2 floors to the basement, hang a left and walk towards the JR lines - this is easier than negotiating the underground from the hotel's basement-2.If you do get the opportunity to join the hotel's in-house loyalty program, please do so. As a reward for staying 5 nights, I received a breakfast coupon. You can choose a whole array of rewards from their program. We were very comfortable at Park Hotel Tokyo. No real complaints here. The staff are friendly and helpful, the room is good value, and the extras like the laundry, good concierge and central location make this hotel a winner in our books. We will certainly stay here again when we are back in Tokyo.

Booked a non-smoking room and what I first found on entering the room was a room reeking of smoke. I called reception to ask if a mistake was made but they said I was on the non-smoking level and eventually after 10 minutes of speaking they sent someone up to check. They agreed and changed my room. I had the unfortunate pleasure of being in the hotel on the 31st floor when the recent 7.4 earthquake struck. After the tremors cooled off I tried to reach reception to find out what was going on, I went outside and all the lifts were out of order, the emergency exit nearest my room was locked, doors labelled emergency exit were not actually doors and the signs on the ceilings pointed you in a loop.
