I managed to find the 2nd emergency door on the floor and went down to reception and the flight of stairs were filled with trays that had the remains of meals left over by other customers. I complained to the hotel manager 'Atsushi Ono' and he said that the emergency doors only unlocked in an emergency and I replied, so a 7.4 earthquake isn't an emegency - to this he had no reply. I also said why is one emergency door open and the other isn't, and why the only that's working is littered with trays - again no response. I find it disgusting that a hotel in this day and age takes the wellbeing and safety of it's customers so apathetically. If you care about your safety, I would advise you to stay clear of this hotel. On checking out of the hotel they tried to charge me for 2 breakfasts when in fact I only had 1. I asked for the receipts as they get you to sign it when you eat. After 20 minutes they said they found 1 but couldn't find the other. All in all, a really bad and disappointing experience that really affected my stay in Tokyo. My advice, pay a little extra and stay somewhere half decent.

We staid at the Park three times within the last 3 weeks and we found that it was an excellent choice! A smart place but not fussy, excellent staff. We booked for a Queen but when we arrived we asked for upgrade to twin corner and we got it! Fabulous view on Mt Fuji.. When we returned we asked for King corner and we got view on the river, very nice too but less impressive! Breakfasts are very good and fresh. We tried the "French" restaurant, we loved it and returned twice. Chef is well known, his food is simply exquisite. The bar is also very nice and skilled barmen will propose excellent cocktails. But certainly this hotel is very well connected to metro, JR line and mono rail to Haneda, quite important if you stay in Tokyo! Yes we will recommend Park Hotel and return.

English is following after Japanese.久々に日本に帰省した際、アメリカ人のパートナーを連れて３泊しました。リクエストしたとおりの東京タワー側の高層階、禁煙のダブルルーム。スタッフの対応はとても良く、英語の対応にも問題はありませんでした。私のパートナーは、東京の夜景を一望するロビーと部屋からの眺めの素晴らしさ、日本のホテルにはない、簡素かつモダンな、国際的でスタイリッシュな雰囲気をとても気に入っていました。まずは、インターナショナルな雰囲気と洗練された建築様式で、建物、施設、スタッフの制服など、すべてが簡素でモダン。小さめでも機能的に設計されている無駄のないコンパクトなスタイリッシュな部屋は、ホテルなのにパリやニューヨークのアパートメントのような、まるで自分の家のような感じがする、自然な居心地の良さが感じられるホテルでした。スパと朝食は利用していませんが、スパと同じThannのアメニティの香りがとても良くて癒されました。朝食もこじんまりとしていながらも、おいしそうなビュッフェでした。また、私たちはピローフィッターを利用して、自分たちにあった枕を選んでもらって使いました。このサービスは、セールスのためではなく、ゲストがホテルで安眠できるために提供されているサービスです。私たちはホテル滞在中に選んだ枕をすっかり気に入り、日本を発つ前に同じ物をデパートで購入してニューヨークに帰りました。次に、できるだけ早めに予約することと、３泊以上泊まれるとかなり安くなり、交通の便の良い都心のホテルとしてはかなり手頃な価格で泊まれます。世界にある他のデザインホテルと比べても、こちらのホテルはかなりリーズナブルです。部屋はダブルルームでも小さめなので、カップルでも大きめの部屋が良い方は、コーナーツインにするのもいいかもしれません。一方で、他の方のバスルームが尿のような匂いがしたとか、ホテルのエントランスがわかりにくいというクチコミを読みましたが、私たちの部屋のバスルームも、チェックインしたばかりの時は匂いが気になりましたが、シャワーを使い始めてからは匂いが消え、まったく気になりませんでした。わかりやすい入り口は地上2階か地下の入り口。1階はタクシーが使えて、地下はこちらのビルのファミリーマートのとなりにあり、2階はゆりかもめの汐留駅の出口の目の前です。新橋駅から歩く時は、汐留方向に歩いて、2階のデッキに上がって歩くとわかりやすいです。ちなみに、このあと私たちは、お台場にある、こちらのホテルよりも値段が高く日本的なホテルに2泊したのですが、雰囲気がまさに日本のホテルで仰々しすぎて、広めな部屋にもかかわらず、自分の家にいるようなリラックス感はありませんでした。私たちは一番眺めのよい部屋に泊まったのにもかかわらず、こちらから眺める景色より、パークホテルからの景色の方が感動的でした。次回も東京で宿泊するときは、迷わずパークホテル東京にします。 結果として、一般的な大きいホテルのように、滞在中多くのスタッフとすれ違うことが多く、監視されてるような雰囲気はいやだけれど、ビジネスホテルほど簡素でなく、ホテルのようなサービスとセンスがあって、眺めの良い部屋に、自分の家にいるようにリラックスして滞在したい方には最高のホテルだと思います。We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for three nights when we went back to my home country, Japan. Our room was a non-smoking double room had one double bed with Tokyo Tower view on high floor per our request. All staff were attentive and their English skills had no problem. The hotel was no more new hotel, but it's carefully maintained and kept clean.My partner is Italian American was very impressed by the beautiful view from the concierge and our room and that the hotel had international atmosphere which was simple & modern was a kind of like it's a not typical Japanese hotel.First, as an Design Hotels, the hotel's architecture is a beautiful and sophisticated has an international atmosphere. Their facilities and the staff's uniform are simple but stylish and practical.Our room was a little small which was like a hotel in New York City or Paris, but also it's a stylish and practical. We could relax as if we were living there as our own apartment of Tokyo. :)We didn’t use spa, but the Thann’s room amenity was same as their spa was great aromatic smell! Breakfast buffet also looked so good!In addition, we also enjoyed their pillow fitters service. The service is provided for the hotel's guests can sleep peacefully while we stay there, it's not for their sales of merchandise. We liked our borrowed pillows were fitted with us, and we bought them at the department store and took to our home in New York City.Second, this hotel is very easy access for both sightseeing and business.If we can book this hotel earlier and stay longer, the cost is lower than the other hotels in the heart of Tokyo. Also this hotel is a very affordable price comparing with the other Design Hotels over the world.Even double rooms, they are a little smaller than the other big hotels in the city of Tokyo, thus you might be prefer to choose the corner twin room if you're a couple and want to stay in a big room.In contrast, I read other reviews that “the bathroom smells like urine.” “difficult to find the hotel entrance.” I also felt a similar smell in our bathroom when I just checked in the room, however, we didn't smell anything after starting to use shower. This hotel is in Kyodo News company’s building 25-34th Fl. Easily understanding entrance is underground or 2nd Fl. Ground floor entrance is better to access by cab for visitor. Underground Entrance is next to Family mart (convenience store - Japanese style convenience deli for 24 hrs) easy access from subway stations or walking underground from JR Shimbashi Station. The 2nd Floor entrance faces on Shiodome Sta. of Yurikamome line. When we can walk from JR Shimbashi Sta. to the 2nd floor entrance, walk upstairs to 2nd Floor has wood deck board walk from street level around Shimbashi Sta. Yurikamome Line, so easily access to 2nd Floor entrance. Sounds like complicated, but you’ll get used to be soon if you stay there.For comparison, after this hotel, we stayed another expensive hotel of big Japanese airline company's group in Odaiba, Tokyo for two nights. But, the hotel's atmosphere was an ordinal Japanese old school style. Many staff were everywhere in the hotel and polite. However, they were a little too much for us. We were not comfortable as same as Park Hotel Tokyo. Despite our room was best view room in the hotel, Park Hotel Tokyo’s view was more impressed for us. Therefore, we definitely stay at Park Hotel Tokyo again when we go to Tokyo.As a result, I highly recommend this hotel for the people emphasize the enjoyment of relaxing of private time like living our own house in stylish atmosphere, luxury & services like hotel but not too much, and view of beautiful the center of Tokyo from high floor in the center of Tokyo.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights. It was a wonderfull experience! The lobby is located on the 25th floor. The floors below are offices. Personnel was very nice and spoke English perfectly. We thought the view from the lobby was great, but when we got to our Corner Twin Room on the 33rd floor we where blown away! The view of the Tokyo Skyline is absolutely breathtaking. It offers great views of the city and its inhabitants. Shinbashi Station is directly below the hotel, lots of subways pass through as well as lots of Shinkansen trains. The roomsize is average, not to big, not to small. The room was clean and came with all sorts of amenities. We booked well in advance so the roomprice was affordable enough.The location of the hotel is maybe not as vibrant as one would expect (mainly officebuildings) but Ginza and Shinbashi are within walking distance. The fismarket is a 20 min walk (I think it will be a bit shorter once the roadwork is completed) Also the subway offers great connections to other parts of the city. The unmanned train-station Shiodome is right next to the hotel and connects to Shinbashi Station and more important the artificial island Odaiba with lots of shopping malls, movie theaters and Gundam shop!The hotelbar was expensive, 10 euro for a beer is ridiculous....

The Park Hotel is attractively priced, serves a very good breakfast buffet, and offers some terrific views over Tokyo. The staff is friendly and helpful Unfortunately, the hotel entrances are hidden in a maze of underpasses, overpasses, up and down escalators, and tunnels. Even after three nights there we found it hard to locate the way back from Shinbashi Sation, and it didn't help that there are two other Park Hotels in the vicinity plus a Shiodome Tower that is not the Shiodome Media Tower. There is no surrounding neighborhood, just a confluence of expressways. (Despite some claims, it is not really near the Ginza). On a cold night, you think twice before going out again, and the hotel's restaurants are expensive.

First trip to Tokyo and loved it. Stayed with family for 4 nights at the Park Hotel (2 adults, 2 girls). Good value and size by Tokyo standards with a location that can't be beat.Top 10 things that we liked about the Park Hotel Tokyo:-Views galore: Located on the top floors of the Shiodome media tower, hotel views couldn't get better. Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji on one side of the hotel and Tokyo bay on the other. Unbeatable, especially Tokyo tower at night. With its iconic red color, it beats the Eiffel tower IMHO. -Location, location, location: Ginza is a 5 minute walk. Shiodome and the very connected JR Shimbashi Station are steps away. This station can take you anywhere in Tokyo. Tsukiji fish market is a hop, skip and jump away.-Our corner room: A little bigger for our family, and with Tokyo Tower bidding us sweet dreams every night, a veritable treat for the eyes.-Staff: Japan is known for its service, and this hotel definitely did not disappoint. We were met everywhere with smiles and a can-do attitude from the check in staff, the bellhops, to the Japanese and English speaking concierge staff. English speaking Chris was a bit off his element during our trip (we were a bit disappointed given the previous rave reviews) but the Japanese staff was incredible.-Cleanliness: Spotless. Everywhere. -Art: Whimsical and interesting. Even the photojournalistic exhibit of the adjoining Kyodo News office on the lower floor was a nice welcome back home.-Vending machine that changes foreign currency in the lobby. Enough said.-Airport bus from Narita goes directly to the hotel. Take the direct bus and don't try taking the trains from the airport unless you know the area very well. The tunnels and walkways will take some getting used to.-The 7-11 convenience store located in the basement of the hotel. I can't tell you how may trips a day we made to get rice balls, green tea kitkat, ice coffee, water, japanese beer and more. Extremely reasonable prices in expensive Tokyo.-Finally, the Ghibli clock show right outside the hotel on the NTV building is an amazing experience. OK, not technically part of the hotel, but so close that we linked it to our stay. This clock was designed by the famous Japanese animator Miyazaki and there are several showings a day. We sometimes timed out trips to and from the hotel to see this free clock show. Incredible.Things that the hotel could work on:-More comfortable beds. We slept well, but could be a tad more comfortable.-Ice machines. Could be more robust. We had to research several floors before we were able to find our favorite (one with a reliable supply of ice).-WiFi: Weak signal in the rooms. Free in the lobby but experience would be vastly improved with room access (especially considering this is the "media" tower).-Gym: Should be free (rather than cost $) especially since it is just a shoebox of a room. But on the bright side, this forced me to run outdoors and explore the interesting areas off the beaten path.-Room furniture: Just showing a little wear now with scratches and such. All in all, we would come back to the Park Hotel as a family. Also cool that Tablet Hotels features this hotel as well.

Stayed here in Nov for 3 nights on a holiday. Hotel is in a convenient location – next to Shiodome Station, minutes from Shimbashi station and an easy 10 minute walk to Ginza. Great view from the reception of Mount Fuji and Tokyo tower. Rooms are compact but functional. Bathrooms equally aren’t massive but seemed to be filled with the biggest toilet westerners have ever seen ! (fully equipped with music, heated seat and a spray arm!) Rooms were kept clean and staff on reception were great – really helpful and no issues with the language barrier. Free 24 hour access to the internet in their business area (in reception). Very efficient with the booking and organising or the Airport Limousine (would recommend this to get to/from Narita – cheaper and easier that train/taxi) Hotel is also really easy to find – you’ll soon get your bearings.

Very nice hotel located very close to Shinbashi station, which is a great location to move around Tokyo. Shinbashi is accessible directly by Train from Haneda Airport (no change needed) and very easily connected to Narita via train.To access the hotel from the train stations:- if you arrive through NR Shinbashi station or Shinbashi: follow first Shiodome and then exit 7- if you arrive through Shiodome station: follow exit 7From exit 7, you should go up two floors to access the ground floor and then take the elevator... Hotel lobby is at the 25th floor.Big room (for Japanese standards) and a very good ration quality/price.Very clean hotelPositive points:- a change machine so that you can convert your euros or dollars into yens... which is very convinient as only a few ATM in Japan accept foreign credit cards.- Free wiFi available- great view from the hotel.

Couldnt fault this hotel. But be aware that very close by is another hotel called Royal Park Hotel....totally separate from the one we stayed at. Dont get confused but we couldnt work out the reasoning as to why they would name 2 places so near to each other with similar names. Anyway the Park Hotel reception desk is on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Tower and then the residential floors are above. Cant think of anything we didnt like about it.

Extremely helpful staff, great English, clean rooms, on the edge of the Ginza district, had an amazing view of Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji. Good food, wireless internet, really great hotel. There was nothing I didn't like.

This is a really great hotel. The view is amazing on all floors because the hotel starts at the 20th or so. Good breakfast buffet which I paid for, and the beds are very comfortable. Rooms also super clean along with the entire hotel and everything in Japan. Cleanest place I have ever visited.The building is a big commercial building with a lot of professionals during the day. There is a coffee shop on the bottom floor, along with a 7/11, and small restaurants. The metro is downstairs in the building, so the location can't get any better. Ginza is about a 5 minute walk from the hotel, and right outside across the street is a fantastic nightlife area with great food, bars, pachinko, and anything else an adult in Japan would enjoy. Tokyo station is only a few stops away, and if you are coming from the airport, its really easy to take the train in. Don't worry about getting lost, its really easy to take the metro in Japan. VERY self explanatory, no need for the shuttle.

We were looking for a good quality hotel in Tokyo, in a central region. We chose to stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo because of a promotion we found at TabletHotels website.This hotel is located right at the exit of Shidome underground station, and close to Ginza, so you have a large range of transport options there. It is located in the top floors of a modern business tower, and has beautiful views of Tokyo. The rooms are comfortable, even though small (but not for Japanese standards), and very very clean (Japanese standards!). Wifi was free, concierge very helpful, the lobby smelled super nice, and the food was good too.A great base to explore Tokyo in modern Tokyo style.

not to be confused with Royal Park Hotel, which has a similar address (it's just across the road really) and is a similar hotel, but is in my opinion not as great.really good location in central Tokyo, for business or pleasure - walking distance to Ginza or to the fish market, really close to JR station Shimbashi, which is on the Yamanote line and on the lines going south to Yokohama and Kamakura.as many hotels in this area, it shares the building with offices - the first 24 floors or so are office spaces, and the hotel starts at the 25th. there are separate entrances though, and the hotel elevators don't stop at the office floors, so you don't really notice it.... except when you look out the window from the room or from the huge windows in the lobby, and are treated to great views over Tokyo.but apart from location and views, the Park Hotel has an extra something that's not easy to define but it sets it apart from other places in the neighbourhood - understated elegance and attention to detail come to mind, from the kind and helpful attitude of the people in the reception to the quality cosmetics in the bathroom to fine choices in the mini-bar.

Confusing entrance system with no street level door service to guide you to the 25th floor check in.A helpful building security officer showed us the way.Our first room furniture was so dirty and the room smelt so badly we requested a different room which they quickly offered. Second room was cleaner but still had the same rank body odour type smell prevailed until we had the air con running for about an hour. This repeated everytime we left the room and returned more than an hour later. It took more than an hour for the room air to 'purify''. Can't fault the view from the room we had which was room# 3304 and facing Tokyo Tower. The desk service was mixed with some staff pleasant and others quite grumpy. The reception area bar was pleasant enough but confounds me why they have the reception desk and bar area set up with the reception desk having the views of the Tower and the bar area parked at the rear of the room with no views. Surely the Tower view is what you'd want to be looking at when you are paying the prices they charge for a drink ? One of the two internet computers didn't work and with no wii-fi in rooms there was a long queue for the sole computer. There was no offer of assistance with baggage when we checked out and we had to find our own way to ground floor and onto the street to find a taxi. If it wasn't for the killer view from the bedroom I wouldn't go back. Location is reasonable as its right above Shiodome Metro station and not far from Ginza night life.

I've stayed in this hotel twice for business. The first time I had a tiny room and found it very difficult to work in my room as the desk was small and the chair uncomfortable. I didn't even have enough space to unpack my clothes as the wardrobe was tiny. The second time, I requested a corner room and found the space much better and the general standard of the room much higher quality (larger desk, better chair, larger bath).Both times, I found the wifi internet very patchy and unreliable. The room service menu was very basic and over-priced. They also were engaged for long periods of time and seemed a little understaffed. The location of the hotel is good and once you've mastered the walkways and tunnels you'll find the area has lots to offer.

We stayed in Park Hotel Tokyo for 4 nights plus other 4 nights in August 2012.The hotel is very well located, closed to JR Shimbashi station, closed to the fish market, Hama Gardens and Ginza... The hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower from floor 25-35 ... wonderful view!The room was very confortable and quiet with free wi-fi and nice view (our room was on 33th floor), the bathroom was cleaned and with every amenities you may need everyday.During the w-end the staff at the reception didn't speak english and this was a problem, while during week they were friendly, helpful and speak english!Breakfast was ok but the restaurant and dining options in the hotel are limited. Anyway Caretta Shiodome nearby has good choice of restaurants.

Had a bumpy start to the hotel as they got our reservation wrong and checked us into a Queen Room instead of the larger King that we had booked. Luckily I had all documentation so the error was fixed when I saw the room, but left us with feeling this is a good hotel but not a great one. Service was excellent (as everywhere in Tokyo) and the prices are reasonable. The best thing about this hotel is location - I would definitely stay in Shiodome area again, even in a different hotel. Suitable for work or pleasure.

You can't beat the location, the service or the views from this great hotel, floors 25 - 35 of this waterfront hotel. Truly 4 or 5 stars. Great breakfast buffet ($25) and gracious staff. Single rooms are small but more than adequate.

Terrific. Tokyo is a busy, hectic, large city. This is a perfect home base. Its near subway and train lines, the fish market (for the 4 am walk), the ginza, ueno park and the business district. The rooms are efficient. The staff are knowledgable and profession. Ok, the funky music on the 25th floor lobby needs to be changed, but otherwise the rooms are quiet. Finally, the price is fair and reasonable. Eat at the breakfast buffet

Excellent hotel for business or for pleasure. Smallish rooms, but always efficient as Japanese rooms are. Excellent location close to JR Shimbashi Station, Yurikamome line and Oedo Subway line. Great breakfast if you want to spend the $25. Good business center if you need to print documents or use a browser. Shimbashi area is right next to Ginza and has eating establishment galore, as always in Japan - tough to find a bad restaurant.

Stayed for four nights. Hotel is in a good location but its wherabouts can be confusing at first. Once you realise everything seems to link from Shiodome station then getting about can be quite easy.Be prepared for very small rooms but the views are spectacular. Staff were helpful although communication was difficult at times, breakfast was fine but the dining options in the hotel are fairly limited.All in all a reasonably priced option in a very expensive city, but nothing really special

The hotel is very well located in Ginza and has a direct acess to a subway station. Our room on th 31st floor had a great view. The room itself is well equipped, quite and I found nothing to complain about. The stuff was very polite and helpful.A good place to stay.

Stayed in this hotel in April on our first visit to Japan. Very easy to get to using the Limousine Bus from Narita airport, room on the small side but the views across the city were just breathtaking. Brilliant location - underpass and overpass links you to Shiodome and Shinbashi stations (walk the bit further to Shinbashi as it has much better connections). Caretta Shiodome nearby offers good choice of restaurants, and the Studio Ghibli clock on the next door building is unmissable. Convenience store in the basement handy.

The hotel is very nice - new and very well located - very close to Ginza (the fancy neighborhood) and the fish market (which is a nice place to visit) and downstairs there is a connection to the subway, which is very convenient in a confusing city as Tokyo. Rooms are small but clean and well organized. Breakfast, however, is no more than ok. Super nice skyline! Notwithstanding these positive aspects, we had a very bad experience with the staff of the front desk / concierge. Unfortunately, they were not able to speak and understand (which is worse) English which led us to spend almost 1 hour and a half under the rain (WHITH A 9 MONTHS BABY) to get to Ginza, which normally takes 10 minutes walking or 2 minutes by subway (which is downstairs). The front desk guy gave us completely wrong directions and did not informed us that the subway was downstair. C'mon...it was raining and he saw we were with our baby!!!! Worse than that is that in the next day, we were asking about the "hop on hop off bus" (we checked in the internet that Tokyo has some alike sightseeing bus) but only 40 minutes later the staff managed to understand what we wanted. I asked for the manager and I was informed that it would be impossible to talk to him as he was in a meeting in another building and would be back by the end of the day!! What a surprise that 5 minutes later I saw the manager walking by the hotel!!!!! In general, the hotel is very good, clean and very well located, but our experience with the staff made our stay a little bit disappointing.

Great staa. Rooms are small but well appointed . Extremely clean and great bathroom amenities . Get the prepaid breakfast you can skip lunch after that. Metro is right below the hotel extremely convenient . Rooms very quiet and great housekeeping staff. Just 5 minutes from Ginza shopping area. Great job on the selection of staff. 5 star quality

Although on the expensive side it is worth every penny. The service was personal, extremely polite and quietly efficient. The hotel room gave us all the amenities expected from a 5* hotel including a super view of the Tokyo tower from our 30th floor room window which we were in awe of both day and nighttime. The restaurant food in the French restaurant was of a Michelin standard and the table service was remarkably friendly but also remarkably professional. The concierge and reception staff were very helpful, very well-mannered in that Japanese way and helped to make our stay a superb one.If I had to make one very minor criticism it would be to improve the signage to the hotel from the labyrinthine underground of Shimbashi/Shiodome stations. This was our second visit and it certainly will not be our last.

Pros: Decent rooms (large by Tokyo standards too), right by Shinbashi hub, great views, excellent food, close to fish market, helpful staff, great bar for late evening drinksCons: It's hard to find any big issues with this place, maybe a pool would have been nice to freshen upBased in the Shiodome Media Tower, you'll need to travel a few dozen floors up just to reach the reception of this hotel. But that's great - it lifts you up and out of the Mecca that is Tokyo and opens up excellent bar-level views on to Tokyo Tower and the city, while the rooms - which are yet further up - also offer sublime views of the city right towards the waterfront. Location-wise there's the morning fish market a short walk away, a waterfront park also a short walk away, while Shinbashi is a major hub that's essential to getting around the city. The whole Shiodome media park also has various fun things going on depending on what time of year you're out there. For a four star hotel there was nothing missing. Ok, so there's no swimming pool, but we knew that in advance so it wasn't a problem. On the first night, suffering from massive jetlag, a short walk around was all we could manage before falling back to the hotel to grab some easy food. The burgers with avocado that we had, while a little pricey, were seriously good. Just what we needed. Although the rooms aren't necessarily going to blow you away, they're a lot larger than you'd find in most Tokyo hotels. That's a huge bonus. They're not "American sized", but "European sized" is probably the best way to explain it. The staff were really good to us too. After a strange insect bite at Fuji they were very good in getting us to see a doctor at a hospital for further advice. This had impacted further excursion plans, so the Japanese concierge was able to phone up various venues and explain in Japanese what had happened in order to cancel on our behalf. Was very useful. Then after a magnitude seven earthquake offshore the staff were equally chilled out and unfazed by something that had really shook us up! Very reassuring in their explanations.The bar was a frequent hangout for us too. The Japanese, at least at this place, chill their port. Not sure why, but it tasted good enough to see me back in the bar pretty much every night and the barman was always great to chat to as he was trying to improve his English skills. It's really hard to find much to moan about. An exceptional property.

Beautiful view from spacious (for tokyo standards) and clean room. Carpet bit stained. Switched rooms, and the new one was only less stained. Overall room and hotel clean and well maintained.Proper working and silent airconditioning.Comfortable beds (not too hard or too soft). Tv with only some english news channels and lot of japanese channels.Wifi lousy in terms of speed and stability. Cable with laptop works fast. Complimentary.Breakfast meets 4 star standard. Nothing too fancy. €25 (!). Nearby starbucks 5 min walking. Get out 3rd floor, outside take a right, walk about 50m and go 2 stories down with escalator. Shimbashi big station 10 min. walking. Ask for directions because it's quite complex ar Shiodome area.

This hotel really exceeded my expectations!!!I have heard that hotel rooms in Japan are notoriously tiny but our room was surprisingly of good size. The hotel had easy access to a mall and the train and subway station which made it easy for us to go anywhere. There's a coin laundry in the hotel (which was a definite plus!), payphones, currency changers, vending machines and everything you could possibly need!The views from our room were also excellent and the cleaners always keep our bathroom well-stocked with high-quality toiletries. All the staff were very helpful and would greet us everytime we pass them. All in all, this hotel made our holiday extra memorable. Would definitely book this hotel again when we go back to Japan!

Normally I stay across the street at the Royal Park Shiodome but it was booked. While I still prefer that hotel just slightly, this is a nice alternative and one that should be equally considered. I can see where some would prefer this hotel because it does have superior views. The weakness is in the quality of materials used for small details like desks, chairs, fixtures, including carpets, etc. It just doesn't have the same polish, except in the lobby which is superior to the other. Average rooms are small, similar to other Japanese hotels.The staff here is excellent and they seem to handle American guests very well. If this is your first time to Tokyo and you want to get around on your own, this is a decent home base. The very first thing you wan to do is pick up a subway map from the Concierge that's numbered as the station maps are all in Japanese. There are several subway lines all within walking distance and the cab to Tokyo Station is not that expensive.

This hotel was everything you'd expect of a business class hotel - excellent staff, quality rooms, and good location. I can't fault it too much.There were just two minor downsides. The first was an overly strong scented air freshner being used - almost sickly at times. The other was that the restaurants were ridiculously expensive - so much so that I opted to take breakfast elsewhere. Obviously everything in Tokyo is expensive, but even on expenses I felt uncomfortable using the hotel for breakfast or evening meals. Not that evening meals are a problem - there's millions of fantastic eating places very close to the hotel.

After arriving at 5am and getting lost and rained on and hot the hotel was so nice and let us check in super, super early. The room here was the largest we had in Tokyo and very comfortable. The hotel has a walkway that connects to the subway making it very convenient. The fish market is about a ten minute walk from the hotel as well as many restaurants. We also had free wifi in our room which was very helpful. I would recommend this hotel for sure!

We stayed here for 5 nights and got a great rate through the hotel website but you need to book well in advance to get the best rates. We wanted to extend for an additional night upon checkout but the rate was more than double the rate we had paid as an early booking so we moved to another hotel. Great location being walking distance to Ginza and the fish market and a short walk to Shinbashi and Shiodome station. These are on different lines which is great as you can travel almost anywhere from both of these locations.Room was a good size and we had a view of Tokyo Tower. On one day it was clear and we could see Mt Fuji which was a real treat!There was free wifi in the rooms and a conciege to help with information / day trips. Also business centre with free use of computers with charge for printing. Highly recommend for the price, hotel and location.

We booked a city twin room for a 1 week stay. Our room was on the 27th floor with a view of the Sumida River You can find good rates for this hotel on their website that don't seem to differ much from the major booking websites. I did learn that when my first flight was cancelled that I needed to call the booking agency to change my reservation rather than calling the hotel directly. Rooms are small, as is normal in Tokyo, so leave your largest suitcases at home and travel light. Bathrooms are clean and functional. I was worried that the room might be too warm in light of the push to save energy but that wasn't a problem. You have full control of in room temperature and they have the quietest cooling system I have ever experienced in a hotel (usually, the noise keeps me awake the first night). Furnishings are nice and the hotel staff is very friendly and helpful. They speak enough English to help with most of your needs. Housekeeping is unobtrusive and thorough. The hotel can be reached via a long, confusing underground walk from Shimbashi Station (follow the overhead signs for Shiodome) and a shorter underground walk from Shiodome Station (use the maps of the area on the wall to find Shiodome Media Tower). If you have heavy luggage, or are too jet-lagged to follow directions, I would recommend taking the Airport Limousine Bus that delivers you from the airport to the front door. You can also take a taxi from Tokyo Station if that's where your train or bus leads you after arriving in Japan. All the buildings in the Shiodome area seem to be connected via the tunnels with shops and restaurants galore. There are bilingual maps along the way when you get lost. Make sure that you are navigating to Shiodome Media Tower. The lobby is very attractive and a comfortable place for a drunk or light meal. They have a number of well regarded restaurants in the hotel.

The hotel lobby is very modern and cool. There is free wifi in the lobby, so it was nice to sit there and check emails etc. The room was clean and the amenities were good, robe included. The breakfast was great, but kind of pricey. The room was very spacious and comfortable. The staff was amazing- so friendly and helpful. The area is great- I went for a run one morning in a park not too far away. There is a lot of nice shopping during the day (no markets), and the Tsunjiki fish market is walking distance away.

This hotel is in a great area in Tokyo - walking distance to Ginza, the fish market and the Hama Rikyu water bus (that goes to Asukusa). It also rises above the underground shopping mall in theShiodome Media Tower. And from the mall you have access to various stores, a family mart, the metro, subway and JR line - so traveling anywhere in Tokyo is easy. The hotel offers great services, a bar, restaurant, comfortable lobby and evening a reasonable priced laundromat. It's a beautiful, comfortable hotel with great service. It's not cheap, but it's definitely affordable and we stayed there 5 nights which gave us a significant discount. The hotel starts on the 25th floor of the tower and rises to the 34th. We were on the 33rd and had the most amazing view of the city! I would recommend this to anyone touring Tokyo.

Location: very convenientService: very hospitable, careful to attend to my needsF&B: good, nice setting, however after 10.00pm restaurant is closed and not much choice after that.Rooms: very small but well furbished. However, this was my second stay (first stay in October 2011) and some furniture are now deeply stained and need to be renewed / properly cleaned.Gym facilities: nothing available apart from a treadmill and a bicycle...And it is chargeable...

Nice location and acceptable rooms for a 4-star class hotel but, with a few exceptions, the staff aren't particularly friendly or helpful, especially front-desk/managerial types. All this could have been passable. However, when I had to use the hotel laundry services they managed to lose my necktie somewhere along the way. So far so good (so to speak) but after a couple of conversations with hotel staff (front-desk and manager), they flat out refuse to take any responsibility or (at the very least) apologize for the mishap. Instead they insist that it I never delivered the item since it didn't show in any of the laundry reports.Great way of screwing up a couple of vacation days shopping for replacement clothing instead of doing actual vacationing... Pity that the room was paid in advance, otherwise I would have moved to another hotel.

As with most hotels in Tokyo, the rooms in this hotel are tiny. The staff are fantastic, although they sometimes have communication difficulties (I had asked for two rooms next to each other repeatedly and was assured this would happen each time. It didn't.)However, the rooms are nice, with spectacular views and the position is perfect. It is close to the Yamanote Line's Shimbashi Station from which you can get anywhere as well as being perfectly placed for an early morning vist to the spectacular fish markets. There is even a direct line from Shiodome Station right next door to the hotel which goes to the new Tokyo Skytree building. It is a nice walk to Ginza too, which is an added bonus.

The hotel is very well located, 10 mins walking (trough a pedestrian bridge) from the Shinbashi station, very well connected to almost all the main areas of Tokyo.the area around the hotel is full of cafes, restaurants and tipical food sellers (around the train station) so it's perfect if are spending few days in Tokyo.Most of rooms has an amazing view on the Tokyo tower and they are quite big (considering the Japanese standards).The only bad think I found was the checkin time (but I found the same problem in all the other Japanese hotels in which I've been): the had not flexilibility, it was at 3 pm and no way to make them change their mind, even I was arriving directly from Europe and I had wrote them in advance.Breackfast was not so rich as I was expecting and quite expensive, but the quality was good.

Great value for money hotel in expensive Tokyo. Rooms were excellent. Service was great. And price was excellent for a hotel of this quality. Only downside that it is a little (only a little) far from the JR station and subway. However, it is only one stop away from Ginza.Highly recommended!

My wife, teenage son and I stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights at the end of August. It was our first trip to Tokyo and I booked the hotel after doing ample research on Expedia and Trip Advisor. From those sites, the hotel appeared to be very modern and clean, situated in a great central location and at a very reasonable price. A huge plus was the ability to have 3 persons stay in one room. We booked a Premium Twin room which gave us a 2 beds and a sofa bed AND an amazing view of the Tokyo skyline with the new Tokyo Skytree off to the North! The views at the hotel are amazing due to the fact that the hotel is situated atop the Shiodome Media Tower.We thoroughly enjoyed our room and felt it was a good size for the 3 of us. We definitely enjoyed waking to the beautiful views of the city and ending our day overlooking the city lights below. I truly believe this room/hotel helped in making our trip to Tokyo that more special. The staff is incredibly friendly, polite and willing to help -- always greeting us with a smile as we came back to our home away from home.As for location... some reviewers on trip advisor had been critical of the location. We, however, found it to be ideal. In a nice and modern part of town, it is within easy walking distance of many local attractions as well as several train and subway stations. Heck, even the train to Odaiba has a station just steps from the entrance to the hotel. Head out there if you're looking for some shopping, dining or just for fun! We did... it was great. We also enjoyed easy walks to Ginza and the areas around Shinbashi in the evenings especially to watch all the activity after work hours and people flooded the streets. Great photo opportunities! My wife and I are photographers and Tokyo did not disappoint!There is so much more to say about this great hotel and it's great staff, but I think I've gone on enough. I'm sure I'm missing great stuff as well. I'll add it if I remember more! I HAD to write a review so this hotel would get the praise it definitely deserved. PLUS, we already have plans to return to Tokyo next spring and will be staying at the Park Hotel for our entire stay... Hopefully in a Premium Twin room again. But with a different view so we can enjoy waking to a new part of town! Can't wait to return to amazing Tokyo!

Hotels in Tokyo are expensive. Park hotel strikes the balance between cost and quality. Lobby is beautiful, with a large atrium, sleek looking reception and large windows. Gives a feeling of an expensive 5 star hotel. The rooms don't disappoint. Our room was relatively small but had everything we needed. Comfortable beds, clean functional bathrooms and coffee making facilities. As a bonus we had a fantastic view of the Tokyo skyline. Location is excellent - right next to shiodome metro station on the oedo line. This proved to be extremely useful as we could easily roam around tokyo In the knowledge that our hotel is 2 mins from a metro stop. Overall I was very happy with the hotel and would definitely stay here again.

My husband and I celebrated our tenth anniversary with a week's holiday in Tokyo, and we knew that choosing a good hotel in a convenient location was vital to making the most of our time.We could not have made a better choice than the Park Hotel Tokyo. The only reason why I might stay elsewhere in future is if I wish to have a more traditional experience at a ryokan. If you're looking for a new, modern hotel with easy access to the subway (Shiodome station was literally just downstairs and Shimbashi station was a 7-minute walk away), a convenience store and close proximity to good food and major attractions, this hotel is a winner. What's more, if you manage to secure a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower, the night view is nothing short of spectacular.What elevated our experience from great to amazing was the service we enjoyed. During our stay, not only were our needs promptly accommodated on every score, we felt that the staff really went the extra mile to build a relationship with us, and to fulfill with every request to the utmost. For instance, when we asked for recommendations to karaoke lounges nearby, Lettow, a young gentleman with immaculate manners, came up to our room with specially printed maps to three lounges, and proceeded to explain the pros and cons of each establishment, give clear directions and even provide us with discount coupons. When we missed our flight home because of a mix-up between Narita and Haneda airports, Mr. Yasuhiro Kodaka, one of assistant managers, as well as his colleague in the next shift, tried for more than three hours to contact the airline by phone on our behalf. He was so sympathetic and helpful that we felt almost glad to be staying for an additional night. He arranged for us to have a room with a direct view of the Tokyo Tower at a fantastic rate, and kindly said that he hoped the view would cheer us up! One of the bellboys, whose name I'm sorry I didn't get, took charge of our luggage while the Mr, Kodaka was still trying unsuccessfully to reach the airline, and did his best to soothe us by making sure we were waiting comfortably on roomy couches with glasses of iced water. He actually stayed almost half an hour past the end of his shift for our sake, only leaving when we finally let him know that we would probably be checking back into the hotel.My husband and I were really touched and gratified by the efforts of the hotel staff to help us make the most of a bad situation, and at how genuinely glad they seemed to be for us when we managed to get seats on a flight the next morning. This is simply the best service I have ever had the pleasure to enjoy in any hotel. A big thank you to the wonderful staff of the Park Hotel Tokyo. I'll never forget our wonderful stay there.

Arrived at night, first time in Tokyo, impossible to tell all the buildings apart, so just taxi it here if you come in on the NEX. We walked in out of the pouring rain, and the staff were extremely polite and helpful despite us looking like a couple of drenched hobos. The room, whilst not enormous, as you'll discover is huge compared to most rooms in Japan. It was comfortable however, with your own thermostat so you can lower or raise the temp as you wish. The view was fantastic. Close to Tsukiji fish market, would still recommend taking the train there, it's a 15 minute walk.The entrance to the hotel is actually on the third floor, and the elevators have no ac, which during the middle of summer is a nuisance. But regardless of all that, this is a lovely place to stay.

We arrived in Tokyo at 10pm and this hotel around 11pm. We found it very difficult to figure out where the lobby was and how to get to it, there were no security guards and very little light and signage. Once we made it up the 25th floor it was fine. It was very hot when we were in Tokyo and even though we put the thermostat down to 18 degrees in our room it never really got below 24 or even higher. The room was small but had a great view and some English speaking tv channels. The breakfast buffet was reallly good, offering both Western and Japanese style dishes and was included with the room price. We ate at the Japanese retaurant for dinner one night and were not impressed with the food or the service, it seemed to take a really long time to get our food. There is a cash exhange machine in the lobby so you can change currency with a decent exchange rate and do it on your own schedule.

Stayed for 2 nights as part of our honeymoon trip. Great location being on 2 metro lines and a short walk to the Ginza district. The staff were amazing, everyone so polite and helpful. Chris the concierge gave us great recommendations for areas and bars to visit. Our room was fine, we didn't notice it being too small. The free wifi is great and simple to connect with no passwords so we could use on multiple devices. We tried the breakfast once and it was fine although there are bakeries and a grocery store nearby which make for a cheaper option. For the price of the room, we booked on their website, it was amazing value for this type of hotel in this central location in Tokyo. Would definately stay again

This is a rather nice hotel is conveniently located and has direct access to subway and metro stations. Close to the fish market and Ginza.Clean, friendly staff, free internet and free use of computers business center.

I stayed for the 1st time in this Hotel. The hotel is conveniently located and has direct access to Shiodome railway station (E19 on Oedo Line) from basement. Hotel starts from 25th floor in Shiodome Media tower and has beautiful view of fully illuminated Tokyo Tower on one side and Tokyo bay on the other. Rooms are good, clean and with everything required in room. I was on 32nd floor facing Tokyo Bay. Rooms are specious by Tokyo Standard. Family Mart on 2nd basement level (B2) is very good and convenient. Shimbashi rly station is 10 min walk and Ginza area about 20 min walk ( which is underground and very peaceful). There is direct train to Haneda Airport from the next station ( Daimon E 20) by Monorail which takes only 15 minutes to Airport. The Hotel has very good restaurant and bar on 25th floor. Hotel staff is very helpful and courteous. Wifi and internet is good and free. There is shuttle bus from hotel to Narita Airport which costs about Japanese yen 3000. Next time, I will prefer to stay at the same hotel.

This is a nice hotel in a good location. I was in Tokyo for business for two weeks. Everything is very modern. Although the room is a little small, it is still a very pleasant room with a nice bathroom. All of the staff spoke English very well and the lobby is very nice. This is also a short walk to ginza and right by many major trains.

Room size is pretty standard for Tokyo, the staff are extremely attentive and pleasant. Rooms very clean, loevly atrium, lovely view and close to Ginza for shopping which is useful. Air conditioning could be stronger in the atrium, but it's such a large space this might be the problem.

Stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 4 nights. The room was compact, but reasonable size for Tokyo. Despite being a reasonably new hotel, the room had a lot of scruff marks on the carpets and walls - making it feel a bit cheap. The views were ok - particularly at night - although the window does not open. Ask for a room the faces the Tokyo Tower when booking.The hotel is near lots of public transport, although the immediate area lacks the vibrancy of other areas in Tokyo. Smoking is permitted in parts of the Lobby, which can impact on the various food and drink options available. The bar lacked life and the drinks were expensive - the nearby Conrad Hotel bar, while also expensive, has a much better vibe.The bed, bathroom and internet access (free) were all fine.The staff were polite and attentive - with the tour desk going an extra step to help us with booking tickets for the Baseball. Important to note that there is a small laundry for guests - this is not mentioned on a lot of the booking sites. Hotel is near the Fish Markets for those making the early morning trip. Being close to the JR circle line means it is handy to most of the main sites and attractions.

I stayed here with my partner for 4 nights and it was a delight. We had the non-smoking room with the view of the tokyo tower - it is beautiful at night!! The bathroom was very clean and the bed was vrey comfortable to sleep in. There isn't much space to store your luggage but the ambience and the view over Shimbashi station was quite nice especially at night. It is close to the JR Shimbashi station although its abit tricky to find if you walk through the underway passage. There's a family mart super market which is really good if you need snacks late at night. Its a close walk to Ginza and the fish market as well. The staff do speak English well and their customer service is great. I stayed at Shinagawa Prince Hotel (main tower) on my last night in Tokyo and think that Park Hotel Toyko was MUCH MUCH BETTER!!

Don't be fooled by the upscale modern lobby, if you stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo, you are undergoing a true test of endurance. The first time I walked into my room I was hit by a wave of cigarette smoke which caused me to cough as the trip continued. Upon informing the front desk, they said they would clean the room, though when I returned the smell had not improved. After bringing it to their attention again, I was moved to a second room where the same smell, albeit weaker, was still present. This however is NOTHING compared to the lack of air conditioning here. Turned to the lowest temperature on full blast, the a/c is barely a trickle and the room soon heats up to unbearable temperatures. You are in a skyscraper so the windows cannot open, and so you are essentially in a sauna for the duration of the trip. This was an issue in both rooms, and after speaking to the manager, he informed me the room could not be made any cooler. My traveling companion and I literally draped wet towels over ourselves to sleep, as the room sweltered and stunk. It was the bare minimum of what I would accept from a hotel experience and needless to say I will never stay here again.

The Park Hotel is in a great location near several large subway stations. Hotel seems to cater to a lot of business types, but has its share of tourists as well. So, don't expect a gift shop or Micky D's in the lobby area. Only high end restaurant and bar lounge. Very contemporary decor and ambiance. Rooms are a little on the small size by US standards, but bigger than most Japanese style hotel rooms.Its a 10 minute walk to many of the shops and restaurants in Ginza. Its also a 10 minute walk to the big fish market that offers some of the best sushi in Tokyo. If you're looking for a clean, modern hotel that offers excellent service and a place to relax in quite after a day, then this is the hotel for you. If you're looking for a younger party scene, then maybe look for hotels in Shinjuku of Rippongi.

I stayed here for one night. My room, and my traveling companion's room, stunk of old cigarette smoke even though they were non-smoking rooms. I paid the same for this hotel as the Hilton Tokyo the prior week and I thought the Hilton Tokyo was a far better experience. The Hilton's room was twice the size and didn't smell like smoke. I won't stay here again.

We stayed at the Park Hotel at the beginning and the end of our trip in Japan, and in both occasions we were very satisfied.The service is really good, the position of the hotel is ideal, the views fantastic.The Michelin starred restaurant in the hotel is also well worth a visit.In terms of value for money, it might well be one of the best in town.

The staff was exceptionally friendly and attentive. The hotel was spotless.Other than the rooms being a little on the small side, they were spotless, well equipped and more than adequate for my needs. The location was superb.Minutes from the shimbashi metro station.I would absolutely stay here again.

The airport limousine bus goes direct from the airport to the hotel (note that the next stop is The Park Hotel as well- but get off at the first one !) for £25. You check in on the 25th floor- and if you join the loyalty programme at once you can benefit from a half bottle of Lanson champagne ( as advised on this site by previous visitors-thank you !). The staff are extremely helpful, polite and friendly.Supermarkets for ALL needs are located 5 minutes from the hotel (Lawsons, 711, Family Mart).if you go walking out of the hotel make sure you have the hotel name written down in Japanese so that in the case of getting lost you can get into a taxi and he can take you back to the hotel. It is extremely easy to get lost when you are walking in the area of the hotel- even with a map.The room was quite comfortable with a small bath- but after all it is a small country! Tea-making facilities are in the room and there is also a washing machine on one floor.We tried the Japanese dinner which they put on for residents at a special price- it was interesting, but not sure we would do it again or advise it !! Good free computer facilities.

I was fortunate enough to have stayed at this fabulous hotel recently.... it was convenient in terms of subways, clients, shopping, sight-seeing. Staff first class, ambient atmosphere, room very comfortable, although it took me a few goes to work out the loo which was totally hilarious. (It's been a few years since this writer has visited Old Edo, and had forgotten such vagaries). Sans dout, will definitely stay here again, and look forward to call this hotel my Tokyo home.Lisa Jane Gordon-SimonsDip. Law (S.A.B.)Company DirectorSydney, Australia

This is an awesome hotel, with a view of Mount Fuji ( I had to pay a bit extra for the view). High tech toilet seat with built in water jet. The hotel will organize luggage transfer to other cities ( it is done by dimensions, around $40 for a large suitcase). From Narita, take the airport bus directly, or to T-CAT and a taxi to the hotel. There are a lot of restaurants near the train station. The high rise restaurants.at the Sky Tower are expensive, though they come with a great view of Tokyo city. Ginza is a ten minute walk, and some young and friendly young Japanese guided us there. The restaurants in Ginza seem to close a bit earlier, though.We also used Tokyo Free Guides, and we're very pleased by our guides. One can find them on the Web or Facebook.

The hotel location is great, however I was overall very disappointed and poor. First, it is not maintained and it looks really "dusty" and old. The lobby is with old furniture and it looks old fashion. The rooms are tiny, which is OK for Tokyo, but they need renovation. The carpet is stained and the walls in bad shape. Same, the bathroom looks like it was 15 years old. I arrived to the hotel at 10am and they said their policy is not allow check in before 2PM. I had to negotiate for an earlier check in and got 12pm. The first room they gave me was facing a railway and trains were passing every other minute, with lots of noise. The were kind to change my room instantly (and not surprised at all, they should be used to this) however one should note that half of the rooms are extremely noisy because of this.The hotel website mentions that they have a gym. They charge 500Yen for gym access and the gym is a 10m2 room with very limited, poor and old equipment, that you need to book 45mn in advance. Finally, food in the Lobby is way over priced.I was expecting much better based on the reviews I read.Will definitely not stay there next time I am in Tokyo.

Friendly staff, good location near several transportation options (Oeno line and Yamanote right under the hotel, Shimbashi station with 2 other subway lines and the JR lines 5 minute walk away, one subway stop away from Monorail to Haneda airport). Walking distance (1km) to Tsukiji Market for travelers who are up at 5 am with jet lag. Within a 20 minute walk to Ginza.The views are breathtaking. Rooms are smallish by US standards (think mid range New York City size), but seems to be standard for Tokyo. Staff very helpful and friendly. One of our phones got wrapped up in the sheets, and the staff were able to recover it largely unscathed.WiFi is available in room. Breakfast buffet was tasty with Western and Japanese options (cost about 2200 yenper person).We were here as tourists and enjoyed our stay. Would stay again. The price upgrade to a room with a view of the Tokyo tower is worth it, but the view from the other side ain't shabby either.

The reception for the Hotel is on the 25th floor so do not expect a grand entrance or anyone to help with luggage when you arrive. The room was spacious with an amazing view of the city. It also had tea and coffee facilities in the room. The hotel is well located and the fish market is within walking distance. The food was very good and would recommend staying here if in Tokyo

This hotel was a good find, reasonably priced. Pretty cool that the hotel starts from the 25th floor and the hotel rooms are even higher! The room was neat and beautifully fitted, we felt at home. Lovely large windows to enjoy the city view, beautiful at night. Heated toilet seat was a new experience to us.I thought the location was good, it is walking distance from two stations - Shiodome and Shimbashi. Very easy to get everywhere, we never took a taxi. There are walkways connecting them all up so no need to cross the traffic streets. The Shiodome area is a business district so it can be quiet at night For us it was a nice change from the busy Tokyo streets. Felt very safe in the area.Buffet breakfast was included and it was amazing, western and Japanese both provided. I tried the japanese a few days, loved it!We walked to the Fish markets one morning, worth going to! There is a 24 family mart downstairs which was very convenient. If i do come back to Tokyo i would stay at this hotel again.

Among many hotels at the same level I've stayed, I am sorry to say that I was quite disappointed... at the front desk staff not smiling (polite, but depressing), and at what I felt with my foot when I enter the room... someone's finger nail. OK, I threw it in the bin. ( I was too tired to complain and just wanted to relax). Then I went to the bathroom to take a shower, where I found two pieces of brown hair sticking to the bathtub wall, which is absolutely not mine. Furthermore, I found a fairly amount of dust under the sink, which is clearly seen from the bathtub. Other places were OK...I'm glad at least bed was perfectly clean. I was just unlucky, perhaps...but I really want to say, 'Please clean the room'.

This hotel is great, located next to the Shiodome train station and an office building with several restaurants. The hotel is modern, clean, and comfortable. If you want a quiet place away from the busy areas, I would stay here. The customer service was also superb. However I had previously stayed at a hotel near the Ginza strip and that was much more convenient due to the restaurants being open for later hours and being surrounded by stores.

Smack bang in between Shimbashi and Shidome. Getting up to the hotel lobby was a ride in itself as it was on the 25th floor and had a see-through glass elevator door. It knocked the wind out of me the first time I travelled up it and felt a hint of vertigo with that falling feeling when you’re just about to wake up from a dream. We were lucky enough to get a corner room on the 32nd floor and the views were spectacular! So much so that I needed to take a picture to remember it on our last day there. I was inspired by a shot taken by my dad about 20 years ago when when he took a similar night and day shot in China.Have a look at the view from our Room at the Park Hotel Tokyo: http://youtu.be/Jh4nRkXiWfY

My first visit to Japan, spent 3 nights here. Location is great, metro, JR lines all within 2-3 minutes walk. Walk way is all connected between the hotel and the train stations. Ginza is a mere 5 mins walk away. Rooms is small but functional. Lobby is on 25th floor, very helpful staff and good english. Overall, great stay here.

In the middle of business district, close to beautiful garden along the water front and the famous Fish market. For restaurants, shopping and night life not so convenient. Small rooms with little character. Pricey for comfort level.

My first experience of a Japanese hotel! On first appearances the PH was a rather typical, high rise, city centre hotel. Not distinctly Japanese in any way but the hotel lived up to be a superb base from which to explore Tokyo.The main lobby and lounge were restful and quiet. My interaction with staff was relatively limited but no complaints or communication problems. The Japanese breakfast buffer was fascinating and whilst there I developed a taste for rice and fish in the mornings!As expected rooms were small but well designed and appointed. The big plus for me were the wonderful views across the Tokyo skyline - even more dramatic at night.As jet lag left me a very early riser, the hotel is walking distance to the fish market and its array of food stalls. Definitely worth a visit at 6am!

Stayed again at this property. As with the last two stays, we love the location. Staff is great. Great value for rooms and decent quality (not super fancy but good enough). If you book well in advance, I often find the best rates. Sign up for the loyalty program also on arrival. We did and for doing so, with our 4 night stay, had a nice half bottle of champange sent up to our room for free. Just for signing up.I find the subway station that is closest to the hotel allows you to get to many places much easier than going to Shimbashi station and is not too busy. Top notch restaurant in the hotel. Also, a short walk to places to eat - Hibiki (high end izakaya - be sure to google for your free beer coupon) and Yakuniku both at the 46L in the caretta...and also close to tsukiji...this time we went Sushisen (the one across from the places with all the lines)...I could have had the Conrad for 100 bucks more a night and to be honest, I do not think it is worth it. This place is great and location is just as good as the Conrad...well, you look down on the Conrad almost...

Great hotel and great value in a great neighborhood.We stayed in a standard room which was comfortable and spacious. The TV had 4 English speaking channels and the bed was quite comfortable.The staff was very friendly and helpful (special mention to Chris), speaking good English and offering good advice on what to do and where to go.The area is also nice. 10 minutes walk from Shinbashi and Shiodome stations for JR trains and subway. 15 minutes away from Ginza and many restaurants and shops.We would definately stay here again.

My partner and I decided to celebrate our 30th anniversary in Japan and we couldn't have picked a better starting point for our asian adventure.The Room: Brilliant! It was small-ish - but thats normal for Japan. It was beautifully done. Very clean and contemporary. Sleek and modern. We had a gorgeous view of the city and Tokyo Tower. We even saw Mt. Fuji one afternoon when the clouds broke!The Location: Perfect! It was a very easy walk from the Shimbashi train station. There were restaurants nearby and lots of shopping opportunities in the nearby Ginza District.Amenities: We really enjoyed the breakfast buffet even though it was a bit pricey. Every single person we encountered there was willing to bend over backwards to help us with whatever we needed. Seriously. We were treated like royalty from the moment we walked in to the moment we rolled our suitcases to the elevator. The concierge went above and beyond to help us plan the best route to whatever we had planned that day. I have nothing but praise for the staff there. They were wonderful.Note: They are very Gay Friendly. They were featured in an episode of "Bump", a gay travel show on the Logo Network....so there was no awkward moment when two men were checking into one room with one bed (like we have encountered on other trips). I will never stay anywhere else when I am in Tokyo. This is home.

Have just returned from Japan and spent 5 nights in the Park Hotel. We would recommend this hotel, loved the location (above the Shiodome station, with subway access to Shimbashi station and the JR lines), easy walking to the Fish Market, Hamarikyu Gardens and Ginza. Our room was on the 33rd floor with fantastic views (especially at night), the staff were so helpful, room was quite large (by Japanese standards) with a fridge (which is not so common in Japanese hotels), if I want to be picky there was no separate shower (had to stand in the bath) but not a problem, the complimentary toiletries were good quality. Tariffs not the cheapest, but worth paying, would have loved to have had breakfast included, it cost about $35 each so we didn't have it, but it looked really nice and the dining area fantastic. The hotel is surrounded by so many cafes, restaurants, takeaways and really good Family Mart is accessible from the Hotel building and open 24 hours and sells most things

We spent one night in Park Hotel before flying back to Europe. The hotel is located right next to Shiodome metro and skyline station (literally in front of the door) and within walking distance to Shinbashi train station, and the lively Ginza area. The reception is on floor 26 of the building, with rooms in higher floors up to 35 (we think). The view out of the rooms is excellent. We had view on Tokyo bay, but you may also have view on Tokyo Tower depending on which side of the building you are. Check-in formalities were very friendly and warm. The agent was speaking excellent English (he was European), our baggage was taken care of and the room was properly introduced. The atrium in the center of the building goes up to the glass ceiling of the roof which makes the lobby extremely spacey. From each of the guest room levels you can look down in the atrium. Breakfast is being served in the lounge in the atrium. There is also an attended bar (it was not open though when we wanted to visit, at past midnight). The atrium is filled with artwork, from probably changing artists as it had brochures about the respective artist.Our room was on the 32nd floor and was average size (maybe even big for Tokyo standards), very nice bathroom with a lot of luxury amenities, a large TV with quite a lot of channels, some among them in English, a wide variety in the minibar with pretty reasonable prices. In the whole hotel they offer you a speedy wifi free of charge. Breakfast was not included and would have been around 1900 Yen. We didn't make use of it though.The "Friendly Airport Limousine Bus" stops right in front of the hotel (about 90minutes to Narita) and has to be reserved with the concierge. Our concierge was speaking average English but was not very helpful with our inquiries. Overall, the hotel is very nice and compared to other hotels its not too pricey for what it offers. We would certainly recommend this hotel and would be staying here again.

The hotel offers the perfect location and views over the most buzzing part of Tokyo. It was our first visit to Japan (and our honeymoon) and the Park Hotel had that special edge. The location near Ginza and in a very modern area of Tokyo was great, it was also very close to the Shimbashi station so easy to get to other parts of the city. The views were the most spectacular - we stayed on the 33rd floor and could see Mt Fuji on our first day, but make the most of the view as you can only see it on a very clear day! Staff were also very helpful with directions. We felt the prices of food (especially breakfast - however probably in line with other Japanese hotels) was quite high but there are plenty of more reasonably priced cafes in the locality.

We picked this area of Tokyo for the last two days of our trip so that our aunts could shop at Ginza and my cousin and the kids and I were relatively close to tokyo disneyland and disney sea. This hotel was amazing. The picture windows allowed for spectacular views of tokyo tower and on a clear day Mt Fuji.The breakfast buffet western and japanese was very good. The reception, bell and houskeeping staff were excellent and very helpful with directions. The beds were very comfortable and the views were amazing.

Hotel is in a convenient location, close to tsujiki fish market and Ginza shopping area. It is also close to a few subway lines. Great view of the tokyo tower too.Rooms are a little small but I guess it is a decent price by the city standard.

My family and I stayed at this hotel a few times during our recent travels throughout Japan (a total of 7 nights for 4 people). While the hotel was good and was in a great location for getting around, unfortunately it was lacking considerably in friendly customer service from their reception staff.I stayed at this hotel for work a while ago and enjoyed every aspect of this hotel - especially the great customer service - hence why I booked it again. This time around the reception staff weren’t friendly and I was made to feel that I was an inconvenience when asking a few simple requests (cancelling a restaurant reservation due to the Typhoon and storing of bags when we were checking back in). On our final departure from this hotel - we received no thanks for staying and no assistance with our baggage to the lifts - instead they simply processed the bill and that was it. Also on asking a question about Disneyland and if it would be busy on the day we were thinking about going - we were told it would be quiet and not busy - to arrive there and find waiting times for rides were 4 hours due to it being school holidays!!!!We experienced great customer service everywhere else on our travels - so it was a shame not to have been able to experience this at the Park Hotel Tokyo also. On a separate note - I can say that the restaurant staff were brilliant and were very friendly.

Our trip to Tokyo was about what we did and not where we stayed and so althought you can pay a lot and feet a lot we liked here a lot more we payed enought and got a lot:-) location is good , rooms are small ( does anyone excpect large n tokyo?) but very very well layer out and overall it was perfect for our purposes I would be happy to recommend to anyone new to Tokyo or not wanting to spend a fortune but stay in comfort Or to anyone who is adding the famous tokyo fish markets to their list as they are around the corner ( but go early - we went at 4.30 for 5.00 am to be told WAy to late for ate day and it was our last day :-(Oh and to note they were very accommodating and polite ( Japan ) re late checkout at 3pm with a nominal fee but certainly worth it !

We stayed 5 nights there with 2 small children. The whole place is great and friendly, they didn't seem To mind 5 and 3 year old running around.Rooms are good but small ( normal seize for Japan), with all you expect from a 4*.The lounge area is welcoming and the restaurant ( the french one) is divine!A few tips:- ask for a non smoking room as they don't take it for granted (we assume that coming with 2 kids makes it obvious), if it is your wish.- ask for the Tokyo Tower facing room. You may even see Mt Fuji on a clear day.- look at their promotions online, it is worth it, and spend what you saved on their excellent french restaurant one night.
This hotel is located near Ginza district an close to metro and train.Fish market within walking distance.They offer good price deals in 3 or more nights journeys.

Ginza, Tokyo Station, Tsujiki Fish Market and the metro all in walkable reach of this fantastic hotel. Views of Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji from the lobby and every room faces outward so there are great views in all directions. Only criticisms would be the breakfast was expensive (it is Tokyo though) and the hotel can be hard to find on foot, especially for the disoriented or jet lagged.

Park Hotel Tokyo is similar to its neighbor Royal Park Shiodome, to the point of being almost undistinguishable. What they have in common:- both are business hotels conveniently located next to Shiodome and Shimbashi stations; less expensive alternatives compared with the Conrad, also next door, the offering being consistent with the price. - rooms: tiny and functionally equipped; internal decoration, clean and modern but tending towards the cluttered, resulting in a slightly cramped feeling; good beds, showers, and sound isolation.- service: up to Japanese standards, i.e. attentive and meticulous. Small differences in favor of Park Hotel Tokyo: a slightly larger lobby and lounge area, better restaurants, and a more convenient road access, making it in my opinion a marginally better product. All-in, the quintessential business travel experience: one is happy to go about one's business, experience no hassle, leave the hotel and go bak home.

We have stayed in this hotel on two visits to Tokyo and will do so again shortly. The location is excellent - right at JR Shimashi and walking distance to Ginza. The rooms are quite small (remember, it's Tokyo) but are modern and very comfortable. The staff are terrific and helpful. As reception is on the 25th floors, all levels of rooms have great views across the city, including Mt Fuji on a clear day. Highly recommended.

Stayed at the Park hotel Shiodome in Feb for work. The hotel is situated on top of the train/subway station Shinbashi/Shiodome, and while that's supposed to be convenient and all, the complicated tunnels and walkways take some time to get used to. The hotel didn't have a gym at that time, but as I was checking out they mentioned they were working on a simple workout facility. Next to the hotel there are restaurants in the office buildings, and Ginza is about 10 minutes walk away. Shiodome is an interesting area filled with office buildings and bridges that take you across main roadways and connecting some of the newer buildings. My room at the hotel is quite basic, and not big by any means. The view was facing the opposite side of Tokyo Tower so I got an interestingly distorted reflection of the tower at night thanks to the Conrad Tokyo that's across the street. From Haneda airport, the hotel was only 15-20 mins away by taxi, and the airport limousine bus makes a stop right in front of the hotel. There is free wifi, and the toiletries are Thann from Thailand. Nothing much else to say - the bed was not particularly comfortable compared to those at the Hilton or Hyatt tokyo, but nothing to complain about. All in all, if you're travelling for business and your meetings are in Ginza or Shiodome, this is a good hotel to stay at. If you're looking for a base in tokyo so you can shop around shibuya, Shinjuku, etc, it is about 30-40 mins away - not exactly convenient. One good thing about the hotel, similar to the international chains, is that room temperature is not centrally set across the property, and you can adjust it to your liking UNLIKE some of the Prince hotels in japan.

I needed a place near Shinjuku and read frantically through the TripAdvisor reviews to find the right hotel. My friendly reviewers at TripAdvisor did not let me down. Staying at the Park Hotel enhanced my Tokyo experience. I got a corner room with an incredible view of the city. Even met the English guy that works at the hotel and told him he was famous on TripAdivisor. This area of Tokyo is very modern, clean, quiet, and comfortable. Only downside was the room smelled a little musty, but it did not bother me at all. Highly recommend this hotel for its convenience to the train stations. Took a day off and caught the 70-minute bullet train ride to the mountains for a great day of snowboarding.

Stayed here for 4 nights, and was spectacular view, as with the hotel starting on the 25th floor. We decided to pay a little bit extra to get the Tokyo tower view, and we were glad that we did. The view was spectacular, any time of the day. Staff were always helpful and willing to assist with anything you needed, even giving a good map showing where all the local international ATM's were located.Very easy to get to, and close to train station (we walked from JR Shimbashi station, and it was labeled on all the maps in the underpass/shopping complex).

Comfortable, safe, convenient hotel, good price for this, esp if you book in advance. Stayed here for Tokyo Marathon and right by train stations that will take to to/from race, the expo, or anywhere in the city. Walking distance (about 1 train stop) from fish market and adjacent to hotel are inexpensive restaurants and a few are good. The hotel staff pointed me to the good ones. No fitness center but coin laundry machines quite convenient.

Park hotel is a peaceful and to the point facility with the extra touch of a design hotel and a perfectly accomodating staff - friendly and attentive, super flexible and helpful. business and comfort wraped in a non formal atmosphere.

The hotel is very new and occupies levels 25-40 of the Shiodome Media Tower.Adjacent to the Shiodome subway station (exit 7).My room, a "corner room", was comfortable with modern bathroom, desk, large windows and city views.Free Internet (wired and wireless).Only 3 blocks (900m) walk to the Fish Markets.Only a little further to the Ginza area.Less than $15 taxi fare from Tokyo central station (which is probably the easiest way to get here if travelling with luggage).Highly recommended as a value option in Tokyo.
