Park hotel is one of the Tokyo hotels that worth paying the bit extra to get amazing views day and night. Remember to ask for a room with Tokyo tower view, as we did and becasue it was my birthday they also gave us a bottle of champagne sent to the room! Nice touch Park hotel.Me and my friend stayed in a standard twin for five nights during January, the room is small but has everything you need, even body lotion which we haven't seen in any other Japanese hotels we have stayed this time. The bath tub however aren't the nicest, small and out-dated, for what you paid for I guess we could expect a bit higer than that.We get free buffet breakfast included in our deal which we consider is good value. You sit at the lobby area with five-star view of Mt Fuji and breakfast is served with western and Japanese choices. I personally preferred the Japanese ones which I believe is of good quality, you get the standard steamed rice, seaweed and dry fish rice toppings, miso soup with dried tofu, smoked fish, various kinds of vegetable dishes, and Japanese half-cooked eggs. The western food provided on the other side are quite plain, but the coffee here is better than the average Japanese hotels. Service is always very attentive.

We visited the Park Hotel as part of our honeymoon stay in Japan, I was keen on staying in a place that had great views, the Hotel stakes up the top 25 or so floors of a modern skyscraper structure in the media/advertising area of Tokyo. It is very close (well literally on top of one Metro station) and is a few seconds walk from the elevated railway that goes to Odiaba, you can also access Shimbashi Station which is a 5 min walk through a series of walkways, some elevated, mostly underground that have shops and cafe's/restaurants. You are also a few mins walk from the Caretta Shiodome building which has a fairly extensive food court. The tube stations nearby provide close access to whichever direction you might be heading in to the centre of Tokyo.Worth noting also, the Hotel is 10 mins to Tsukiji Fish Market, we made the most of our jet lag and got up early to see the tuna auctions, a great experience.The Hotel itself is welcoming, staff very polite and helpful, the room was small (but average sized by Tokyo standards, I'm told) but was well designed, not claustrophobic and had amazing views over the harbour and Odiaba (from the 29th floor.) Service was very good, laundry was taken care of very efficiently, our luggage was couriered onto Kyoto by the staff with no problems or hassles. Everybody was polite and friendly.I had a strong, free wifi signal in my room, which was a pleasant surprise, I had assumed that the wifi was centred around the Reception area, but there was an alternative router entitled something like 'Park Hotel Games' which was great. Breakfasts were plentiful, both European and Japanese style, the European style breakfast was not quite like you would find in a European Hotel (the way the bacon, eggs and sausage were made up etc:) but that is to be expected I think and it tasted just fine to me.The main thing for me was the Hotel's location. For a first timer, Tokyo is a mildly confusing place and even though you don't walk out right in the middle of the action, it's right by Ginza, Odiaba and Tsukiji, having the Metro in such close proximity made travel around the city very easy and pleasurable.

I've stayed in a few different 'neighbourhoods' around Tokyo. The Park Hotel is a little more out of the way than is ideal for first time travelers, but don't dismiss it on those grounds, especially if you're a little more familiar with Tokyo (or are traveling on business).The hotel is nice and modern, with compact but attractive rooms featuring great views of Tokyo (especially at night! Wow!). There are English-language channels on the television, a couple of good restaurants, a laundry room with a couple of washer-dryers (which is a real boon! Don't get stuck in Tokyo without somewhere to wash your clothes, unless you want to pay the hotel $10 to clean your socks!)The staff are friendly and helpful, and very professional. English is no problem. I stayed for five nights and really enjoyed myself.**Another word on the location: Shiodome is a business area. To really get your bearings, you'll need to undertake a little trial and error with the various walkways and bridges. There are nearby restaurants beneath the office blocks, but the streets don't offer much to tourists and you'll need to walk to the train to access most Tokyo attractions. I love walking and Ginza and the Tsukiji Fish Markets are both within easy range (especially since everything's so flat in Tokyo) if you know which direction to head in. However, travelers with children should take note.**

We recently stayed a couple of nights at the Park Hotel. The room, although small, was comfortable and clean and had wonderful views of the Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji. The most impressive thing about this hotel was how the staff (in particular guest relations chief, Chris) went the extra mile to help arrange our booking and trip to a hot spring in Hakone. They took the time to make our reservations and write down all the necessary details for us. Thanks to this we had a lovely stay in Hakone too.

The Park Hotel is a very nice, well-managed hotel in the Shiodome area of Tokyo. Shiodome may very well be the hotel's greatest asset and it's greatest detraction. The disorienting layout of Shiodome physically isolates the hotel from the surrounding areas, which makes the area very quiet and peaceful, but also makes it slightly difficult to get to other areas of Tokyo. The Ginza and Shinbashi are quite close, but the layered walkways of Shiodome make it seem much further away. The rooms are small, but very comfortable and well-appointed. The views from all the rooms are just extraordinary. If you want to be in the middle of Tokyo's hustle and bustle, I wouldn't recommend the quiet and isolated Park Hotel, but if you want to a nighttime break from big city chaos, the Park Hotel certainly fits the bill.

For those seeking a low-key, comfortable boutique-like accommodation option, Park Hotel is the ideal choice. Booking the Premium Corner Room is highly recommended as I found the City Queen too small and claustrophobic; the higher room rate is worth it for the amazing views and extra breathing space! The staff were superb and very obliging. Try to fit in relaxing massage from Wako at the in-house day spa, it will do wonders after a long day of exploring the sights and sounds of Tokyo.

Tokyo doesn't have a great quality in hotels, so this is why compare to similar properties internationally this one is average, but for a Tokyo it is a good value for money.One of the best feature of the hotel is the view. Looking at Tokyo Tower is really nice. Rooms are small, but with a big window. Bathrooms are a plastic cubicle not really the most comfortable but its efficient and you have the famous Japanese Toilet ...Access to the hotel can be tricky through the subway and its galleries, but it is connected to the subway with covered pathway or underground gallery, which is really convenient.Room service menu looks like a 3stars vending machine menu, and after testing it the service is approximately the same. But a lot of small and good restaurants around.Also tried lobby lounge, nothing special, can be useful for meeting that's all. Overall people a re nice, room does the job, and location is quite good because close to major subway and easy access from everywhere.

Have stayed at the Park Hotel half a dozen separate times in late 2010 and early 2011 and can strongly recommend it.Standing in the way of 5 "blob" rating are: i) there is no gym or workout area ii) it would be nice to have some more Japanese dishes at the breakfast buffet iii) no so ideal to get to Tokyo Central other than by taxi.If you are feeling brave try out the raw chicken sashimi at the upscale yakatori across the road from the taxi rank on the lower ground floor (sort of cross the bollarded area and a bit to the left under the flyover, only about 30m away... I was taken their by my hosts and have lived to tell the tale.

The rooms are very small and not in perfect shape (some stains on the furniture), but the hotel offers good value for money (especially if you book in advance), nice views, and a convenient location near Shimbashi station and Tsukiji fish market. Free WiFi is available in the lobby (very beautiful), which is useful.

The perfect location for the first trip to Tokyo! The staff were friendly and went to great lengths to accommodate us. Upon arriving in the evening during the holiday season (December 2011), Chris with guest services provided us with helpful information on the area and suggestions for New Year's Eve. Staff was unbelievably helpful compared to what we experience in the U.S. From hailing down taxis to assisting me in obtaining over the counter medicine at the local pharmacy, we could not have been more pleased with the staff at Park Hotel. The Blue Forest Illumination at the Shiodome (short walk) was spectacular! We were able to enjoy the Hama-rikyu Gardens (short walk) on a beautiful day where we took gorgeous photographs. We were able to access numerous attractions that Tokyo has to offer by using our Rail Passes at the Shimbashi station just a short walk away.Tsukiji Market & Ginza area were also walking distance from hotel. We were fascinated with the busy Tsukiji Market and the food samples that we were able to taste, octopus....mmmm! The night skyline scene from the Tokyo tower observation deck is amazing and a must see. We celebrated NewYear's Eve in Shibuya where mobs of people gathered around to ring in the new year. We look forward to spending more time in Japan and would definitely stay at Park Hotel again.

As a reward for good exam results, my dad booked up my dream trip to Tokyo and this included the Park Hotel Tokyo. And the stay itself is an incredible experience. From riding the super fast elevator up 25 floors to the hotel lobby, looking up to the sky through the atrium, the breathtakingly dramatic skyline (including an illuminated Tokyo Tower) framing the reception desk, and the Grand Pianist playing in the evening. It was intoxicating. The rooms were large and decorated with a great deal of taste, possibly with European leanings. The staff were nothing but friendly. Neither of us having any real idea on where to go, we ended up just having a chat with the concierge about our interests and he booked us up on two fantastic trips; a day trip to Mount Fuji and the volcanic lake, as well as a smaller scale (but equally enchanting) guided foot tour to the Ghibli Museum in Mitaka. In a country that is famed for it's unfailing politeness, the staff at Park Hotel were no exception. The main criticism I'd offer is that there isn't a great deal in the immediate vicinity of the hotel. There is a small shopping centre which can be accessed by the sky walkways, and it's a short walk into Shimbashi or Ginza, neither of which I personally felt offered the quintessentially Japanese experiences that can be found in Shibuya, Shinjuku or Asakusa. However the hotel is directly connected to the Shiodome station and a few minutes walk to Shimbashi station, so accessing the rest of this amazing city is never a problem. This hotel and the trip associated with it will always remain with me as one of my fondest memories.

LOVED the location, though the hotel is part of a multi-building complex and so can be hard to find (don't forget to get a "here's where I'm staying" card in Japanese from the front desk to give taxi drivers). It's close to the Ginza and the metro, and the view from the 25th floor lobby is spectacular. The rooms are small, which is to be expected, but the finishing and the overall vibe could be a bit more slick, considering the price. There is poor wireless service, a skimpy mini-bar, and cheap finishes in the bathroom--great shower head almost makes up for the faux tile, plastic shower rod, wafer- thin shower curtain and tiny counter space (the fact that you need to leave the bathroom door open because the steam might set off the fire alarm is nuts!).Like most places in Tokyo, the service was EXCELLENT. All the staff were extremely kind and courteous, and eager to help. Of note, Chris (English gentleman) at guest services was fantastically helpful.In short, would absolutely consider staying here again. But the management *really* need to re-consider the room rate.

Like everywhere in Japan, The service is excellent. Location is convenient, walking distant to Tsukiji Market & Ginza. A short walk to Hama-rikyu Garden near by where you can take a waterbus ride to Tokyo Bay area and all the way to Asakusa passing through 14unique bridges.

This is now the second time we have stayed at The Park Hotel. It's in a very convenient location as both Shimbashi and Shiodome stations are very near by. The room may not be massive, but the rooms sizes in Japan are smaller in general anyway. The room is very well appointed with tea and coffee making facilities with a nice bathroom with a Toto toilet, what more could you want! We didn't have a tower view room, but even if you don't the views from the rooms are good, and you get a excellent view of The Tokyo Tower and if on a clear day of Mount Fuji from the panoramic window behind the reception area. There are limited T.V channels if you don't speak Japanese, but you don't go on holiday to watch Television. If you don't take breakfast at the hotel there is an Excelsior Coffee, Tully's Coffee and Starbucks all near to the hotel.

If you go to Tokyo you must stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo .... Only one word to describe to hotel, the staff and location PERFECTThe staff are so helpful only a 5 min walk to the nearest station which will get you anywhere in Tokyo. Just make sure you get your JR rail pass before you arrive as you cannot buy in Japan and this allows you travel on the majority of trains & buses around the country. Will definitely be staying here on my next visit.

Stayed December 2010, was arriving late in the evening after a daytime flight and emailed the day before to notify that I would be arriving late - and I received 2 emails to confirm this was fine, despite the fact it was Christmas Day. But that is the level of service provided at the Park Hotel Tokyo - they will help wherever they can.The room is small, with an even smaller bathroom, but if you get a Tokyo Tower view room the view is spectacular - you can spot Mount Fuji through the giant window and that makes your room feel a bit bigger! The bathroom is small but still had a combined bath and shower. I didn't have breakfast at the hotel but did have room service, which was very expensive and somewhat unusual in taste. There are also vending machines on each floor where you can buy beverages, and a convenience store downstairs.The location is excellent - you can get to either Shimbashi and Shiodome station very quickly, or walk up to Ginza - take in the lights and check out the department store.A lovely hotel and pleasant place to stay.

Everything was great...the staff...the hotel...the view from the room...and last but not least the price! Such a great value and breakfast was included in our rate! AND the in-room wifi was free! I will definitely be staying there when I return to Tokyo....

The perfect choice for our honeymoon in August 2010.Clean, cosy, friendly staff, fantastic view of the Tower, nice buffet breakfast.Everything was fantastic. The subway station is just at the basement, very easy to reach.The room was slightly smaller than we desired.Very close to Tsukji Market, which we reached on foot.
the location is perfect, the service is really efficient. Views are breathtaking...

My wife, young son and I stayed for 7 nights at the Park Hotel in Shidome. Our room on the 32nd floor looked out over Hamarikyu park. The room was clean, quiet, and everything worked. From our arrival through to our departure, the staff were friendly and helpful. We didn't take up the breakfast option, but there were plenty of places in nearby Shidome City Center to grab a bite to eat in the mornings. Getting around Tokyo was easy with multiple subway lines and the JR line at Shimbashi station.
Nothing much at all. Rooms are small. It's so basic i don't know why it is a design hotel.

We stayed in Tokio in October this year. This hotel is perfect for sightseeing tours in Tokyo. You have beautiful views from the rooms. We very lucky - looking right at Tokyo Tower. The rooms are fresh and well equipped. There was nothing missing. Breakfast was not included so we did not use their kitchen. There are many coffee shops close by. Bying breakfast extra is quite expensive.

I made the huge mistake of staying at Park Hotel Tokyo based on previous reviews, and I find it very difficult to imagine we stayed at the same hotel.Firstly, I have travelled to Tokyo on numerous occasions, so my review is based on what I have experienced at similarly priced hotels in Tokyo, and over 20 years working in the hotel industry. I would be ashamed to have anything to do with this property. Park Hotel Tokyo is at most a 3 star property by international standards, with no facilities (pool, gym etc). Service was just as basic, and who ever is in charge of their F&B dept needs to rethink their career choice. I have NEVER seen such a poor room service menu, even at limited service properties. To give you an example, my wife & I checked in at 11pm, and were very hungry after a long flight. Park Hotel's late night menu has only 4 items available, we had the worst spaghetti & pizza we have experience in a very long time, and when I asked for a bottle of wine, was told they couldn't do that, but when I went down to the lobby, I had to ask the restaurant for a bottle & glasses. If I can buy a bottle in the lobby, why can't Room Service do the same? On a subsequent night I tried to order a hot chocolate, but amazingly, even something as simnple as this was beyond them!!!!The rooms are very basic, yes, they are clean, but looking pretty worn with frayed carpets, and if this is a "business" hotel, why do they put a hard wooden chair at the desk. For some reason, the hotel management has chosen the most complicated TV remote control in the world, but if you are a non-japanese speaker, your options are very very limited.The one highlight in the rooms were the Thann toiletries, which are very nice.The lobby is a dead area compared to what they could do with it. Yes it has an atrium, but there is no sense of a relaxing communal area, no music, and I had to chase for service. Dressing your staff in formal wear doesn't constitute high quality, just a lack of imagination.In summary, there are a lot of much better hotels in the area, or close by with much higher quality for around the same price. I would NEVER willing return to Park Hotel Tokyo, and will be steering any friends & colleagues travelling to Tokyo to go elsewhere

We booked into this city centre hotel as the rates were really reasonable. We had previously stayed in the Conrad opposite in 2008 but the exchange rates were much better then. The hotel itself was very good and staff were friendly and helpful. We had a triple room with Tokyo Tower views and it was small by normal standards but completely adequate. The electronic toilet and shower were very good and toiletries were brilliant - they even supplied free razors which is a first for me. Coffee and tea was provided in the room and free internet was available, although wifi reception was disappointing in the rooms. However, I got good speeds using the ethernet line provided. Food and drinks in the hotel was very expensive as expected. We chose to have meals outside which was the right choice in this recession climate! There were plenty of noodle and teppanyakki restaurants surrounding the Shimbashi area, and also Subway, etc. The only downside was the lack of a pool.Overall, I would definitely come back to Tokyo and stay in this hotel again as it was perfect as a base to explore the city from. The Toyko Metro system has to be one of the cheapest and best underground systems in the world. We never struggled at all in getting around the city with two small boys in tow. International cash machine facilities were just next door and the exchange rate was actually better than in the UK!

Can't fault this hotel, it's super! Polite efficient staff and placed conveniently near to Shimbashi Station. I REALLY CANT believe the person who gave it two stars.Have stayed twice now , both for a week's duration. I will stay again.Rooms are smallish (This is Tokyo !) but perfectly formed.If you stay for three nights or longer you get a free SUICA card or a half bottle of (good) Champagne..
The room is very small, but has a big screen TV with few English channels. Can meet the basic requirements, but not fit for long business trips. The hotel with no gym will not be my choice next time.

I stayed here for a week recently. I traveled with my wife and two small children ages 5 and 8. I picked the Park Hotel because of its location and reputation. I was pleased with the room size. Not quite "US Sized" but a Premium Twin was just big enough, had a 32 inch Panasonic with a HDMI input that allowed me to tranquilize the kids with dozens of .mkv movie files. The internet connection (I brought my own LAN to WAN adapter but they will loan you one) was good enough to allow me to make voip phone calls, stream some movies from my Sling Box and download a free game from Steam (Yes, we left the room occasionally).The location is, to my mind perfect. Not as much hustle and bustle and after 1830 hrs, quiet. If you want the silliness, it's a 500 meter walk to Shimbashi JR station and Square and the Ginza is just beyond. Literately attached to the building (Level 3) is the Yurikamome Shiodome Station (You're in Shiodome, dummy) which can take you pilotlessly to Odaiba for some shopping, museums and plenty of room for two kids to run around. In the basement is the Family Mart convenience store (where you will be eating if you try traveling with two bottomless pits) and the subway station. Both the Anpanman and Pokemon stores are within walking distance to further wear out the young 'uns.The much discussed vie de France is located in the Shiodome City Center building (Level three, across the bridge, turn left, down 2 escalators, straight ahead through a pair of really cool rotating doors, viola! You in France!)We understand that there are many luxury amenities that are available to you here at the Park. I'm sure they are quite nice. However, we chose to hustle ourselves through the lobby with a minimum of fanfare and disturbance. There's a bunch of Tokyo out there to be seen. No matter where they stuff you, the view from your room will make your trip worth it.As soon as I find another choice airline miles Credit Card deal, I'll be back.

We stayed 3 nights in the Park Hotel Tokyo last month. It was my 2nd stay. First time for my husband.He was a little apprehensive at first due to cigarette odor and the small size of the room. But, we adjusted to the environment quickly, and we started to appreciate the more positive qualities like the stunning view from our room, the easy access to the subway and a convenience store in the same building. Actually, it was very easy to visit Roppongi and Tsukiji Market using Oedo Line. (The station Located basement level of the hotel. So, you don't have to go outside.) We had a chance to experience Tsukiji Market, Ginza, Roppongi Hills and Tokyo Midtown all in one day and still had time to enjoy a great dinner and drinks in Marunouchi after a long nap.We visited the Conrad Hotel next door with our friends and we had a terrific time. In the lounge, they had a live Brazilian band who played Bossa Nova. Obrigada! The room our friends stayed in was much bigger (Premium Twin?) however, they paid a lesser room rate. But, our room had a better view and was closer to the elevator. Over all, our experience at this hotel was great. The hotel staff were extremely polite.We thought, however, the hotel needed some updating. Compared to my last stay (2 years ago), the hotel looked a bit tired...

On my first trip to Japan, I felt very comfortable at Park Hotel. The staff members are very kind and generous people. The rooms are nice, quiet and private. I had a wonderful view to wake up to everyday. The hotel is easy access to the subways and is connected to skyways that make walking in the area convenient.I was on an individual trip to explore Tokyo and I hoped to experience the day to day life beyond the normal tourist attractions. I also wanted to socialize and get involved with Japanese people. My deepest gratitude goes out to Chris Parish who made my trip more memorable than I anticipated. My stay in Tokyo wouldn't have been the same without his advising and assistance. I enjoyed the food and the areas he suggested for me to visit. Chris, thank you so much for all of your help! This was the best summer and birthday I've ever had. I can't wait for my next visit to Japan as Park Hotel will be the only place I stay.

I stay here more than a week and it was very cool experience, hotel/room was dead silent and I received a great room in last floor. in off seasons, for sure you'll get better price.well, it's not cutting edge design hotel but quite simple and comfortable. the personal are very helpful and very kind.location was good, but depends what you are looking for, it's easy to reach main attractions by metro however tokyo metro is so large and you must always walk couple of 100 meters (even for line changing). there is 3 different metro line that's is reachable from the hotel easily and one monorail system. you can also use friendly limousine service from the airport for this hotel.there is 24 hours open market downstairs also (well it's quite usual for tokyo as i see). also around this area there are many business centers and so the restaurants. you can also try to walk shinbashi station, to see locals' life and taste karaoke. inside the hotel: there is michelin starred french restaurant and japanese restaurant. for both: especially fr the french restaurant you really should book in advance.

Me and my husband have stayed at the Park 3 times now - its our first choice for hotels in Tokyo. The rooms are comfortable, quiet with stunning views. its within very easy access of trains, a short walk to ginza, and the abundance of office blocks around the area means there are plenty of fab restaurants to eat at, at excellent value for money. The lobby was stunning, and the whole hotel had a very chilled atmosphere - perfect for when you need a break from downtown tokyo. The staff were friendly and efficient, and quite simply this hotel was fantastic.
We had a stop over here on the way back from Australia visiting our daughter - a great few days in a very nice hotel with excellent service in every department

Even though Shiodome may not be the most exciting part of Tokyo, it has good communications and is close to e.g. Ginza.The hotel itself is highly recommended. Room size is OK and has everything you need. Views over Tokyo are fantastic as rooms are situated on floor 26 and up. But the best part is the service, all staff really made me feel welcome and helped out with whatever was needed.Normal prizes seem fairly high, but we had a deal with breakfast and free minibar for 15000/night. A bargain for what you get!

We stayed here the first time in 2008 and enjoyed it so much that there was no question about a return visit in 2010. I booked the 5 night special online, so got the room for a very good price. This time we chose a corner twin room - they are more spacious. So if you can afford it, this is a good option. We got a view of Tokyo Tower, which was brilliant. One clear evening we watched the sun set over Mt Fuji and the city lights slowly come on - magic!The hotel is located in a business area, but is a very short walk from Shimbashi and Ginza. So there is no shortage of good places to eat, be it cheap and cheerful or wonderfully indulgent and expensive. And there are plenty of coffee shops for breakfast thanks to the businesses in the area. The hotel does serve breakfast, but like all hotels of this calibre, it appears to be extremely generous and thus not cheap. As we don't eat much for breakfast, so couldn't justify the expense, so can't really comment on its quality.It is an easy walk to Tsukiji Fish Markets (where you can get a fabulous breakfast or in our case, brunch), and then stroll to Hamarikyu park, where you can jump on a boat for a trip up the Sumida River to Asakusa.By using the underground access from the hotel you can walk to either Shimbashi Station (which is on the Yamanote line,) or to the subway. There's also a convenience store in the basement, very handy for those little things you need. Go above ground and you can get on the driverless train to Odaiba.It is not a busy area at night, like Shinjuku or Shibuya, so if that's what you're after, don't bother staying here. We actually like the fact that the streets are quiet at night, just to get a break from the mayhem of Tokyo during the day. In any case, there is very easy access to any of these places by a short rail ride. The room was very comfortable and clean, with a great contemporary design. What is even better is the foyer with its massive atrium that runs right to the top of the building. (Do note that the hotel only starts from level 25 - below that are offices) It's also great in the evening when there's live music playing in the foyer, as there was during our visit.The bathroom is well stocked with goodies. In fact I love the products and actually sought them out when we returned to Australia the last time. The only downside was some instruction about not boiling the kettle while the bathroom was in use, or something to that effect. It didn't bother us, but unusual to say the least.We didn't know there was a wireless facility when we were there, but then again, maybe it wasn't there at the time. We didn't think to ask as cable still seems to be the norm across most of Japan. As long as we can send a couple of quick emails and check news at home we really don't want to waste a lot of time on the computer, we'd much rather be experiencing the city, or country, whatever the case may be.The staff were fantastic. Always friendly and helpful. As an example, they certainly gave us the best advice on getting to the airport. We would have struggled with 2 big suitcases on a train, not knowing that a limousine bus stops right out the front. It was cheap, easy and very comfortable.I always plan to stay in the best hotel we can afford before flying out of Japan so we get a good sleep before an overnight plane trip home. The beds are extremely comfortable, and guarantee a good sleep. There's no doubt we'll be back when we're next in Tokyo,

I relied on TripAdvisor reviews to choose this hotel in Tokyo. Although it is convenient to the train station (Shiodome and Shinbashi stations), the hotel feels rather isolated within the city. The room is bare bones and definitely shows some wear and tear (frayed carpet, dingy towels, etc.). There is no wi-fi and spotty internet service at best, which is unacceptable in a technologically advanced country such as Japan. Breakfast buffet in lobby restaurant is rather overpriced and low quality. Although my room was on the next to top floor (33rd), I could hear the trains passing through the station below at all hours, not to mention my neighbors in the room next door...poor sound insulation in general. Overall, I was really disappointed and in many years of using TA, this is the first time ever that I've felt TripAdvisor reviews to be inaccurate and misleading. The staff is friendly and tries to make amends for any hotel inadequacies, but management should really consider making some improvements.

From the first second after arrival to the last second just before departure we got perfect service. The personnel is knowledgeable about tourist attractions, restaurants and Tokyo in general and extremely friendly and helpful!The hotel is placed in a business area but only a few minutes walk from the Hotel lobby you'll find three different train-/subway stops that can take you wherever you want.We stayed at the 28th floor (the lowest floor for the hotel is 25th) and the view over Tokyo was terrific, especially during night.

Wow, this was a fantastic find in Tokyo. 3 nights at this hotel concluded our vacation to Japan and we could not have been more pleased. Hotel is located on top of the Media Tower so all around its great views. We had an extra large room which was spacious and very comfortable. From the lobby you could see Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji (when its clear). The hotel is an ideal location with connecting access to the Shiodome station and the Shinbashi station. Since it is an office building connected by elevated walkways, there were 2 coffee shops and several eateries nearby. In addition the other Media Tower in the complex has several restaurants on the 41st and 42nd floor, so there is quite a bit around. Just a 10 min walk outstide the hotel and you are in Ginza. Shiodome is on the pink subway line with easy access to Roppongi and Shinjuku which was very nice. Shinbashi station let us easily access Ueno and Akasuka, so all in I could not imagine a better location. Concierge was super helpful in providing recommendation and directions. WIFI is free in lobby, but you need to request a free adapter service to utilize it in the room. The service from staff was also very helpful with luggage and securing a taxi back to the airport. Overall a fantastic stay in the great city of Tokyo. Would definitely stay here again!

me and my wife stayed at the park in june and were extremely impressed by the level of service we recieved. we used other hotels in tokyo at the end of our trip but none really came close to the friendly, helpfull environment that the staff provided at the park hotel. the staff member from england made things alot easier as well. he was the only foreigner working in a hotel we met on our travels and it was not only the language where he excelled but also with the suggestions he gave us. things we would never have found on our own. things which we will never forget. a mi esposa tambien le encanto el ingles porque sabia hablar espanol!! a big thank you chris!the area itself was nice as well with what seemed like hundreds of restaurants to choose from. we tried something different every night and also really enjoyed the jolly summer atmosphere when just walking around the ginza and shimbashi areas.we hope to return to tokyo at some point and we would only go to the park hotel if we did. excellente!!

We stayed at the Park Hotel in January for 1 week. This is the third time we have stayed here in the past 2 years and we love it. It's in great location, walking distance to Ginza. It's on top of a train station which can take you in any direction. The hotel is clean and modern. The staff are helpful and friendly. The rooms are a good size. If you can get the tokyo tower view rooms...its amazing to see it at night and first thing in the morning with mt fuji in the distance.

For me it ticks all the boxes. Convenient location for transport to/from the airport. Lovely clean comfortable modern furnishings, excellent value for money, fast free broadband, breathtaking views, efficient staff and a comfortable ambiance throughout. I'm about to book my next stay here and will continue to do so whenever I'm in Tokyo.

I stayed here for one night in July for business. The rooms are simple and stylish, and the views are breathtaking. I had Tokyo Tower view with a glimpse of Mt Fuji at sunset. Would definitely stay here again.

I stayed in Tokyo Park for 4 nights during my holidays in Japan last December. There is really nothing I can fault this hotel for. Service was impeccable, ambiance was great in all public places, the rooms well appointed, clean and good sized by Tokyo standards. What will stay in my mind for the rest of my life however, was the view to the city. We asked for a city view room and we could see the whole of Tokyo, the Tower, Ropongi, Shibuya, Shinjuku, the lot. With something around 170 euros a night, Tokyo Park was a real bargain you rarely find in Tokyo for a genuine upper 4 star hotel. From a practicalities point of view, the truth is it's a bit far from the main party lands like Shibuya, but it has great tube connections to everywhere (the station is right in the basement) and it is just a stone throw away from the fish market and Ginza. Shiodome itself is very impressive and there are some great small eateries in Shinbashi just over the railway bridge opposite the hotel. I cannot recommend this hotel more. It really is one of the things to remember from our trip to Japan. Isn't that what every traveler wants?

The staff at Park Hotel Tokyo was polite as expected , but they went beyond that. At the end of every day, we had drinks in the lounge. They came to know our order , asked us about our day and truly enjoyed interacting with us. The Waygu beef melted in my mouth and even when we visited the same hotel restaurant twice on our trip, they remembered our previous order and encouraged us to expand our horizons. A short walk to the Ginza and right on top of the Shimbasi station. A special shout out to Ishida Kenji and Nanmoku Kouji . You made our trip great!Thanks Kathy and Corey
Good location, very easy to reach.Hotel room is small, but cosy.Free internet.
Very modern hotel with great views – Rooms are small but well designed – Nice lobby / breakfast area – Good Bar – Convenient Location

Stayed here for 8 nights in May. Service impeccable - friendly, considerate, attention, and by the second day they were using my name when I returned to the hotel from meetings.Stunning lobby, with view over tokyo tower, the rooms have a simple elegance. I stayed in a Premium King - which was a good size, quiet, and had nice views towards Hamariku gardens. Great bed - good night's sleepThe only let down could be the breakfast - not in choice of items, or in price (usual Tokyo hotel price - high) but the quality of the items could have been a lot better.Location great for getting to the business districts of East Tokyo (Otemachi, Marunouchi) - or for tourists who will have great access to the Imperial Palace, Ginza and direct access to the subway. However, If you have a lot of business meetings in Shinjuku or Shibuya you may want to consider a hotel on that side of town.My trip before this one I stayed at the luxiourious Conrad across the way - in future I'll stay at the Park for the personalised service.

The location and price of this hotel were both fantastic, but what would make me recommend this hotel to others is the impeccable service we received.We arrived at night and after a quick bite to eat went to sleep. I woke up to what I will refer to as a "medical emergency". I called the front desk and asked where the nearest hospital was. They told me it was 5 minutes away by car. I said thank you and proceeded getting dressed. Almost immediately, the phone rang again and the lady at the front desk told me that although the nearest hotel was indeed 5 minutes away, it would be a better idea to visit Tokyo Clinic, since they were more experienced in dealing with expats. The lady on the other end of the telephone proceeded to inform me that if I could get ready immediately, she could secure an appointment for me in 20 minutes. If not, the next opening was later that morning (she had already checked). I said thank you and started to get dressed, in order to make the earlier time slot, until there was a knock on our door.The shift manager was at our door, asking if I was alright. Please keep in mind that my initial enquiry was less than five minutes prior, merely asking for the nearest hospital! He asked me to stop by the concierge desk as soon as I was ready.Upon my arrival in the lobby, I found a packet waiting for me. It contained the following: Directions in English / Japanese to Tokyo ClinicAn image of the clinic's exterior so I would recognize it upon arrivalA floor map of the offices within the clinic with an X on the office where I would be meeting my specialist.A confirmation of my appointmentPlease bear in mind that I did not ask for any of this. The staff went above and beyond what was expected of them. As they ushered me into a taxi that was waiting for me, I had a huge smile on my face thinking how lucky I was to be in Tokyo at this hotel!

Stayed here twice on a long tour of Japan (5 night stay upon arrival and 8 nights at the end). Staff were astonished; no tourists ever seem to want to spend a fortnight in Tokyo but we loved every minute of it and the Park Hotel was a major contributer to the experience. Not to be confused with neighbouring Royal Park, this ultra-modern property is located in Shiodome, a brash new development between Shimbashi and Ginza. The hotel occupies upper floors of a media tower block and the building is quintessentially Tokyo: high rise and futuristic. Shiodome station is right underneath, you can take an elevator from lobby to station. The lobby is a cool place to chill out, they have piano music, soft lighting, free internet and stunning panaoramas of the city. TY Bar is dark, atmospheric and redolent of 'Lost in Translation' bar where Bill Murray meets Scarlett Johansen. TY adjoins a Michelin starred restaurant (pricey). A giant atrium means each accomodation floor looks down upon the lobby through soundproofed glass. This ensures a great night sleep, didn't hear a pin drop during the small hours and staff are so unobtrusive. Room is compact but extremely comfortable and as clean as you'll ever see. Breakfast served in the lobby was adequate but overpriced. We bought yoghurts, fruit, muffins etc in the shop on the ground floor and stashed in our minibar fridge. There are some good eateries in adjoining building (follow signs) e.g. To The Herbs Italian style restaurant and a cool bar where salarymen choose from a variety of 75 beers. Roppongi is 3 metro stops away (loads of bars). You can also walk under the skytrain tracks towards Ginza and you'll find a plethora of Japanese diners etcOutstanding hotel

stayed here from March 8th (yes we were there during the earthquake!). It is a great hotel - with great views over Tokyo. The only drawback we had was on the night of the earthquake we had to walk to our 32nd floor bedroom - but the hotel put on a buffet supper free of charge which was very much appreciated. Highly recommend this hotel.
Good location for getting about Tokyo. Helpful staff. Would I return to this hotel - Yes

we had a small room but with a terrific view over the city. everything was very clean. easy walk to the fishmarket. the hotel's subway stop is on the airport line, so that was convenient. one of the restaurants in the hotel's building had 2 michelin stars. we had the tasting menu but weren't terribly impressed and would skip that next time. basically, we liked the hotel's location and the room's cleanliness. the beds are queen size but seemed fairly short, so tall travelers might find their feet dangling off.

Settled on Park Hotel Tokyo on a recent trip to Japan after a pretty extensive search. I was looking for something that worked within my budget, was conveniently located in the center, and offered a host of other amenities I desired in order to make my stay a little more comfortable. This was somewhat challenging a), because Tokyo—as most people know--isn't particularly inexpensive and, b), amenities that may come standard elsewhere one tends to pay a premium for here, so not surprising that my task was quite daunting. In the end, I was quite pleased I chose Park Hotel as this hotel turned out to be precisely what I was looking for. Park Hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower, in the Shiodome business district of Minato, in Tokyo. It is literally a stones throw from the Shimbashi subway station where you have access to the Ginza and Toei Asakusa subway lines and JR lines, and walking distance from the luxury emporiums that flank Chuo-dori Street in Ginza and world famed dept. store, Mitsukoshi (don’t miss it). The lobby is located on the 25th Fl of the Media Tower and guest rooms from the 26th Fl upwards. At these heights you can imagine what sorts of views await. The lobby with adjacent lounge, for instance, has sweeping views of the Tokyo skyline, with the Tokyo Tower in perfect view.Standard rooms are on the smaller side but I found mine to be quite adequate for a solo traveler. They come with flat panel TVs, standard complementary beverage service, and free hi-speed internet connection via ethernet cables. The bathroom's just as modest, space wise, but the bath/grooming set is actually pretty impressive. I couldn't resist stashing a few toiletries away just before leaving; they were that good. There are several restaurants and a café onsite, and the hotel features a daily breakfast buffet--though I didn’t particularly find this to be of value. I thought it was a little on the pricy side for the scant selection. At those rates, for just a little bit more, I would suggest checking Conrad next door where you can enjoy a much nicer selection and an equally impressive view at one of Gordon Ramsay’s restaurants. Transfers back to the airport can be easily arranged by the very accommodating front desk staff or the Concierge. Overall, lovely place to stay.

We had a very enjoyable stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo thanks in large part to lots of wonderful advise from Chris, one of the lobby staff. He gave us all the information we asked for and then on top of that gave lots more suggestions for any remaining free time. Very helpful indeed to find a natural English speaker who was always willing to answer any questions with a beaming smile. Search him out!The hotel is within walking distance of Ginza and Shimbashi where you can find anything you could possible want to eat from the very cheap to the ludicrusly expensive. Don't be affraid to explore as everyone we bumped into in the street was always willing to help when we looked lost.All in all a great experience and would love to go back.Say hello to Chris from us!!

We visited the Park Hotel Tokyo in mid-December. We arrived late in the evening after a long, delayed, grueling flight and were delighted to be greeted by bell hop Chris, a Brit who had recently started working at the hotel. My son speaks conversational Japanese, so it was not essential, but it was still nice to be greeted by a native English speaker. Chris provided us with our first set of local maps and subway info and gave us some tips on the places we were planning to go. English was never a problem at the hotel. The Japanese hotel staff at the reception counter and the concierges all spoke excellent English. And even the restaurant and bell stand staff spoke some. When our questions were beyond their ability, they quickly summoned a more fluent English speaker for help.The hotel is beautifully appointed and the rooms were comfortable and included Yukata and slippers for use in the room. The breakfast buffet which we paid to include with our room was extensive and provide plenty of Japanese and Western choices, loads of fresh hot coffee and juices, fresh fruit, etc. Many hot and cold choices which satisfied Mom, a dedicated sausage enthusiast, and son, a vegetarian. We filled up at breakfast and mostly were able to skip lunch, and just have a light snack during the day.Service at the hotel was excellent. We were there at a very quiet time, but there was a plethora of staff to whisk away plates at the breakfast area. The service was professional and gracious, but not cloying or overbearing.A bonus was a nice view of Mt. Fuji from the reception area of the hotel on clear days. The hotel is located in a high rise above an underground mall area with many restaurants and shops and convenient access to trains and subways. It is a short walk to Tsukiji Fish Market and Hamarikyu Gardens. The hotel is near a busy intersection of roads and has a series of somewhat complicated overpasses to negotiate. This stymied us a bit the first day but once we got oriented it was very convenient. We returned to Tokyo later in our trip and stayed at the famed Park Hyatt Tokyo in Shinjuku, but I actually liked the Park Hotel and it's location better. It was warmer, friendlier.

THE SITUATION: The spouse and I were off to Japan for the first time. We spent the first half of our stay in Tokyo, a weekend based in Nagoya (to venture out daily to Suzuka for the Formula 1 Japanese Grand Prix), and finally a week in Kyoto with daytrips across Western Honshu (Hiroshima/Miyajima, Himeji, Osaka).THE LOCATION: The Park Hotel Tokyo sits atop the Shiodome Media Tower, in the Tokyo media/advertising mini-city of Shiodome. The hotel is right next to the pricey shopping & dining of Ginza and the markets of Tsukiji. The hotel is part of a business center development connected to a sprawling transit station, with connections to Japan Rail (stop: Shimbashi), the metro (stop: Shiodome), and even the automated Yurikamome rail line to Odaiba. It is also conveniently located stops away from major JR hubs at Shinagawa and Tokyo station for connections to/from Narita Airport or to bullet trains traveling to Kyoto and beyond. In short, it's a good place to base your trip. There is a FamilyMart convenience store located on the basement floor of the building, just outside the lobby entrance; this was extremely useful for picking up cheap meals to-go, toiletries, and other daily items. Given that the hotel is in a business area, the foot traffic is controlled chaos during rush hour, and the immediate surroundings are sort of "dead" after 5pm. However, there many moderately priced food & drink options nearby in adjacent complexes like Caretta Shiodome; they are all accessible via the underground passageways. However, exiting the complex after business hours on the JR Shimbashi side is like a salaryman's playland: with tons of pachinko parlors, bars, cheap eats and bright lights, it affords the chance for an off-the-beaten path experience.THE LOBBY: The lobby on the 25th floor has definite "wow" factor, from the multi-storied atrium to the panoramic view of Tokyo Tower behind the front desk. The hotel hosts a series of live jazz in the lobby with no cover charge, which was nice to unwind to (with cocktail in hand) after a day of sight-seeing. The lobby is the only part of the hotel with free Wi-Fi internet service.THE ROOM(S): We actually checked out a couple of rooms during our stay (sorry, I've completely forgotten the room numbers!). The first room on arrival was a standard City Queen room on the 32nd floor, which had an impressive view of the rail station below... but also looked right across at the adjacent skyscraper. We elected to pay an extra US$20 a night to switch to a Corner Twin on the 34th floor with views of Tokyo Tower. The beds were mounted apart and couldn't be pushed together (as you might see in, say, a European hotel), but we loved the view too much to pay any mind. It is worth the extra cost to book a room with a Tokyo Tower view; be sure to specify this when booking. The rooms have a warm modern feel, although I would have liked better storage options: the closet is very small and the only dresser drawers are in the office desk. The Corner Twin was also considerably larger than the City Queen, both in the bedroom and bathroom spaces.THE FOOD & SERVICE: Front desk service was informative and always helpful; although I speak Japanese, my husband does not yet he was able to talk with the staff without problem. In addition to dealing with switching our room (handled without any hitches or bad attitudes), they took care of setting up advance reservations at a deluxe sushi restaurant via e-mail a few weeks prior to our arrival in Tokyo and answered our questions about watching the Tsukiji tuna auctions (the concierge offered to call a cab for us but we chose to walk--if you're particular about queuing up *real* early for the first batch of auctions at 4:30am, it's better to take the taxi, turns out). Cocktails at the lobby bar are expensive (average US$15), as is generally the case in Japan, it seemed. The hotel also offers complementary pillow fitting consultations, but the consultant was only available during the early afternoon when we were still out sight-seeing.Overall, the hotel was a good base for our first trip to Tokyo that I would recommend to my friends and family, provided they could stomach the high prices to match the great views (or score a deal).

The hotel sells itself as a 'design hotel', it leads me to question what is the standard that enables it to be a design hotel? The room is clean and functional and closely resembles a City Inn hotel i.e. it is more budget than designer. We booked and paid for a city view room and got a view of three skyscrapers, not ideal. The lobby and staff look sensational, much like the Soho hotel in London but staff aren't overly helpful they took our luggage from us and left it 5 feet away for us to collect again when we got the key. Overall clean and functional rooms, superb lobby great location but not necessarily worth the money - shop around!

I've stayed in many Tokyo hotels and now I think I will stick with this one. There are certainly nicer hotels in Tokyo, but for the money this is my favorite. It has a luxury feel but it's still not outrageously expensive. If you go much cheaper, you may feel like you're staying in a dump. This hotel is really nice. Location is so convenient to where you want to go (probably - Tokyo is huge so it's not going to be close to everything). Underground shopping and eating if the weather is bad.Be sure to get the Tokyo Tower view rooms - it's worth it. Views of Fuji if the weather is nice.Last night I was there, I heard the tv next room which bothers me, but it's the first I've had that there after staying there for a total of about three or four weeks over two years.

...I ended up in Tokyo last minute and went with the Park hotel. I really wanted to like this hotel but the service and food are subpar.I'll start at the beginning. The hotel is located on top of the Shiodome Media tower, the top ten floors. So check in is on the 25th floor.I arrived at about 7:15 at night and although there is a kiosk in the lobby of the Shiodome, nobody was there to meet or assist with bags. Someone did come down in the elevator when I called it, and escorted me to the front desk. Check in was fine, no escort to room or again no offer of assistance with bags.The room is nice but small. I expected small and do not fault them for it. As small as it is though, it's pretty well laid out and spotless. The tub is also small (not very long) by North American standards. But it was deep and that helped make up for it. The offered a lot of nice amenties - toothbrushes, toothpaste, razor, etc.The bed is extremely comfortable but not the pillows. The view was very nice but not spectacular. The hallways are cool - they wrap around and look down on the lounge in the lobby. I ate twice at the hotel. Once was in the evening for appetizers in the lounge. They do not advertise appetizers in the lounge, in fact when I asked they told me to go to one of their restaurants. When I pushed the point as they did not answer my question, they said yes they do offer appetizers/small mealsds. The guy running the lounge did not write down my order (he spoke perfect english though) and proceeded to forget half of it.Breakfast the next day was no better. They ignore you at the entry. Some of the wait staff even looked directly at me but offered no assistance. I finally seated and started to serve myself at the buffet when someone magically showed up and immediately gave me a bill (I hadn't even started eating yet..?!!). They did this to another lady as well. As for breakfast - food was pretty bland, eggs not hot, could have more variety. Keep in mind this hotel is not very well marked on the outside. If you stay here - make sure you take a good long look at the front of the hotel and the entranceway and memorize its features if you go for a walk. To add to the confusion, there's another PARK hotel right across the street, and I walked into it by mistake after walking around.One last thing. Because of its location, you will at some point probably want to eat here. Although there was a mini-bar, it was stocked with drinks only. I found them very reasonably prices- less than $5.00 for a beer. However, room service is incredibly expensive. A BLT is $30.00 plus a 10% service fee. The appetizers I mentioned in the lounge before were reasonable though, and breakfast was around 2500 yen - I think $28.00 but that included a buffet.Can't recommend this hotel. I wanted to like it but will stay elsewhere on my next trip.

Last night in Tokyo we decided to spend at higher level (floor ;-)). It wasn't cheap, comparing to Crowne Plaza in Osaka, but one night - the last one - why not? Nobody was at the ground floor, but we've read that front desk is located at 25th floor. Frankly talking I was disappointed - it was too expensive for small room, small bathroom, not so clean as we got used to in Japan, not so quiet (some reconstruction of the street was proceeded during our stay - during the night!!!) - only the view from 32nd floor was ok, but was it worth the money of almost 200 euro for one night without breakfast? There are better places in Tokyo...

The Park Hotel is a beautifully modern affair, right above the Shimbashi and Shiodome train stations. It's really a convenient location and the lobby starts right on the 25th floor (definitely not for those with a fear of heights, especially with a window to the outside in the elevator). I really don't have any gripes at all about the service (which was spot on and courteous...always...and I mean always....). The rooms were a tad smaller than I had expected and it was the first hotel I had ever stayed at that had oversized twin beds. The bathroom amenities were nicely presented and ran from shower cloths to emery boards. You have a choice of either international/continental breakfast or traditional Japanese, the latter of which I liked. For some reason, I always felt like something was missing from the international/continental but I can't put my finger on what. There was also live jazz music in the atrium in the evenings. The view was really pretty incredible, seeing as that the Tokyo Tower is practically right next door. All in all, it was a wonderful hotel and well-located, an elegant option for a stay in Tokyo. Definitely the type of place I would see business types staying at. Great for that quiet getaway because this is definitely low-key.

Was a little tricky to find as we arrived by train (Shinbashi station): went first to Royal Park Hotel by mistake... they are very near each other in a biggish complex of high-rise buildings and pedestrian routes on three levels (underground, street level and overpass walkways). Hotel room (Queen with Tokyo Tower view) was fairly spacious for a Tokyo hotel, perfectly clean and service was good. Free internet in rooms for people with laptops (ethernet cable), free wireless in the lobby. The selling point for us was the view from the room, though! You have to ask for 'Tokyo Tower view room' especially when you arrive at the hotel, and pay about JPY 1200 per night extra, but it's well worth it (see photos).There are no shops & restaurants in the close vicinity to the hotel, but it's about 10-15 minute walk to Ginza. There is a Family Mart convenience store, however, right by the entrance on the underground level (B2) should you wish to buy some nick-nacks on the way back to your hotel room in the evening.Got a half price deal with Expedia so price was good value for us - normal price a little high, I would say.

Just spent 4 nights at the Park Hotel. beautifully appointed property with fantastic amenities. It was in a fairly good location in as much as it was close to Ginza and the Tokyo subway. It could probably do with a little bit more signage at the JR station and the subway station to make it easier for those coming in by train as we did. It was a little over priced but it was wonderfully clean and modern and the free internet access from the business centre was appreciated

I've stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo 4-5x over the past 4 years. This is a great business hotel that feels luxurious and offers great service. The rooms are nice but small though this is typical for Tokyo. The bathroom amenities are very nice - great bamboo-scented shampoo and conditioner, and soap that has those little flecks inside so it's like using a loofa sponge! Can't forget to mention the well-appointed toilet that does more than my laptop - wish I could take the whole bathroom home with me! Sorry to write about the bathroom and then food, but the English style breakfast buffet is very good. The scrambled eggs in the buffet are too runny for my taste, but they always make me some to my liking. There are no pancakes but there are lots of patries. One time I stayed there I had a very minor emergency and needed to go to the hospital in the middle of the night to get anti-biotics The front desk staff found me a hospital that practiced American medicine. Then about a year later I returned to the hotel and the man at the front desk remembered me! Maybe they don't have too many Americans that need a hospital in the middle of the night. Another time I stayed there there were a bunch of people from Expedia staying there, so if that's where Expedia stays when they go to Tokyo then you can have confidence that it's a top-notch hotel. The hotel is within walking distance of good restaurants and attached to a mall and a convenience store. It's also withing walking distance to the Pokemon Center. If you have small kids and you go to Tokyo for business you HAVE to go to the Pokemon Center. You'll get lots of toys that you can't find in the US and you'll be a hero. One thing is that the whole ambience of the hotel is very quiet. So if you are traveling with kids, this is not the place I would stay - at least not with my kids! Plus it's probably more expensive than I would pay on vacation. Oh yeah, if you want to take a bus to the airport they can arrange it at the front desk.

I went for a conference for two years in a row. This year stayed at Park Hotel, and last year stayed across the street at Villa Fontaine. The Park Hotel is nicer looking and slightly bigger rooms, but the price is much higher. At the VF, breakfast was included but at Park Hotel it was 2500Y.

I spent 6 nights in Park Hotel (from Sep 20 to Sep 26) on a leisure trip. The hotel was the perfect choice for the trip. The hotel is located on a walking distance to the famous district of Ginza and is also very close to the fish market. There is a subway station below the hotel, which is very convenient to go to distant areas of the city. The hotel has a very huge lobby, with 2 restaurants. Staff is very friendly and helpful. Room is not very big, but that seems to happen to very hotel room in Tokyo (the lack of space is a real problem in the country). The bathroom has a lot of amenities from the hotel spa. Breakfast costs around 15 dollars and includes a wide choice of bread, fruit, juice, cheese, eggs and also some items of the japanese culinary. If you arrive in Tokyo at the Narita Airport, don´t miss the limousine bus, which drives you to the hotel door (don´t even consider getting a taxi from the airport. it will cost you around 300 dollars).

the building is a skyscarper surrounded by some others, mainly offices.the hotel takes palce from the 25th floor. This is the lobby. A "private" elevator takes you there, so don't be afraid of 96 (or whatever) stops before you get to the hotel.nice building (as much as a skyscarper can be...). cool lobby with a small japanese-like garden.helpful, but not that friendly staff.nice and big enough rooms. absolutely clean and modern. "stylish without style" i would say.the location is perfect. really, it is and it's still quite quiet. you can reach easily two undergroud lines (like 4 minutes walk). ginza district, the fabulous fish market (if you are interested) and hamarikyu garden in walking distance.

Not the best location in Toyko, with little close by. I would recommend you stay in Shinjuku instead, which has a lot more going on.The room was very basic, dated & had stains on the furniture. There are also strange requests, such as do not leave the bathroom door open when showering/bathing as this may turn on the smoke alarm. Do not use the kettle & hairdryer at the same time as this will cause a short circuit in the room. I would also suggest you move room if your room is next to the elevators, you can hear entire conversations.Staff did their jobs, but weren’t particularly helpful.Only positive was free internet in the room

The hotel is located in a business district, which makes the quality of sleep by night excellent. No traffic, no noise. Besides, the lobby of the hotel is located on the 25th floor and going up, so amazing views and no street noise. Our room was a standard double on the 32nd floor and it was very nice (again, amazing view). Quite large, with a desk and a sitting corner, flat screen and free internet connection. Complementary tea and coffee in the room. Nice bathroom with all amenities. The service was excellent. We took the shuttle bus from the Narita Airport (which stops at major hotels across the city) and a member of the hotel staff was already waiting for us downstairs to help with the luggage. The view from the reception is amazing. On a clear day one can even see the Fuji mountain. The hotel has a very relaxing atmosphere. The lobby was very nice, live piano music in the evening, two restaurants: French and Japanese. Breakfast was a bit disappointing in the sense that we expected a greater variety for the price (35 USD pp). We would not recommend eating at the hotel, as it is rather expenssive. But then again, Tokyo is an expenssive city. The staff at the hotel restaurants were super nice, always willing to give advice on sites to visit and directions. The hotel is located between two metro stations (connection to the JR Yamanote line) which made exploring the city very easy. The metro stations are a mere 5 min walk from the hotel (access to one of the stations is actually in the Shiodome Media Tower where the hotel is located). All in all, the hotel was great, it was even listed in the top 100 designer hotels. We really enjoyed our stay there, it offered the peace and quiet we needed after we spent the days out in a very busy city. We would deffinitely come back again and recommend it to our friends.

Recently took my first trip to Japan, mainly for a convention but also to explore. Park hotel was my choice based on the positive reviews here. I booked a corner suite with two beds. The room was decently sized. Apparently its bigger than the other ones but I've seen bigger corner rooms before. I wasnt stepping on my friend's toes but still it would be hard to call it a large room. The biggest sell for the room though is the view. What a view it is. The world famous ginza is at your toes and you really do feel the excitement of vibrant tokyo. The hotel itself starts at the 25th floor so i can imagine every room has a decent view. Our room was on the 33rd. Which was one away from the top floor. The view is just spectacular. One caveat however, is that the hotel is definately very high in the sky. If you are uncomfortable with high floor rooms or afraid of heights then I'd look elsewhere. I felt my ears popping everytime i went up to my room. Mixed with jetlag, I did find it hard to adjust. You have your jetlag and the high altitude which probably sent my body in all sorts of weird sensory overloads. Hard to fault the hotel for that, so I didnt do so in my review but something worth considering.I took a notch down on cleanliness because on my day of checkout i checked under the beds to make sure i hadnt left anything and it seemed really dusty. Also some of the carpet in the hallways had some spills. Aside from that it was fine. They give you ample toiletries and alot of extras that other hotels skimp on or you have to physically ask for (toothbrush/toothpaste/hairbrush/ floss). Another nice suprise was that the in-room bar is actually not gouging your eyes with rediculous pricetags. We were in a pinch and snagged two beers from the minifridge. At 300 yen, it was even better than going down to the convenience store. The beds were quality mattresses but they felt a little short in length. I know twin size beds arent that wide but it felt like maybe length wise they were a bit short also, I dont usually have my feet dangling off. Also the pillows coulda been a little firmer, or maybe have more of them available.Location wise, its great. You can walk to the Ginza and even take a cab over to the more popular stations like Tokyo station without breaking the bank. You can also walk over to the fish market. Nearby Roppongi is also within reach. I'd recommend this hotel, as it made my stay in Japan enjoyable. The staff are very professional and speak enough english to help you get around which is kind of rare in tokyo.

Second time at the Park Hotel in two years and on both occasions the experience has been excellent. We have stayed in both harbour view and city view rooms - both have been clean, well-maintained and appropriate for the purpose. This hotel is well located with easy and convenient access to multiple public transport links, and other services such as coffee shops. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Restaurant tateru yoshino Shiodome on level 25 is well worth visiting for an excellent meal. We discovered it by accident on our first visit and were very pleasantly surprised by the fine cuisine on offer, and our second visit did not disappoint.Nearby Vie de France is a great choice for an inexpensive breakfast and coffee.

The hotel belongs to the Design Hotel Group and offers excellent ambiente and perfect location for travellers in Tokyo. The rooms have standard equipment, are not as big as in european hotels of the same class but not too small either and offer simply a wonderful view to Tokyo Tower or the Hamarikyu Garden and the harbour. From Narita Airport you can reach the hotel fast and easy with one of the limousine busses and the hotel is directly connected to the Yurikamome-line and the Tokyo Metro and you can also reach the Yamanote line within a few minutes walk. This and the fact that it is also in walking distance to Ginza and other tourist attractions makes it an ideal starting point. There is even a small 24h convenience store right next to the subway entrance if you need late supplies.The only thing that one could miss is a indoor pool. And last but not least: It stands rock-solid even during an earthquake.

We were here twice on July 2010. First 5 nights in very nice and clean room with wiew to the Tokyo Bay. But next week we came back for 2 nights and got tired noisy room facing to the Shimbashi busy railwaystation. Both rooms were in same floor 27th, so it can really make a difference what you got from the front desk. Both rooms had free good coffee and nice feather blanked bed. Slippers and ropes also. Cheap real Champagne in minibar, just 15 €/ bottle. Flat TV, all channels included. Aromatherapy shower set and full size bathroom.Location is very good, skytrain Monorail has a station by the building 3rd floor. Few minutes to the Tokyo main and other direction you can enjoy even real beach in just 10 minutes drive over the bay.Shimbashi station you can walk less than 10 minutes and catch all major lines from there.

OK, I will preface this review with the fact that it was my first time in Tokyo - so maybe my standards are higher based on experiences from other hotels in Asia. That being said - there was truly nothing special about this hotel. It was OK at best. It just missed the mark in a lot of ways and a lot of little things could be changed that would make this hotel excellent. Hotel staff was friendly and did speak English which was awesome... but didn't do anything extra special. Food at the hotel was crazy overpriced. Internet in the room was free but spotty... had to sit in a certain position for it to work properly. Entire room (and bathroom) needs some sprucing up... getting quite dated. There wasn't a plug for the hair dryer near the vanity so I had to blow dry my hair at the mini bar while my husband was showering (because we can't open the door while showering because a note in the bathroom that says the steam will set off alarm). My biggest complaint is that the air conditioner never got cold. We couldn't really sleep well because our room was too hot. Location was pretty good with coffee shops and bakeries nearby for breakfast if you didn't want to drop the yen for the hotel breakfast. Like I said, maybe this is 5 stars for Tokyo - but based on my experiences, I will find another hotel until this one gets a makeover.

My husband and I felt that this hotel was perfect for our needs - exquisitely clean and centrally-located (literally, if you look at the map of the subway) by the Shimbashi subway station. Despite reviews to the contrary, the rooms were quite spacious, with efficiently used-space. Sure, don't expect to do cartwheels in the room. But on the nights when my husband and I felt the need to recooperate in our rooms after long days of travelling, this room had plenty of space, without us feeling like we were constantly in each other's space. The staff was gracious and always willing to help. And lastly - I would certainly use the airport limosine (actually a bus) if you are coming from/going to the airport...it'll drop you off right at the hotel. Overall, this hotel is highly recommended and was appropriately listed under luxury hotels (no joke, along with the Ritz!) in the Tokyo brochure!

Excellent friendly staff, always welcoming and striving to help. Good, not huge, room with everything expected from a good quality 4* hotel, including free in-room internet (netbook or equiv needed). Very clean rooms & comfy bed. Plenty of restaurants nearby, ranging expensive to cheap Mcdonalds, and coffee shops, including Starbucks. Metro nearby, although their underground is initially quite confusing. 15 min walk to Ginza, a major shopping street with many Dept stores. View of Fuji on reception side of building, weather permitting, which it seemed is not that often. Plenty of no smoking rooms/floors, although smoking is still permitted in the bar area, which as non-smokers is our only negative consideration. Happy to recommend this hotel and would gladly stay here again if we return to Tokyo.

Great hotel, fabulous views (we could even see Fudschijama!) and very convinient location. The corner rooms are very spasious but also the standard ones (we stayed in the hotel twice and got to learn different rooms) are big enough, considering the Japanese hotel room standards whiche are rather small. Only the breakfast is not worth the money, but you can get a bright selection of everything in the cafes nearby.

This hotel was perfectly located ! It was walking distance from all the major attractions and was fantastic to get to. However be aware that most taxis dont know where it is so keep a card with you at all times. The rooms are tiny (but then what is new in Tokyo) but doable if it is only for a couple of days. Prices however food or beverages in the hotel is exorbitant. The most crazy thing in Japan was that you have to pay $$15 extra to use swimming pool and the gym !

I stayed in this hotel 6 night.Wonderful place,wonderful scenery!The rooms are spacious and the bathroom amazing!Western breakfast includes fresh fruit,coffee, yogurt, french pastry,more salads, vegetables, seafood...Book your stay at this hotel.

I stayed four nights at the hotel. The room on the 33rd floor had a magnificent view on the Tokyo Tower and the "Sea of Skyscrapers" in South Western Tokyo (Small extra fee for tower view). Single Room was quite spacy, compared with other 4-star-rooms in Asian capitals I have stayed. Very clean, efficient service. The area around is a business district - quite calm in the evening but some places for dinner around.

Just a bit small room but the bed is very comfortable, internet accessible. All the other things are so good. Excellent service and helpful staff which is very friendly too. Good value, What a lovely hotel.

We stayed in this hotel on the 32nd floor having a fantastic view on Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower. The room was a bit small to my opinion but still confortable for 'sleep use'. Personell is extremely kind. Subway just on the basement of the Shiodome Media Bld, but only 1 line. Fish market and Ginza at walking distance.

what I liked:1. The tokyo tower view on the lobby floor and in some of the rooms. 2. The books provided in the lobby area and the rooms. (heart)3. The bed is comfortable. 4. The service 5. Everything needed can be found in the room. 6. Location (really convenient) what I didn't like:1. The rate is high and breakfast is not included. And the rooms are small. (but this is tokyo, so I guess I can only accept it). 2. The design of the atrium that wastes so much space. (If the rooms are large enough, I wouldn't mind this design. But with the current room size, they really can do a better job on space planning. For example, if the atrium is on the 30th floor and only spans 5 floors, the rooms can be much bigger given the same room numbers. ) 3. All the highlights are on the lobby floor. (Again, it's unbalanced compared to the plain rooms.) Even the toilets beside the lobby are better than the ones in the rooms.

My sister, daughter and myself stayed 4 nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo and was very pleased with our accommodation. Staff are very friendly and more than willing to help if need be. Rooms are large with great views. We were on the 29th floor. Bathroom was very neat and tidy. Only complaint was that my daughter had to sleep on a sofa bed which was very uncomfortable. I would definitely stay at the Park Hotel again.

The Shiodome area is centrally located just south of Tokyo and is right next to a subway and JR (Japan Rail) station. The location is fantastic, and the staff are excellent. They all speak English and were very friendly and attentive. I honestly can't say enough about the service and help we received when we requested any A+.The rooms are what I would consider typical European.........smallish. However, by European standards, they are perfectly normal. If you plan on bringing children, ask about a larger room option.Overall, our experience was positive, but my one gripe would be about 'extras'. By this, I mean the bar/restaurant, pool (none), and additional services (none). The bar/restaurant especially irritated me since it required a cover charge of approx $12 US just to enter even if you were a hotel guest. Frankly, I thought that was odd. We purchased some drinks at the stores nearby and had a beer and cigar in the beautiful lobby instead.All in all, a nice hotel if you plan to travel around the city most of the day, but don't plan on spending any quality time relaxing or enjoying the hotel outside of watching TV in your room.
