This hotel was wonderful. The view from the towering rooms (at 60+ floors) is breathtaking as you look out over the city of Tokyo. Book the rooms where breakfast is included- it's traditional Japanese or Western- the Japanese was such a blast and so tasty. The rooms were tiny, of course, but the staff was kind and it was a place where memories are made. Be sure to bring your walking shoes and also, make sure to go to the fish market which is within walking distance (go at 5am- do it!), which is a rare thing in Tokyo.

Our brief one night stay in the Park Hotel was one of the most pleasant experiences we have had in all our travels - anywhere. Although a little hard to find, the hotel is absolutely superb; modern, clean, professionally staffed, and conveniently located. Most notable, however, are the stunning views of the city from the high floor rooms. Watching the metropolis of Tokyo light up in front of us at night was an amazing and unforgettable experience!

I usually visit Tokyo multiple times throughout the year and stay at the Park Hotel since 2004, virtually when it opened. The hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower, which makes it convenient to reach nearby Ginza, take the train to Haneda Airport, other subways or the Yamanote line.The design is modern minimalistic, service quality meets highest japanese standards, staff is friendly and swift. However, the rooms are small (but ok for Tokyo), you might want to consider the slightly larger rooms if you prefer more space. Free Internet is available and the hotel has the usual 4* amenities - which makes price/value just excellent.Check out the hotel bar for a nice view and superb drinks, but mind the early closing times,

This hotel has everything you need for a comfortable stay in Tokyo and at fantastic value (in an expensive city). We found the location to be the only drawback, and this was really only a problem late at night. Taxis are, however, an affordable option after the metro has closed.

We stayed in this hotel after a business trip in Yokohama in March. We wanted to take few days to tour the city and because of reviews in tripadvisor, decided to book the hotel through their website. we took a cab to this hotel and the driver brought us to a different Park Hotel. there are numerous Park Hotel in the area and this hotel doesnt have a visible signage. even in subway station where they list hotels in the area, this hotel is not on the list. We had to pay the cab driver twice the price for bringin us around the city trying to find this hotel. the lobby is amazing! it is located on the top floor of a business building. the views are amazing. it is part of the "Prestigious Small Hotels" in the world and we were impressed. Room was clean and cozy, nicely decorated and new. bad thing, we can hear the subway below everytime. so if you are a lighsleeper, you can only get some rest once the subway stops running. also, although it is connected to the subway station, figuring out your way around is like a maze. the building has its own overpass and underpass that connects to other commercial building. it is very confusing. location is not as i expected. our friends were staying at the Mariott Ginza and the location of that is so much more convenient, although rooms were dated and not as nice as Park Hotel.
We stayed for 10 days including leaving our luggage whilst on a trip to Kyoto. Great location, very central and quiet. Reasonable room rates and free wired internet. Highly recommended.

My wife & i spent four days at the Park Hotel last month, and it was very pleasant surprise. The hotel is located on the upper floors of the Shiodome Media Tower, which is part of a relatively new office complex, which included shops, restaurants, and an underground mall which leads to the subway. the mall came in handy when we chose not to pay high prices for breakfast at the hotel restaurant.The views from the upper floors were excellent, and we even saw Mt. Fuji from our room one morning. We stayed in one of the larger rooms at this hotel, which was comparable in size to a standard room at an upscale hotel in the U.S.. Other rooms in the hotel seemed somewhat smaller. The hotel staff was excellent, and was very attentive to our needs.The hotel location was great, being only a few blocks from the trendy Ginza district, and access to other parts of the city was very easy on Tokyo's incredible transportation system. I would definitely recommend the Park Hotel for its location, service and amenities, all at reasonable rates.

Stayed at the Park Hotel for four nights in mid March during our first visit to Tokyo and Asia. It's a great hotel to set up shop and get to know the city in comfort. World class view of Tokyo to get your bearings. Very comfortable room for those used to traveling in the US and Europe. Modern amenities and aesthetics. Incredible value. I think if you book more than a month in advance you can get the best deals. Good location within easy walking distance to Ginza and Tsukiji Fish Market. 10-15 minute walk to Shimbashi station and lots of trains.

They always say "location, location location" and the Park Hotel, Tokyo was certainly the perfect location. Situated literally a stone's throw away from the private Shiodome station, we were surprised to find the entrance to the hotel only a few meters away from the station exit. The hotel was stunningly decorated, and when we arrived on the 25th floor where the hotel lobby was situated, the elevator doors opened and almost immediately there were staff waiting to take over our luggage and guide us to the front desk where the check-in was fast and efficient. The staff speak good English and were able to answer our questions and even happy to give us tourist information on how to get to certain places. The room was small-ish but when you compare it to other hotels in Tokyo, it was actually quite spacious and offered AMAZING views of Tokyo especially sitting on the bay window at night. The room was clean and had everything that you could even think of (they even provide hair brushes). My only con to this hotel is the price. The price of the accommodation is one thing (in Tokyo, accommodation is expensive pretty much most places you go) but the food and drinks in the downstairs restaurant/lounge area are overpriced so I highly suggest rather than eating/drinking in, you go out because you can find some much more reasonably priced food if you look around. Other than that, it really was the perfect stay for our leisurely trip. I would definitely recommend this for couples or people on business who don't mind splurging a bit to spoil themselves for a bit of luxury and comfort.

I was incredibly impressed with this hotel. The first 24 floors of the building are taken up with private offices and media businesses, so the actual reception is on the 25th floor. You are greeted with a truly awe-inspiring view of Tokyo through floor-to-ceiling windows, including Tokyo Tower and (on a clear day) Mount Fuji. The staff are polite and efficient and happy to assist with all enquiries. My room was clean and spacious with lovely view of Tokyo Bay and the Hama Rikyu Gardens through the surrounding sky-scrapers. I ate in the hotel as I arrived so late, and both the food and the service was impeccable. My only complaint is that the hotel still allows smoking in it's public bar, which isn't very nice if you're trying to have a bar snack and enjoy the jazz - I do appreciate that the smoking ban hasn't hit Japan yet so it's not really a complaint, more a personal preference! Breakfast wasn't great - weird scambled eggs, American style bacon (ie.so thin you could read your paper through it), but coffee and juice was plentiful as was the fruit salad and toast. It loses a point on location as it's a bit out of the way, but easy walking distance to train station and the Ginza shopping district.

We stayed here for 4 nights in a double room in April. The hotel is at the top of an impressive tower in Shiodome in a business complex close to the upmarket shopping area of Ginza. Our room was on the 34th floor (not for those with a fear of heights) and had amazing views over the city. It was compact but not cramped. There were mod cons such as TV, room safe, and ethernet cable for free internet. The bed was a little hard, but we got used to it pretty quickly and it didn't affect our sleep. The bathroom was also compact but very well appointed with lots of nice bath accessories.The hotel reception / bar / lounge are in a huge atrium on the 25th floor (i think). It's all very classy and a nice place to sit, although not cheap.All the staff were super friendly and helpful. For example they were more than happy to organize sending our luggage to Kyoto via Takkyubin. (A cheap and efficient luggage delivery service - a must if you are traveling around as it saves carting suitcases on the train.) Shiodome station is directly accessible from the hotel basement, or it is a 5 to 10 minute walk to Shimbashi station. It is also a short walk to the Yurikamome line which goes over Rainbow Bridge to the man made islands where you'll find the beach, Fuji TV building and so on.It's also a 5 to 10 minute walk from the hotel to Ginza, a large shopping district with lots of upmarket stores and plenty of restaurants.In the complex surrounding the hotel were various shops and coffee places, which we used as a cheaper alternative to the expensive hotel buffet breakfast.Overall this was a great upmarket hotel and we would stay here again.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights on a first visit to Tokyo after a business trip in Kyoto. We were pleasantly surprised when the hotel staf upgraded us to a King bedroom upon us telling them that we were celebrating our wedding anniversary! We were on 33rd floor and the view was fantastic. The room was very large for Japanese standards and with all amenities we wanted and more. The hotel is directly on the subway station so the connection with anywhere in Tokyo is very easy. We selected this hotel for his proximity to the Tsukiji (the renowned fish market, the larger in the world) and we weren't disappointed. After a short stroll, we were able to taste and look at myriads of varieties of fish, in an incredible setting. Worth the visit to Tokyo by itself. We'll be back."

We planned this trip back to Asia for a long time and Park did meet our expectation with almost all levels. Upon arrival, the check in was fast and the staff members were helpful. We had the most amazing room with Tokyo Tower view and managed to be able to see Mount Fuji in the distance in the last day, lucky us!The room was surprisingly bigger then those what we thought of the Tokyo standard, the bathroom is tiny tho. The first night was absolutely a nightmare to drag our lovely 4 luggage all the way from JR station up to the overpass.., it was extremely convenient once you figure out the way around the hotel - please book the shuttle bus to and from the hotel for $3,000, it's worthy! We have not tried those highly recommended-Michelin restaurants in our hotel, we are more street-vendor kinda people when we travel, maybe we will give it a try next time. And do not listen to the hotel staff to order room services! Ginza area is just 5 mins away, and just walk in any restaurant that is opened! They are mostly reasonable priced, food is delicious, and they are mostly having English menu.One thing me and my partner found very frustrated was that you really have to ask a very precise question, for instance, from our hotel walk to Tsukiji Market takes no time, but the hotel staff told us "go outside and look for a tall/grey building then walk along the pathway.."?? hello? look around, they are all tall and gray buildings; or for instance, they will tell you how to get to the temple via which station, but they will not tell you how to get to the temple from the station and there has no signs anywhere else around the station..Overall, we need something modern, convenient, and comfy with reasonable price ($200 per night), and Park managed to do that. But be aware of the smoking gang in the lobby (or anywhere in Tokyo..), it is not New York anymore!

The location is great, right next to the subway and the mono-rail. The hotel looks good from the outside (in a skyscraper) and the inside, with nice rooms and interiors.But the best is really the fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower. You get a top notch view of Tokyo, but way cheaper than the other big skycraper hotels.The staff is nice and actually knows how to speak proper English.This is one of my favorite hotel / location in Tokyo.Amazing city night views!

We spent five nights here in March at the beginning of a two week vacation in Japan and hotel was seleced by the travel company making all our arrangements. Would definitely recommend it due to location alone. There is access underneath the building(s) to about 3 subway lines, the monorail and a train line. We found that we only needed to take one of the lines to see our required sights, i.e., Tokyo Museum, Ginza, Odaiba, Kabuki theater, etc.Rooms are satisfactory in size but not large and well kitted out: not only sleepwear and slippers but big fluffy robes. Plus the usual (for Japan) items as refrig, every possible toiletry and all refilled each day.We ate in bar first night as all else was closed and had two BLT sandwiches plus one wine and one beer for about $70. But breakfast buffet was great - bread is incredible. .We ate in nearby restaurants the rest of time. Again location gives one access to almost everything including small general stores, coffee shopsHotel was very helpful with arrangements as to luggage. Fr.ee internet access via business service center with 2 PCs in lobby.

We came back again this year to Tokyo and re-upped on the Park Hotel. A $30 airport limo ride from Narita and we were at the doorstep. We experienced the same excellent care and attentiveness as last time. The fact that its not plopped into a busy city scene appeals to me. It has easy access to the madness with the subway downstairs and Shinbashi Station a 5 minute walk. The room was not as nice tho, it looked a little worn, not as crisp as our room last year. The wall had some black luggage scuffs and the beds were made so they were lumpy and not as appealing as last time. But all in all, its a gem, and will stay there again as we are mastering the area quite well.

We stayed here for four nights in total, two at the beginning and two at the end of our recent fortnight touring Japan. It's an excellent base - really well located for loads of sights, the subway system, and Tokyo station: you can reach the nearest station, Shiodome, from within the hotel building (and the hotel is helpfully signed from within the station), but the better-connected Shimbashi station is only a few minutes' walk away, and Tokyo station only two stops from there. There are loads of local eating opportunities, in the station area, in neighbouring buidings, or a 5-10 minute walk away in the Tsukiji fish market area - or you can go further field by train v easily, eg, Shinjuku. The hotel is a great introduction to Tokyo, being located in the upper floors of a very tall new building, in the modern Shiodome area - whilst the ground floor entrance to the building is fairly anodyne, taking the lift to the 25th floor brings you to the v helpful Reception, and another lift takes you from there to the rooms, which go right up to the top of the building, on the 34th floor. The rooms are a good size, modern and clean, and have decent bathrooms (with ginger-scented toiletries). The rooms all have large windows, with great views over Tokyo - on the city side you get a great view of the skyline, some nearby towers, and the station far below (with shinkansen whizzing past on a regular basis); on the other side, weather permitting, you get Mt Fuji on the horizon, and more great city views. Breakfast is served in the lounge, which is at the base of the atrium, and it's v comprehensive, with continental, cooked, and Japanese food on offer - which you can mix and match in entertaining ways, eg, hotdogs, fish, croissants, pancakes and syrup, broccoli, and pasta with pesto sauce and mushrooms. The staff are all v helpful, and English-speaking. It was great to know we were coming back here at the end of our trip. The staff remembered us on our return, and kindly upgraded us to a Fuji room on the top floor, which was a great end to the holiday. We'd definitely go straight back to the Park Hotel if back in Tokyo. And the beginning of April is a good time to go: the cherry blossom was out in force all over the place.

Just recently stayed there for 3 nights and I'd wish that I'd booked it for our final night back in Tokyo. This is one top notch quality hotel! With excellent staff that are always helpful with your needs and primed in the central business district with excellent views of the city I could not give any fault with the hotel except one. The train station is located right next to the hotel so even though we were staying on the 27th floor, you can still hear the trains zooming by every now and then. It can be quite frequent because there about 6 different lines that cross it. With our room it had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower and the Tokyo Imperial Palace, you kind of forget about the trains and just admire the view of the city.

this is a nice hotel. we paid a bit extra for a l arger room and it was very nice and had a great view of the city. the location is very convenient and it is a 15minute walk to many areas. one of the conceriege was very good but the other was worthless. My pet peeve--no seperate reading lights for each side of the bed. the light was either on or off. also wish there was more than CNN in english on TV.

A good night's sleep was had at the Park Hotel after an exhausting flight from the UK. The room was smart and clean with good views of the city and the hotel had an excellent concierge service. Nice reception area with a fairly expensive restaurant. All of the staff had some English although few had excellent English. Tokyo is huge and so everywhere will involve some walking and the Park is part of a sprawling underground station and shopping complex which was hard to find but the room and the sleep made up for it!
great design and location. great service. small rooms.

wow what can i say about this hotel its a real luxurious elegant hotel. The staff will bend over backwards for you and always quick to help. the breakfasts in the morning are beautiful and really essential for a buisy day wondering around tokyo. The rooms were spotlessly clean and modern with panoramic views of tokyo you can see literally every single corner of tokyo its amassing, the lift (elevator) is an exsperience in itself , we stayed on the 25th floor it was breath takeing.The sourounding area is full of small japanese restraunts and boutiques and areas like harajuku are a short subway ride away.This hotel is amassing i really have no negatives .... really dont, its a lovely quiet place to return to after a buisy tokyo day and just chill and relax and listen to the live piano in the lobby truly elegant.A truely japanese exsperience !!!

2nd stay at the Park - excellent choice. A sanctuary of clean, peace and good sleep way above the hubub. beautiful view of Fuji and Tokyo tower from foyer - went for cheap room with city/odaiba views - doesn't disappoint. room size modest but functional. Discovered blade-runner-esque restaurant area immediately under/outside shimbashi railway station - all locals, not touristy at all, buzzing with salary men til last trains at midnight. Location of hotel excellent for Yamanote line (shimbashi stn ~7mins walk or Shiodome metro station in basement of hotel bldg).

We stayed for 3 nights in total. Upon arriving (by 'limousine' bus from the airport directly to the hotel - 6000 yen for two), we were a little surprised that there's no real entrance - the hotel is located on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower, a sort of tall, officey-style building. Once you take the elevator up, the lobby itself is quite nice in a subtle, understated way. Soft lighting, a quiet calm atmosphere. Not grand, more functional. We got a fairly good rate by booking through agoda and having the room pre-paid might have been one of the reasons why check in was super simple and quick - about 2 minutes in total, with our bags whisked up quickly by a porter.Our room was actually quite tiny, though we were kind of expecting that in Tokyo, which is known for teeny weeny rooms. Despite the size of the room we didn't ask to change because other than that, it was perfectly fine. The general style and decor is fairly pleasing though not fabulous.We did have a fabulous view of the Tokyo Tower through a big plate glass window in our room, something which really did enjoy.The bathroom toiletries are by the Thai product line Thann - good quality and fairly generous. (They automatically included toothbrushes, a spare hair tie, shower mit, razor, etc. which not all mid-range hotels do) They are highly scented though, so you'd definitely need to be a fan of strong woody fragrances if you use them all at once! Quick list of some of the additional pros:- Shimbashi station is less than a 5 minute walk away across the elevated sky bridge walkways from the 3rd floor. - Ginza is only a 10-15 minute walk away. Great high-end shopping district, all the major international brands right there on Chuo Dori, lots of interesting restaurants in back streets to explore.- Truly lovely, accommodating staff. Getting flights reconfirmed (including seat requests), asking for directions and/or help, luggage storage, general needs, etc. were all met with ease and grace.- The restaurants in the nearby Shiodome City Center (a 2 minute walk) were actually quite good if you don't feel like venturing out further for dinner. We ate at a great little tonkatsu place on one of the lower floors there (great pork cutlet!) and had a nice dinner on one of the top floors at En (where they accidentally served me up stewed beef tongue instead of pork ribs, which was actually really gross).- The hotel was really peaceful, something which we appreciated after the hectic pace of Tokyo during the day. The rooms were also super quiet - we didn't hear other hotel guests at all once while we were in our room.- We found the hotel really clean and well maintained.- Free cable internet access in the rooms. We travel with our own laptop and this is always important to us.A few of the cons:- Unless you get breakfast included in your rate, it's really not worth paying for. The breakfast buffet is pricey and looked decidely lacklustre so we didn't bother trying it out - no fresh juices, a big tray of premade scrambled eggs, that sort of thing. That said though, the nearby cafe options for breakfast aren't fabulous either - after a couple of less than ideal starts we ended up just going to Starbucks and having coffee and a muffin. Not great but then, you don't really go to Toky for the great western-style breakfasts!- No complimentary drinking water is offered with your room at all, with expensive little Dean & Deluca bottles in the minibar fridge being the only option if you don't remember to buy your own water. Buying big bottles of water at the FamilyMart downstairs solved that problem pronto.- Apart from two expensive restaurants and an aromatherapy relaxation spa (which we didn't actually try), the hotel doesn't really have any guest amenities such as gym facilities, pool, sauna, etc. As one of the staff at the reception desk so cutely put it "aaahh yes, this hotel very unfortunate for fitness guests". - The room service spaghetti I ordered one night was pretty bad - oily and bland, with no salt & pepper included on the tray (something I only discovered the necessity for once the room service attendant had left and i was already eating, by which point I couldn't be bothered chasing it up). It was actually the only western-style meal I ate for the entire time we were in Japan, as I love the local cuisine, but I was super tired and the thought of a bowl of steaming spaghetti was very appealing at that point. Best to give it a miss.- Despite its proximity to Shimbashi station and Ginza itself, for those expecting to be right in the midst of all the Tokyo action, it may seem a little out of the way. And to be honest, heading out to dinner in other prefectures at night in the middle of winter did prove to be a bit of a mission in that regard.Despite the cons I've listed above, we actually did enjoy our stay there, and if you hunt around to get a really good rate (we paid less than $250 AUD) then it is very good value for what it is. Would we stay again? Probably not. I'd pick something closer to Shinjuku/Shibuya so we can get around on foot at night a little easier.

Hotel is clean with a nice hot shower, comfortable bed, good tv with room size adequate and bathroom was a bit small. Hotel is in a great location with plentry of shops and restaurants around. Hotel has a good breakfast with plenty to please all tastes. Note food in Japan is different to Japanese food in Australia. If you do not like Japanese food, there are plenty of other cuisines to have. Tokyo is a busy place and Japan is not designed for the tourist. I cannot speak Japanese, but got around with no problem. It is a wonderful and clean country with very proud people.

I've stayed at the Park Hotel a number of times over the last few years and it is always wonderful. Last visit the wine waiter even remembered my name and which wine I liked from a year prior before I sat down! Now that's personalised service. The location is fantastic but be prepared to walk -there is disabled access but distances from Stations to the hotel are a good walk - although flat. The rooms are gorgeous, the lobby bar while kitschy, is lovely and Ithe live music is fun. The Japanese restaurant is delightful but very fine dining Kaiseki Ryori style so thos who prefer simpler fare would be better off trying Tsunahachi "SUI" in the basement of the neighbouring Caretta complex. There are also geat sushi places and a range of other reasonably piced Japanese restaurants there. The French restaurant is famous and hard to get in so book in advance.I found the staff incredibly helpful and I would recommend that you visit the Tsukuji fish markets if you've never been - go when you are hungry as they will give you free samples! Also, the Ginza is nearby - get the subway as it will also take you to Harajuku (Omotesando for teh 5th Avenue ambience, Meiji-Jingumae if you'd like to see the shrine - be prepared for a 5km walk once at the shrine) I lived in Japan on separate occasions in the 1990s so I know Tokyo well. I ave stayed in many hotels including the famed Keio Plaza and the New Ohtani. They ae also lovely but HUGE. What I like about the Park Hotel is that you're so happy to get back to it at the end of the day and you will sleep very well. The beautiful surprise of a spectacular view of Fuji-san is also a bonus that is a first time visitor's dream! Stay at the Park, it's great!

We stay in Tokyo fairly often, and decided to try the Park Hotel as Shiodome is an excellent location to pursue some business / leisure. Upon arrival at the hotel, which is part of a media complex, we were not met at the ground level by any hotel staff. Instead we lugged our own cases to the lobby residing on the 25th floor. Staff were civil and pre-paying the hotel (by bank transfer?!) seemed to make the checking-in process easier. The standard rooms are a disappointment, and are beginning to look shabby (marks on the wall, stained carpets). The beds are relatively comfortable, with extra pillows at a premium. Bathrooms are tiny, but clean. While the hotel itself is well located, trekking to and fro from room to street level takes a good 15 minutes if you include waiting for lifts, etc. There are a number of restaurants and a very expensive bar at lobby level, the quality is good, but you are better exploring the plethora of fantastic restaurants elsewhere in Tokyo. If you are particularly unlucky, you will experience the jazz entertainment during the evening: if you've ever seen the jazz flute scene in the movie Anchorman, you should get an idea of what to expect. This is a hotel frequented by a fair mix of Japanese and Western tourists, with plenty of Australian and US families, and the occasional C-list UK actor, staying for a few nights before heading elsewhere. I suspect that using the hotel as a base is a good idea, especially as the room price is quite competitive compared with other hotels. However, compared with some of the less-well marketed hotels (see review of Daiwa Roynet in Nagoya as a comparison) that do not often cater for non-Japanese clients, the Park Hotel seems over-rated for "boutique on a budget".

As an international traveller with a love of shopping we reserved a premier room. It was a good size that accomodated two large suitcases without being in the way. It was spotlessley clean and felt more luxurious than its hotel rating.The sky bridge meant a short walk to main transport links. It was handy to Ginza shopping and perfect for breakfast at the fishmarket. The staff were very helpful. The only downside was that the european breakfast buffet needs improving

The hotel is fine and good value for the price - the rooms (queen bedroom) are pretty small but everything makes sense and works well and is clean/comfortable. The view was fantastic and I imagine all rooms have a great view due to the hotel starting on 25th floor. The location is pretty good - about a seven minute walk to the main action in Ginza which in the cold January weather is most easily done via the spotless underground route rather than the elevated and exposed walkways above ground. You can get a two minute cab ride between the hotel and the main street in Ginza - about 800 yen per trip. The hotel doesnt have much charm but the staff are helpful (eg organising bus, handling and storing luggage) and the 25th floor reception/lounge area is quite nice (a business oriented atmosphere). The immediate area surrounding the hotel is quiet and a bit desolate. To grab a coffee and snack without going too far, head underground (take the hotel lift from your floor straight down to level B2) where a number of cafes cater to the subway-using private sector employees who work in the area.

Some contributors have mentioned "very small rooms" and bathrooms, but our experience was different. We booked two rooms and both turned out to be twins. The room our kids had, was a huge corner room with 270 degree views. There were two beds, not next to each other but in different corners of the room at different angles. They had a large lounge/divan and a large bathroom too.Our room was three doors away and although about half the area, it was not cramped. There were twin beds in the usual layout.We had the buffet breakfast in the lobby. Some seats are around coffee tables, and a little low for comfort, but there are other full size tables in the side rooms- which we were shown to. I thought the breakfast was good value- though it had more western items than Japanese. Coffee, pastries and croissants were magnifique!Unfortunately, the hotel's French restaruant, which has been highly recommended on Tripadvisor, was booked out, so recommend calling or emailing ahead to make a reservation.

My friends and I stayed for two nights at the Park Hotel and had a very enjoyable time.The lobby and atrium is impressive, and the hotel is very quiet and comfortable. The bathroom is slightly on the small side, even for Japan it would seem, but nothing you can't get used to! The toiletries are abundantly stocked, and I found the beds to be very comfy. Our room featured a magnificent view of the Tokyo Tower.The staff were incredibly efficient in delivering our luggage which was missing in transit for two days, thanks to Qantas! They went out of their way to deliver it as soon as humanly possible, which was great considering we were there in the midst of the typhoon without coats or umbrellas. The staff were helpful with all other enquiries too, and when we checked in, our tickets for our JTB free plan Kyoto tour were waiting on the desk in the hotel room- Great service!The location was a little bit out of the way, but only a quick walk to Ginza and surrounded by trains and subways to take you anywhere you need to go. The transport system in Japan is a well oiled machine, so efficient... We easily negotiated our way by train to the Ghibli Museum in Mitaka, during peak hour, on our first day. I loved the futuristic feel of the neighbourhood, and if I you want to experience a quieter, more businesslike side of Tokyo I would definitely recommend staying at the Park Hotel.

We booked this hotel on the basis of the positive reviews and were not disappointed. Excellent value for Tokyo, we paid the equivalent of AUD$200 per night for a decent sized room (for Tokyo) with well-equipped bathroom and views across to the river. Efficient check and check out, helpful staff. Location in Shiodome is a bit quiet, but it is literally a five to ten minute walk to the lights of Ginza and very handy to Tsukiji. We preferred having a quiet escape from the craziness that is Tokyo. Easy access to metro, monorail and JR stations. Heaps of restaurants around in the office towers and department stores. For cheaper eats, go to nearby Shimbashi rather than Ginza.

Clean and efficient no-frills hotel in central business neighborhood. Ginza and fish market within walking distance. Rooms are tiny, but well kept and comfortable. Somewhat bland overall atmosphere and therefore not a particularly exciting hotel experience, but excellent value for money.

You can se Mt. Fuji, Tokyo Tower, the city and shrines from the window of your room.Also it's very near the Hayao Miyazaki clock, just at the exit of the 3rd floor entrance, and they have japanese traditional performances at the lobby too.

This hotel has been covered thoroughly by previous reviewers so I will just add some highlights from our visit.* We arrived at the Shimbashi station via Japan Rail. We got a Japan Rail pass (great value if you are planning on taking a bullet train out of Tokyo) which included access on the Narita Express. It took roughly one hour to get to Shimbashi station and then a 5 minute walk through the frenetic station to the hotel. * I am confused by a recent review that says the hotel is poorly located - it is within walking distance of Ginza, Imperial Palace, the Fish Market, and is on Japan Rail's Yamanote ("Circle") line and two subway lines. All of the "big" tourist attractions are quite easily accessible.* There are TONS of restaurants within the Shimbashi/Shiodome station area, less than 5 minute walk away. The station is like a mini-city, with hotels, coffeshops, restaurants, convenience stores, and limited shops. You can also walk to Ginza (~10 min) which is an upscale shopping and dining district. Even though we are experienced travelers, it is a bit intimidating finding restaurants in Tokyo due to the crowds and limited English...perhaps that is why some reviewers weren't happy with the restaurant selection.* Rooms were quite nice, certainly not big by Western standards but bigger than I thought they would be. Bathroom and toiletries were quite nice. View was gorgeous (and we had the "bad" side!). TV was a bit disappointing because there were no English channels but I didn't come to Tokyo to watch CNN.* Didn't go to restaurants within hotel, also didn't try the breakfast buffet. Everything looked nice but expensive. We would walk to Vie de France (also in Shimbashi station) for morning pastries and saved a bunch of money. It was fun seeing the Japanese version of a french bakery! Numerous coffeshops also available.* We didn't bring a laptop but there is free internet. We enjoyed the free access in the business center - 3 terminals with a gorgeous view of Tokyo.* We got a good deal on hotels.com, <$200/night. I thought that was a solid value for a nice room in the heart of Tokyo.

My family stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo from December 31 to January 2 to conclude our week long Japan vacation. The hotel is located in the media district of Shiodome, an easy 8-10 minute walk from Shinbashi Station and right above Shiodome station (with access to the monorail). Besides being close to Shinbashi station, I found the location of this hotel to be one of their weaknesses. Although centrally located in Tokyo, there are very few restaurants close by and the area is pretty much deserted. However, I feel their is potential for this area to grow in the future. But if you are looking for a hotel close to all the action, keep looking!The Park Hotel itself is pretty stunning, The lobby is on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower with panoramic views of Tokyo. We were given 2 rooms (a corner twin and city queen) on the 30th floor facing Tokyo Tower. The views were spectacular as you can see from my pictures. Seeing the sun set over Mt. Fuji with Tokyo Tower was a highlight. It is definitely worth paying an additional $25 for rooms facing the Tower. The room was a decent size. The beds were also really comfortable. The bathroom was a little smaller then the previous hotels we had stayed at on our trip, but their was plenty of amenities. Buffet breakfast was served in the atrium/lobby area. There was a large selection of food and it was all really tasty. However, it was slightly awkward to sit down at the tables in the lobby because they really weren't meant to be eaten on.One of the main problems we encountered at this hotel was the service and attitude of the staff. They were extremely unhelpful and never smiled. We were also surprised that the concierge didn't speak much English. This is surprising considering this hotel seemed to cater to a more western demographic. When asking the concierge to find a good restaurant close by, it turned into a major struggle because she only had names of restaurants in the hotel complex. She was also very unknowledgeable about Tokyo. Since we were staying over new years, we wanted to know which major sites would be open . Two concierges told us Harajuku and all the major attractions were closed and our only option was visiting odaiba. This was ridiculous!! We ended up ignoring their advice and had a blast going to Harajuku and Meiji Shrine. How can a hotel of this caliber have such an untrained concierge? Throughout our visit, the staff had a cold attitude and were unhelpful, which made it uncomfortable to be in such a beautiful hotel.Overall, I would still recommend this hotel to anyone looking to visit Tokyo because the views were so spectacular. I can only hope you will have a better experience with the service.

The hotel is quite far away from the main attractions of Tokyo, but it boasts a nice view of the surrounding skyscrapers. The service is attentive, but unfortunately the only restaurant in the hotel closes very early, which forces guests to look for alternatives. Worthy of being mentioned are the very small rooms - which are normal in Japan for 4 Star establishments, but not a 5-Star hotel.

Very nice hotel. Chic design, comfortable details, perfect view @ the bay side rooms. Friendly employees and good service. Good spot for leisure trips. Close to Ginza and other main attraction areas. Very easy to reach Tokyo metro and change for different lines. Definitely recommended!

Room: Like a lot of the other reviews we could not believe how small the rooms were, although I assume the same can be said of other Tokyo hotels. The room was however very comfortable and clean. A free newspaper was delivered each morning in English. In room safe included. There is not much character, it's very white and clinical looking!Location: The hotel was based in a location which made it a great base to get onto the metro and see Tokyo, we had dinner for several nights in nearby Roppongi which is where those who are not adventurous can dine; Hard Rock Cafe, TGI Fridays etc! Also, Roppongi is where there are lots of sports/Irish bars showing English Premier League football! This hotel is also a good location to take trips, tours will collect from this hotel.Hotel: Hotel staff where polite, helpful and they sorted a room out very quickly as we arrived ahead of standard check in time. The internet in the business centre is free for hotel guests which always saves money when abroad. We didn't eat at the hotel as the prices looked very high. The hotel is very quiet and peaceful.

This was the first hotel we stayed in when getting to Japan. It has immediate wow factor becuase the building is modern and clean and the lobby is on the 26th floor! Great clean, modern, simple lines inside the lobby, with a fantastic view behind the reception desk of Fuji-san and the Tokyo tower.The rooms are perfect, 2 single beds in ours, desk and armchair, plus a fair sized bathroom. The bonus for me was a large window ledge that you can sit on and gaze out at Tokyo from. Although we didn't have a view of Fuji we could see the nearest station and plenty of Tokyo life, I spent many happy hours of my jet lag watching this view.The hotel is 3 (ish) mins walk from Shimbashi station, and a few mins walk from a beatuiful garden (the fish market is within 10 mins walk as well apparently).

As the other reviews say if you can get a room on the same side as reception you're in for a treat!!! This is a great hotel with friendly staff who speak very good English. Being right on top of a subway station is a bonus too! It's about a 10 minutes walk away from the Ginza district which is filled with swanky department stores and the famous Yakitori Alley (this is under the railway tracks and easy to find). The room was spacious with plenty of room for two people and their suitcases. The bathroom was spotless. Will definitely stay here again when next in Tokyo!

Upon arrival to the hotel, service was fantastic. Check in was quick and smooth. The hotel staff settle you in your room and hand you with a map of the area and answer any questions you have. They do not accept tips as they say service is included in your room rate. Concierge was extremely helpful and helped me with whatever queries I had. The maps handed out were very useful. The restaurant in the hotel was a Michelin star restaurant and the food was absolutely fantastic. The view of the train station was fantastic from our room as we were able to see the different trains. Bathroom was well equipped with luxury toilteries and was quite spacious too. The hotel kindly let us store our luggage overnight as we were travelling to Kyoto. Overall, great hotel and excellent service offered by all staff with the exception of one receptionist, who was rather rude.

LOCATION: Good hotel location in a business area. Tokyo is huge and there is a lot to see and neighborhoods are spaced out. The hotel is within walking distance to the Fish Market and Ginza. Everything else is easily reached by Tokyo's fast/efficient Metro. The hotel is under Shiodome Station and a short walk to Shimbashi Station. We got to the hotel by local train (Yokosuka line), which is half the price of the Narita Express train and only take 20 minutes longer from what we're told. Expect a 90 minute journey in total. The train from Narita stops at Shimbashi station, then a carefully guided maze-like journey through the underground to get to the hotel. The station, like most, is very busy and be careful not to get trampled in rush hour. (Also a good experience).ROOM: We were very disappointed with the room. Very small room. We understood that every tour book says that rooms in Tokyo are small. What we didn't understand is the gigantic lobby with the very high multistory atrium. Sure, the open public space is nice, but not a good trade off of for a tiny room. The TV was a small table top LCD with poor picture quality, not expected for what we understand Tokyo to be the electronics capital of the world. There were no TV stations in any other language except Japanese. Even CNN was translated into Japanese. The toilet was more high-tech than the TV. Don't get me wrong, I don't expect every hotel and restaurant to cater to English/Western desires, but this hotel is being benchmarked to other hotels we stayed in Europe, not to mention Bangkok, Hong Kong, and Singapore during this trip. All of which offered larger rooms, better amenities, and TV channels in Spanish, Chinese, French, German, Arabic, English. The room did not have an iron either. The bed and pillows were very uncomfortable. Overall, at the price paid, the room was very sub-par. The price paid, relative to New York, Paris, Sydney, is not correlated to the comfort/amenities.STAFF: The hotel staff is polite and helpful.HOTEL: Common areas are very clean. The lobby is on the 25th floor, then your room goes up from there. The lobby area has a smart contemporary design. The hallway's leading to the rooms need some updating. The hallways together with the rooms almost seems to be of a budget hotel. That's were our disappointment sets in. (Nice book cover, bad book.) Free internet is offered on three computers in the business center right next to the front desk. The views of the city are nice, depending on the room location. If you don't get the Tokyo Tower view, you can always take a look from the front desk. DINING: Didn't eat at the hotel. We had breakfast at Vie de France, which is located in the nearby complex called the City Center. Vie de France offers baked goods and coffee. All this at a fraction of the cost to the hotel. Tokyo is expensive, so look for anything that can save you cash.CITY: Tokyo is huge, so plan wisely. Set you sites in order of priority. We had 3 days in total and didn't accomplish everything we set out to see. To us, Tokyo didn't offer as many eye-popping attractions as many other cities. But Tokyo/Japan is a different culture, differing from even it's Asian neighbors. Spend time to learn how things work. You may also appreciate the peoples way of life, even though it may seem different. English is not widely spoken. So a few words in Japanese should help.NOTE: All our reviews are not evaluated on the exclusively mutual experience at the respective hotel. Our ratings and standards are benchmarked with other hotels that we have stayed.

This was my fourth stay at Park Hotel Tokyo - I actually found out about it from Tripadvisor, and couldn't believe that I had found a chic hotel in a good location for a decent price. I love it more now than ever. I've stayed in several rooms, including their smallest, the single with a double bed. Believe me, their smallest is far nicer and bigger than many of the more expensive hotels. The issue is that most 4 and 5 star hotels in Tokyo have several types of room - standard, deluxe, club, etc. So if you get stuck in a single standard, it's like a tiny outdated prison. Not at the Park Hotel Tokyo, where they don't have different classes of rooms -- all of them are both sleek and cozy at the same time. The toiletries are my favorite of any hotel I've stayed in. The TV is great, internet is by lan (cable provided) and free and fast.Some people say the location isn't the best or there aren't many shops around. Actually there are TONS of shops around. You just have to know where to look. Within a 5 minute walk, there's 2 Starbucks, 2 Subways, a McDonalds, a Godiva, a Vie de France, and in terms of Japanese foods, TONS of options. Just ask the concierge and they can definitely help you. I would recommend that people use the limo bus to the hotel from Narita because it stops right at the hotel, and if you use the subway, you have to find the hotel through the underground labyrinth, which isn't easy the first time you do it, especially with luggage. On the way back, you'll have figured it out well enough to walk to the Shinbashi JR station if you'd like so you can go to Tokyo station and catch the train to Narita. I really love the location because it is very sleek and chic and has a great vibe. There's always performances or art or something that is new and interesting. Ginza is within walking distance (get the concierge to show you on the map). The Shiodome station is right below the building (B2) and it can take you anywhere you want to go. The location is one of the best things about this hotel.In terms of downsides, first, the smoking in the lobby is disgusting. I always brace myself when I come back from meetings or shopping or whatever, because I know I have to hold my breath between the lobby and the elevators. They really need to do something about this. However, I have never smelled smoke in my room (or I never would have been back). The other issue is the service. It's normally great. One reason I stay here is their English is so good and they always help me extensively in getting places. Often times my Japanese contact just gives me an address to meet them at, and it would be very difficult to find without Japanese help. So the concierge has always come through for me, normally with maps, subway timetables, and everything. However, there are a few people on staff who act as though you have leprosy - they don't smile, they act almost annoyed that you are there, I can almost here them thinking "gaijin" in their head. Maybe it's just me, I don't know. But there's definitely an unfriendly vibe from just 1-2 people there. I think they need to seriously fix this because it has no place in a top hotel.Finally, the breakfast buffet. This is the first time I tried it, and it was fantastic. Lots of food, good offerings, and they made me decaf coffee every morning for free (I can't have caffeine). It was 2000 yen, but it filled me up until 2-3 pm, so I was glad to pay that. Again, not so great if someone happened to light up a cancer stick nearby, but thankfully it only happened once.I predict that I will continue staying at Park Hotel Tokyo for a very long time -- mainly because of their affordable, sleek rooms with great English-speaking staff in a fantastic, exciting location.

We stayed twice at the Park Hotel in Tokyo, at the beginning and end of our holiday in Japan. Booked it through Trailfinders in the UK.GOOD- Great location in Shiodome, at the top of a skyscraper, with great metro and train links and only 10-15 minutes walk from Ginza. Lots of coffee shops within 2-3 minutes walk in the Shiodome area (Excelsior Coffee nearby especially recommended)- Clean, modern rooms - a little small but perfectly adequate. Excellent bathroom and shower.- Great views from EVERY room - we actually preferred the views of the harbour than the 'upgraded' view of the Tokyo Tower we had on our second stay- Friendly staff - always welcoming, carried luggage for us, helped us book sumo tickets, kept a bag in storage during our trip to Kyoto - just great- Good value- Hotel map is initially confusing but it's easy to find - a short walk from Shimbashi (Yamanote line) either overground or underground walkways, or above Shiodome station on the Oedo line- Free wired internet in rooms- Tea and coffee in roomsBAD- A slight musky smell in the room on entering, but it soon went. Nothing else bad to say.We didn't try either of the restaurants as there was so much choice nearby, and for breakfast the loser of the coin toss went to nearby Excelsior Coffee for coffee and cakes! Overall a great choice in Tokyo - in a modern but quietish business area but great transport links to the more bonkers places like Shibuya - highly recommended.
the hotel starts on the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media tower. Great views, cool vibe. Nice rooms, a bit small but when in tokyo, how much time do you spend in your room?

I recently stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo as part of a trip to China and Japan. It was our first visit to Tokyo so we did not have a clue where to stay but we took this hotel on a friends recommendation. Firstly Location; There really is no such thing as central Tokyo, I can only describe it as lots of cities within a city. So no matter if you chose Ginza or Harajuku, you still have to travel around by train or metro. The hotel is on an area called Shiodome which is a very new district right next to Ginza (apparently it used to be rail yards). The hotel is housed in the Shiodome Media Tower which is connected to Shinbashi station by a number of elevated walkways (aprox 5-10 mins walk). The fact the hotel is at the top of a skyscraper means one thing - views!! The views are amazing, spanning across the whole city. We were lucky enough to have a corner suite with views over to Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji. The rooms have floor to ceiling windows and you just get mesmerized by the view. The rooms are nice but nothing special, comfy beds, standard bathroom and average in size. The Tv has international channels including BBC and internet is free though not Wifi. So why 4 stars?? The big let down is the breakfast. The buffet offers very little choice and what they do offer is not that great. Hot drinks include one type of coffee and one type of tea. When I asked for green tea I had to pay aprox £4 more!! Also we had to present a coupon every morning which I have never has to do in any hotel I have stayed in, so we usually forgot to take it down an then had to go back to up to get it! Overall Its a great hotel in a good location but save yourself some cash and go room only.

I have made my business travel life in Tokyo much easier since i picked the Park Hotel as the place to stay when there. Thanks to Tripadvisor of course. It's hard to find something bad to say for this place. Location is perfect (Shinbasi and Shiodome stations right next door, Ginza district walking distance away). Fantastic views accross Tokyo skyline. Rooms cosy and stylish and of course ultra clean. Nice staff. The internal court is a great place to meet. Lots of eateries and shopping at underground level. And all that at very a reasonable price.

Stayed here for five nights last week. The rooms, while smaller than typical rooms in the US, were comfortable, clean, and stylish. Service was very good, check-in efficient, and check-out well done. The location of the hotel was perfect for the business meetings I had in the Tokyo business district.

I always rate a city hotel on whether or not I'm actually looking forward to getting back to my room at the end of a heavy day of sightseeing. This hotel far exceeds that standard. It's a really fantastic hotel and a great all-rounder. First, location is excellent. We loved the super modern Shiodome area with skyscrapers, numerous restaurants, shops and dramatic architecture. We ate each day Vie De France for breakfast - take the lift from the hotel to the basement complex. From the hotel it's very easy to get all around the city with the Shiodome Subway connecting directly to Roppongi and Shinjuku and the Shimbashi Station going to Tokyo Station on the JR Line. Public areas are beautiful at the hotel - a real highlight. The atrium reaches from the 25th to 35th floor - flooded with light and stylishly furnished. We loved the giant projector screen in the evening. Bedrooms are small but exceptionally comfortable and homely. The lighting is really adjustable and i had some of the best nights sleep I've ever had in a hotel on the very comfortable bed. The toiletries are really lovely and the mist free mirror in the bathroom is always appreciated. Excellent water pressure from my room on the 29th floor. We didn't pay for Tokyo Tower view rooms and still very much enjoyed looking out over Shiodome. Staff at check in weren't super friendly, but polite and efficient. Other staff we spoke with were warmer and more engaging. A brilliant hotel - relaxing, stylish, comfortable and well located.

I was very disappointed in this hotel. The hotel had the worst service I've ever encountered. First, the concierge's hours were very short so good luck getting advice. When we were able to find the concierge, she told us to go to Roppongi Hills for dinner. Roppongi Hills has HUNDREDS of restaurants, which we discovered when we got there. Not helpful. Second, the concierge was surly and rude.The hotel lobby allows smokers. The lobby is on the 25th floor so there is no ventilation. It's unbearable.The rooms really are tiny. Think college dorm room.Not sure what we were paying for besides a cramped place to sleep and a shower (that was clogged).On the plus side, the hotel is conveniently located near two good subway lines (Ginza and Oedo).

This is a very well placed hotel in a business district. We got around on the underground easily. Not easy to find from Shimbashi station intially but...the reception is on the 25th floor in a lovely atrium with great views of Tokyo., From our room on floor 26 we could see for miles and had a good view of the Tokyo tower- too misty while we stayed for Fuji anyway! The bathroom was the best we had in Japan- very large and well equipped. The buffet breakfast was a let down- very pricey so we went to the arts cafe on the ground floor for a little continental- very pleasant! If you like trains you can see all the different typed pass by and the area itself is very interesting. It is not good if you hate heights as the express lift has a clear window!

We spent 6 nights at the Park Hotel and had a wonderful stay. The room was clean and very quiet (we faced away from the train station). The staff were very attentive and spoke perfect English. The free internet in the lobby was also handy.We didn't have the breakfast in the hotel - I highly recommend Vie De France bakery which is near the entrance to the Shimbashi station. They have a huge selection of wonderful breads and pastries.In terms of location, it was perfect for us as we wanted somewhere quiet to crash after long days of walking . The area is pretty much deserted after 8pm. However, there are still many restaurants to choose from in the neighbouring office buildings - the Caretta centre was our favourite.For those looking for nightlife I would suggest other locations.

Booked this hotel in advance on expedia and got a ridiculous discount through an early booking rate - I suggest you look for that too. Given how expensive Tokyo is, this hotel is an amazing value. The service is excellent, the location is great, the lobby is stylish and the food is supposed to be excellent. The concierge was quite helpful and made our trip to Tokyo more streamlined and enjoyable. While our room was small, that's expected in Tokyo even at more expensive hotels and it was well appointed and had an amazing view of the city. I would definitely stay here again if I returned to Tokyo and would recommend it to all my friends.

Stayed for 2 nights at the the start and end of our trip to Japan. Great location, access to JR Yamanote Line at Shimbashi and also TKY Metro lines also at Shiodome, walking distance to parks, Fish Market and Ginza area.Impressive lobby, friendly service and a fantastic view of TKY tower.Beds a little soft and rooms are a bit on the small size - similar to Sunroute Shinjuku but a slightly classier feel.You pay a premium for the view and the decor in the lobby in my opinion.

We recently stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. The location is excellent, the hotel is very clean. I agree with other review that the rooms are small but by Tokyo standards they are better than most.The hotel lobby is gorgeous and the only slight thing that let this place down was the buffet style breakfast, which was a tad basic. Other than that, a fantastic choice of hotel.

Friends we were traveling with recommended we stay here and we highly recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo. We stayed here for the first five nights and left our suitcases for the next two while we traveled to Kyoto. Staff was accommodating and welcomed us back upon return for our last night. We were allowed late check out as our flight out of Narita wasn't till the late evening. American breakfast buffet at Ty's (lobby level) was convenient and impressive, although price little steep. Hotel is centrally located to Shimbashi Station and is part of the Shiodome complex. Typhoon Melor was scheduled to hit Tokyo in the afternoon and we wanted to brave Tsukiji Fish Market in the morning. Female staff ran down the block in the wind and rain to flag down a cab for us! Bus limo to Narita drops off and picks up at this hotel as well. Musubis in nearby Family Mart were the best!

I was originally searching for a room in a much cheaper price range, a lack of vacancies led me to this hotel. Although I think you can get more room space for your money elsewhere, if you are looking for wow factor, the Park hotel is perfect.

This is a nice hotel in the TV productin area, a kind of business district. We were there over a holiday, so the area was kind of dead. The hoel is close to the fish market, close to the Ginza shopping district, and close to the train station. It is a good area to walk around in, once you figure out the elevated walkways.

This was the second time I stayed at The Park and once again I was extremely happy with my choice. The hotel is in a fabulous position above two metro train stations and easy to move around from being on the Ginza line. It is also walking distance or a short cab drive from most destinations in Tokyo that one may want. The rooms are on the large side for Japan and very clean. The staff are friendly and speak very good English. As Tokyo can be hard to navigate the hotel provides maps and advice on how to get to where you want to go. A little tip is to grab a card to show taxi drivers how to get you home...most taxi drivers have NO English, plus there are a few Park Hotels so be sure they are taking you to the correct one.Enjoy the bar or hope across to the Conrad Hotel (next door, much more expensive and not as good) for a Martini and a fabulous view. The Park also has amazing views from the lobby and the rooms. You'll be high up.

Nice central location in Tokyo near train stations and elevated walkways. Service (as is always the case in Japan) is outstanding. Room clean, but tiny by western standards. Buffet breakfast selection limited. I'd go there again, as long as pricing remains under $150/nt.

We stayed 4 nights at the Park Hotel back in July. The hotel is in the Shiodome media center. It was a bit tricky trying to figure out the underground/above ground walkways, but it's nice that the Shiodome subway stop is pretty much next door, and the Shimbashi train station is a 10 minute walk. Ginza is only a 10 walk, and the fish market about 15 mins. The Hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower, and the lobby is on the 25th floor! The staff is very professional and helpful. We stayed on the 32 second floor. The rooms are small, which is to be expected in Tokyo, but they're extremely clean, quiet, and have a wide assortment of toiletries. To the right of reception, there's a small room with a few computers for free internet. The only downside to the hotel was that the Shidome area is a business center, and therefore pretty dead at night.

Great value for money, good location, excellent views. Service was good too. Well-designed and modern interior.The only negative point was that it was quite a walk from JR Shimbashi Station. Took us about 12 mins with our luggages. But if you take the subway, its almost immediate access to the hotel. On our last night, we discovered another way using the overground bridge which may be faster from JR Shimbashi.If you're going to Odaiba, this hotel is excellent as its right across the Yurikamone line which goes direct to Odaiba.Free internet access from your room was really handy too.Overall, I'd highly recommend this hotel for couples and business travellers.

Arriving at the hotel we were greeted by friendly and helpful staff who could not do enough for us. The rooms were small but what you would expect for Tokyo- they are clean and very modern. The location to this hotel is perfect, close to the JR line and the subway, on the edge of Ginza with lots of shops and restaurants available. What makes it so special though is the outstanding service. You will not be sorry for staying at this hotel.

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo in August 2009 for 4 nights. This hotel is not particularly luxurious in my opinion, but it has many conveniences. I consider this hotel as a very nice mid-range hotel, not something to compete with luxury 5-star places. The hotel lobby is on the 25th floor with a good view of the Tokyo Tower behind it. The center of the hotel is an empty atrium, so all rooms are outward facing with panoramic views. Dramatic views of the lobby from your room floor, which start at the 30th floor. The rooms themselves are reasonably sized, not particularly large nor small for a mid-range hotel. We had a corner twin room which is slightly larger then the regular rooms. They are a little non-descript though in decoration.The beds were comfortable. Bathrobes, Yukatas, (small) slippers are in the room. Free internet through ethernet (ask for a cable if you didn't bring one).  The bathroom had a counter of a molded man-made material instead of granite counters. The de-rigeur Toto heated/spritzing toilet is there. There are toiletries aplenty - good quality but not luxury brand. A very complete set - including razors&shavingcream, hair-brushes, q-tips, nail files, toothbrushes, show caps, aromatheraphy shampoo, conditioner, body wash, etc. A nice touch is the heated mirror which doesn't fog up. Water pressure is good. The entire place is LITERALLY spotless.Shiodome is a high-rise business district without nightlife, but its a good transportation hub:1) 10-15 minute easy walk to Ginza. 2) mass transit at your door-stepa) Shiodome metro station - 15 seconds from 3rd floor pedestrian deckb) Shimbashi metro station - 5 minutes from 3rd floor or 2nd basement floorc) Shimbash JR train station - 6 minutes away (connected to metro station)d) Yurikamome monorail to Odaiba island - 15 seconds The only downside to the hotel is that you can still hear the JR train go by. It didn't really bother us. The restaurants within the hotel are over-priced, but cheaper/better alternatives are just minutes away:1) Walk through the Shiodome metro station and you're in the Tokyo Shiodome Tower and the Pedi-dome food floor with 8 casual restaurants. 2) Walk on the 3rd floor deck to the Caretta Shiodome Tower (4 minute walk), and there's a food floor in the 2nd basement and high-end restaurants on Floors 46 & 47. For breakfast places:1) Excelsior Cafe (Starbucks competitor) in Pedi-dome2) Vie en France (bakery) below adjacent Shoidome City tower outside the metro station3) McDonalds a few hundred feet away from 2) There's a famous garden 2 blocks away, but we didn't have time to see it.

I booked the Park Hotel on the last leg of a 5-week Asia tour as an indulgence. We arrived via bullet train and you DO have to walk a bit from the subway station via underground to get to the hotel elevators. It's a bit of a warren to get there, so be warned. The lobby is quite spectacular with views of downtown Tokyo to enjoy as you wait. We were automatically upgraded upon check-in. Our room was well-appointed and had spectacular views of Tokyo Tower. The decor was elegant and all amenities were as top-notch as you would expect from a high-end Japanese hotel. Staff were very attentive and helpful. The hotel held our luggage for us for an entire weekend while we explored the mountain regions of Takayama, and re-checked-in again upon our return. Would definitely stay here again.

Really enjoyed our stay, staff really helpful, rooms lovely views amazing, once found our way to subway really easy to access Tokyo and sights all around. The breakfasts excellent and catering for all diets, excellent start to our stay in Japan.

We stayed here for a few nights on our first trip to Tokyo. The room was very nice, with amazing views of the city. The restaurant / atrium of the hotel is gorgeous. Although the hotel is in a business district, it's a very good base from which to get around. The hotel staff were very helpful indeed - including booking us tickets to a sumo tournament (an experience not to be missed if you're there at the right time of year). Also very close to the fish market - well worth heading down there very early one morning. We stayed all over Japan on this trip - including in another large hotel in Tokyo - and this place was one of the best, as well as being excellent value.

Stayed at this hotel for 2 nights, you need to walk quite a bit to get to Ginza, or to JR station. The room is very small even I booked the twin corner room., it was alreadybigger than the regular room. However, it is still very small, the TV is small.The bath room size was okay. The carpet has stain on it. It is abouttime to renew the carpet. I would not stay again in the future. I stayed at Granvia Kyotofor a much cheaper price. This hotel rate is high and not worth it.

Based on reviews read here, we tried this hotel and found it to be a lovely, modern hotel in a great location, the Shiadome, as cited, close to restaurants, the metro and the Ginza shopping area. The only glitch was the requested airport connection to the hotel which we paid for online and didn't receive. No one from the hotel was there to meet us; we phoned the hotel with the help of the transportation desk at Narita, to ask about it, & they had no clue how to resolve our problem. We were left to make our own connections to the hotel and pay for them, again. Later, when I asked to have the limo charge removed from our bill, they were totally confused and again, had no answers. Unlike the Western hotels, their English proficiency was limited, which no doubt caused the confusion. Eventually we did get the charge removed. But a better choice would be to take the metro to the shiodome, a much easier and cheaper option.

we found this hotel to be exactly what we expected from japan and more. Our room although not large it was very adequite a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower. a real treat was on waking in the morning we could see Mt Fuji, I was told by our Japanese friends we were extremely lucky we had a clear morning we treasure that experience as our time was short and it was the only oportunity to see Mt Fuji. the hotel was lovely the staff extremely helpful polite nothing at all was a problem for them but this is typical of how we were treated everywhere in tokyo. I would congratulate this hotel it was one of the best on our 3mth trip, we would definitely stay here again, we did not eat here as we were meeting japanese host children so we went with them for meals , i would say though the eating places in the hotel did look inviting, not sure of the cost.

Stayed twice at the Park Hotel Tokyo a year ago during the end of March, beginning of April 2008. With the exception of a hotel in Tsukuba (Okura Frontier Hotel), this was by far the best hotel we stayed in while in Japan. If you're lucky as we were on our second stay, you'll get an amazing view of Tokyo Tower. The location worked out fairly well, there are three subways lines within easy walking distance. The room was quiet, clean and the staff were always helpful. We'll be staying at the Park Hotel Tokyo when we return to Tokyo.

Got here through HRS Booking and felt amazed by this Shiodome Tower Hotel having a reception on the 24th floor. Reasonably sized and well appointed rooms for one person...comfy toilet and ultra available porters and luggage assistants that brought me to come back three times during my Japanese discovery tour..Toilet amenities good but limited tv channels availability.Beware of the Japanese restaurant expensive and not outstanding..

I was in Tokyo for 4 nights for a family trip with my parents and siblings. The Park Hotel Tokyo is an excellent location. Near 2 train stations, within walking distance to Ginza shopping district and located between Roppongi Hills and Shibuya. The staff is friendly and helpful. The rooms are very clean and large by Japanese standards.

We stayed here for 3 nights. The staff are lovely and the rooms are clean, not very spacious, but modern with everything that you would need. There is free high-speed internet in the rooms which is really helpful too. The location is good, walking distance to Ginza and literally 2 minutes out of the door to the subway with direct links to Shinjuku and Roppongi. However, it is quite a business district. The hotel seemed mainly for business travellers as there were quite a lot of business meetings going on in the lobby restaurant. The hotel is costly, £180 per night, but is clean and modern so we had a good stay.

I took my wife, our 2 year old daughter and my wife’s parents to a 10 day trip to Tokyo and Kyoto. I have put up my photos on my website, Shuweb, so if you want to see photos, and more importantly, links to key information about Tokyo and Kyoto destinations, please check out my site. You will also find that I’ve done similar travelogues for other destinations.The Park Hotel Tokyo is an absolute gem – it is the perfect hotel for the business person or a couple looking for a relaxing, quiet time in a high end setting. That said, we took our 2 year old with us, and she enjoyed the stay too (just don’t let her run around and shout in the main lobby, because the voice will echo due to the high ceiling).LocationThe hotel is located on the 25th floor of the Tokyo Media Tower, and occupy the top 10 floors. Because of this, the hotel has a staff who will greet you on the ground floor and take your luggage upon arrival. Alternatively, you can take the elevator up to the lobby on your own. Either way, it’s quite high up there and the elevator ride up is sort of interesting. And as for location, it is about a 7 minute cab ride from the Tokyo train station. Just tell the driver that you want to go to the Park Hotel on the Tokyo Media Tower, and they’ll take care of the rest. Our room faced downtown, so at night we saw the glowing lights of busy Tokyo. It was rather nice. We had a second room (for our parents) which faced the waters – you can see the Hama Rikyu Garden and the Tsukiji Fish Market out in the distance (about a 10 minute walk; more on this later).The hotel is interconnected with the surrounding hotels, which makes it really convenient (called the Shiodome City Center). If you exit the hotel from the third floor, you will find that there are bridges that link the buildings. There are several restaurants in the adjacent buildings, including some high end restaurants (we went to EN, which is located on the 42nd floor. Excellent food and service!) and some regular restaurants (noodles, curry, etc.) that business people go to during lunch and dinner. You will also see that there is a direct connection to the Shiodome train station (non-JR) just steps from the hotel. If you go to the underground floor, you will find a whole new world down there. From here, you can connect to the other Shiodome buildings, but in addition, you will find book stores, cafes, CD store, convenience stores, etc. You will also see that there is an entrance to the subway, in case you want to go to Harajuku or the Meiji Jingu Shrine (maybe a half hour ride on the Oedo line).If you walk even further along the underground passageway (maybe 15-20 minute walk? Not sure anymore), you will find the JR station. Here, you will find the familiar Wing Department store, which is basically a sea of smaller shops and restaurants that sell absolutely everything. If you resurface to the ground floor from the JR station, you will find yourself minutes away from downtown Ginza. Ginza is the Rodeo Drive of Tokyo. Find the main street of Ginza. There, you will find a row of skyscrapers with major brands… and no car on the main road.Lastly, if you want to check out the Tsukiji Fish Market, get up at 5:30am and start walking toward the waters. It’s a 10 minute walk, but just note that the Fish Market doesn’t have a giant sign that welcomes tourists (I think the fishermen actually hate tourists). Eat breakfast at one of the small sushi restaurants located in the Fish Market (from the hotel, go past the big grey Fish Market building, turn right at the gas station, and turn right again after you see a small temple display. Walk down a couple of minutes and you will see a swarm of tourists. You are at the restaurants). As for the Hama Rikyu Garden itself, don’t bother. So in summary, location was good.Room We had a triple on the 27th floor, which meant that there were 2 beds plus a third bed, which was a convertible sofa. These beds had comfortable, fluffy down feather blankets. The carpeting was nice, the bathroom was just fine, the TV had several channels (yes, people, this is Japan, so you primarily get Japanese channels!), and slippers that they have in the room were nice. This is a non-smoking floor, and I didn’t smell a bit of smoke. I really can’t complain about anything.ServiceThe service was excellent. Their staff speak English, and in a country in which good service is the norm, they were terrific. And they carry it out in such calm and tranquility that you would not see in larger hotels. Breakfast buffet is served on the main floor (25th floor), and again, it was rather quiet. Because we were a party of 5 including a 2 year old, they pretty much gave us our own dining room. That was nice.I’ve read here on Tripadvisor that their service is snooty. Could it be that it’s a cultural misunderstanding among the tourists? I speak both English and Japanese, and I didn’t find them snooty (and neither did my wife’s parents, who are not Japanese and don’t speak a word of it)… in fact, the opposite. My impression is that their professionalism can come across as snooty for the non-Japanese who don’t understand Japanese “office culture.”Lastly, we arranged a bus to pick us up to go to the airport (about a little over an hour ride). The cost is around $30 per person, which is about what you’d expect to pay for the service. Just make sure that you reserve the bus ride at least a day in advance.

Sorry, wrote this ages ago, but lost an upload and forgot to repost! We initially booked via the hotel’s online reservation system, but I ended up emailing to see if it was possible to get the 4nt+ discount on a 6nt split stay. It was and they offered us a good rate on a queen room plus discount breakfast tickets.Our taxi driver used the printed out map I had to locate the hotel, so I agree with others – it’s best to take an address/map – preferably in Japanese – as not all drivers we used knew it. As per other reviews, our welcome was warm and impressive. We’d requested an early check in and were relieved they could do it, albeit very discreetly as the guests in front of us had to wait until the standard 2pm time for their room.We were really impressed with our room on our first stay. Good size, lovely amenities and amazing view. Couldn’t see Fuji cos of clouds, but Tokyo Tower was fun to watch by different lights.Although Shiodome is away from the main tourist sights and in a business district, it does have its advantages. The skyscrapers themselves are a sight to behold and it’s brilliant watching all the comings and goings of the trains and people. Also, all the main attractions are really easy to get to from Shimbashi station, which has excellent connections to metro and the JR Yamanote Line.
