Also only 2 stops away from Tokyo station which makes onward travel much easier.The map and directions we got from the hotel weren’t brilliant and we did get lost finding Shimbashi on day one and finding Tsukiji fish market on day 3. But once you work it out, it is really easy to get around. We ate in the hotel for breakfast and a couple of evening meals. The Japanese breakfast was amazing – exquisitely presented and filling. Think we were the only westerners in there most times. Western breakfast, however, is very average. We had the ‘casual kaiseki’ meal a couple of times, which was a delight for the eyes as well as a feast for the taste buds. Excellent if you fancy a treat without going out after a long day of sightseeing or travelling. From our experience, the staff were discreet, rather than overtly friendly. And I was rather disappointed by our second stay. People say they were given bigger greetings on their return trips, we didn’t. In fact, our room wasn’t ready by 2pm and we didn’t get the queen room we had agreed, but a very small single for double occupancy. I wanted to complain and change, but my hubbie was ill and just wanted to sleep and have no fuss. Airport transfer was easy peasy – we used their Airport Limousine Bus, arranged very easily through concierge. We thought we’d have several pick ups but it went directly from Park Hotel to the airport and took less than an hour.One more thing, would also recommend the ‘Zen’ restaurant in the basement of the media tower. Very lively with excellent service and food to match – we loved the tempura set meals.

Just returned from 4 days in Tokyo staying at this hotel. Found it to be very convienient, clean and modern. Superior room was a great size for Japan. Would stay there again. The staff were very helpful and attentive to our requests.

We stayed here for 8 days on our honeymoon in May 2009. We found the staff very helpful and polite. The hotel amenities were excellent and we particularly liked the business centre with free internet access all day. As it was our honeymoon, they upgraded our room to one with a view of Tokyo Tower for free which was a lovely surprise. The views were amazing, and having stayed in a room on the other side of the hotel, I would say the tower view rooms are slightly nicer with a bit more space and slightly nicer decor. Definitely worth paying a little extra for.The hotel's location is excellent. Ginza is just a few minutes walk away and just across the road is the Sio-Site area with about 20 or 30 restaurants to choose from if you don't want to go too far. To the other side of the hotel is Hamarikyu Gardens which is a nice place to go for a walk or picnic. The Park Hotel is next to Shimbashi station where you can take the subway to a lot of the attractions in Tokyo.It's also very convenient to Narita airport as the Limousine bus will drop you off at the hotel door.

I was a tad disappointed with the hotel. Yes it is in a great location, walking distance to the Ginza and with 4 or 5 subway lines converging in the basement of the building and it has won Trip Advisor awards.The hotel is located on the top of a major media office building, part of the massive Shiodome Complex, from floors 25 to 34 with the reception lobby atrium going all the way up to 34. The reception backs onto spectacular city views to Tokyo Tower.The breakfasts are fantastic, get it included in your room rate and there is free internet access. Ask for a room with views over the water.The hotel is part of a group called "Design Hotels" and I had expected something interesting in the hotel's design. The atrium is bland and the rooms are small and very average in design. I had a queen size room which was small particularly the bathroom. The furniture is IKEA inspired with very few extras you would expect from a five star "design hotel". The flat screen TV is small and the channel selection is pathetic in a country with 100s of cable stations. There were basically only 3 English channels, no free movie channels and even just a small selection of Japanese stations. I know you are not coming to Tokyo to watch TV but when the weather is bad it would be nice to be able to watch some TV. There was no ipod outlet which is expected in new modern hotels.Now don't get me wrong, it is a nice hotel to stay at when in Tokyo but the "packaging" in regards to design and room amenities is disappointing.

An unforgettable memory, sleeping with a view on the whole town, it felt like sleeping on the top of the world.Ask for a room with view on the Tokyo Tower, only 15$ more per night, and it's really worth it.Really good location, not far from subway & japan Railways.Hotel located on the top floors of the Shiodome Tower (25-33rd floors).The only thing I could reproach would be the room size although it is quite OK for Tokyo, the rest was wonderful.

I visited the park hotel in may with my wife and 2 young daughters. the rooms have great views and the location is ok as long as you can work out the way to the metro and how to use it with limited english language support! service was polite but a little snooty.A couple of warnings though - 1) do not buy anything from the bars or restaurants without taking a close look at the prices, they are outrageously high - even for a tokyo hotel. Also the service in the lounge restaurant is very slow. If you fancy a snack or a drink, just go down to the basement and head towards the metro, you will find what you want for at least a 3rd of the price.2) do not expect to find a non smoking room, even if it's on a non smoking floor. we specifically requested a non smoking room but on the 2 occasions we stayed here we were given rooms that had obviously been smoked in recently - one on a non smoking floor. Even when we asked to be moved to a non smoking room we were still given one that smelled of smoke. Tokyo is still a place of refuge for smokers, unlike a lot of european cities, but you should be able to sleep in a room that doesn't stink of smoke.

The Park Hotel, Tokyo was the first hotel we stayed in over a two week period, the second being the Claska. Both hotels are at opposite ends of the hotel spectrum. The Park Hotel is situated about 5 minutes stroll from Ginza and the Ginza Metro line. The hotel was large airy and beautiful, although we spent most of our time out until the early hours and then in our rooms kipping; the ambiance was one of peace and quiet especially in such a large business, tourist hotel and area. The staff where always super helpful and the barmen mixed mean cocktails and gin and tonics (jet lag sleep cure). The rooms where typically Japanese and not overly spacious but everything we needed/wanted was there. The bed was super comfy and the bathroom modern and very clean. As a whole this hotel was great and a brilliant base to explore and indulge in shopping, sight seeing and eating out. The price was very good, although we didn't eat breakfast or dinner which might bump up the price, we preferred to explore and find our own little places to eat. The bar was chilled and relaxed and as I said the barmen where chatting, curious and very handy with a bottle. I would recommend this hotel to everyone because it caters to everyone. Finding your way back in the evening was quiet random because of the subways, stairs and various routes but we got there in the end. The Hotel is similar in style to the Mitsui Garden Hotel which is just around the corner, but the Park Hotel Tokyo is cheaper and more spacious. This is my second time in Tokyo and I'm in love with the city and the people. I hope to return every year until I can move over there. I probably wouldn't stay at The Park Hotel again simply because there are just so many other places to experience in the greatest city in the world.

hotel in the shiodome area which may put some people off but I loved the whole area, really reminded me of a blade runner set, because its a media area there is loads of street scene technology which gives the place a cool feel. The hotel is located a short walk from the bay front gardens and near to ginza. Transport links are really good, the hotel actually has a tube station in the bottom floor which is cool.Good location, space age area and small but perfectly formed rooms! enjoy

We had such a fabulous time in Tokyo, and I know part of it was that the hotel was just fantastic! The hotel was a class-act from the moment we checked in. We upgraded to the corner room, which was SO AWESOME, wow, what a view, including Tokoy Tower. This room did have two separate (large) twin beds. After 10 days of vacation with my husband, I was totally fine with my own bed :) and you know, you can always join your spouse if the mood strikes you... The room is just fantastic, high tech and gorgeous. As everyone says, the bathrooms are a marvel. The Japanese are so ahead of us in every way. !! The Park Hotel is close to the train, and just (as with any hotel in Tokyo) understand your maps, and be sure to bring a printout of the hotel map in Japanese. If you like big cities with loads of culture and history to offer you as well as amazing modern style and people, you will LOVE Tokyo, and you should stay in this hotel, hands down. I cannot believe the value for the money, our stay was perfect here. I want to go back very badly, definitely will book the Park Hotel when we do.

Excellent location and a great hotel. 2 metro stations within a short walking distance as well as Ginza area. Away from the busiest areas in Tokyo, but still easy to get everywhere. Frendly staff and the front desk staff speaks perfect english. Would deffinetely stay here again!

This 6 year old hotel is beautiful and well maintained. Their deservingly proud of their hotel's mention in numerous books and magazine's(evident by the staff placing them in the desk drawers), as well as their being voted one of the top fifty design hotels. They also hype their Michelin Star winning restaurant which looked fabolous but I had more interest in food elsewhere. There is a sense of casual luxury everywhere here. The hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower away from the crowds that swarm in certain parts of Tokyo. Felt secluded yet well connected to the rest of the city via the subway, Ginza Line at Shimbashi station and the closer Oedo Line at Shiodome underneath the building. Ginza is within walking distance for those who like to walk. 24 hr convenience store(Family Mart) is located in the subway corridors as well as Seven Eleven(open till midnight) which is the closest ATM that excepts American cards. Hotel signage on building is limited and a few taxi drivers had trouble finding it. No hotel employees are stationed downstairs and the lobby is on the 25th floor with the Tokyo Tower framed by the windows behind the checkin counter. Guest floors start on 26 and therefore all have great views of the city. Rooms are of ample size for japan, and come with pajamas, mini bar, safes, and flashlights in case of emergency. Well appointed, though a little small, bathrooms have premium toiltries and the infamous high tech, heated seat, push button bidet, toilets. Beds are not typical stiff boards I found in other Japanese hotels, they were soft and comfortable. TV's are flat screen and have a decent array of channels. The lobby is in a beautiful atrium. Smoking is allowed in the lobby so those sensitive to smoke may be a little put off(didn't bother me). Premium service provided by staff, from the concierge to the maids to the bartenders, everyone is supremely friendly and you get a feeling their not just doing it because it's thier job. I wasn't staying in a suite or spending mega amounts of money and yet I was called by name by several different staff members during my stay. In particular Wada(bar staff) and I hope I get this right, Mr. Kenji Ishida(bar mgr) were very helpful during our stay. They gave us personalized service and recommended a more local side of Tokyo where tourist don't venture as much. For mixed drinks they take blocks of ice and chip away till it makes what's called dragon ballz(solid balls of ice), very cool. The bar is open late(past 1 am) and is great for unwinding after a long day of exploring with views of the calming, blinking red lights of Tokyo's skyline.

Very good service, as is the norm in Japan, with a small but clean room. The views from the rooms are very good as the hotel is situated from the 25th floor and upwards, we were on the 27th floor and the views were fantastic.The location of the hotel is in the Shiodome centre and this is predominantly a business area. Shimbashi JR station is the recommended transport hub to use and this is a 10-15 mintute walk, through a modern underground subway. Close to Ginza too, a 20 minute walk and also 20 minutes to the Tsukiji Fish Market. Travel on the underground or JR lines are pretty cheap and I would recommend getting a PASMO, stored value card.

Stayed here for 5 nights, then another 8 after a week down in Kyoto. It is an absolutely fabulous hotel, nestled on the upper floors of a quintessential Tokyo skyscraper in the space-age Shiodome district. The staff are so discreet yet faultlessly obliging and the lobby of the hotel is breathtaking. I really enjoyed their free internet terminals by the big bay windows overlooking the fantastic Tokyo skyline. Accomodations are snug - as is de rigeur in Tokyo but the beds are so comfortable, there is a fridge, minibar, LCD TV and radio. Bathrooms are plush and are with fitted with heated toilet seats! View from room is giddying and I love the silence in the corridors with the soundproofed glass and the ten story atrium. You can have breakfast in the lobby but we preferred to buy provisions in the ground floor shop and stow them away in our fridge! There is a restaurant (didn't try it but understand it has a Michelin star) and a wonderful wine bar called TY. Prices are steep in TY but worth it for the dark ambience and stunning views (think Scarlett Johannsen and Bill Murray in Lost in Translation, except that their hotel - the Hyatt - is about a grand per night!). The Shiodome station is just downstairs and is on the best metro line...Roppongi is 4 stops away, Shin-juku 7 stops). You can also walk underground to Shimbashi station which will bring you to Ginza. Walking to Ginza also enjoyable...just ten mins away. Make sure to take the monorail to Odaibe island, it weaves in between the skyscrapers of Shiodome. Plenty of nice bars and restaurants in the towers surrounding Park hotel e.g. Drunken Bears with 80 beers from around the world, To the Herbs Italian restuarant etc. Can't say enough good things about the Park Hotel. Don't confuse it the inferrio nearby Royal Park however!

We've stayed at the Park Hotel twice and were even more impressed with the service, cleanliness etc on our second stay. Staff are attentive and helpful without being over the top. On our previous trip we wanted to look at contemporary jewellery outlets in Tokyo, and the concierge was very patient and helpful in explaining how to find the various obscure locations we had identified. On this trip I stupidly left my mobile phone in the hotel room. Staff were happy to post it back to the UK.The rooms are small by international standards, but a reasonable size for Japan, and were spotless, well equipped, and with stupendous views (larger rooms look out over Mt Fuji on a clear day: if you are staying in a standard room ask for a room on the harbour side as these are slightly quieter and have an even better view).We have eaten in both restaurants. Neither is cheap, but both are good: Tateru Yoshino has a Michelin star, which it deserves, especially for its desserts. Alternatively you can eat well and cheaply in the numerous food courts dotted around the Shiodome commercial area, or walk to the fish market (ten minutes) for the world's best sushi. The hotel is in a large area of walkways and tower blocks, two stops from central Tokyo. Very commercial, and busy (with people, not traffic) both day and night. There are four stations within five minutes walk. Our only slight criticism of the hotel is that its entrance doesn't exactly flaunt itself. We recommend arriving by taxi the first time. The entrance is seriously hard to find from the subway, even using the map provided on the hotel's website, and this is not something to do laden with luggage after a long flight and trip from Narita (as we did).

Stayed 3 nights with wife and daughter (aged 9) and had a great experience in this design hotel with gorgeous view. The hotel is located at the top (25-36 floor) of the Media Tower (that's the name you should use with taxi drivers as many have no clue about Park Hotel). Ginza area is not far away. A taxi to/from the central Tokyo station will take 5-10mn and cost ¥1,250. The room (triple in our case - what they call Premium Twin on their web site) was roomy and very comfortable (first class beds). High speed (31Mb/s download, 21Mb/s upload tested) internet connection available in room via RJ-45 cable. The bathroom was very nice and the room had a refrigerator and a safe. The night stand had a built in clock with alarm, and had built in switches for most of the lights in the room. There is Family Mart shop downstairs by the entrance to the underground walkway for water and Häagen-Dazs ice creams. There are plenty of restaurants (even a Mc Donalds not shown in google maps) in the Caretta Shiodome (stunning view of Daiba island with Rainbow bridge from the 47F restaurants) located nearby or in the Shimbashi area. The only drawback was that even from the 26th floor, you can still ear the Shinkansen and metro tracks noise. Highly recommended though!!!

The Park Hotel was in an excellent location, at the South end of Ginza beside Shinbashi and Shiodome Stations. If you enjoy walking it is an easy walk to the Imperial Palace and Diet.The City Queen room was spotlessly clean but certainly by US and UK standards small, as was the bathroom. The staff were very attentive and extremely polite at all times.I felt the hotel was a business hotel. The prices in the lounge, bar and restaurants were high and would not be readily affordable to an average couple and most certainly not an average family. If this had been a business trip on expenses then I would most certainly have rated the hotel at least as 4/5. This was a leisure trip and therefore I have graded it 3/5.

We spent a total of 6 nights at the Park over two stays in twin bed rooms on the 28th floor. The rooms are modern clean and well equipped with nice amenity kits and tea and coffe making facilities, not much room for luggage but that is to be expected in Tokyo, we also had great views over the city and of the Tokyo tower. The staff we dealt with were both friendly and efficient. We didn't try any of the hotels food outlets or breakfast but noted they were expensive, for breakfast alternatives there are many coffee shops in the immediate area. The location is pretty good for touring the city with Shiodome station 5 minutes walk (access to Roppongi 12-15 mins, Shinjuku 15-20) and Shimbashi 10 minutes walk (Tokyo JR 4mins, Asakusa, Shibuya 15-20 mins). You can walk to the bottom end of Ginza in 15 minutes. There are plenty of restaurants in the surrounding buildings, notably the Caretta and City buildings for those who don't wish to eat further afield. I had an enjoyalble hassle free stay and becauses of the great price in what is a very expensive city I give the Park a 5

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights. We booked a double room without breakfast (we went to a bakery in the Shiodome City Centre for b'fast instead). Hotel lobby is on the 25th floor with a nice view of Tokyo tower. The room is spacious, bright, comfortable and clean. The bathroom is a tad small but clean nonetheless. There are different subway lines close to the hotel (the Oedo line is below the hotel and the Shimbashi, JR Yamanote, Asakusa and Ginza line is a 5-10 minute walk). The Ginza district is not too far and there are plenty of places to eat nearby (on the street and in the Shiodome City Centre). Buffet lunch at the hotel is supposed to be the best in Tokyo (we were out everyday and did not have the opportunity to try it).

I have never written a review before but felt compelled to write about our experience in this wonderful hotel. It has the feel of a boutique hotel of 5 star quality. I can't recall getting quality this high for this price anywhere in Australia. Stunning reception/lounge / bar area with great views. Excellent service. The rooms were very modern and well maintained. I was pleasantly suprised by their size. Found the location was perfect -quiet at night but so easy to access transport with Shinbashi a short walk away or Shiodome just below.Did not eat in hotel but there is a building next door- can't recall it's name - that has several floors of dining options.Would not look elsewhere if I come again

My husband and I spent 2 nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo at the beginning of our honeymoon. We chose this hotel because of its price (we paid about 200 USD/night including taxes) and because the Limousine Bus from Narita stops here. The concierge at the hotel will book your return bus trip for you as well. Overall, we were very impressed with this hotel for the price we paid. It was very clean, the lobby was nice, the rooms were a decent size for Tokyo, and there was free internet access in the business center. There is a subway entrance in the basement of the building and a mini-mart which was convenient for getting beer and snacks for the room. We had the buffet breakfast one morning which was pretty good. Although this is not one of the most exciting neighborhoods in Tokyo, there is a small area of bars and restaurants about a block away from the hotel, and Ginza and the Imperial Palace are within walking distance. We would stay here again.

- Modern Design- Comfortable Room but very small. Even for the Deluxe Corner room.- Small Bathroom as well.- Nice Lobby.- Good value, but was a bit expensive.- Walking Distance to Subway Station. 15 min walk.- Some restaurant nearby. (Caretta, Mos Burger, Tully's Coffee)- In Shiodome which is an office area- Walking distance to Ginza (20 mins), if you can find the way.Had a nice stay.

Well I have to say stepping out of the elevator to hotel lobby and reception is quite impressive.However once you take that second elevator ride to your room what a let down.The hallways are sterile, There was dust all along the baseboards and window sills in the hallway .We stayed on the 30th floor in a city queen room.Wow the room is the size of a postage stamp and GENERIC beyond words.The bathroom is smaller than small.The kicker is the note in the bathroom to keep the door closed while showering as to not set off the smoke alarm!!!!!We travel frequently and always stay in 4 or 5 star hotels, this was a let down. We have to agree the location is wonderful.The staff was friendly.The bathroom products were nice as well.Concierge lacking in restaurant expertise.

After visiting Tokyo for the first time for business in 2007, I decided to return to properly get to know it in April 2008. My wife and I spent a whole week at the Park Hotel and we loved it. Whereas on my first time in Tokyo I managed to cope with the jet lag (probably because I had to work properly) this time it took me a week to adjust. So we spent nights staring in awe at the views from our window, and used jet leg to our advantage to visit the Tsukiji fish market, which is a block away. It is best visited very early in the morning, and we had sushi for breakfast for the first time in our lives. The room size is decent, price is very decent for a hotel of this quality (there is no way you can get a room like this for this price in London or Rome, for example), but the extras are pricey. I only had breakfast once at the hotel, as breakfast for two cost a fourth of the room rate, which I found disproportionate. There was no wi-fi either, which I found strange, as Jpan is supposed to be so hi-tech. I couldn't resist the wine bar at the hotel, though, which was a great option for a sleepless night. If you're after nightlife and bars, this might not be the best place for you, as this is a business area. But is totally possible to manage the subway from here to the more agitated areas like Roppongi. This is also easy to reach by train from Narita.The staff was really friendly (well, I never met a rude person in Japan), and even helped me getting tickets for a show. I am greatly fond of Tokyo and the Japanese culture and I enjoyed every minute of my stay in this vibrant city.

I stayed 6 nights here for the first time. Used to stay at the Dai Ichi Annexe, but this hotel was cheaper and I was impressed by the reviews on this site. Location is unique - in the midst of a futuristic collection of skyscrapers. Less than 10 minutes walk from Shimbashi station. In the evening, it feels like Blade Runner without the violence. Fine view of serene Mount Fuji, right next to the hideous Tokyo Tower on the skyline. Room and service impeccable. My room did not have Wifi, but the hard connection was free and very fast. Comfortable bed. Room safe. One gripe (common to Japanese hotels): no dresser-type space for shirts, socks, etc. Will certainly come back.

Great central location and great value for a high end hotel.The views back over Tokyo and Tokyo tower are awsome and the service was great.Right on the train line, i would recommend for anyone wanting to stay in Tokyo... got a fantastic deal via online research. We will be going back for sure.

This hotel was a very good choice. We didn’t have any luck finding a cheap but well- reviewed 3 star in Tokyo, which is what we would usually go for, but the Park Hotel seemed relatively cheap. We stayed for six nights and had no complaints.The location is very good: it is away from the main tourist districts, which I usually prefer, but it is right by a metro stop so access is no problem. Crucially, it is also walking distance from the tuna market, so the very early start to get to the tuna auction and have sushi for breakfast when the stalls open is painless. For that reason alone, I would stay there again. The area, the Ginza, is also well served for high-end restaurants.The hotel has a beautiful main atrium. I wasn’t as impressed by the view as others: mainly because I don’t regard Tokyo as an attractive city, but the main atrium is a very pleasant place to have a drink and sit around; sometimes they have jazz musicians.The rooms are compact, but everything works as it should and there is a very tempting mini bar. The hotel had free in-room internet access (not Wi-fi). We did not eat in the hotel (even for breakfast) so cannot comment on the food except to say that it did not appear to be a cheap option. We had sushi for breakfast at the tuna market three times. My favourite was Sushi Bun, the first one we tried (recommended in Time Out Tokyo), and which did not have queues as long as you get at Daiwa Sushi or Sushi Dai (which, having eaten at the former, do not reflect an actual difference in quality between them and Sushi Bun).There is also a decent coffee and donut place just down the elevator from the entrance to the Softbank building (go right out of the Park hotel building’s front entrance and then up an escalator). The 7-11 in the basement of the hotel building is also useful for snacks and there are various places to eat in the Shiodome complex.There is no pool or gym.Away from the hotel, I particularly recommend eating at Kanda Yabu Soba in Maranouchi and in local sushi bars.

Fantastic room with amazing views over the city to Tokyo tower. The room wasn't enormous, but that is a given in Japanese hotels, however it was comfortable and had plenty of room for a king size bed, a dining area and a bathroom with a super shower and a funky loo. The reception lounge was great and we really enjoyed the jazz on most nights.

We stayed at the Park Hotel January 1st through the 4th and we were pleasantly surprised with the quality of the hotel. The rates were reasonable considering it was A) Tokyo, B) Practically in Ginza, and C) New Years. I think our 3 night stay was around $770 USD, which is also the result of the plunging dollar against the Yen. Lobby was modern and finely furnished with complimentary jazz performances during 2 nights of our stay. The show was jazz with a Japanese take. Entertaining nearly made the $15 dollar cocktails worth while. Great view of the Tokyo skyline and you could even see Mt Fuji in the distance. Rooms were not large but clean and comfortable. The room had a refrigerator , mainly for a mini-bar, but you could rearrange the contents to store a limited number of perishables. Did have problems with the complimentary internet connection after the first day and was not interested in dealing with the potential communication/language differences from hotel staff to get resolved.Location was convenient to site see from. 5 minute walk to the Yamanote Line (main loop line in Tokyo), which made it incredibly easy to travel the city. 20 minute walk, if you know where you're going, to the fish market.Due to the timing of our visit, New Years, much of the restaurants and sites of Ginza and greater Tokyo were closed. Finding a decent, moderately priced restaurant after dark was difficult. Even when we had directions to restaurants, the streets and addresses were rarely labeled which made navigating futile. If our Eyewitness Travel book said a location was a 7 minute walk, we usually budgeted 30 minutes to reach the final destination.Overall, this is quality hotel that I would recommend to travelers who are considering staying at a American hotel (e.g. Marriot, Hyatt, Hilton, etc) while in Tokyo.

Stayed in the Park Hotel for 4 nights in Sept 08 towards the end of our honeymoon. Our room was small but adequate, same applies to the bathroom. Both were spotlessly clean at all times. We had an amazing view of Tokyo from our room on the 27th floor and we really liked the public areas of the hotel. The location and price are whatever what really sell this hotel. The hotel is right beside Shiodome metro station (you don't even need to go outside to get there!) and is also approx. 7 mins walk from Shimbashi station which has fantastic connections all over Tokyo and beyond. There is a 7 Eleven shop and some casual restaurants and a coffee shop right beside the hotel, which proved very handy. Cocktails at the hotel bar were lovely and the service great. For the approx. £100 per night we paid, well worth it.

We booked the Park Hotel on recommendation from a friend, and we had a great stay.The hotel itself starts on the 25th floor, and from the second we came out of the lifts we were completely looked after.I loved the design of the lobby, with the beautiful atrium that went up to the triangular glass roof.The hotel felt boutique, personal, and warm.The rooms were not huge (we had a standard twin room) but had incredible views over all of Tokyo.As the hotel was quiet when we were there, they upgraded us to the side of the hotel with views of Mt Fuji and Tokyo tower.The concierge spoke reasonable English and helped us with many enquires.The location near to Ginza and Shinbashi station was great, as we had the Japan Rail pass which is only valid on the JR line, (not the metro) which runs through Shinbashi station.This line loops round in a circle to nearly everywhere you want to go in Tokyo.The Shidome center is also very close if you need somewhere to eat close by.Thann toiletries were supplied fresh everyday, and every night live music was played.The breakfast however was very pricey, we ate at the station most days which had lots of reasonable choice.We paid 260 Aus $ a night. We viewed other hotels in the $200 dollar range, including the sister hotel to Park, the Shiba Hotel, and we felt that the extra $60 a night gave us a 5* hotel with amazing views in a great location, at mid range price.Definutely worth it.

The Park Hotel is a very swishy hotel, located on the 25th+ floor of the Shiodome Media Tower. The staff are friendly, speak very good english, but not as friendly as in other hotels. We found it fairly rare to be greeted, but the checkin desk is a few metres back from the lobby, so it wasnt so bad. They have a nice lounge and sometimes music played by a band or quartet. It has a fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower behind the counter. The rooms are big, with comfortable beds and pillows, in-room internet for free (although it is a little confusing reding the instructions) and a great view of Tokyo. It is two stops out of Tokyo station, and one stop to Ginza. The mall below the hotel and joined to the shinbashi station has a few boutique stores, walkways joining to the other shiodome towers (there is like 5 of them) and mini-marts. There is a subway station around the corner from the hotel, next to the subway restaurant, just to confuse. It is also about a 5 minute walk from the Tokyo Central Pokemon Centre, a favourite for young and old alike. This is round the corner from the World Trade Centre, a great place to get views of Tokyo and Tokyo Bay and the Tower.There are a few restaurants in the hotel, we didnt have anything from them, we found the Pedi Shiodome around the corner is the best tower, with lots of places to eat at reasonable prices. Being christmas, there was fake snow in the mall underneath the towers, a christmas show (with prizes) for the kids, carols and differnet events each day. Which was nice.It was nice ot be only a few stops from Tokyo but its a decent 20-30 minute JR ride (all stops) to shinjuku and harajuku from shinbashi.

Stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 5 nights.First impression was good as the lobby is really beautiful with a kind of indoor courtyard where you could see all the floors.On the left you have the lounge and breakfast area, and restaurants on each side. Behind the reception you could see the Tokyo Tower, a great view of Tokyo, and, on a clear day, Mt Fuji (really fascinating).The hotel occupies about nine floors of the Shiodome Media Tower, on the 25th floor and above.The disappointment came from the room, really small and average with some kind of Ikea furniture with an even smaller and very neutral bathroom. The other minor problem was the noise from the train and metro 30 floors below (my room was not on the best side of the hotel).Breakfast was excellent with great choices.The location is convenient as Shimbashi and Shiodome metro stations are only a few minutes walking, very easy to explore Tokyo.The staff was very pleasant and helpful.Overall it's a good and convenient hotel with decent prices (especially for Tokyo) but my room was really too average and small.

After a 8 hr flight from Sydney, we arrived in Tokyo and navigated our way from Tokyo Central Railyway station to the Shidome Tower where the Park Hotel is located on foot. The hotel staff were very welcoming and helpful. English speaking staff were available. The hotel is clean, modern and close to many great spots to eat. Close enough to walk on foot to Ginza area and also to get back on train/subway. Electric City short train trip. Fish markets in walking distance. We booked two rooms for three nights. Would stay again. Tokyo is beautiful and the people of Tokyo are very polite. This is a wonderful city to visit.

We stayed at this hotel for our honeymoon, it is great considering the prices of Tokyo and the space you get for any room.It is close to the undergroung station and within the business district. The hotel amenities are great and the service of its staff never let us down.We would stay here anytime when we go back to Tokyo.

The Park Hotel was absolutely fantastic. The reviews are correct. We stayed for 3 nights early december then left to go to Nagano skiing at Shiga Kogen, we left our unneccessary luggage at the Park and then returned for to the Park for one night on our way home to Perth. The staff were excellent, very helpful, and gave you detailed maps and helpful hints to make getting around easier. We had a spare 2 hours and they even had recommendations for short walking sight seeing trips. The hotel is expensive for food and drinks especially the rooms service. Overall a great hotel, would stay again and highly recommend it.

Tokyo's best kept secret. This hotel was not listed in any of my guide books but I was totally impressed. It was the classic "Lost in Translation" experience I was looking for, but for about 1/3 of the price of the Park Hyatt (and in a much better location than far western Shinjuku where the Park Hyatt is). Shimbashi station is only a 4 block walk from this hotel. Ginza is a 6 block walk. Tsukiji fish market is an easy 10 minute walk... And if you don't want to walk anywhere, the wildly futuristic Shiodome complex where the hotel is situated has plenty of good restaurants and bars. All in all, the Park Hotel took very good care of us and we were sad to leave after 5 nights.

We arrived at the hotel around 7pm and were extremely tired from our long flight in from Seattle. The hotel suggested taking the Limousine Bus from the Airport and that worked out marvelously. It cost about $30.00 US for each of us and it took us to the door step of the hotel. I must mention it was extremely easy to find the Limo place inside the Airport and they were super friendly. Once we arrived a guy from the hotel greeted us and took us up to the lobby. As soon as we looked out the window we saw nothing but the most beautiful view of Tokyo Tower. It only took about 5 minutes to check and we headed to our room right away. Everything was super clean inside the room. They even provide you with the little things you tend to leave behind like tooth brush, q-tips and nail filer.The hotel is located right above a major train station (Shimbashi) and has tons of stores and restaurants within the station. From the hotel you can access the underground station by elevator which is wonderful. The places you can find down there are MacDonald’s, AMPM, Starbucks, a book store, and many more restaurants. Once you arrive within the station terminal you can take a train pretty much any where you need to. From Shimbashi station we took one train to, Shibuya, Harajuku, Akihabara, Ueno Park, and Yokohama just to name a few. Take the train, its so much fun and so cheap plus to hotel will provide you with a map of the rail way and tell you which train to catch.I must say everyone in the hotel was more than helpful. They all spoke English if that is important to you and went out of there way to make sure we new how to get to the places we needed to go. Bravo Park Hotel Tokyo!!!Going to Tokyo for the first time was amazing and staying in this hotel just made it even better.

Stayed here on the way to Australia earlier this year for three days, booked it totally on the strength of reviews on this site and was not let down. Got the Narita Express to Tokyo Station and a taxi from there. Until you have had time to explore the area I would take this approach to the hotel. Underground there is a warren of subway walkways and it can be a little disorientating after a 12 hour flight. It is much simpler to just grab a cab and roll up to the front door. I loved the lobby and reception desk. It was a beautiful day and the backdrop of the Tower and cityscape of Tokyo was a fantastic welcome to the hotel and to the city. Staff are not falling over themselves to make you feel at home, but neither are they rude. Generally I found the service in Tokyo awesome, they are a class apart, very very polite and very friendly.I had emailed in advance to request a room with a view and an early check-in, they duly obliged, which I was most appreciative of as it was 9 am. The hotel is in a great location and is well appointed. We got a great rate and after shopping around I don't really see where you would get better value in the city. The subway system is really easy to get the hang of, surprisingly, as I had been led to believe it was indecipherable. I loved Tokyo, every minute of it and will be returning for longer as soon as i possibly can. The Park Hotel is a great hotel to base yourself in for a great price. Highly recommend it

This is a great place to stay. Be sure to book a corner room for the view. The rooms are comfortable and well laid out. Before you go do a little backround research into the subway system and print off a map in English. It will save you a lot of trouble. Great staff.

We stayed here from November 1-3, 2008. I have to admit we were a little confused when we arrived at the office building and then we figured out we had to go up to the 25th floor. We arrrive late in the day. Once we arrived on the 25th floor, the view was incredible and there was a pianist and bass player playing jazz music. It was so relaxing. The staff immediately greeted us and took our bags. Everyone seem so respectful and helpful. When we arrive in our rooms, the person who helped with bags mentioned no tips are accepted by the staff. They have a free busines center with two computers for anyone to use. The breakfast was good and nice variety to choose from. The rooms are small but efficient. The toilet is programmable and this is common in Tokyo. Overall, this hotel was a good value and convenient to the subway, restautants, and shops.

We were in Tokyo for five nights and we spent two of them at The Park Hotel. Lobby and views are impressive but the rooms are a dissapointment - they reminded us of a slightly upgraded Travel Lodge. You can also find same cost hotels in much better locations (with an atmosphere which this hotel has none of). The concierge was also useless. We tried to book a trip to Hakone and arrange a few restaurant bookings for the following nights, but she could only tell us what we already knew from leaflets and could never seem to get through to the restaurants, which we ended up booking ourselves. Luckily my husband has been to Tokyo before so has a little knowledge of the different areas and the langauge but, if we had been first time visitors, we wouldn't have been able to rely on this hotel for helpful advice.

Booked through Agoda. It was cheaper than the hotel website.We put our bag in the hotel for a few days while we went to other city before coming back to Tokyo. They were so nice to keep our bag.Getting there is very easy by the Yurikamome line. It's actually in a walking distance from JR Shimbashi. But it's just right beside the exit of Yurikamome Shiodome station. It's on top of office building, can't remember what's the lobby floor, 2x th?The lobby is awesome. Tokyo tower is just right at the window of the lobby. Too bad our room doesn't have that view, but it's still nice nonetheless. But I unfortunately forgot to take picture of the nice room. The coffee in the room is in a special packet, so cool. It's a modern stylish hotel.Tsukiji fish market is also in a walking distance. But we had no idea where is the fish area is and sick because having had too much sushi. A bit dangerous with the people riding motors(?) around so fast, but it was interesting.Tsukiji market is also reachable by train. It's one station away from the hotel by the subway. Convenient. Though we went by taxi.The airport limousine bus was available for us right in front of the hotel.

We stayed here for 3 nights at the start of a group tour of Japan. Access from Narita was easy - we chose the Keisel line (Y1000 instead of Y3000 for the Narita Express, which only saves 15 minutes) with an easy transfer via the subway system.The hotel is very well situated next to the Shiodome station. It was a quiet location - especially as the rooms start at the 26th floor - and the hotel itself was quiet with good sound insulation and soft-closing doors.The public areas of the hotel are on a grand scale and very comfortable. The staff were excellent and helpful. The room was not massive, but had everything we needed. The included buffet breakfast (Western or Japanese) was terrific. The restaurants looked good but were expensive, but there are plenty of eating options either at Daiba (5 min ride on the monorail), around Shimbashi station (5 min walk) or in the Ginza district (10 min walk).Yes, an excellent and convenient hotel!
We stayed at the Park Hotel for a stop over weekend in Tokyo in August. Awesome staff, location and yummy breakfast. We were upgraded to a room with a view! Highly recommend it.

We stayed two nights at the Park Hotel in late October. Overall, we had a good experience although this hotel is not perfect.The hotel is quite stylish, very modern. The lobby has a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower at night, and the hotel rooms themselves also have wonderful city views. All the furnishings were carefully chosen and look quite nice. A neat feature is the heated mirror which keeps an area usable even after a steamy shower.However, as is common in modern design, the hotel is not so practical. The rooms are small, which means doors open into each other. The bathroom is cramped and has bad ventilation. You have to prop the door slightly open and keep the light on in order to dry it out. There aren't enough towel racks so you have to hang towels in the shower. The desk is also very small and there is not much space to place luggage. The location of the hotel is convenient within the city, although it is a good walk from the JR Shiodome Station; you have to go through two malls, and up multiple escalators and elevators to reach the hotel lobby. The path is somewhat confusing the first time too. It is also very close to Tsukiji fish market, making that early morning trip much easier.On the plus side, the staff was excellent and very helpful. Their english was the best of the three hotels we stayed at in Japan. Overall it was a very nice place to stay, but perhaps not the best.
Absolutely fantastic hotel. Great staff, great central location, amazing views, very accommodating. Highly recommended.

We really enjoyed the stay at the hotel. The prices were reasonable for Tokyo, the location was quiet and convenient. It is located in the business district which is very quiet in the evenings and weekends which we really appreciated, especially after a day's walk in busy Shinjuku or Ginza. Great place to rest! The room was really comfortable and nice, no complaints at all. For the taxi ride, be sure to state Shiodome, Park Hoteru, Media Tower, next to Conrad if they have no ideas. There are many restaurants within a short underground walk to the Caretta Shiodome. Check the Caretta Shiodome's website for a list of restaurants! Starbucks in the Conrad's basement which is next door. Train and subway stations are within a short walk underground. There is even a supermarket right above the train station on ground level where you can buy quick meals as well. Can walk to Ginza or take the subway. The subway line right outside the hotel on the second level takes you on a scenic ride to Odaiba where there's a great indoor hot springs, Oedo Onsen Monogatari. Also, a nice walk to the Tsukiji market for great sushi breakfast when you are jet lagged. Left the hotel by airport shuttle booked through the hotel which was easy. A bonus was there were different all-girls bands playing every night we were there!Will definitely stay there again without question if we ever go back to Tokyo!

Very modern and elegant hotel situated in Shiodome which has great transport links. We stayed there for 4 nights as part of our honeymoon and found the hotel a great place to stay. Getting there was fine - we just took the Friendly Airport Limousine service which took just under an hour and a half (traffic), and which stops at the hotel as one of its stops. Checking in was smooth - our travel agent had organised a bottle of champagne for our arrival. Our room was on the 33rd floor and had amazing views of Tokyo Tower and all of the surrounding area. The bed was comfy, everything was clean. We had the infamous japanese toilet which comes with bidet and shower. The anti-fog mirror was great - I'd never seen one before! We didn't have any meals in the hotel restaurant, but there are quite a few restaurants in the surrounding areas. Overall, staying at the Park Hotel was a really good experience - the building is so modern and sleek, the staff were extremely helpful and friendly, and the views were breathtaking.

Fantastic hotel in the Shiodome district! Great location (only 2 stops from Tokyo station, and right near the fashionable area of Ginza). We can also walk to the fish markets in about 10 minutes. The views are amazing (reception is on the 25th floor) and the hotel is stylish and spotless. We stayed there on two occasions (once on the 31st floor and then on the 33rd floor), so the view you get of Tokyo is breathtaking and worth every penny you spend. The rooms are comfortable, bright and well proportioned, so we were very happy with our decision to stay there. The hotel just celebrated its 5th birthday so it's thoroughly modern and sleek. In addition to all of this, the service was excellent too, so we would totally recommend the Park Hotel both for business and leisure travelers - we will certainly return next time we are in Tokyo.

Stayed here for three nights in September as part of a longer trip. The hotel is located in a business district but is close to the subway station and not far by subway from entertainment areas - we never felt we were too far away from the action!Note - my taxi driver took me to the similarly named Royal Park Hotel, which is across the street, by mistake. The Park Hotel is located on the upper floors of the Shiodome Media Tower, in the same building as the Kyodo News agency, so you may wish to ask for that if traveling by taxi.As previous reviewers have mentioned, the hotel is well designed, rooms are reasonably sized for Tokyo, and the view is great since it is on the upper floors of the building. We had a view of the Hamarikyu garden and the Sumida river. Service was excellent, bathroom was nice.The cafe in the lobby is pleasant but in my opinion overpriced (800 JPY for a coffee versus 250 JPY in a cafe). There is also free internet access from a little computer room just off the main reception, with a nice view of Tokyo Tower - only grumble here is that only one of the two terminals allows access to online email services like gmail/hotmail.Overall, one of the best hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo - would definitely return.

This hotel is quite spectacular in many ways. First, its lobby starts on the 25th or so floor; the wall behind the reception area is glass-panelled and you have a first-rate view of Tokyo. Then the stunning view repeats itself once you in your room (don't take the cheapest room category - no good views there). It's the Lost in Translation feeling. On top of that, the lobby's atrium extends for some 10 to 15 floors. Architecturely the place is quite a sight. That being said, the rooms are on the smaller side, as could be expected in Tokyo. But everything is new (the hotel just celebrated its 5th anniversary) and very clean. Moreover, the hotel is centrally located. Lots of restaurants around and a 10 min. walk over to Ginza.

We went to stay there for 5 nights, based on the positive reviews here. We weren't disappointed - its rooms were small but we didn't expect anything else in Tokyo (for the price anyway). Service is as good as any other hotel in Tokyo. My partner is not 100% keen on the location but I thought it was fine - Shiodome had good transport links, and lots of restaurants. The only issue was that we normally shopped in the west side of town (Shinjuku, Shibuya) and this hotel is on the east side. But you can get to those locations within 30 minutes tops. I'll definitely consider staying there again.My only complaint was that there was no gym, but I don't think many hotels in Tokyo actually have one anyway...

My wife and I stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 3 nights and had a great experience. We were able to get a special rate with a minimum of 4 night stay. Due to complications with our flight we only needed 3 nights and were able to cancel one night and keep the 4 night rate with no problems. The Friendly Airport Limousine Company has bus service from the airport to the front door of the hotel, which takes about 60 minutes and cost 3000 Yen per person (they take credit cards). The Tourist information desk will help you find them, and will help you if you decide to take the subway. The bus is much more convenient and there is a lot less to worry about than taking the subway which cost about the same. A very friendly hotel porter met our bus, took our bags and guided us up to the 25th floor for check in (the elevator is located next to a small desk with a hotel sign on the ground floor lobby, and only goes from the 1st floor to the 25th floor and up, which makes it easy just in case no one is there to help). She then took us to our room and explained the features of the room, and gave us a map of the hotel area to help us find the subway stations and local attractions (map from website: http://www.parkhoteltokyo.com/directions/pdf/park-hotel-tokyo_map.pdf). The area looks like a maze, but with the map and most signs in English it’s actually pretty easy to navigate. We had a standard room without a tower view, but were very happy because we had a room with a view of Tokyo Harbor instead. I don’t think any view could be bad, because all rooms are above the 25th floor. The room was a little small, but very comfortable. The bathroom was very nice with the heated toilet, built in bidet, anti-fog mirror and portable shower head. The room also had a refrigerator, but no microwave (use the tea pot to heat up water for the ramen noodles). The night stand had a built in clock with alarm, and had built in switches for most of the lights in the room. The hotel apparently has personalized pillow fitters that come up to your room and sizes your pillows for no extra charge, although you will not find any literature about in the room. Unfortunately we didn’t have time to try it. They also have a very expensive room service menu, and also a service for in room massages (the prices didn’t seem that bad). The Family Mart downstairs by the entrance to the underground walkway was very convenient and much cheaper than the mini-bar. There are also a couple of restaurants down there with English menus. We didn’t eat at the hotel restaurant. The business center has 3 computers with free internet and a great view of the city. The concierge was very helpful, from finding hours of a museum to telling us what trains and boats to catch. There is a boat that will take you from inside Hamarikyu garden (5 minute walk) north to Asakusa. It cost 300 Yen to access the garden and 720 Yen per person for a one way trip. English is spoken by most in the hotel and was never a problem. Overall with the great service, good location, and comfortable rooms we will definitely stay here again the next time we are in Tokyo.

I stayed 5 nights in this hotel in a single room type CITY QUEEN. LOCATION: It is located in the Shiodome area, next to elegant Ginza. The area is very quiet, but with very convenient connections with no transfer need from Shimbashi and Shiodome to Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ueno, Tokyo Station, Roppongi, Odaiba, Yokohama, ... Trains/metro run until 12PM. Great views from the reception and room. I used a bus from the airport that leaves you in front of the building.ROOM: The rooms are located in the top floors of a very modern, elegant building. Room is a bit small, but clean, comfortable.STAFF: very friendly and ready to help in all you need to move in Tokyo. Almost all staff speaks some basic English and some of them good enough to communicate without problems. I arrived in an early flight and they managed to let me check-in 2:30 hours before normal check-in time, which I appreciate after a long trip from Europe.BREAKFAST: I had 3 times breakfast. You have a big selection of food and the quality was quite good.INTERNET: you have free LAN connection in your room, but no WIFI. Next to reception you can use 3 computers for free.If I come back to Tokyo I would probably go to same hotel again.

My wife Bel and I stayed at the Park Hotel for the fist 3 nights of our honeymoon, from Jan 16 to the 19th, 2008. I realize that it was the start of our honeymoon, and that there is the threat of being blinded by warm and fuzzy feelings when looking back at our time at the Park Hotel, but I will try my best to be objective here.We landed at Narita, which is a good hour to 90 minutes away from downtown Tokyo. It really doesn't matter which hotel you stay at, you are looking at a long commute into town after what was likely a mega-long flight to Tokyo (13 hours for us from Toronto BTW). Word of advice, opt for the bus into town instead of the train. Its about the same price ($25 per person). The bus will take you right to your hotel's front door, the train will take you to a subway station where you will have to carry your bags into a subway to continue on. After a huge flight, I really didn't feel like "amazing race-ing" it to my hotel. The extra 10 min the bus took was fine.The Park Hotel is located in a convenient part of town from what I could gather. Although Tokyo isn't known as "walking" city, we did find that quite a lot of sites were within walking distance (ie, Tsukiji Fish market is 5 min, Ginza 10, Sony showeroom 10min, Imperial Palace 15min). The hotel is located in TV land. It is located I believe on the 25th floor of a skyscrapper right beside a subway and train station. The entrance or lobby to the hotel was very impressive. We arrived at night to the soothing sounds of a light jazz in the atrium played by a talented little trio. Check in was a piece of cake, the staff very polite and respectful. The reception desk itself sat infront of a large panaramic window offering stunning views of the city; particularily the Tokyo tower (exact replica of the Eiffel Tower) and Mount Fuji. It didn't matter how many times we walked through the lobby that view always stopped us in our tracks for a moment. It was just a really cool, soothing lobby/atrium set up, which pleasantly surprised us. Relaxing there with a cold pint of Saporo at the end of each day was immediately something we grew fond of. Front desk was nice enough to upgrade our room for our honeymoon. Don't be shy to let them know, it doesn't hurt to try. We ended up with a fantastic view of the city. The room itself was not too shabby. Though it was on the small side (which was expected), it was big for Tokyo standards. The room was very comfortable, very very clean, bed fantastic and washroom fully loaded with any toiletry item you may need (the toiletry items were so cool I have to admit we still have some at our home today...still can't find a wash cloth as cool and effective as the one they provide for you at the Park!). The washroom was actually pretty crazy...I couldn't believe how high tech it was (toilets with buttons, heated seats, retractable bidet arms.....just incredible). Even the mirrors had some sort of chemical on them which prevented the section of mirror above the sink from fogging up, even after the steamiest showers. While the hotel didn't have a pool, it did have a small but decent business center with free internet. The computer room was actually just to the right of reception and also offered that stunning view that I described above. Though we weren't there during peak season, we did find the rate we paid to be very reasonable for what we got. I believe it was about $200 CDN per night. Quite a bargin consideing the sophistication, elegance, prime location, room quality, and stunning views the hotel had to offer.I wouldn't think twice about staying at the Park Hotel if we were ever to return to Tokyo. They just do a lot right. You would really have to knit pick to find something wrong with this place.Enjoy your stay in Tokyo. It is an incredible city, with amazing culture, architecture, and the friendliest most respectful people (the grounds crew at the airport bowed at our plane as we left the gate for crying out loud!). With some 30 million people living in the greater Tokyo area, the city is a marvel of modern transortation. The city really operates like clock work; it was just facinating to see first hand. The Japanese really make the logistics of public transportation an art form.Enjoy your time in Tokyo, probably one of the most advanced cities in the world. We did despite the jet lag, and hope to return one day soon.Safe and happy travels to all.Cheers, Anthony

We stayed on our first 3 days in Tokyo and this hotel is a well suited nice stylish hotel perfect for all your needs.We booked a premium king room. The room was georgious and quite big. However my one complaint about this hotel is NONE of their premium rooms have a view of facing Tokyo tower. Only standard and corner rooms have a tower view (or so I was told , when i enquired) so bear this in mind when booking. You would think premium meant not only larger room but also better views, sadly not so. However the city view from our room was adequate.We had breakfast each morning , expcept on final moring when we had to catch a shinkansen to Hiroshima. The breakfast was ok not huge but satisfying.They have 2 computers and a laptop with internet connection which was free of charge. The lobby is beautiful and nice for a drink or two late at night.The hotel is well connected to the JR and Metro lines. However can be confusing arriving for the first time. I recommend arriving at shiodome metro station , its closer.We also found the family mart on the ground floor of great help.Please email if you would like to know more about hotel e.t.c I am happy to advise from my experience.

Service by hotel staff is fantastic eg our bags were out of the boot of the taxi and inside the hotel before I'd had a chance to pay the driver! Also very helpful desk staff for booking taxis etc.The lobby area is a cocktail lounge which has its own jazz band playing most nights, but you really need to get out and get on it elsewhere ... Room spotless, and okay size, with great view out over city. Bathroom something else: heated toilet seat, with all sorts of apparatus! a condensation-proof mirror ... with all your usual 'boutique' bathroom stuff refreshed daily.As stated elsewhere, at the bottom of the building is a small mart where you can get some essentials in eg water. Also tube stops are right there for both subway and Yamanote 'circle' line. Tubes - spotless too - run until about 1 am - worth bearing in mind as taxis are relatively expensive, and can be hard to get late at night, though there are seemingly millions of them about!Oh - if first time there, forget Rappongi - Shibuya and Shinjuku are where it's at. (So only 'improvement' on Park Hotel I can think of is to find a similar quality hotel in those areas.)Time Out Tokyo really good too for info on where to go, but sometimes you just have to take the plunge ie you find a bar is up on the 4th floor, accessible by lift, so you have no idea what it'll be like. But we were only stiffed the once ie charged for food put out for us that we didn't request (thus a £15 drink!) ... otherwise really great cool bars, people friendly . Lastly, the food is fanatstic - and not expensive. How? Use your eyes, and eat where the locals go! Drinkswise the beer is London prices ... and Asahi won my taste contest.
Enjoyed a two night stay at this stylish and extremely friendly hotel en route home from australia. The only criticism would be the rooms are very small.

We loved this sleek and stylish hotel. The entire staff went out of their way to be friendly and receptive. English was not a problem. The place is beautfiul and in an ideal location surrounded by office towers and shopping (Ginza only a 10-minute walk). Subway and JR lines can be reached via underground passageways. The Yamanote Line will get you all around the city. Shinjuku and Roppongi are easy rides on the Oedo Line. There are several restaurants in the area. If you have a craving for Western fast food, Subway, McDonalds, and Nathans are all located within the Shiodome complex. We would not hesitate in recommending this hotel and look forward to returning in the (hopefully not too distant) future.

Had 3 great nights at this hotel. Rooms weren't massive but were fine and Tokyo is an exhausting city if you have just 3 days to explore!We ate here on the first night and paid extra for buffet breakfast each day. Was worth it and saved the hassle of finding food outside and set us up for the days. Food was good each time.Staff couldn't do enough for you. Very polite, welcoming and friendly. There was also always some entertainment in the foyet area, be iit a pianist or a jazz band making it a relaxing place to have a couple of beers.Very well priced and great location. Easy to find.

Stayed at the Park Hotel for two nights, then returned after a night away at Hakone, for another night. Hotel was immaculate. Great views. Fantastic staff who were helpful with great English. Free internet access from the room. Rooms were a reasonable size. We had a twin room, and there was room to have both our suitcases down and open, and still move around comfortably. Room had a bar fridge, table, two chairs, desk and flat screen TV. Good sized bathroom. There was no problem with the hotel holding our main luggage when we left for a night away, and we were recognised and welcomed back on our return the next day. Hotel was walking distance to two train lines - subway and JR lines. Also easy walking distance to the detached gardens, Ginza, and the fish market. Other attractions and locations were easily located via train. Great hotel for a reasonable price. Would highly recommended it.

This hotel is located in the Shiodome Media Tower, from the 25th floor upwards and is an ideal location for exploring Tokyo. The subway is directly connected to the hotel so getting around couldn't be easier.There is a 'Family Mart' convenience store on the ground floor which is ideal for drinks & snacks and there is a 'Subway' sandwich shop just outside the hotel on the 3rd floor.The staff couldn't be more helpful and polite. The rooms are clean, spacious and very modern.Internet access in the lobby is free, best time to access this is midday as it can be busy at other times.The centre of Ginza district is just 15-20 walk away with it's high class boutiques and jewellery shops, everything else is best traveled to by the subway or other rail links.The weather was very hot and sticky, but there is a pleasant breeze.Western mobile phones will not work in Tokyo, apparently there are hire facilities but we chose not to bother.Don't hesitate in booking this hotel, you won't be disappointed.

I've stayed at the Park more than once and think it's an excellent choice - good rooms, location and value - and deserving of its Tripadvisor rating.Positives -Reception, restaurants and rooms have excellent views (starting on the 25th floor), and are also stylishly well equipped and furnished.Nice bar and restaurants.Really good value for Tokyo, in comparison with other hotels of a similar standard.Free use of internet etc.Negatives - Anyone who has been to Tokyo knows that the city is so expansive that there is no such thing as a perfect location. However - if you're going to be spending most of your time in Shinjuku/Shibuya this may not be the ideal choice.24 hour facilties - would be good to offer a lounge with 24 hour food etc - especially for business travellers.

Booked this hotel after seeing the great reviews on Trip advisor. It was a great hotel. The best feature was the subway stop below the hotel (Shiodome). This made it so easy to get everywhere in Tokyo. The room price was so reasonable too for Tokyo! The rooms were a bit small, but I was expecting that for Tokyo. The bathrooms were on the smallish side too and did have a kind of funny, musty smell, perhaps from a lack of ventilation. We just kept the bathroom door shut and it didn't bother us. Even with that, the room was clean and had newer furniture and free hi-speed internet (not wireless though). The location was great, we walked to Ginza and there was a great park across the street. The Tsujiki Fish Market is only one stop away on the subway line! It was nice staying in this area because there were less people around than other areas of Tokyo (like Ginza/Shibuya/Shinjuku). So if we wanted to go shopping or to restaurants, we'd hop on the subway and go to those busier areas, but when we got off the subway at our stop, Shiodome, it was quiet and not crowded at all and more peaceful.

A good choice - location is handy and safe but in a business area - don't let it put you off though. You are so handy for the excellent subway system. Rooms are compact but ultra clean. The toilets are something else!! We had a super view of Tokyo Tower and Mnt. Fuji - simply stunning. I would stay here again.

Customer service in Japan is legendary and rightly so. The Park Hotel lives up to these high standards with excellent, friendly service. As a bonus, the staff all seemed to speak very good English. The ten-story atrium is beautiful. Rooms are on the small side but modern, bright, quiet, and (most importantly) immaculate. We had a lovely view of the bay and Hama-rikyu gardens. Loved it!

This was my husband and my first trip to Japan - on our own. Staying at this hotel was a perfect base. Our day tours picked us up from the lobby plus access to the JR, subway and every train line you can image. (note: it took me several days to learn the system and once we got it it's super easy and convenient.)Location:Near upscale Ginza, location was a good start to get around Tokyo and beyond (like we did to Kamakura) I agree with other reviewers - nightlife is hard to find - need to go to Shibuya or Shinjuku for that. Consider the location a business location but the peace is welcomed after long days.Room:Room was clean but a bit smaller than our Kyoto hotel room. But after long hot days, the room was perfect. The bed was super comfy and bathroom was great. I already miss the heated toilets.Service:They staff was super pleasant and excellent. Before arriving, the concierge arrange getting tickets for a Tokyo Giants game for us. I can not complain as for their service was the best I have experienced and I travel a lot to know.Overall: You can not go wrong with this choice. If I return (crossing my fingers I do) I would return.

This hotel was a great find. The rooms were a reasonably spacious given Tokyo standards, and I would definitely stay here again. Ginza is a short walk away, and the hotel is near Shimbashi station (a major train hub).However, I would caution you if you are seeking nightlife. The hotel is tucked in amongst a cluster of office buildings so you won't find bars and clubs right outside your door. You'll either have to walk to Ginza or grab a train.

The lobby on the 25 th floor of the Park Hotel Tokyo has a fabulous view, great service, a very relaxing atmosphere, and from there on it just gets better. The rooms are average sized, but has all the amenities you need – even though you'll have to make do without wifi. The bathroom's a pleasure to use, the air condition is very responsive, the beds are very comfortable and the rooms are well kept. On the ground and underground levels of the building you will find a convenience store, and a small food court.Transportation wise, you'll have no complaints. The elevator from the lobby takes you straight down to Shiodome station which serves the Toei Oedo metro line circling central Tokyo. The Siodome also functions as an end stop for the Yurikamome mono rail, which'll take you to the Odaiba area across the Rainbow bridge. From Shiodome you also have underground access to the Shimbashi station, which serves the Ginza and Toei Asakusa metro lines, and the very efficient Yamanote train line. Shiodome is also a stop on the airport limousine routes.The area around Park Hotel Tokyo consists mainly of hyper-modern, commercial skyscrapers, but sights such as the Tsjuki fish market and the Hama Rikyu garden is a ten minutes stroll away. Also the area around Shimbashi station a few minutes away offers a wide variety of small shops, cafés and pubs.There are no real downsides with the hotel, but a few things are still worth mentioning. The lobby, which can not be avoided on your way to and from your room, is not smoke free. The breakfast is not included in the room price. And although the area around Shiodome can offer both great transportation, opportunities of shopping and recreation, it is not the most exiting area of Tokyo. By day you'll have no problem getting anywhere in the city, but taxi will be your only choice by night as both the metro and city train lines close between midnight and 1 am. Also be sure to keep cash, as the ATMs accepting foreign cards are hard to find, but this goes for the city as a whole.All in all it's not difficult to recommend Park Hotel Tokyo!

Gorgeous hotel - excellent views, perfect for getting around Tokyo. Shimbashi station next to hotel and runs on the main yamanote line, where all the major stops are. Staff were great and very helpful.

Myself and my wife Suzanne stayed here for 4 nights as part of our honeymoon.On our arrival we received a bottle of champagne,as a little honeymoon present ,which was nice.We were looking for a nice,clean and prices that did'nt break the bank.We really liked this hotel.The hotel does have a business feel to it which some might not like.The rooms are tiny,I mean really small but clean and modern.I had never stayed in Japan before,so maybe smaller rooms are the norm.The room had fabulous views of the city and of the Tokyo Tower which were spectacular.I must mention the toiletries which were really nice.The hotel is located close to a lovely park and to the subway.The staff were all really helpful and polite.We only stayed for a short stay but we will be back and we will stay in this hotel again.

Stayed four nights here in June. This hotel is exceptional - beautifully designed and with a fantastic, relaxing atmosphere. Everything was so calm and tranquil. Stunning views of Tokyo Tower from our bedroom - 2808. The hotel is spotless and immaculately cleaned. Staff could not be friendlier. Would not fault one thing and hope to go back soon. Really miss it now!

This hotel was very comfortable and Modern. The room was quite small but this is usual for Hotels in Tokyo, but well appointed.There were fantastic views from our room, and the public areas.Breakfast was good, and the Airport transfers efficient.Great hoel, well located and easy access to the metro system.

We stayed at the Park for three nights and loved it. The hotel is so stylish the lobby area and bars are great places to relax and chill out. As the hotel starts on the 25th floor views are amazing from all areas (even the internet room has mindblowing views)The hotel has two Michelan star restaurants, we dinned at the Japanese one and the food was amazing.Our room was a touch small but the bed and covers amazing, like sleeping in silk. The room had all modern features and teh view was amazingThe hotel has very easy access to a subway station that takes you to all parts of the city and is walking distance from Ginza A great hotel and at the price £100 night amazing value in tokyo

We recently stayed at this hotel having seen it recommended on Tripadvisor. As we only had a couple of days to explore Tokyo we thought this was a great location - very accessible from airport and hotel situated adjacent to an underground station. We could get everywhere pretty quickly from here, especially the superb fish market (Tsukiji) and Hama Rikyu Teien garden.The hotel is in the Central Busness District area so staff are super efficient with great English. Hotel and room were spotless with amazing views.Good bar - great evening views - amazing Barmen who does impressive ice carvings.

I had a lovely stay at this hotel. The staff are very respectful. The room is clean. the view from my 31st floor was amazing. The breakfast was different than I would normally eat but there was lots to choose from.Internet in the room was good. toilet pot ...heated spayed and shower me along with a heated seat.he he ...I would recomend this hotel. be warned the lobby... reception is on the 25th floor, that puzzled me at first.Its close to all amenities. Oh no swimming pool or gym..

We recently returned from our trip to Japan. We stayed in Tokyo for 3 nights at this hotel. Hotel was nice but the hallway to our room smelled a little musty. It might have been from the lack of air conditioning in the halls. there was air condition in our room and the room was very clean. the staff was helpful but we did have some language barriers. it was conveniently located to the subway and the fish market which was great. we went to the fish market for breakfast and at first i thought it was going to be gross eating fish but it turned out to be so good and of course fresh.

We felt that the Park was a great bargain for Tokyo. Though the rooms are not the fanciest, they are very comfortable and offer exactly what we needed. It was the quietest hotel we have ever stayed in, we were in a room right next to the elevator and did not hear a thing (and I'm very sensitive to noise). We had a laptop and they did not charge for internet access, and there is a cable in your room. Everyone was very helpful, welcoming and most people spoke English. One employee even ran down the street to hail a cab for us (we couldn't envision that ever happening at any US hotel we'd ever stayed in). Subways are very easy to get to and there are a lot of eating options in the area ... cafes, restaurants, even Starbucks. There's free coffee and tea stuff in the room too. (The only problem we had had nothing really to do with the hotel itself - a rude cab driver took us to its sister hotel, the Royal Park, and insisted we were at the right hotel despite the fact that we had a little card from the hotel with the name and a map. Just beware that could be confusing.)

I chose this hotel because it was ranked number three and the price was right. There are a few issues: 1. Carpet is coming out from the baseboard. 2. The caulk seal around the bath tub needs to be replaced. 3. House keeping cleaning the room cups in the bathroom sink.4. The cup with water that I had left in the morning was returned to the shelf with the same plastic cover that I had removed to fill it up two days ago. The water is still in it.5. There is no iron in the room; you'll have to special request one.6. Smoking is allowed in the lobby and it fills the entire lower level with that god-awful stench. There is no way to go around it. You have to take the main elevator to the 25th floor and switch elevators for the rest of the floors, through the lobby.7. There are no English speaking channels available. 8. Figuring out how to make the lights come on, or turn off, is not easy and there are no instructions.9. No fan in the bathroom.10. Pillows are not comfortable. Come to think of it, they are pretty bad.11. NO GYM or POOLOn the upside:1. Excellent location! Safe, clean, beautiful Shimbashi district. 2. Right off of several subway lines. 3. Shopping mall next to the hotel at: City Center. (Malls are the best places to find good, cheap food in Tokyo).4. The price is good.5. The staff is friendly.6. The American buffet breakfast is great (though it is $25.00pp).
