My current favorite hotel in Tokyo. I've had the pleasure of three visits so far. There is no better balance of value for cost out there. If the location suits your needs, then you must stay here. Having said that, I can't comment on the restaurants or bar, as I rarely use those facilities in the hotels that I stay in. The plus side is that there is plenty of choice within a minutes walk. Truly one of the most comfortable beds I have slept in, in a hotel. Great selection of linens and attention to such seemingly minor, but important details are found throughout.

We stayed for 2 nights in Mid-May 2008. From the Narita airport, we took the Airport Express (about 40 minutes) and then changed to the metro which took us to Shimbashi station. It was only a few minutes walk (completely underground) to our hotel. The hotel staff was indescribably professional. The entire hotel, including our room, was spotless. The decor was very modern. The room was on the small side, but it was what I expected in Tokyo! The bathroom had all new appliances and was very clean. The toilet even had a bidet. We were able to access the subway that was just below the building, so we were able to go everywhere in Japan for just a few bucks on the metro. In the evening, we had drinks in the lobby in cushy modern seats while listening to a live jazz band. My only complaint was the breakfast in the hotel. Our stay did not include breakfast, so we paid for it out of pocket at $25USD per person, and it wasn't very good at all. Not much of a selection at too high of a price. However, we discovered that at the building across from the Shiodome Media Tower (which is where the hotel is), there is another building that has tons of affordable restaurantes for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Finally, on our last day, the hotel arranged an Airport Limo to take us to Narita. It costs $30USD per person, but it was worth the convenience. All in all, I would definitely recommend this hotel, and I plan to stay there again on my next trip to Tokyo.

Booked via Designs Hotel site for the best rate at the time. Agree with most other reviewers...great hotel and fantastic value for money in a city where hotels are expensive. Very minor points: They could use another computer or two for internet access as the supply frequently outstripped the demand.Initially, the hotel can be a bit tricky to find. If you have a couple of large bags you may wish to consider either the airport express bus direct to the hotel, or take a cab from Tokyo station. Loved the Park and would definately recommend to friends and would come back again.

We booked the Park Hotel, Tokyo from the reviews we read on Trip Advisor and we made our booking through Agoda.com as they had very competitive rates and we were able to speak to a representative on-line with any questions. We had booked a Premium Twin room (33 sq) for seven nights and it was a fantastic room with very firm comfortable beds. The bathroom was amazing with a heated toilet, wonderful shower and toiletries that were replaced every day.The staff were a credit to the hotel, every staff member, and there were plenty, were helpful and spoke English. They were able to direct us to the correct train line and advise us of areas around us that were worth traveling to. We have read previous reviews that mentioned the staff were a bit offhand to casually dressed guests but we did not find any staff that were like that. We were wished good morning and good night every time we passed reception.There is a business centre right beside reception with two computers that are free for hotel guests to use. You cannot book a time on them but there was not often that you had to wait long. Most guests were accommodating and when they saw you were waiting they finished using the computer in a couple of minutes. Of course the time when you really needed it to book your seats on your flight that was when the rudest guests would not let you use them even when you had explained why you needed them – nothing to do with the hotel mind you but just a hint - if you need it at a certain time I would head down there about half an hour earlier.We found the map on the hotel website was fairly easy to follow but you must make sure that you turn right directly after the ampm convenience store and then follow the large signs that have Park Hotel marked on them. We used the train station every day and we purchased a Suica card from the machines at Shimbashi Station. I have attached a picture of the screen to my review). Make sure you touch the English picture and then touch the green Suica Card picture on the bottom right of the screen (the left My Suica white picture requires you to fill in your name and other details that are not necessary). We decided not to purchase a JR Rail Pass here in Australia before we left as we were not traveling down to Kyoto, Kobe or anywhere out of Tokyo so we couldn’t see the value of paying 28,000yen $280AU that we would use anything like that on local trains. Our Suica card cost us 2,000 yen ($20AU) and covered us for the eight days.There are so many eateries around the area and especially in the large buildings around the Shiodome Media Tower. We found a wonderful Japanese restaurant in the Tokyo Shiodome Building. Come out of the Shiodome Media Tower on the 3rd level and walk right past the Subway café. (Just as you enter the building there is also a nice breakfast café there). You then come to Level 2F of the Tokyo Shiodome Building (Pedi Shiodome it appears to be called). Stay on that level and walk right to the end of the level. The restaurant is called Ootoya and it is frequented by business people and locals before they head home. It was ALWAYS busy which shows just how good it is. We were able to have a main meal with rice (two of us) for a total of 1,700 yen. The first night we went to a pasta restaurant and spent 1,700 each on a main course. It is not just that the price is good at Ootoya it was the food that was excellent, there was always locals eating and some of the staff did understand a little English.On our walks to the Shimbashi station we would sometimes stop in for a French cake from Vie de France, a wonderful bakery. Something that we thought was strange, we called into three Banks to change large notes into smaller notes but none were ‘banks’ as such. Apparently you have to go to the Post Office form something like that.We would recommend the Park Hotel, Tokyo as we really enjoyed our stay.
Staff is excellent and no problem conversing in English. The room is smaller than most U.S. hotel but very nice. Very clean room & bathroom. Includes slippers & robes and green tea.

Wonderful design driven Hotel, located above the Shiodome Station . We were given a room on the 33rd floor. It was clean and more then adequate for the both of us. My husband and I travel extensively and have stayed in hotels from 2 * all the way to luxury 5* Hotels but we can never quite understand the many reviews we read that are so hung up about the size of a room.Found that this Hotel was well positioned for a lot of things. Modern in design, comfortable bed & pillows.Tsukiji Fish Market 10 min (easy walk), which is a must . Afterwards treat yourself to an early morning Shushi. Lots of choices. Shiodom(e) Station & Shiodom(e) City Centre just below the Hotel, The City Centre houses an array of shops and Restaurants. The Station connects to Odeo Line,Shimbashi Station only 5 min. walk away (JR line Ginza line). Ginza almost right on your door step. Metro easy to use.The Imperial Palace about 30 min walk.Hotel Staff exceptionally helpful and most do speak English and will understand you just stay at a slow pace. They want to please.Take the Limousine bus from the Airport. Excellent service 3000 yen per person. each way. Tickets can be bought at the Airport all very effortless. The bus will take you right outside the Hotel. The ride is comfortable and takes approx. 1 hour 15 min, we thought it much easier then the train ride, which is a bit shorter but you will have to take a short walk to the Hotel. To sum it up ,we loved our 5 day stay at the Park Hotel and will absolutely return on our next visit , the location and price were fantastic. Enjoy !!!

I stayed 3 nights in the Park Hotel from 11th-14th April 2008. The hotel is beautiful and in such a great area of Tokyo. I was blown away by the beauty of Tokyo and the friendliness of the locals. It truely is a city I want to go back again soon as it has so much to offer. More about the hotel.ROOMS:The rooms are small but very functional. The bed was very comfortable and my view of the city through the small window was lovely. The plasma tv, space age toilet give the hotel a very new and clean look.STAFF:Staff are friendly but not the friendliest i've met along my travels. Considering that I found Tokyo people to be the nicest I have ever run into this is only a small let down for the hotel.FACILITIES:The facilities are second to none in the hotel. The free internet room beside reception to the surrounding area where restaurants, shops etc very accessible.It takes a while to get used to the 'madness' of Tokyo but just embrace it. The hotel is situated in the Shiodome area which is the 'Docklands' area of most cities where new high rise skyscappers sit in a very clean, safe area near the bay. I loved it and felt totally safe and believe me that includes being lost at 7am in the morning after too many beers. The locals go out of their way to help. I got lost so many times and acts of kindness will never be forgotten.I thing to remember if you are an international traveller. My visa card would only let me withdraw cash at Citibank ATM machines. It was a bit fustrating as there are only about 10 in the city. The 7-11 store ATM's did not work for me. So please have some cash with you before you go and then use the Citibank ATM's if all others fail.Overall Tokyo has a big heart and the nightlife and food and people all add up to an experience i wasn't expecting. wow!!!!

The Park is not the swankiest hotel in Tokyo, but it's much nicer than you'd expect from the bargain rates. The location is good, near a metro station; the room was large enough, if not enormous; the views are spectacular, or can be (a friend's room looked down on the Ginza, while mine had a view of another high-rise); and all rooms are equipped with high-speed internet. Just the thing to check in with loved ones at home.

Stayed at the Park Hotel for 5 nights. Great location, central to everything. Choose hotel from reviews and primarily for location which was great. Railway subway adjoins the hotel with clear directions from the terminal. About a 5-10 minute walk under the subwy. Once you are familar with signage its an easy walk to the hotel lobby. Very clean hotel, fairly new, contemporary small rooms but adequate. Staff were always friendly and accomodating. English speaking staff memebers which was nice as many Japanese do not attempt to speak English.Would hightly recommend hotel to tourists wanting someone central to all attractions and the railway system (which is a must use in Japan).

My wife and I stayed at the Park Hotel for a week last November while on vacation. The hotel was wonderful. Overall, the hotel has a high-class business travel style. The atrium was very impressive, but decorated in a subdued style – lots of dark wood. There was also a business center next to the registration desk with two computers with free internet access, one of which was usually available. The view from the panoramic lobby windows was spectacular, especially at sunset. The room was great. We selected the larger room, which was perfect. There was a good closet and chest of drawers that easily held all of our clothes. There was also a small refrigerator with things like soda, beer and wine, and a tea setting on top (the tea was fantastic). The bathroom was somewhat small, but meticulously clean and highly functional. The space-age toilet was also interesting, with a heated seat and several functions that I dared not try. Once again, the view was amazing. All of the members of the hotel staff were extremely polite and helpful. Check-in and check-out were each a breeze, and the desk staff helped us with directions, sending mail and other routine tasks. The concierge was very friendly and responsive, and booked all of our tour activities and a couple restaurants (although there was one mix-up in a restaurant location, but it was worked out). The location was good. It is located in a business district, not a tourist area. It was fun to see the tides of office-workers going to and from work everyday. Maybe it was just because we were on vacation, but we always seemed to be heading in the opposite direction. In any event, there is relatively easy access from the hotel to Tokyo’s awesome train system, which can get you nearly anywhere. In fact, one of the train lines has a station at the bottom of the hotel. The regular JR station is just a short walk away along the under-street walkways, which are filled with shops and small restaurants. It is actually easy to find the way once you know it, but we got hopelessly lost when we first tried it (we came right from the airport with all of our luggage). Thankfully, a helpful florist pointed us the right way. Finally, we were impressed with the value. The Park Hotel is not the cheapest place to stay, but you get a lot for the money. I would definitely recommend the Park Hotel to anyone traveling to Tokyo for business or pleasure.

We write briefly to add our support for the Park Hotel Tokyo and mention a few other notables. We found the location of the hotel to be perfect for our tastes, first as a designated stop on the limousine bus line from Narita airport, then as a point of departure to the Ginza district, the Shiodome subway station, and the JR Train station.(But be forewarned and make no mistake about it: maps and guides and compass and preparation notwithstanding, you will inevitably, as our guidebook stated, get lost at some point....Have no fear for you will eventually, given enough time and practice, figure out the lay of the land in Tokyo and, failing that, come to rely on the good nature of a Japanese stranger for directions)The area surrounding the hotel is chock full of restaurants, shopping areas, and one of the neatest, large scale, colorful, imaginative, acrobatic, musical, clock towers we have ever observed (see the third floor promenade). The check-in desk, it bears repeating, is backlit by an amazing view of the Tokyo skyline. The lobby is ample with soaring sight lines. We had a city view room with a queen bed. The 'snug' size of the room set us slightly aback at first but we adapted; ditto the bath and shower. Housekeeping is dependable. We were generally comfortable. The breakfast buffet is a real treat with a nice selection of items, set up along one of the back walls in the lobby. Guests sit informally in oversized chairs at low set tables. The cost is about $25/pp at current conversion rates. Service at the hotel is, in the seeming Asian tradition, attentive, polite, endearing. Our room rate, roughly 17,500 yen for an 'early bird' booking, is terrific. We hope the hotel is able to maintain such an attractive rate. We would surely like to return.

Based on review from Trip Advisor, we booked 4 nights in the Park Hotel for April. The view from the room was great. Free internet was nice. The room was a bit smaller than I would have expected but it worked.Unfortunately the metro station in the building isn't a very useful one. It's on the Oedo line which doesn't go to many touristy places and it's not a quick connection to get to a more useful line. 95% of the time we ended up walking to Shimbashi station which is on the Ginza line. It's about a 10 minute walk from the hotel but involves using highway overpasses and crosswalks that go across 6 lane roads which can take a while. If you're caught in the rain, it's not a fun walk. Plus getting into the hotel isn't always straight forward. The raised entrance from the highway overpass and JR station closes at night which can be annoying. Also you have to take two elevators to get to your hotel room. One to get to the lobby on the 25th floor, and another to your room. Not really something you look forward to after a really long day; and the elevators are really slow.The restaurants in the hotel were grossly expensive, but this isn't a deficiency unique to this hotel.If you take an elevator from the lobby to the basement level you can get right to the Shidome metro station on the Oedo line. In the basement there are also a bunch of smaller restaurants that are reasonably priced. You can walk past them and outside to get to a FamilyMart (ubiquitous convenience store in Japan).All in all I'd say the hotel itself was fine. Really nothing special. Next time I'm in Tokyo I'll be looking for something with a better location; both for walking and for using the metro.

Booked based on TA reviews and we weren't let down! We received an adorable room with an outrageous view of the Tokyo Tower. We slept with the windows open both nights to admire the view. The hotel described the walk to the hotel as 7 min. but it was a good 15 for us with large luggage in tow. Using the hotel's provided maps and directions the property was very easy to find from the JR Yamanote Shimbashi station. Check-in was a breeze. The room size was slightly small but perfectly sized for our needs. The room was very modern and the bathroom decked out with a fancy toilet with all the bells and whistles. A TON of nice toiletry/spa amenities available. For a 2 day stay in Tokyo the hotel couldn't be better located. We were within short walking distance to the Tsukiji Fish Market and Hama Rikyu Garden. Additionally the JR Yamanote line gave us great access to the Shibuya/Harajuku/Shinjuku areas. The hotel staff didn't have a great range of English, but they did go above the call of duty in one case. I bought an int'l/domestic calling card from the lobby and tried to make a call to a local cell using the card but upon help from the concierge I learned the card I bought couldn't call local cells in Japan. He was kind enough to let me use his cell phone to call my friend - a huge help. Just a note that most US cell phones don't work in Japan as apparently they are on a different network. We had a 9am flight to Beijing on our final morning and the concierge wasn't really able to help us arrange travel to the airport other than recommending the T-CAT since the airport limo bus did not run early enough for us to get to the airport by 7am - again, lost in translation. Upon recommendation from our friend we were able to take the JR Yamanote to the Keisei line at Akihabara and make it to the airport in under an hour. Thanks to all for the great feedback - this hotel was an awesome find!

First - the good points...The view from the rooms is STUNNING! on many occasions, we would get breakfast from a nearby cafe and bring it back to the room so we could sit by the window and just look out at the buildings and trains below.It really isn't a huge problem to find this hotel - I took a taxi from Tokyo station the first time and it was only a short drive and a reasonable price - make sure you tell the taxi driver that it's the park hotel in shiodome media tower, as the royal park hotel in shiodome tower is opposite! confusing?! nah!The location is fine... it is a bit of a walk to Shimbashi station which is the station we used the most but it wasn't too bad.Bad points - I totally agree with some of the reviews saying that the hotel staff are a little 'off' and cold. I have been living and working in Japan for the last 7 months and have been stunned every day with the kindness of the Japanese so I was so surprised to see such a change when I entered this hotel. I think they do probably give a bit more attention to people wearing suits rather than jeans and trainers which seems unfair as we're all paying a lot of money to stay there!Also, I found the room a little bit tired... lots of marks on the wall and a few stains on the carpet. I know this is bound to happen but it just surprised me when the lobby area is so stunning and immaculate.Overall, this is a good hotel to stay in - I would definitely recommend this for the view but if i were to go to Tokyo again, I would find a new hotel.Enjoy the craziness of Tokyo - Gan batte!

Stayed for 3 nights (april 21 till 24) at this property after reading about the greatness of it here on tripadvisor. the bed was impeccable and the view from my room is great too, although mine's not facing tokyo tower, but it does look out into tokyo bay!The pillows are great and i had great sleep there. Toiletries are great too with nice aromothrapy from one of my favourote brand, Thann of Thailand.The bad thing is travelling to the hotel if you are arriving into Shimbashi station. Although the walk is 10 min underground, so no sweat, but getting to hotel involve going down stairs. The escalators only go upwards; meaning checking out and getting to station is actually better than getting to hotel.Staff is only ok. Lady at check in was sully and not very friendly, and since she's in black, I would think she's one of the higher ranking ones. On my last day, i went to the 1 starred michelin star reataurent and food and service was average. Generally I feel that staff in this hotel are polite only when you are dressed in suits and all formal. I was in jeans and tee and most of the time i did not get any hellos or greetings from lobby staff on my way out and into the hotel. Service is negligible; this place is only good for the beds and toiletries. period. the bath tub is small and i am 5"11 and i am already having bad time soaking my self.

Chose this hotel from TA reviews and it was excellent. Decor is modern and stylish and service impeccable. We were upgraded on arrival to a top floor room with views over Tokyo Tower, which on a clear morning gave us a view of Mount Fuji.Very good location as part of the Shiodome Complex with its access to 3 stations, plenty of restaurants and coffee shops to suit all tastes and shops to cover essentials.Good area to be in as it's close to Ginza & the Imperial Palace, and away from the frenetic areas like Shinjuku.We'd been warned that it wasn't easy to find if you arrived by train so downloaded a map from the hotel website and the instructions couldn't have been clearer.Very easy to get to from Narita airport. The JR line stops at Shimbashi which is part of the Shiodome complex, or there's several other easy options. Plus if you look puzzled Japanese people always ask if they can help.

Can't praise this hotel highly enough. It was extremely clean, we had 2 superb large rooms with dizzying views towards the Ginza and lots of windows. Didn't hear any noise at all. Bathrooms were fab and the toilet was fun! There is a button on the TV remote to remove the Japanese voice-over on BBC and CNN. Breakfasts offered a wide choice including lots of fruit which you don't see much of elsewhere in Tokyo. Croissants, toast, hot choices ,cereals etc. Or you can choose a Japanese breakfast if you prefer. The staff were great and lots of English was spoken.There is a room off the lobby where you can use the computer for free if you haven't brought a laptop. This was useful for checking out restaurants and opening hours of places we wanted to visit. The hotel is superbly connected via an underground maze to at least 2 subway stations and is 10 mins walk to the Ginza, much of which you can do underground if it's raining. We would highly recommend 3 visits from this hotel:1. Walk to the local Hamarikyu Gardens and experience the tea ceremony there.2.Take the Yurikamome Line from Shiodome station to Fune-no-Kagakukan and visit the Museum of Emerging Science (aka Miraikan) to see the robots in action! Watching the humanoid ASIMO run across the room in front of us was quite extraordinary. And brilliant for our teenage kids who were enthralled.3. Walk to the Tsujiku Fish market - it's very wet and fishy underfoot so wear the right shoes!Can't wait to go back to Tokyo and will definitely stay in this hotel.
Excellent location (2 subway lines), close to Fish Market, great views from any room. We stayed 3 nights in this hotel and it was fantastic! Too bad I booked another hotel for the end of the trip....

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in March 2008 and we were very impressed. The hotel was easy to find from Shimbashi station thanks to the detailed map on the hotel's website. The hotel foyer has gobsmacking views of Tokyo and the staff were friendly and efficient. The room was spacious by Japanese standards and was spotlessly clean and comfortable. They even provided yakutas to sleep in which was a lovely touch. While Shiodome is not the most exciting neighbourhood in Tokyo, the fact that the underground and JR stations are downstairs means that it is very easy to get around. Another advantage of staying here is that the Tsukuji fish market is a 20 minute walk away - definitely worth getting up at 4.30am to see this!

Excellent hotel, had a room on 29th floor facing Shimbashi station, the trains can actually be a bit disturbing if you are a light sleeper. Very clean and free wired internet (excellent!). Staff speaks english. Didn't have the hotel breakfast but opted for one of the numerous coffe shops in the plaza below the hotel, great value for money.

The hotel was very nice, but a bit overrated from previous reviews. The location is pretty good. We walked to Ginza and train lines were around the corner. Staff was pretty nice, but not spectacular. I know it is Tokyo, but I found the room a bit small. The courtyard concept is pretty cool, but one would think they would reduce the size of empty space in the center and make the rooms a bit bigger. A highlight: amenities in the bathrooms are absolute top notch. Rate was very good.

My friend and I stayed at the Park Hotel for 4 nights in January, and it was fantastic! LOCATIONThe hotel is right near the Shimbashi station. Not really knowing how to get there from the NRT airport, we took a bus, but it took an hour and a half due to the number of stops along the way. You can buy a Japan Rail Pass prior (this is good if you are traveling to other cities in Japan. We used it to travel from Tokyo to Kyoto -- you purchase the exchange order outside of Japan, and then get the Rail Pass once you arrive). With the rail pass, you can take the metro to Tokyo Station, and a cab to the hotel from Tokyo Station is not that expensive (by tokyo standards). The hotel is also walking distance to Ginza and the Tsukiji fish market. Underneath the hotel area is a mall or restaurant area -- we discovered it on our last night, and it had a lot of restaurants. perfect if you are getting in around the evening and don't want to travel far for dinner. Can't remember exactly where or what it was called b/c it's been a few months, but the hotel staff should know.STAFFextremely friendly and VERY helpful. The Japanese are normally very polite and courteous, but I thought the concierge was exceptional. They helped us get tickets to a Sumo tournament (we were lucky enough to be staying in Tokyo at the time of the tournament), and assisted us with directions everywhere else.HOTEL ROOMSWe stayed in Tokyo for 3 nights, went to Kyoto for 2 nights, and then came back to the Park Hotel for our last night. Japan hotel rooms are usually very small, and it is the same here, but that is normal. On our last night, the hotel room was a bit bigger and nicer (i posted pics).Great experience overall, would definitely recommend!

Fantastic hotel, especially if you book very early and get the early bird price. We got a great room with a great view for about £80 per night. Stayed for 4 nights and it was a great base for seeing Tokyo. Walking distance to Shimbashi station and the JR circle line around Tokyo which takes you everywher you want to go, and its free if you have a JR Train Pass. Good location for shopping in Ginza and nightlife in Shimbashi. Also walking distance to the famouse fish markets.Easiest way to get here is the Narita express to Tokyu station and then a cab (£6), takes you to the door, so you dont have to navigate the rather confusing overhead, underhead, through your head walkways, which you eventually get the hang of, 5 minutes befoire you leave Tokyo.Only drawback, was the bar life, restaurants etc was a little dead in the hotel as everyone goes out.Would definately stay again.

I've stayed twice at the Park Hotel Tokyo. The first time was ver recent to their oppening and I had a hard time with the taxi driver finding the place, but the second time (one year later) was smooth and with no problem (the first time I was there, they were still building the roads to get to the hotel, buit now everything is fine).What I like the most about this hotel, that I always recommed and I'm happy to see that jumped up to the second best choice in Tokyo for TripAdvisor users is):1) The location: is perfect, because at the ground floor you'll find the metro connections to almost anywhere worth a look in Tokyo2) The friendliest staff you can get (I've only been to another hotel in Tokyo besides this one, but the staff is just a 10/10.3) The shows at night. Once you get to the hotel at night you'll find some show (piano playing, a chorus line, some music) at the ground floor. You can have a drink while watching the free show, and that's just perfect4) The japanese restaurant at the groun floor is as best as it gets. Please, try the shasimi if you're into raw fish because it's excellent.5) The place itself is awesome. The lobby is somewhere around the 40th level, and the look up to the hotel from the looby is breathtaking.6) The spa might not seem big but will do the job just prefectlyOn the downside is the size of the rooms that are quite small but who care when you plan to stay in them just to sleep. Besides, the views are just amazing.So, in all, it's the perfect hote in Tokyo for the price. I've been to another, more focussed on the western taste and didn't meet the expectation as well as the Park.

The Park Hotel is a medium sized very modern hotel in the very modern and relatively new Shiodome area of Tokyo. The lobby is on the 25th floor of a large building, with the rooms being in the 10 floors above that. Below the Park Hotel, the subway is only an elevator ride away, which is extremely convenient.Also only an elevator ride away on the floors at the ground level and below are a Family Mart (convenience store), the US chain Subway sandwich shop, and several restaurants. If you want more restaurants, there are loads of them (dozens) in the three main large buildings adjacent to the Park Hotel in the Shiodome complex. However, they are mostly Japanese and Asian restaurants! None of them say they have an English menu, but most of them do -- you just have to ask (learn how to say "Do you have an English Menu" in Japanese and you'll be fine!) Our favorite was the Singaporian place in one of those huge buildings (not Pedi Center -- sorry, don't remember which one!) The weirdest one was Ducky Duck, whose menu consists of a Japanese version of various pastas and various dessert cakes!Outside in the walkway area of the Shiodome complex you can find Mos Burger, Nathan's hotdogs (all beef, same as NY) and a donut shop. There is also a British-type restaurant, but believe me the food is not very authentic!The Shiodome Complex was finished around 2002, so it's all very modern and new -- if not somewhat stark and futuristic. You won't feel like you're in a neighborhood here, but you won't lack for any conveniences either. Check out the weird motion sculpture with the huge clock that comes alive at 10 a.m., noon, 3 p.m., etc. It's like something out of Disneyland!Now for the hotel itself.....Our kids are young teens. They had their own room, so we paid for two rooms. The rooms are small but very clean and the beds are extremely comfortable. The rooms are also extremely QUIET, which is one thing you really want after spending an exhausting day of sightseeing in noisy frenetic Tokyo! Seriously, this is probably one of the quietest hotels I have ever stayed in. And the views of Tokyo and Tokyo Tower are terrific!We took an overnight trip to Hakone and then came back to the Park Hotel. We had booked non-smoking rooms but unfortunately the rooms they gave us wreaked from smoke. The staff was very apologetic and gave us new rooms -- nicer ones at the corner that were non-smoking for no extra cost! The corner rooms had a lot more windows and great city views! We slept with the curtains open every night because the view was so fantastic (we were on the 28th floor).The shower heads are great -- incredible water pressure, although the flopping shower curtain was annoying.The high-tech toilets are fun, especially the heated toilet seats! Now that I'm back in the States I really miss them!Each room has a small flat screen TV with a few cable channels, mostly in Japanese. It's easy to get an internet connection. The current is the same as in the US. If you need an adapter plug for a three-prong device, the hotel can lend you one.The decor of the rooms is very modern and understated, as is the decor of the entire hotel. It's like a boutique business hotel. The lobby is at the bottom of a huge atrium similar to the way Embassy Suites does its hotels. The difference is that there is an extra glass barrier between the atrium and each room, which accounts for each room being very quiet. But the lobby itself is very echoy. Drop a fork at breakfast and everyone hears it, LOL.On the weekend nights there is jazz music in the lobby, which is a really nice touch if you want to relax with a drink or a light snack.The staff speaks excellent English and is extremely helpful and accomodating. My kids have various food allergies. We notified the hotel of this in advance as we'd be having breakfast there. I was so impressed -- the first morning we went to breakfast they were waiting with our information and told me what items on the buffet my kids could safely eat. They even read the labels of the cereals to ensure their safety. I was so grateful!!!The buffet breakfast is not a huge elaborate affair as I'd had in other Asian top-end hotels. However, it is quite filling and nice. You get breads, chocolate croissants, scrambled eggs, various meats, cheeses, salads, smoked salmon, various cereals, nice plain yogurt, fresh fruits, granola, coffee, tea, juices, and bottled waters. It was expensive (around $25 per person; a little less for the kids) but on those first days in Tokyo it was better than trying to hunt down breakfast elsewhere. If you want something cheaper I suggest going down the elevator to Family Mart and trying some of the interesting packaged goods there. Each room has a small refrigerator, so if want you can go to Family Mart or Subway Sandwiches and stock up on some stuff and put it in the fridge for breakfast or snacks.Each room also has a tea pot and some coffee and tea (both green and black), sugar and powdered creamer.There is no microwave or any way to heat anything up aside from the tea pot.The location of the Park Hotel was very convenient, especially since the subway was at the lowest level of the building's elevator. There are several stores and a few restaurants at "subway level." If you want to head over to the fish market, it is only one or two short subway stops away. But go early -- many sushi restaurants are shut down by noon, or have huge lines for lunch!I would highly recommend the Park Hotel hotel for many reasons. BUT -- if you want a hotel with a "neighborhood feel" then this may not be the place for you. We stayed there 9 nights and were very happy with our decision.Oh, by the way, several hotels were in the exact same complex -- the Royal Park and the Hotel Fontaine (in case you were trying to compare hotels). We went into the lobby of the Royal Park. Seemed fancier and larger, but we liked the Park Hotel better!

My girlfriend and I stayed in the Park Hotel for 8 nights in mid-March, and I don't have any complaints. From the efficient way they helped us check-in as soon as we arrived from the airport bus, to the smooth check-out, everything was well done. The reception desk staff were faultlessly polite, and spoke better English than at Cerulean Tower, the room was a decent size, and very nicely appointed, and the bathroom was really nice. The shower in particular was awesome. Our view was of Shimbashi Train station, which was ok, but not really inspiring in any way, but that's ok. Basically the only possible problem I can imagine anyone having with the Park Hotel is it's location. Shimbashi itself is not the most exciting area. But it is on the Yamanote line, so it's really easy to get anywhere in Tokyo from here within 30 mins. Personally I preferred Cerulean Tower, but has to have the caveat that Cerulean is about twice the price. Booking the Park Hotel guarantees a comfortable, well-connected, impressive hotel, and at a very reasonable rate. Highly recommended.

My 20 yr old son and I stayed at the Park Hotel twice - once when we first arrived in Japan and again as we left. I was a little worried it would be hard to find but we had no trouble at all and found the location terrific for our needs. Whilst we didn't spend much time actually in the hotel (other than in the evenings), when we were there the staff were most helpful . The room we had first time was amazing with huge windows, so it was a wonderful introduction to Japan for my son and we loved the view when using the hotel computers at night. There was a great patisserie not far from the hotel in the undergound and we chose to eat breakfast there most days for a very good price. We could then jump on the train to anywhere in Tokyo and we found using the train system easy once we'd figured out the colour coding. The toiletries were gorgeous - the best of all the hotels we stayed at in Japan, and although it wasn't cheap, we enjoyed our stay there very much.

We spend three nights here en-route to Australia. It's too far away for a one night stop-over, probably close to 2 hours door-to-door from hotel to Narita Airport. Anyway the hotel, the hotel is great. It is spotless and modern. The decor is stylish and has the feel of a top class hotel. The staff (although lacking charisma) were extremely helpful. It is a short stroll (12 mins once you figure it out) to Shimbashi station, the Shiodome station that is closer to the hotel doesn't really connect well with the main areas of interest. So the location is fine because there ain't a 'centre' in Tokyo, you'll get to anywhere you need from Shimbashi.The food in the hotel was great. We had dinner there one evening and also has breakfast in our room each morning (don't think this cost anything extra). There is a Michelin-star type restaurant and a more informal restaurant area to dine in. There is a cocktail bar there also but honestly the place was lacking in atmosphere when we were there (as these places tend to be, it is a hotel bar after all).Our room, a premier room, was brilliant. It had a stunning view of the city (therefore breakfast with this view won hands down versus the dining area). It was a spacious room that faced towards Shimbashi, some people mightn't like looking at the station and tracks but I found it facinating watching the people march along like ants in different directions. The beds in Park Hotel Tokyo are probably the best I've encountered anywhere in the world. Which was welcome to weay travellers like us.I would stay here again, in a premier room, in a heartbeat.

Stayed here for one night on our last night in Japan, wasn't expecting too much (stayed at the Cerulean for 3 nights, then went to Kyoto, then back to Tokyo for our flight). We arrived early (around 10:30am) and were told that the hotel was having some 'facility issues' and that if we wanted to check in on time, we would have to be downgraded from our queen room and would be given meal vouchers. We agreed as it was only for one night and were hungry. The room we were given was a city single- 19 sq meters- it was TINY. This is apparently normal for Tokyo, but after being in the Cerulean it was a box. One double bed, a very small bathroom, and we were tripping over bags constantly. That said, the room was tastefully furnished and the bed comfortable (though small). The hotel is somewhat small and seems like it's only there since they decided there wasn't enough demand for office space. Service was good, and the breakfast was a typical buffet. Nothing special. We were there on a Saturday-Sunday and did not like the Shiodome area for the most part. It was empty and sterile. It's next to a great garden though and we took a ferry to Asukasa- definitely recommend- great view of the cherry blossoms! Shiodome was convenient for restaurants, which were all empty on a Saturday night. It worked out perfectly as we had an amazing meal at the Korean restaurant on the 42nd floor of the City Center, dressed like complete slobs. However, we probably would not have been able to get a private room in a restaurant like that during the week, so being at the deserted Shiodome worked for us. I think this would be a great hotel for business, but think most tourists would be better off in a more exciting neighborhood.

My husband, 7 year old daughter and I stayed here for 5 nights. We got a triple share room. I thought the room was adequate in size and definitely very nicely appointed. Location is great! The building is around office towers , there were a lot of good office lunch places with very reasonable prices. 10 min walk away from Ginza. The staff were very helpful , a couple of concierge personnels spoke excellent english and gave very efficient service. We liked the hotel for its "boutique - like" feeling , quiet and calm, we prefer it this way than a big chain hotel that can be chaotic and impersonal during peak hours. So happy we chose this hotel based on the reviews here. We will definitely come back. Great value for money!!!!

This hotel is super-great. Location is right next door to a subway station and the interior of the rooms are impeccable. If you like modern, you'll love it. Was a bit worried as I selected this hotel purely based on reviews as I was rushing for time. Its subway station (Shiodome) is well located and close to many tourist sites. Would not hesitate to recommend this hotel.

We stayed here en route to Australia as part of our honeymoon. The hotel was chosen on the basis of other reviews here on Tripadvisor.Upon arrival we were told that we were upgraded thanks to our newly wedded status and given a premium room with a stunning view of the Tokyo Tower. It snowed for part of our time in Tokyo, so we ended up just seeing clouds from the room on one of the days, which we thought was very cool.This is a smart, clean hotel. The toiletries are excellent and I absolutely loved the toilet! Oh how I'll miss the seat warming and jet "cleaning" facilities!The hotel is easily accessible to the subway. Just hop in the lift and you're pretty much at the station. The staff were great and couldn't do enough for us. Tokyo itself is fantastic, with politeness and safety on a level the rest of the world can only dream of. The subway train was gleaming with a floor so clean you could eat your dinner off it. You'd also be hard pushed to spot any graffiti in this city.A few things to be wary of :- there's no Wireless Internet access (only a cable connection) in the rooms or throughout much of the hotel- Tokyo can be tricky to navigate for western tourists and you can get easily lost, especially if you want to see the sights. We found a real lack of tourist information especially at subway stations and on the street. This is especially true if you arrive at a station and want to get to a tourist spot.- ATM machines and Credit Card ePOS terminals are not all the same! We ran out of money and went from machine to machine where it spat out our cards time and time again. Thanks to a helpful man in a bank, he said that the only machines compatible with our UK bank cards were at Post Offices (although the only other machine that worked was at Narita Airport). We had the same problem when purchasing some CDs at one of the major record stores. Our cards were rejected at the till, but we hadn't had any problems in restaurants.

We spent 3 nights at the Park Hotel in February and thought it was great.We arrived late evening & were very impressed with the size of the premium room we booked as some reviews suggested rooms were small. When we opened the curtains we were very impressed with the view of the neon lights & energetic Tokyo. The view was just as good in the morning especially with the sun glistening.As mentioned by several other people the heated toilet was a novelty & the toiletries provided were very good.The hotel staff were very helpful & friendly providing maps & advise on how to get to places.The free internet access was handy to look up places to visit or log onto tripadvisor for tips.The view from hotel reception has been mentioned several times before but is fantastic - Tokyo tower & Mt Fuji in the distance.It was our first visit to Tokyo & we were happy with the location but have nothing to compare to. The JR train line was only a short walk away & we got that everywhere. Would be happy to come back to this hotel again in the future as its excellent value & a good base to explore unique Tokyo.

We just got back from a 10 night stay in Tokyo and found this hotel to be perfect for our needs. We stayed in a standard queen bedroom on floor 33 looking out at the park and the bay. While the room is small, I thought it was extremely space efficient and didn't need anything larger. The room was stylish and very clean, and the housekeeping was fantastic. Our room was on the train station side, which I was quite wary of due to the reviews here and being a light sleeper, but strangely enough they didn't bother me. I found it more of a "white noise" than anything else. Your mileage may vary. I did not find the hotel front desk staff to be rude; they are certainly not as friendly and welcoming as most Japanese customer service staff we met elsewhere, but nothing to get your knickers in a twist about.We didn't use the room service or hotel restaurant, there is just so much choice in Tokyo that I didn't find it even remotely necessary. Keep in mind that my partner and I are both in our early twenties, and were keen to explore the city every day and most of the night. So really all we did at the hotel was sleep, shower, and watch a little tv. While Shiodome is not exactly in the heart of the action, so to speak, this can be a positive or a negative depending on how you look at it. I loved Shibuya for exploring at night, but as far as staying there? Not really that relaxing. Shiodome on the other hand, was clean, brand spanking new, and almost like a little retreat from the hubbub of Tokyo for us. We used the nearby Caretta mall restaurants and the convenience stores on a daily basis, and the walk through the underground passage to Shimbashi station was really convenient. Overall I adored this hotel, its amenities and services, the location and the room. Would love to go back some day.

I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in February 2008 while visiting Tokyo with my boyfriend and his family.We had a wonderful stay here and I cannot think of a single thing I didn't like about this hotel.We paid what seemed to have been a very cheap rate, though whether this is because of the roadworks going on below (which did not affect us at all as we used the overhead walkways) plus being winter, or whether this is their usual rate I am not sure.It is an excellent location- a very short walk to the Ginza and not far from Shimbashi train station (which most/all subway lines pass through), and Shiodome station is right next door (which has two subway lines). It is in the 25th to 33rd levels of Shiodome tower in a nice business district.The interior is very stylish, not what I expected at all for the price. The lobby is very comfortable and never seemed too full, and drinks aren't too expensive. Staff are very attentive. Rooms have a good view over Tokyo, beds are comfy, there is good lighting, good tea and coffee and minibar supplies, with drinks vending machines tucked away in some hallways. There is free internet next to the lobby and free secure wireless internet.Bathrooms are excellent, and well stocked with everything you could need, even razors and toothbrushes.The rooms are spacious enough (for a hotel room) with good lighting, radio and tv. There is a walkway leading from the 3rd floor of the tower so you don't need to walk to the street, which then blends in with all of the other walkways, so it is easy to get around.We had a wonderful stay here, it was one of the best hotels I've stayed in, and I can't think of anything I didn't like. Admittedly I didn't eat at the restaurant there, so cannot comment on it, but I don't usually see the point of staying in the hotel to eat anyway! It's only a short wlak to the many restaurants at Ginza, and it's a very safe area to walk around in at night.I highly recommend this hotel!

We stayed at Park Hotel for the second time Feb 2008. We had 2 rooms, one premium twin on floor 33 and one city twin on floor 28.The views from both were amazing, especially from the premium twin, the night views are to die for.Rooms, well, the city twin is rather small but more than adequate for my inlaws, they didn't complain at all. Our premium was just lovely, even with the extra bed for our son, it was comfy and roomy. Beds are great, maybe a little on the hard side, but I liked them.Service was great, we send our luggage to our next hotel and the girl on the bell desk did fantastic job helping us out, just excellent. We didn't find anybody rude etc on the front desk staff, but maybe we were just lucky, I don't know.As for the location, it is very close to few subway stations and only a short walk to Shimbashi JR station which connects you to JR Yamanote line. We didn't try hotel restaurant, since well, it is tad pricy. We ate few times at restaurants in Shiodome City Center and Caretta Shiodome, good food, nothing very fancy, but good, solid food. We ate most of our breakfast at the Vie De France, good selection on different kind of pastries.All in all, if we ever go back to Tokyo (and I'm pretty sure that we will be, we just love the city, although can't really explain why...), we will definetly stay at the Park Hotel !

After reading lots of brilliant reviews on tripadvisor i booked this hotel on that basis , My review is mixed i am afraid !Hotel great value for money , very clean and stylish in a minimalistic way but void of character. Hotel only had one bar and one restaurant , so not much choice, seating area for both of these seemed to be mingled together with the lobby area . Other reviews mention the restaurants in the basement of the building , all i can say is good luck if you cant read / speak japanese,( we ordered tons of food by mistake!)Rooms were very small and compact ,with comfy beds, lovely toiletries & great heated toliet seats. Location, in a quiet business area with excellent access to all tube stations. The biggest selling point to this hotel is the price as its very cheap compared to other Tokyo hotels, so if i did return to Tokyo (which i wont as its not for me ) i would stay at this hotel again.

Lovely hotel. We're expecting a hotel in Tokyo around this price to be small and uncomfortable. However we're pleasantly proven to be wrong!The staff were very friendly and helpful. The rooms very nice and comfortable. The view were just to die for, amazing from every angle. We definitely will stay in this hotel again!

This was our last stop after a whirlwind 2 week visit to Japan. I booked it on expedia the day before I checked in because I was so disappointed with the original hotel choice. The hotel is very stylish and modern. We sheepishly walked in with backpacks not knowing how we would be received. I was surprised to find everyone was very nice. I read a review below about how the front desk was rude. I will add, in that respect, that I spoke Japanese to book the hotel and initially at check-in. I know in some countries that knowing the local language can make a difference in service, but not sure if that was a factor here. The room had amazing views and reminded me of what I would expect from the New Otani. The room was rather large for Tokyo standards and the was nicely decorated and very modernI recommend this hotel for the last leg of your trip if you want to spend a low key day before your flight home. I woke up very early and walked to world famous Tsukiji fish market which is only a few blocks away. I also enjoyed drinks and an amazing view at the bar the night before. It was an absolute perfect way to end a perfect trip.

I chose the Park Hotel for a 4 night stay in Tokyo in Nov 2007 after much research. The hotel itself was great, stylish lobby, all the mod cons that you would expect in a Tokyo hotel. We had a corner twin room which was the mid range room type. I'm glad we didn't decide on the lead in as the room was small (again as many hotel rooms in japan can be). The fabulous view of the city and Tokyo tower made up for the slightly snug space. The hotel is located in the new business district of Shiodome which though a little quiet outside of business hours did have good rail and underground connections which meant we were less than a 20 min ride to most areas. I would definitely stay at the Park again however next time would possibly look for a hotel in Shibuya which was my favourite area in Tokyo.

Just back from here and it was the perfect place to stay in Tokyo. Here's why:1) Great location - bear in mind you have to get the subway everywhere in tokyo. This place is 2 mins walk to 1 subway, 7 mins to the main station. So its perfect as a base for getting about.2) The staff all speak perfect english and are very, very friendly + helpful. I'm surprised some people found them not to be. Must have been ignorant americans. ha ha3) You can leave your bags there while going travelling elsewhere (we went to Kyoto).4) You can get an early bird rate if you book early enough via the hotels own website and you don't even need to leave card details to do it - so do it anyway and cancel later on if need be. We got a lovely room with a prefect view of Tokyo for £90 a night. Not bad at all5) Heated toilet seats etc - as said by many others. They're dead rightBad point:1) The restaurant is a rip off. Just take a stroll to the main station and theres millions of places to eat for a 10th of the price.

Truthfully, I thought this hotel was overrated for a hotel that has won design awards. The set-up of the check-in waiting/lobby area was great: comfortable, good-looking couches set facing each other in pairs, bookcases with design & other cool coffee-table books, and good lighting. However, the room was ho-hum. While clean & spare, the 'City Queen' room was tiny, much tinier than either of the standard hotel rooms in which I stayed in Seoul (both 4-star+ hotels), and the design & materials of the furniture & bedding were poorer (the blond wood composite was definitely cheaper) -- look at the photos of the small round table. Also, I did not find the service 100% polite and seamless. One woman whom I asked about mobile phone rental (which I mistakenly thought was included with the room) spoke excellent English but was quite rude and brusque. Also, we had to remind them about our luggage for the airport shuttle, as they had forgotten our original request.The special elements of this hotel were the small details such as Dean & Deluca products in the minibar and the quality of the toiletries. The aromatherapy products smelled fantastically fresh and invigorating and I loved the wash-cloth, shaver and other products in the cool packaging. I also liked the computer room with free internet access and the mobile rental desk, both next to the check-in desk.The hotel was conveniently located close to the main rail station and some great places to eat. However, as the Shiodome area is predominantly a commercial area with office buildings and we were there for a couple of days just after the new year, the area was really dead.Overall, this experience was mixed. I would consider going back to the Park Hotel, but probably only if I could book a premium room.

The hotel is well located and as a family it would cost about UDS10-12 to taxi from Tokyo Station which is what we did until we had time to get our bearings right instead of lugging bags through strange passageways. The staff are professional though some slightly aloof but almost all we met spoke great English and even delivered maps and directions clearly marked right up to our room at night. We found that we did not really need our heavy guidebooks. The cleaning staff were so courteous and honest and highly consistent. Depsite our mess the room always welcomed us in superb and almost identical generous fashion each evening. We had small rooms with railway noise though soft , despite request for quiet room. The bathroom is space-age with great auto toilets (in fact greatest toilets in the world are in Japan!). However if you are obese find another hotel! Literally the bathtub took its entire length and the width was 2.5 times the width of the bathtub. The heated mirror was great and the Thai (Thann) toiletries soothing. We found such an amazing choice of restaurants in the surriunding areas that we did not need to eat in the hotel. With JR pass we used the subway free of charge just by sticking to the JR Yamamote Line-(just show to the attendents do not bother with subway tickets on this line) gets you to Akihabara, Shinjuku etc from Shimbashi Stn which is 10-15 minutes walk. The secret to finding the hotel is to follow signs to Hamamatsucho (monorail station). Tokyo is amazingly safe even at night, There is a Family Mart downstairs as well as the AM/PM mini supermarket. Stock up on drinks and snacks for the next adventure in this great megapolis. There is even a Sinagpore Hainan Chicken rice Rest. and Vie de France (see petite Japanese ladies roll out french pastries!) in Shiodome City Centre. Tsuijiki Fish market (15 minutes walk) great experience with almost alien species there but traffic in there can be dangerous.

We stayed here for 4 nights 6/30/07 – 7/4/07 (booked online via hotel website on 4/13/07). Although the hotel was right above a train station, it was difficult to find. We met friends at the exit to the station, and walked for a while to get to the hotel. One friend was Japanese and could read the signs, and even she found it difficult to locate. We finally located the elevator and made our way to the hotel. It was mid-morning, so our rooms were not yet ready. At least one person spoke English at the front desk, and it was easy to communicate.We returned in the early evening, got our keys, and found that our bags had already been brought to our room. Hotel was very nice –large clean room. The best part about this hotel was the availability of Starbucks and convenience stores. When exiting the hotel underground, there are a variety of shops, restaurants, and stores. We loved the convenience store – in fact, we bought most of our souvenirs here – a variety of candies not found in the United States, including Green tea Kit Kat, Cola life savers, and Every Burgers (candy shaped like hamburgers -my favorite!)Breakfast buffet at the hotel was very expensive, and we did not indulge. A coffee and sandwich at Starbucks started each morning.Overall, hotel this hotel was decent, and we would recommend it. Once you get used to the walk from the hotel to the train, you’ll find it is very convenient.

Stayed here for four nights with my husband as part of a three month trip around the world. Absolutely loved the hotel. Arrived to amazing views from the reception on the 25th floor just as the sun was setting behind Mount Fuji and we also had good views of the water and skyline from our room. The hotel atrium and lobby are beautiful and tastefully decorated, as are the rooms. We liked the location and did not find the hotel at all difficult to find, contrary to other reviewers. It is very conveniently located to a choice of railway and subway lines, and is two minutes to the monorail. There are cafes and restaurants in the Shiodome building and the railway station, as well as in the nearby Marriot. It is also only a short walk to Ginza, the upmarket shopping area with a great choice of shops, department stores and restaurants. Our room was big by Japanese standards and had a lovely wide window sill, which I enjoyed sitting on and gazing out at the view. The night scape was particularly pretty, so much so that on our last night we did not even close the curtains. The concierge were very helpful with maps, directions and making reservations and in general the receptionists were good too, with one exception-we did encounter one very arrogant trainee who laughed in my face when I requested a late check out. We did eventually negotiate one, but there was a charge. The only other complaint I have was with regard to breakfast one morning. I had been to the fish market and returned to the hotel about 7am and decided to have a quick breakfast at the buffet in the lobby before going back to bed. I only had a glass of OJ and a pastry and decided to bring some fruit and pastries up to my husband who was still in bed. I signed for the breakfast (I think it was 16 euro for one buffet breakfast) and went towards the lift with my plate but was stopped by staff and told if I wished to have breakfast in my room I would have to order it through room service. I found this rather petty given the price of the breakfast. Despite this gripe I adored the hotel and it was probably my favourite of all hotels stayed in throughout Asia.

the park hotel is lovely but you've got to find it first. It seemed like a good idea to stay in a hotel that was above a train station as i'd heard tokyo was notoriously difficult to navigate. However the hotel was at least a ten minute walk through a maze of bland walkways and not very well signposted. We happened upon it almost by accident. The hotel itself is elegent but just a bit too far from any of the action. The Shiodome centre which it is housed in seems a bit of a white elephant.

We just got back from a three week trip to Asia, and the Park Hotel in Tokyo was one of the best hotels we stayed in. The view from the lobby is great, and the view from the room wasn't too bad either. The room was bigger than I thought it would be given all I had heard about the size of hotel rooms in Japan. The concierge was very helpful about giving us directions to various places and even helped book us on a tour. The location is really convenient. We were able to walk to the subway without going outdoors, which was a plus in December. We will definitely return to the Park Hotel the next time we are in Tokyo!

Am amazed by the positive reviews of this hotel. We just must have been unlucky. Stayed 5 nights in October and found the service (apart from the fantastic concierge) to be absolutely dreadful.Having spent two months travelling across Asia and staying in the best hotels 5-star hotels on that continent (including the Oriental and Peninsula in Bangkok, and the Park Hyatt in Tokyo) this was undoubtedly the worst - by a long, long way.The design is nice, and the location good if your priority is to walk into Ginza every night, but the front desk attitude is beyond belief. One guy was so rude to my girlfriend when she asked for another key to our room, that he was lucky I didn't drag him across the desk and give him a good leathering.Japanese service is amazing - from the taxi drivers to the bank clerks. Don't ruin it for yourselves by staying here, when there are far superior (cheaper/pricier) hotels on offer in this great city.

Just returned from the Park Hotel and can only repeat what others have said. We stayed here at the start and the end of our holiday and stayed in rooms overlooking Odaiba (at the start) and Tokyo tower (end) both views were fantastic.The staff were polite & helpful. Rooms were clean and a reasonable size by Tokyo standards.The room service was pricey.Shiodome is a great base and there is a wealth of restaurants and cafes if you head towards the underground station. The proximity to Shimbashi station is handy. In total the hotel is within walking distance of 3 underground lines, JR line and the monorail which makes travel easy.I would love to stay here again.

Like the other reviews say this is really good value for a new hotel in a convenient location for everything.The rooms aren't large but are well laid out and have amazing views (ours overlooked the water and the city lights) the bathrooms are very small but come with so many amenities you can overlook the tiny size.The hotel itself wasn't too hard to find from the Shimbash Train Station, just follow the signs for Shiodome Media Tower or ask where the big cukoo clock is and it is just around the corner from there!The concierge service was very good, they booked restaurants, gave us maps and directions and where in general very helpful.I would recommend this hotel to anyone wanting a new, very clean, well appointed hotel in Tokyo for a very reasonable price.We booked thru designhotels website and paid AU$200 but heard some people say they ahd booked through agoda.com and got it for AU$160!

This is a nice hotel, located close to the Ginza. The views from the front desk are amazing. The breakfast is pricey but super delicious. The concierge was very helpful in making restaurant reservations, and the staff go out of their way to be helpful. The rooms are nice, but a little small, with simple furnishings. But for the price I paid ($150 per night), it was well worth it. I would recommend this hotel as a nice place to stay. You could pay more and get better, but it's high quality for its price bracket.

My husband and I had a fabulous experience at this hotel. The staff is helpful, the rooms are quite spacious by Japanese standards and the hotel has luxuries beyond what is expected with this price tag. The rooms are immaculate, the views superb, and you are a quick underground walk to two subway locations. I whole-heartedly recommend this hotel, and will definitely stay there again during my next trip to Tokyo. I still can't comprehend how the prices are so low for the experience you receive.

We stayed here for a few nights on the way back to the UK from Sydney. The hotel is well connected to the Tokyo metro network with many lines having a station linked to it within the vast underground network of shops, offices etc. The hotel staff were excellent, finding us taxis, local info and maps (in english) and even lending us an umbrella to keep the rain off our heads.The rooms were excellent and very well presented. The food and drinks were very good though maybe pricey. There is free internet available for those without wi-fi.We would highly recommend this hotel when in Tokyo.

I stayed here one night last week, after an easy transfer on the ever-reliable Limo Bus (3000 yen). The staff is efficient and helpful, the room was spotless and surprisingly big considering I was in a single room and in Tokyo. The location is ok, I found it easy to walk to from the station, but the best thing is the overall quality Vs price paid. Sure, if you have a more generous budget there are other places I would recommend over the Park, but this is definitely the best quality hotel in this price range.

Excellent hotel ..I booked the premium room for the extra space which was money well spent,check in and check out slick,staff courteous and helpfull a great way to start and finish my stay in Tokyo..Booked the Airport Limosine bus service back to the airport through the hotel efficient service all in all very enjoyable.Go for a late drink at the Sky bars and restaraunts at the Dentsu building across from the hotel 46 floors up and killer views of the Tokyo bay area..

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 3 nights in a recent trip to Tokyo. The hotel occupies the upper floors (25-39) of the Shiodome Media Tower in the ultra modern Shiodome district. The location is very convenient; inside the building complex in the B2 level is a Family Mart convenient store. The Oedo Subway Line's Shiodome station is right outside the Family Mart, with easy access to Roppongi and Shinjuku districts. The Yurikamome Monorail Line also stops outside the building if you're heading to Odaiba. A 10-minute walk, either through the upper level skywalk (with excellent views of the nearby skyscrapers) or the underground passage, will lead you to the JR Shimbashi station with access to the popular Yamanote Line. Tokyo station and Shinkansen bullet trains are only a couple of stops away. The Ginza district is just steps beyond the Shimbashi station.The room we stayed in overlooks the JR Shimbashi station, but the noise from the passing trains is definitely not that noticeable unless you pay special attention to it. The double room is above average in size, but with the clean and minimalist decor, it looks spacious. The usual furnishings for a model Japanese hotel are there, including LCD TV, free broadband internet access (if you bring your own laptop), bidet for the toilet, bathrobes and slippers.There are a lot of dining options in nearby building complexs, including Pedi Shiodome, Caretta, and Shiodome City Center, all accessible by the underground passage.All in all, Park Hotel is a great choice if you want to stay in that area of Tokyo. It's a great combination of adequate luxury, convenience, and reasonable pricing.

We(5 people) booked it through its site. It required all your personal information. But the hotel is great. It sits 25- 43 floor with great view. Room is well cleaned and modern. Staffs are frendly and speaks English well. We goes out to the nearby mall for food, which is about the same price as in US. It takes a bit effort to find where the exits are and where to go since there are three floors underground and 2-3 floors above ground. There are two major metro station closeby. SO you can get anywhere. There are also two 7-11ish mart nearby so you can get drinks etc. Overall, it is a great hotel with great view: one side is faced toward Tokyo tower(such as front desk). We will go back without any problem. We stayed for three nights which is probably not enough for this city. I think you need at least one week there. PS, the fish market is 10 min walk from the hotel. And we walked to Ginza from fish market which is about 20 min. I could not post pictures since the wed site only allow file upload <1M or something.

We stayed for a week in late November and had two rooms on different sides of the hotel. Both rooms were above average in size, well lighted and very clean. The room on the side with the train station had some noise but not what has been mentioned in other reviews. Our other room was facing away from the station and it was quite quiet.The staff were very helpful and it is quite nice not having to tip in Japan. Below the hotel is an underground mall connecting this building to a number of others along with the rail system and metro. There are many places to eat in this complex and we had many very nice dinners with a beer or two for $20-$25 per head.There is direct service to the hotel from Narita via the airport bus which was quite helpful when we arrived. Returning to the airport we took the metro and rail which was less expensive but no faster.The location is within walking distance to the Ginza district although the Ginza metro line also has a stop in the underground mall. The fish market is also within walking distance.Next time in Tokyo we will stay here again!

This hotel is above a train station on the top 10 floors of the Shiodome Media Tower, so, you're guaranteed some kind of view whatever the aspect.Hotel is immaculate, excellent service, happy for us to check in early (at 9am!!), wonderful bar, compact but comfortable rooms, small but excellent bathrooms. Our toilet was space age - warmed seats, jet wash, etc,. great products were available for the toilette and the small touches like the lounging gowns, hotel slippers, coat brush, etc. were lovely. Fully equipped, comfortable and well staffed, this hotel was a lovely oasis of calm in the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Also, the Shiodome city housed loads of restaurants frequented by the locals, so good food was plentiful and within easy reach.Would highly recommend it.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights in November in a twin room on floor 26. Our room had an absolutely beautiful view of Tokyo including Tokyo Tower and on a clear day, Mt Fuji. The rooms look like they had been recently renovated and some beautiful toiletries were supplied. The reception, concierge and bell staff all offered excellent service and were fluent in english. The hotel location itself was excellent. Right above the Shiodome subway station and a 5 minute walk underground to the Shimbashi railway station. While we chose not to eat there (the prices were a little expensive) there are a few good places in Shimbashi station to pick up breakfast and the Family Mart (convenience store) downstairs offered some food items as well. The hotel provided free internet access which was definetly a bonus. Overall, I would recommend this hotel to anyone wanting to stay a nice hotel and convenient location in Tokyo.

I stayed in this hotel with my parents for a week when they came to visit me in Japan. It was more than 2 years ago, but our stay was so good that I still remember it well.The hotel is located in central Tokyo near the Shimbashi station on the circular train line, so it's really easy to get to any part of the city from there. The Tokyo train station is also a few stations away, so it's really convenient if you want to go on a trip to Kyoto for example. Plus it's in the most modern part of Tokyo, everything is so clean and easy to find. There are a lot of restaurants in the area, and the chic area of Ginza and the Tsukiji fish market with it's delicious sushis are not far away. The hotel is located at the top floors of a skyscraper so the views of the Tokyo bay were beautiful. We even saw mount Fuji one day when the weather was clear. The rooms weren't huge but still at a good size. The decoration of the room is pretty modern, very comfortable and cozy. A nice surprise : the fragrance coming from the bathroom.The staff is the best my father has ever seen -- and he travels alot. They were so welcoming, kind and patient. They really honoured the Japanese sense of hospitality.We didn't go to the restaurants of the hotel much because they are quite expensive, but there are plenty in the area. We did go to the Japanese restaurant in the hotel for our last night though, and it was delicious, the best sushi I have ever eaten in my life. For breakfast we went to the café at the ground floor, it was pretty good. There is also a Starbucks and a bakery in the Shiodome tower across from the hotel.

To us, this was a luxury city hotel at an affordable cost, and a great first stop in Japan. Easy to reach, within a short walking distance from JR Yamanote line as well as several subway stations (but do print out a map), with a cool atrium lobby and professional front desk staff, fluent in English of course.High class room with all the amenities offered superb night time view over Tokyo Bay, which you can also enjoy from the rather pricey wine bar. However, despite the proximity to Ginza, the surrounding area seemed quite characterless.

Confortable, modern, nice accomodation;Very clean; excellent amenities offering.Convenient location; easy access to transportation means.Excellent service and facilities, including free internet access. Attractive rate/service offering.

Summary: Would wholeheartedly recommend for a business/leisure trip to Tokyo. One of the best hotels I’ve ever stayed atComments..-Great location – right next to Ginza shopping district, 5 min walk from Shimbashi station on the Yamanote line, so it’s really easy to get to the main city districts (it’s not hard to get too/from the station as some people have said)-Good food places nearby – excellent food hall in Shimbashi station!-2 mins from Starbucks )-Very plush, modern – it’s a really fabulous hotel-Great views – the hotel starts from floor 25. We were on floor 33.. incredible view-Very friendly, helpful, professional staff – cute receptionist ;-)-Only two internet PCs – these were mainly available during the day ok, but at night were hard to get access to, with people queuing-Complimentary newspaper delivered to room-Lots of lovely toiletries provided-Absolutely superb value for price paid-Perhaps a bit too ‘businessy’ for a leisure trip-Excellent live music in lobby

This hotel is wonderful; Nothing is too much trouble, the food is superb, particularly in the Japanese restaurant, and the views are breathtaking. My favourite view is looking down at Shimbahi train station from the Japanese restaurant whilst having dinner. From 25 floors up it is like watching a model railway set up but in complete silence. Breakfast in the lounge area is also good and there is plenty of variety to choose from. I know that some folks have thought it expensive but it's less than £12 which is about par for the course. You can get a continental breakfast at the cafe on the 3rd floor if you like but I prefer to start the day with something substantial. The rooms are very good with just about everything you could need. I stayed here twice and my second room was smaller but still fine. The internet is free but usually not too difficult to get on. There is often very good entertainment in the evening. A good range of drinks and cocktails and a very swish French restaurant. Most of us aren't here to eat French food of course but the Japanese themselves seem to love it.The hotel is on the route of the airport bus and has a stop right outside.The only gripe I ever had was that altough Shimbashi station is easy to get to from the hotel, finding the hotel from the station always caused me trouble, even with a map. A bit of signage would be a great help I'm sure.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 7 nights (first week of November) The hotel itself is situated near plenty of nice restaurant's, however you will need to go for a wander into the basements of some nearby buildings. Just a short walk accross the upper level walkways (which really are outstanding) head over to th building with he big clock (you`ll know which one), head down stairs and you`ll find the Rose & Crown bar. The food there is outstanding and the fish and chips were certainly a cut above the common greasy stuff you find at home.There is also a nice pasta place nearby oposite McDonalds which does a lovely plate.Overall the hotel was nice, however one thing that really dissapointed me was the amount of people smoking in the main lobby reception area, Japan has still a lot to learn about health from passive smoking. The rooms while not overly large, were comfortable and very clean. The toilet was an experience in itself...leave you to decide about that.
