Also much to my suprise, you can drink the tap water and clean your teeth no probs. I thought this was the better place to stay out of a lot of others I read into. Thanks to all who contributed on here and helped make up my mind.

This is a great hotel. 7 minutes walk (underground) from Shimbashi JR station, maybe a bit tough for some people to find, but we printed out their PDF and had no problems. Located halfway up the Shiodome media tower, it is very clean, contemporary and reasonably priced (for Tokyo). Rooms a little on the small side (compared to western hotels), but comparable for Japan. Lovely toiletries (Thann) and all the amenities you need. Staff were incredibly helpful ... front desk, bell staff, waiters etc. Did I mention the staff were helpful? (smile) I have no hesitation recommending this hotel and would not hesitate to stay here again.

I've never written a hotel review before, here or anywhere else, but I feel compelled (in spite of all the OTHER good reviews) to write about the Park -- great location, lovely decor, thoroughly competent staff, and a really reasonable price. My husband and I stayed here for almost a week before going to Kyoto for a few days, and then we stayed again for several more days before leaving Japan. Both times we had a very clean, modern room (lovely bathroom with a great shower and lots of great products, by the way -- brush, razor, toothbrush, various toiletries, etc) with a wonderful view of the Tokyo Tower (and even Mt. Fuji on some days!). The hotel is easily walkable over to such great/convenient locations as Shimbashi Station, the fish market, Ginza, the Ginza Corridor (great dining of all sorts), etc. Back to the hotel, they were very efficient and accurate about arranging things such as a day trip to Mt. Fuji and a bus back to Narita at the end of our trip. We never ate at any of the restaurants/cafes there, since they seemed a little pricey and there were a ton of lovely and reasonable places to eat in neighboring highrises that were easily accessible by the over-street walkways that connect the buildings in this area (by the way, highly rec. the "set" meals at the Excelsior Caffe in the Pedi Shiodome building if you're looking for something easy to get to, good, and cheap — for instance, first thing in the morning — think they open as early as 7am), but we did splurge on drinks in the lobby bar on our last night -- we sat and looked at the beautifully lit-up Tokyo Tower and contemplated our lovely stay in this wonderful city and at this wonderful hotel!

We previously stayed at the New Otani and if it's true that the design of the trendy Park Hotel is much more contemporary, it also has a soulless tourist park feel that almost put us off.The location is good but not great - yes it's connected to a metro station but you have to walk about 10 minutes to get there. It's mainly a business district so there's nobody around at night or during the weekend which explains why the restaurant choice is somewhat limited to small lunch joints. We resorted to using taxis (600 JPY for the first 2km - it actually makes sense if you're a couple and not sure where you're going exactly).Even though we got there at 12:00, we had to wait 1 hour for our room and were not even offered a drink at the bar (not great when you're jet lagged and just want to go to bed).The room was pretty small with not much space left for luggages. The deco was nice though and the view was amazing. The bathroom amenieties were nice and the shower very powerfull, although they ask you to close the door as the steam might trigger the smoke alarm (?!).CNN and BBC World were the two English speaking channels on offer.We had breakfast through room service (about 5,000 JPY, crazy expensive!), nice an quick. We also had the buffet breakfast, which was served in the lobby bar and felt a bit like a train station cafe.Yes, everybody speaks English, including guests (mainly American, English and French - not a native in sight...) but what you gain in convenience is somehow lost by the impression that world-class Japanese customer service has been replace by a not so attentive one.That said, they didn't hesitate to give me some headache pills after a crazy karaoke night, lent scissors to open gadgets packaging, were always prompt to bring iron/ironing board to the room and the mini-bar was well stocked.All in all, nice enough stay but we'll try something else next time.
We stayed here for a 3 day stopover on the way to England. Absolutely loved the hotel. Beautiful rooms, very helpful staff, convenient location as near to transport.
Superb Hotel.We enjoyed a great at this hotel. It was very clean, and the location is great. They even have free internet access which was very convenient. The staff was both friendly and helpful.

This is an excellent gem of a hotel situated in Shiodome. We stayed there for a week and was pleasantly upgraded to a room with tokyo tower view at no additional cost. The staff were ultra-friendly and extremely helpful. Transportation via shuttle bus to and from the narita airport to the hotel can be arranged and it beats the hassle of lugging your luggage around in the train stations. You can also request for them to post your letters/mail/bulky boxes for you. Service is always courteous and English is well spoken by the front desk staff. We ordered room service on the first night and the meal was delicious albeit slightly expensive. The dinner set was beautifully presented and top marks for quality.The shiodome station is within 5 minutes walk. We got lost initially because there were no distinct signs. Instead of getting off at the ground level.. get off at the floor which leads directly to the overhead bridge where it will lead you to the train station. shiodome station also has a ginza line and the subway nearby which is extremely handy if you want to drop by tsukiji fish market. I am always a big fan of nice toiletries (Hahn) rather than some crap labelled shampoo/conditioner/shower gel (all in one). Extremely excellent value for money. IF you don't mind that there isn't a swimming pool.

View behind the reception desk is worth the stay. Pay the price and get a premium room, they are bigger. Appears only twin and single premium rooms have a view of Tokyo Tower, never mind the city looks good in all directions. Ultra quiet, free inroom high speed internet is brilliant. All staff speak good English and are helpful without being annoying. Only had breakfast in restaurant on one morning but found it very expensive and not much selection. Don't worry too much about this, there's loads of good places to each close by for much better value. Try the chicken restaurant over the other side of the road near the train line. Almost no English spoken, great food, never knew there were so many parts to a chicken you could eat! Fabulous fun if you want to try something different. Room service is average, 3 out of 4 choices were not available at 9pm on a Sunday night, but don't let that upset your stay, there's a lot of other nice things about the hotel that should not be overlooked.

One of the featured "design" hotels on the Tablet Hotels website, thePark Hotel is in the Shidome district, not far from the glitzy blocksof Ginza. I remember getting here for the first time was slightly annoying, as it's a bit off the main Yamanote line, but once I got lost the first time and walked around on the street, I figured out that it's not that far -- five or so minute walk -- to the train station.The hotel feels compact, as the lobby isn't that big, but the room was decent and just fine. What I remember the most was the breakfast buffet: the croissants, the yogurt-honey-fruit concoction I made numerous times, and the view at night from their small business lounge with a few computers for guests to use.If you've never been to Tokyo, and want a closer base to explore places like Shinjuku and Shibuya, you may want to consider another spot. However, if you're familiar with the train system or don't mindbeing slightly off the main path, it's a decent place to stay for a few nights.

Park Hotel Tokyo was a brillant hotel in a great location and had friendly staff who would go out of their way to help in any way possible.The location is great if either the metro or train is requied. Everything else is walking distance.The hotel was always clean with great facilities. The Centre Mall is opposite and it has restaurants and other shops at the doorstep.I canr fault this hotel and would definitely recommend it to anyone.

Park Hotel is in a great location of Ginza district . It is walking distance to the posh shopping district in Ginza, as well as the to the famous Fish market. It is also about 7 minute walk to the JR Shimbashi station on the Yamonote, which can get you to all of the tourist attractions in Tokyo. The hotel room is a quite roomy compared to the business hotels in Japan with awesome views of the city. The hotel also has a fantastic lobby with live jazz music. For the price that we paid (about $160/night) this hotel seems like the biggest bang for buck in Tokyo. I also recommend the restaurants on the first floor or basement for cheap lunches.

I just returned from a 3-night stay in Tokyo. I booked the Park Hotel based on all the other reviews on TripAdvisor and the hotel didn't disappoint. It is centrally located, within easy walking distance to Ginza, metro lines, Hama Rikyu, fishmarket. The hotel is gorgeous, brand new and has great views. The staff was excellent, very helpful. And you can't beat the price for Tokyo. I highly recommend it.

We have just returned from a three night stay at this hotel - our first time to Tokyo and Japan. The hotel itself is really lovely, with the room (City Queen) an adequate size for the time that's spent there. On reading earlier reviews we requested a room away from the many train lines, which was granted. The view was still awesome - of the bay and the Hamarikyu gardens (you must visit these gardens, easily accessible from the subway under the hotel (exit 7 or 8) and walk over the overpass. You can then get the ferry to Asakusa from the gardens. There's a great tea house and bridges within. Whilst we could still hear the hum of the trains from the two train lines below (31 floors below), it would probably have been unbearable on the other side of the hotel, where I think I counted 6 or 7 train lines - and they NEVER STOP! However, you would get THE best view of Tokyo Tower and at night that's pretty spectacular. (You can visit this Tower until 10pm nightly - a must see also) The size of the city is truly unimaginable until you get up there!The jazz in the lounge in the evening was fantastic. Different every night or so. As per earlier reviews, mostly we found the staff to be extremely efficient and friendly, only one did we find a little unfriendly, but not so much to notice.We had the breakfast on the last morning, and at 22,000 YEN wasn't overpriced for the selection, but the food was uninspiring and cold. The other mornings we took an earlier reviewer's advice and went to Vie de France underneath the hotel in the subway. For directions: if you're heading out of the hotel to the trains, it will be on your right in the building next door.My only complaint would be the directions on the hotel's website about finding the hotel. As the Limousine Bus from the aiport stopped it's route to this hotel ealier than our arrival, we got off at another stop and got a cab. The cabbie didn't know where the hotel was and I ended up finding it for him. The hotel has a great map for finding your way to the subway and JR lines, and back again, but you get that AT the hotel, not off the website. It would be soooo helpful to have it before so you could just get the Narita Express from the aiport. (We did this on our way home and I would get the train every time over that hideous Limousine Bus)! And, if you have a JR pass, and it's still valid, the train journey is free!Hope this all helps! I could go on.....but won't.... Have a great trip to Tokyo!

This was my fourth stay at this hotel and I was not disappointed - something I have come to expect from the Park Hotel Tokyo. I had a "welcome back" on check in which was a nice touch.As I was travelling alone on holiday I booked a single room via the hotel website for 5 nights. No problem with the booking and the rate was very competitive.This single room is a little cosy but because of the decor and layout it did not feel restrictive. The room was spotless and well stocked with little comforts - great bathroom amenities, nice coffee in the bar area and free internet access. Some hotels tend to start showing their age after a few years of service but this was not evident at the Park Hotel. I stayed in the hotel in the year it opened and can say that the hotel looks just as good now as it did back in 2004. The staff are very well trained, exceptionally courteous and speak perfect English. They will go out of their way to assist or answer any questions.The facilities around the hotel in Shiodome are very convenient. Shiodome is a major business district in Tokyo so the eating, drinking and transportation options are plentiful. To stock up on small drinks and snacks in the room there is an am/pm and Family Mart downstairs.I would have no hesitation to stay here again - in fact on this occassion I didn't even bother looking for a different hotel to try. For me this hotel is my "old faithful" in Tokyo.

So everything you read is true - this hotel has an amazing, breathtaking view of the city. The lounge areas are gorgeous and veryrelaxing, and the service is impeccable. The hotel concierge was veryhelpful with maps and directions several times. When you book ahead online you can get a pretty good rate by Tokyo standards.The location is actually quite good in my opinion. Since Tokyo has an intricate subway system, it is important to be in a location whereyou have access to the different subway lines to where the touriust attractions are. This hotel fits the bill. It is all indoor walking to every key subway line as well, which is nice when it's raining. Just makes it nice if you take a subway from the airport, as it is only one change of trains. The rooms were definitely small by any standard, and the appointmentsare not what I would call "upscale". But it was clean and fine. Not many TV channel options, which was a bit lame. And includes high speed internet, which is great. Very happy with our stay overall.

An excellent hotel - new, super clean, superior sevice. The location is close to subway and JR stations thus it's not a problem to get anythere in Tokyo or suburbs. Ginza, fishmarket, Hama Rikyu gardens - all within 15min walking distance from the hotel.Would definitely stay there again

My boyfriend and I stayed at this hotel for 8 nights on our first trip out to Japan. Wow what a place! As many of the other reviews have said, the hotel is extremely clean, all the hotel employees are very polite, are so nice and most of them speak English well enough to communicate effectively. Any questions you might have, I highly suggest that you ask front desk / concierge. They will go out of their way to help you out. Some things that I want to mention that other reviews have not … there are many other “Shiodome” complexes, within walking distance, that have great, reasonable places to eat. My favorite is “Pedi Shiodome”, which is just a short stroll thru the Yurikamome (3rd floor) pedestrian walkways. We tried many restaurants here including Ginzo Sushi and Excelsior Caffe (for my Western caffeine fix).The Oedo Subway Line (pink line) is what we took most. This line goes in a circle throughout Tokyo and connects to all the other major lines. The subway system is very efficient but requires a lot of walking (which I am surprised that everyone failed to mention). Be careful and double check that the subway line and the pay station match since each line requires their own tickets which are non transferable. This hotel overall is an excellent choice and I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend it to anyone staying in Tokyo. Enjoy!

As per some other reviewers, we were on honeymoon and the Park Hotel was our first stop. Interesting location known as "Shiodome"- an area reclaimed from marshland and now a modern scyscraper business area but very close to the main train lines and within walking distance of some of the big shopping areas such as Ginza.The hotel occupies the 25th to 34th floor of the building it shares with Kyoto News. Service could not be better. Anything we needed help with (i.e directions on arrival) they were only too pleased to do. We arranged to meet a friend for dinner one evening and when we asked at reception about getting there via taxi, they printed out a Japanese map with the exact location of our restaurant. Rooms were excellent and super clean. It is worth upgrading to the Premium Rooms as the views are spectacular especially at night.We arrived very early off a flight from Singapore and they checked us in straight away.Also, it is wirth getting the breakfast in the hotel as it is a buffet and can really get you up and running for the day! There is a choice of "western" or "traditional"Finally, from here you can walk to Shinbashi station which is on the JR line and pretty much services the entire of Tokyo. If you have a JR (Japanse Rail) Pass, you really get your money's worth. Get your head around the transport system early in your trip and Tokyo just opens up to the visitor!I will atach a shot with the view from the room when I get round to doing downloads!

This was the first stop on our honeymoon, and left our other destinations with a lot to live up to. We were in a city view room, upgraded as we were on honeymoon. The hotel staff were helpful and attentive. To get here from Narita airport i would recommend the shuttle bus which arrives straight at the door, we got the train (and scenic route), which is fine but takes an hour longer.The nearby monorail takes you to shimbashi station, which is easily walkable, although when you've been walking around all day the 280 yen trip is well worth it. The area is safe, clean and is walkable to ginza.When i return to tokyo i will stay here again as you can get away from the hustle and bustle, but still feel apart of the city vibe.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is located in the new modern Shiodome section of Tokyo. You can walk underground to the train station, the subway station, and the new monorail station. The nearby train station is only two stops away from Tokyo Station where you can connect to all other lines. The hotel is also only a 15 minute walk from Ginza where the kabuki theater is located. The walk is a simple direct route and very safe and well lighted even late at night.The front desk staff and concierge speak excellent English and are very helpful and solicitious. The lobby is gorgeous and the room very nice although not large. The restroom is very nice and the toiletries nicely aromatic. There are two computers available for complimentary internet use. We were there in late August when the weather was still somewhat hot and humid and we really appreciated the ice machine on our floor which also dispensed cold water so we could always enjoy ice water in the room. Also very convenient was the Family Market on the building's ground floor, equivalent to a 7-Eleven, where you could buy snacks, drinks, hot food, medicine and toilietries. We would definitely stay at the Park Hotel again.We booked online and got a special rate of 18,000 yen for making our reservation early. The front desk advised me that special rates are only available online so making reservations at the hotel's website is recommended. If you are unable to book at the Park Hotel Tokyo, in the building next door is the Villa Fontaine Shiodome, also a good choice. The Villa Fontaine is a business class hotel chain and many of their locations are not so nice, but the Shiodome location is new and very nice. We stayed there for two nights when the Park Hotel was full. At the Villa Fontaine Shiodome we had a 13,000 yen weekend rate which included a simple breakfast. The Villa Fontaine has self service washing machines and dryers on every other floor.

We have just come back from a fabulous trip to Japan in September 07, having stayed 4 nights at the Park Hotel. The hotel is in a great location, very handy to all lines on the metro and JR making travelling around Tokyo very convenient. We were pleasantly suprised by the size of the room (queen bed), good views, very comfy mattress and nice bathroom too. Front desk spoke good english and as in true Japanese style were exceptionally courteous and helpful. We didn't have the breakfast - not included in the rate, approx $30 AUD per person which is pricey, but it looked nice (buffet with pastries, cereal, eggs, juices etc). There are plenty of breakfast options though and by the number of people coming into the hotel with supermarket bags this was the prefered one!I would highly recommend a stay at the Park Hotel. It is central, great value and super clean. What more could you ask for. It is a 5 minute walk to Ginza, where you can find great restaurants and shopping. If thinking about Ginza vs. Shinjuku as a base i would choose Ginza - no comparison really. If arriving by train to JR Shinbashi Station make sure you download the directions and map from the hotel website as the underground malls can be a little confusing.

We stayed in the Park Hotel for 5 nights in July, we visit Tokyo regularly and normally stay in the Hilton in Shinjuku but after reading reviews on Tripadvisor and getting a recommendation from friends we decided to stay in the Park. The hotel, as mentioned in previous reviews, is in Shiodome Media Tower with the lobby on the 27th floor. Visually the place is amazing, beautiful views and very serene. The staff at check-in were excellent and upgraded us to a higher floor upon our request. We were looking over the bay area. We stayed in 2 City Queens (standard rms) on the 33rd floor, the rooms are compact but beautifully designed and the beds are really comfortable.We ate in the Japanese restaurant on our first night with great views & excellent food although small portions and reasonably expensive. Be warned that most restaurants (incl. the hotel) in the area have last orders between 9 and 10pm so you need to take this into account when planning your evenings. I recommed trying the top floor restaurants in the Shiodome City Centre building nearby - the view & food are outstanding.From a location point of view you are within 5 mins walk of Shiodome station with excellent and easy links to all the most popular areas of Tokyo.We have just booked our Christmas trip to Tokyo and are staying in the Park again. Both times we have booked on their website and the rates are excellent plus the hotel personally email you to confirm you booking and any individual requests you might have. The City Queen Early Bird rate is roughly $160/nt and for the room, service and location this is an outstanding deal.

I think anyone reading the reviews on the Park Hotel will realise that this is one of the top hotels for Western visitors in Tokyo. I stayed here during February 2007, so forgive the belated review but here’s my impressions and tips.I can confirm that it is difficult to fault the staff and the hotel. The hotel is very convenient for central Tokyo and the travel links are superb, i.e. close to Shimbashi Station for the JR loop line and the Tube. Initially, the hotel is not easy to find but was resolved by taking a taxi from Shimbashi Station (cost less then £3) to the ground floor entrance and subsequently obtaining a ‘directions’ leaflet from the English speaking Concierge for the walkways accessed from the Third Floor. As other contributors have noted, it should not be confused for the Royal Park Hotel which is adjacent. As for the noise factor, for those who have exceptional hearing, there is some ambient noise in the background but this is not significant. This may be dependent from which side you are located; from what I can discern, all the rooms are built around a central atrium and face outwards towards Tokyo Bay or Tokyo Tower. As for dining, the easiest option is to head for the Caretta Centre or Shiodome City Center as these have every variety of restaurant imaginable.As for the negatives, being very pernickety, the size of the room coffee mugs seemed miniscule by Western standards and the free-internet facility in the Lobby was sometimes unavailable. I was also charged 30 Yen for one A4 copy from the internet which I thought was slightly cheeseparing! This said, if you want the futuristic Tokyo experience, this is the place.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is in the Shiodome area, on the higher floors of an office building and it's very close to other hotels like the functional Villa Fontaine (no room service), the Royal Park and the very upscale Conrad Hotel. Having stayed at the other aforementioned places, for my money, I would choose the Park over the rest (not that I can really afford to stay at the Conrad haha) as it offers the best value for its rates. I have stayed here a few times and on my second visit, they upgraded me to a better room with a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower, not much in the daytime but really gorgeous at night. Now, every time I stay there, they have always given me the upgrade, without my having to ask for it.The rooms are very comfortable and the decor is understated and chic. Bathroom amenities are from a Thai company that makes natural and organic products. If you want to take them home (and they do smell lovely), bigger bottles are for sale at the hotel store, tucked in a small corner off the elevators on the lobby.Don't take the breakfast - at over Y2,000 it's very plain and you can get better pastries and bread at Vie de France and the other coffee shops in the Shiodome train station area.The other great thing about the Park Hotel is that it's connected to the Shiodome and Shimbashi stations via an underground passageway -- terrific to get out of the rain or the cold. It's also connected to the Yurikamome station for shopping forays into Odaiba. And the buildings around the hotel have so many restaurants and coffee shops to choose from. Not to mention convenience stores for last minute emergency supplies.You can also book online and they have a special rate for bookings 30 days in advance that was even cheaper than the corporate rate that I used to get.There are no unpleasant suprises at The Park Hotel Tokyo, just consistently good facilities, service and great value!

I have just backed from this pretty great hotel.center of tokyo with easy access to shimbashi station and also to narita express through tokyo stationEverything was great except a tiny room , but who spend time in roomin tokyo ? I asked following one reviewer from here a room on the same side as a reception room - with the great view to ginza including tokyo tower. although the side was the same as station I did not hear anything - I was on 31th floor.Caretta Center- full of different restaurants and we did breakfest at VIA de France - yummy. Try as much as you can...sushi is even better than at tsukuji market (15 minuts from hotel)When I saw differents hotels in tokyo then..please believe me you apreciate Ginza district - and i do not talking about shopping (the best area this is shibuya and harajuku>but neigbourhood. peace and quite after 6pm but simultanously you can take a train and be in 15 minutes in ueno area.absolutely must buy RAILPASS.

I stayed two nights at the Park Hotel. The first night I was put into a double room which was on the 31st floor. Even though I was way up there, the subway trains kept me awake most of the night. At 6:00am I wandered down to the front desk to get a room change so I could sleep and I was taken to a single room, which was much nicer, although smaller, on the otherside of the building. I could still hear the trains but it was a huge differance.Bonus: Toilet seat is heated, has a fancy bidet option as well as a heated section of the mirror so you can see when you get out of the shower and need to do your hair. There is a kettle and coffee/tea in the room as well as good bathroom amenities and soaps.The Japanese restaraunt in the hotel was wonderful and the food was fresh. The girls that were in-training were a great help for shopping and subway directions. They were full of energy and very happy to help, which is more then I can say for the gentlemen at the front desk. The location was good for me as I just took the subway to Ginza to shop and look around the city. There a lots of places to eat in the lower level of the hotel as well as a Starbucks and a McDonalds if you need your western fix. They also offer free internet in their mini business centre with two semi private computers.The last night of my stay, a category 9 Typhoon stormed through Tokyo. The hotel lobby had computer printouts of the weather and kept the guests up to date with what was happening. The television stations had a few good stations that offered english interpretations. No problem in the morning and my flight left on time in the afternoon.They also offer an airport shuttle bus that makes a couple of hotel stops. When I arrived, it was quite late at night and I missed the last bus for this hotel. Thankfully, the airport counter attendtant for the limo shuttel bus service suggested I take the next bus to a close hotel and then taxi it over. This worked for me very well, although beware, taxi's are VERY expensive in Japan. It's a good hour from the Narita airport to this area of Tokyo, but it was worth it. They help with luggage as well as a comfortable ride.

We had a wonderful stay at the Park Hotel for several nights in early April 2007.HOTEL: You must take two different sets of elevators to reach your room, but we did not find that to be an inconvenience. Our room was immaculately clean with an enormous premium-king sized bed and great views. The bathroom was definitely the best part, complete with heated toilet seats and an anti-fog mirror.LOCATION: The hotel in located in the futuristic Shiodome district of Tokyo. It's just a few minutes away from the metro lines and the short walk can be done completely underground through very clean and well lit tunnels. Best of all, the hotel is just a 15 minute walk from Tsukiji Fish Market. We were able to take advantage of its proximity and make a few early morning runs for the best sushi and sashimi in the world!SERVICE: The entire staff was wonderful. The front desk helped us with so many things, from securing dinner reservations at an Iron Chef's restaurant to providing cold medicine when the nearest pharmacy was closed. We also took a 2 day excursion to Mt. Fuji and Hakone and were able to leave our luggage at the hotel while we were gone.I would highly recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo and would definitely stay there again!

Once again, the staff at Park Hotel has proven their worth in gold.I was there in August and the staff took care of my dining arrangements and even helped me to find a book that I needed to get. Special mention goes to Hirota-san (concierge) and Watanabe-san (Front Office) who went out of their way to book me a hotel whan I had to be out of Tokyo over the weekend.It is just the attention to detail that was super, complete with detailed maps and discount coupons that the staff will arrange for you so that you wont lose your way and get the best deal!I am surprised the hotel is not listed as number one on trip advisor for tokyo

This hotel is a real pearl. It's inexpensive, it's chic, the service is great and the location is not bad either. The reception is situated on the 25th floor of one of the towers in the Shiodome complex. You get both excellent views of the Tokyo cityscape going up in the lift and from your room window. It's also easily within walking distance of all the stores in Ginza. We had not one complaint about the service. Everyone on reception was both helpful and efficient. We had read murmurings prior to our trip about the small size of the rooms, but found the set-up similar to many rooms in Europe. The decor is stylish and the bathrooms well-equipped. You have heated toilet seats and the part of the mirror above the sink does not steam up while you're having a shower. So, you don't have to shave or brush your teeth through the mist! For us, the real highlight were the breakfasts, which are absolutely delicious. We live in Paris and the pastries were as good as any we have tasted here. If I had any grudges about the Park Hotel, then they would be slight. The first one would be the difficulty in actually finding it. We arrived at the Shimbashi train station and I had printed out a plan from the Park's website. However, it wasn't 100% clear that we had to go into the underground complex when we got out of the station. There are also steps in the same place going up to an overpass and we were slightly confused. The second thing, which may bother some people is that the tower in which the hotel is situated is right next to a major train line. You can hear the rumbling of trains below all the way through the night. It didn't bother us, but it could be a pain if you're a light sleeper. Otherwise, definitely try out the En restaurant on the 42th floor of the neighbouring Shiodome City Center tower. The views are amazing and the food fantastic.

After a long search in Tripadvisor we decided to book Park Hotel Tokyo and we're very happy with our choice. It is one of the best hotels we've been ever, and through Expedia it was only for 105 euros every night, without breakfast. As there are lots of other traveller's comments and I think that I can't tell you nothing new about the hotel itself, but maybe some tips (useful, I hope) will help.1) How to get to the hotel the first time you travel to Tokyo. When in Narita, to take a train to central Tokyo, step down in Shimbashi station and walk to the hotel along the underground floors seems extremely complicated. One easier possibility is to take the Airport Limousine Bus [--] which in some cases takes you directly to the hotel door. I think first departure from Narita to the hotel is at 13:50, so if you arrive earlier you can take the Airport Limousine Bus that goes to the Dai-Ichi Hotel. It's so near to the Park Hotel than a taxi from the Dai-Ichi to the Park Hotel costs only about 600 yens. The Airport Limousine Bus it's not a limousine, it's just a bus.2) To have breakfast. In the basement floor (press B2F in the elevator), walk to the Shiodome City Center building and you'll see Vie de Paris. Excellent to buy croissants and many kind of pastries, take an orange juice and a coffee.3) Spend some time to familiarize yourself with the hotel surroundings. In the B2F basement floor there are the entrances to the Shiodome City Center, Caretta Shiodome and Tokyo Shiodome Building. They are plenty of restaurants. No need to go far away at night to have dinner, enough good choices beside the hotel.4) Go to the Skyrestaurants floor in the Caretta Shiodome (46th floor). There is a free viewpoint to the Tokyo City. Excellent at night. Don't miss it.5) If you get tired of japanese food, you can go to the Gran Diva restaurant. Excellent pizzas & salads, and with english menu with photos to help you with your choice. It is outside the Nihon TV Tower. To go there, exit the hotel by the 3rd floor (Yurikamome), and walk opposite to the underground station and then turn left, not down to the street, but along the pedestrian deck and you'll find it after the escalators, one floor lower.6) Tokyo / Japan souvenirs. Among all the places we visited in Tokyo and Japan maybe the best place to buy souvenirs was the street in front the Senso-Ji temple (Asakusa Kannon Temple), one of the best spots in Tokyo. There are lots of shops, will lots of things. Be aware, shops close very early, I think between 17:00 and 18:00 hours.7) If are going to travel around Tokyo or Japan with the Japan Rail Pass, and even though you are not going to use it from the first day of your arriving at Narita, exchange your voucher and get the Japan Rail Pass at the Narita Office, because I think in the Shimbashi Station there is not an office to do so.Hope these tips will help you a bit in your Tokyo visit.

Just returned from 6 day family vacation to Tokyo and had a marvelous stay at the Park Hotel. Arranged my stay via Hotel Website after reading accolades from Tripadvisor, very easy to use.Hotel is easily served by Airport Limo Bus Service from Narita Airport. Service is extremely attentive from the greeting at entrance to check in. English is not an issue. In fact, Tokyo is a lot easier to get around now with English translations in buildings, restaurants and subways.Hotel itself is very modern, airy and serene at the top of a 38 story building in Tokyo Shiodome, which is a series of modern skyscrapers serviced by subway and trains below street level and connected via pedestrian walkways on the third floor. Very quiet despite the activity down below. Didn't use the trains, but found the subway connected to the Ginza and Asakusa Lines, which will hit just about every tourist site in the Tokyo area. There is also a monorail that will take you to the seaside development of Odaiba. Hotel is ten minutes from the Wholesale Fish Market by foot--this a Tokyo must see, if you get up early.With my family of 5, got a twin and a triple. Rooms generous in size for Tokyo, bathrooms and amenities were very good. Restaurant services a very good breakfast buffet which our family enjoyed before hitting the streets. Did not eat any other meals in hotel--seemed pricey, but the building is connected to other Shiodome buildings--Carretta and City/Pedi Shiodome had a number of inexpensive and good restaurants offering a variety of Japanese and non-Japanese foods. There is a Family Mart in the basement level of Park Hotel building for snacks. While we were staying in the hotel, there was a free jazz concert every nite in the lobby.Service was excellent. The concierge services were very helpful and helped me to work with a tour agency that had "lost" our reservation for a tour to the Ghibili Museum on the outskirts of Tokyo. Fortunately, the concierge was able to clear up the problem and we got to go on our tour.Can not think of anything negative to say about the hotel, definitely worth the price, would definitely go back and would definitely recommend it to my friends. Thanks to all fellow Tripadvisor reviewers for the high rating this hotel gets and deserves!

We spent 2 nights here and were very pleased with this quiet, unassuming yet elegant hotel. It's lobby is on the 25th floor and has fantastic views. The staff was curtious and very responsive to our requests.

While I enjoyed staying at this hotel (which is a little on the pricier side more 4 star than 3), and the room and service were great, I really REALLY dislike how you could smoke in the foyer area, so I'm taking a star off for that. It is not nice having to walk through that stink every time.This was one of the more classier/expensive places I stayed in. The service was very good, and I got a free upgrade to a 'tower view queen room' (from a city queen room) which was very nice of them (hotel was definitely in low season). They kept my luggage for several days after I checked out and they were very professional and helpful. While the view is quite nice, I wouldn't recommend paying that much for one! (see pics)Room size was adequate, and you could set up a washing line in the SOB. Bathroom was quite nice, nice towels (of all kinds), many toiletries (of high quality and natural ingredients), fancy toilet, slippers, robes. Rom key was electronic, and electricity only powered when key is inserted. Air con was adequate for the hot weather. There was a safe, free internet, nice LCD TV, big bed, room and laundry service, fancy stuff in mini bar. It may seem fancy but stay away... quite expensive stuff in there. There's a Family Mart on the bottom level, go there for cheap food and drinks! I did order a pizza from room service and it was SO SO greasy ... at more than 1800 yen for a good size slice of GREASE, Tabasco and a small bottle of Evian.Bit hard to reach, have to trek from Shimbashi station through the Shiodome complex (which was quite nice clean and modern, just a teeny bit of a hike), find the office building this is on top of and then take a side elevator up to the foyer. But once you find it, it's all good! If you use the map on their site, it's not very detailed and make a note of the levels...I don't recommend eating here, very expensive and didn't look that great.Again... too bad about allowing smoking in the foyer. Plenty of old Japanese businessmen come in to eat at the restaurants and chill out, smoking in the foyer 8-( Everything else was very good, and appropriate for what I paid.

After the long haul flight to Tokyo it was good to have a bit of comfort to look forward to. And this hotel is really comfortable. The beds and pillows were great. The toiletries were very generous - including toothbrushes, toothpaste, hairbrush, moisturiser, bath salts - and the basic "city" rooms are a decent size for Tokyo with great views ( a view of Tokyo Tower costs a little extra, but the other views are good too).The location is also perfect. It's a relatively newly developed area, but within walking distance of the fish market, boat trips, Ginza shopping area. There's a metro station right outside and there are lots of good places to eat in the neighbourhood.Would definitely stay there again.

I stayed in Park Hotel last 18th august and I have to say we really liked the Hotel. The room is quite spacious and we had great views of the Tokyo Tower. The bathroom is not so big but that's Japan!! Everything was so clean and the staff at the front desk just incredible servicial. We booked thru the Hotel website and we got a good rate of 22000Yens with all tax included for a queen. The problem to book with expedia or other websites was that they could not guanatee a nice view and the Hotel offered us that without a problem.

Hello,I found this hotel on Tripadvisor but booked it for 4 nights through my travel agent with an amazing discount. While all the travel sites were showing 250$-270$ per night, she was able to get me the 170$-180$ per night range. So word of advice: worth checking with your agent.The hotel itself is amazing. Just as you see on their Website. The whole place is classy and it feels that way right when you walk in. But it's very unpretentious. We were two jeans-T-shirt type of guys and didn't feel awkward. The staff makes you feel at home.I'll go with the usual Pro/Con description:PROs:- Amazing common areas. Slick boutique style hotel. The only hotel in Tokyo that made it into the Designer Hotels category (or some similar classification)- Great attention to details in the rooms (example: part of the mirror doesn't get condensation so you can shave in that spot right after the shower)- Nice little plasma TV- AMAZING VIEW! With the hotel occupying floors 25 and above, you get a great view of Tokyo and surrounds from the top. Absolutely request a room that faces the tower. The hotel has 3 sides but to avoid any confusion, ask for a room on the same side as the reception. On a good day we were able to see the Mount Fuji. It is worth waiting for a room with that specific view if one is not ready- Location: It is located in an area that has somewhat of a futuristic side to it, above malls. If feels a bit like being in a realistic sf movie when you walk on the top of the platforms with all these tall buildings and the monorail above you.- Plenty of eating options around: restaurants, cafes as well as food stores. Local and western.- The breakfast looked amazing, never tried it though- Amazing value for the price- The staff is really nice and helpful. Take advantage of the concierge, she was a great source of info for shopping for us.CONs- Out room was somewhat on the small size, but very functional- Location: I understand that it could be somewhat off the main touristy attraction. It is not Shinjuku but the area is 1) really not isolated, as you can find malls as well as typical Asian places all around and 2) it's really close to everything by metro. But if someone is more into nightlife he's probably better off with a hotel in Shinjuku.It was the best hotel experience of my entire 5.5 week trip in Asia Australia (with the Mandarin Oriental in Singapore being a close second). I am thinking about a trip to China next year. If I decide to stop in Tokyo, I will absolutely go back to this hotel.Word of advice: there are 3 or 4 hotels in Tokyo with the word Park. So make sure you select the right one. Also, if you go to Japan, make sure to visit Kyoto. Tokyo's temples and gardens really pale in comparison. Kyoto is unique, not to be missed! Spend AT LEAST 3 nights in Kyoto and 3 in Tokyo. For an odd number (7 nights, etc) I would add a night in Kyoto.

Where to begin but the fact that this hotel is on the 26th floor and upwards of a skyscraper with fantastic views of the city including Tokyo Tower and on a clear day Mount Fuji in the distance with its snow cap.If the fact that you can arrive in your room and gaze out across the bustling city (which is absolutely incredible at night but still impressive on waking in the morning) doesn't win you ovr to stay at this hotel then perhaps some of the finer points may.The rooms by Tokyo standard are a good size, we opted for a King room which was more than adequate considering you probably won't spend that much time there. There are corner rooms available if you want a few extra square feet or perhaps are staying for a while.The staff here are very helpful and brought me hair appliances when mine didnt work (ladies be warned its a different voltage from many other countries and straightners dont work so dont waste your luggage allowance) they are also excellant with advice for where to go or how to get there. Just ask the front desk if you need anything.We booked through the hotels website after checking majority of main sites online and phoning the hotel it worked out the cheapest rate by quite a bit. I think we paid $300 USD for 2 nights so about £150 including breakfast and of course the wonderful view.Right below this hotel is a 7/11 convienience store which is not suprisingly about an 8th of the price of stuff in the minibar and obviousley offers some good snacks too.We ate in the hotel restaurant one evening, Don't recall the name but its the one which isn't japanese cuisine. It's not a cheap meal but having said that its not as expensive as things can be in Japan. We had a set menu of 6 course which i think was around £30 each and also a wonderful rose wine to go with it. The food was wonderful, they served two different appetizers, then fish, then a meat of your choice followed by 'pre-dessert' and grand dessert' i dont quite understand the idea behind the pre dessert thing but it was definately delicious.After dinner we drank cocktails in the hotel bar which for me is the only negatve to this place, the bar itself is modern and sophisticated and cocktails were up with some of the best ive had but the view has been ruined by an office building that you just can't quite see over the top of. Whether it came after the hotel was built i dont know, but it does make you wonder why they didnt have the bar on the top floor. Having said this its really not bad as you can watch people still working i their office at midnight and revel in the fact you're away from that.All in all a great hotel at a very good price for Tokyo. I feel you get your moneys worth just from the view but if you dont agree theres always buffet breakfast which you'll definately want to return to for more.

My wife and I stayed at this hotel for two nights on the tail end of a recent trip to Japan. We chose this hotel based on the reviews we read here on Trip Advisor, and wanted to try something different than our earlier stay in Tokyo's Shibuya district.We found the hotel to be clean and modern, as described, but our "Queen" room was quite small, still OK. We found the room fit and finish to be a bit on the spartan side, especially the bathroom. I understand why others have suggested upgrading to the executive floor. But generally speaking the hotel is well appointed and the staff was efficient, although the concierge desk was particularly unfriendly and unhelpful, I guess it depends on the person at the desk. Bellmen , on the other hand were very efficient in dealing with our logitics to Narita.We did not use the hotel for breakfast, but we did have one dinner in the Japanese restaurant in the hotel, which was quite acceptable.I guess our biggest disagreement with other reviewers here is with location. The hotel is right in the center of an office building complex, so if you like empty office lobbies and aerial maze of passageways, this hotel is good. But apart from a strange and quite large mall and outdoor TV studios next door, there is no "there" there.It is a good 15 minutes from Ginza on foot. Our first adress in Tokyo on this same trip was in Shibuya, which we preferred as the hotel was in a "real" neighborhood, and far more readily accessible to public transit, and had the feeling of actually being in Tokyo.

We just spent 8 days at these hotel with 2 kids and I have to tell you how amazed we are by the service we received. The staff of this hotel is amazing, paying attention to every detail and request we had and the concierge was very helpful in booking our day trips. At times I ordered something for my room before I got in the elevator and it was delivered 2 minutes later. The room was impecable with a beautiful view of the city. The bed and pillows were very comfortable and the A/C was fantastic. The bathroom has everything you need for shaving,a comb and nice shampoo and conditioner plus creams and many other things. The location is also very nice if you take the time to explore the area. First of all you have Ginza in a 15 minute walking distance and two metro stops that will take you anywhere. Do not be afraid to use the metreo because it's easy to learn (fo;;ow the color for the line you need and the number for the station) and every station has an attendant who speaks english and gives directions. If you stay at this hotel, always get off on the 3rd floor and use the overpass to get to your metro or walking destination. You have an AM PM across the street for water, fruit, beer and many restaurants in the building next door for dinner or take out.Again, for the money you are getting a very nice staff and a great room. Enjoy Tokyo!

This is a great hotel - spanking clean, wonderful service and great rooms. I selected this hotel based on the wonderful Tripadvisor reviews and I could not have been more pleased. The location is within walking distance of both a JR Station (Shimbashi) on the Yamanote line and a Metro (subway) Station (Shiodome). Check-in was a breeze and we were welcomed when we arrived. The lobby is beautiful and welcoming. Our room had a wonderful view and was larger than I thought it would be. Although not huge - I must say that I have had much smaller rooms in Europe. TV had CNN and BBC for us English speakers and we had Ethernet Internet access in our room. In room safe. An English speaking newspaper was delivered every morning. Breakfast was delicious - croissants absolutely wonderful. Concierge helpful with restaurant and directions (Tsukiji is very close by). It's about 3 minutes to the subway and I would say about 10 minutes to the closest JR station. Both can be reached by the underground pathway system. For those with kiddies, McDonald's in the Caretta Shiodome Building on B2 level is close by as are several wonderful restaurants. We liked Buitoni in the Caretta Shiodome building (B2 level) and also had a very nice meal at China Quick on the B2 level of the Shiodome Media Tower - same building as the hotel. I would stay here again - I wish it was a little closer to a JR station but the walk was fine...
Our stay at Tokyo Park Hotel was really nice: the staff was helpful, the room clean (even if it was'nt too big), elegant and very well equipped. We liked it! :o)

my husband and i stayed in park hotel tokyo after reading reviews on tripadvisor.the hotel is located in the shiodome media tower, starting on the 25th floor. you can walk to it on the skywalk from shimbashi train station. we booked a double en-suite for £85/night. it was far more than what i had expected for my money. the room was very nice and cosy and the bathroom had a modern japanese toilet (with bidet and seat warmer). what came as a pleasant surprise were the toiletries: aromatherapy shower gel and shampoo, bath salt, body lotion, toothbrush and tooth paste, and a razor with shaving cream.the hotel staff was very helpful and nice at all times. and the atmosphere was very tranquil as there was a classical music band playing in the lounge (the same place where breakfast is served).perhaps what made own stay there so enjoyable was the fact that on a clear day, you can see mount fuji from the reception area.the only downside is the existence of only two computers available to the guests.i would recommed this hotel to any traveler visiting tokyo as it is great value for money
I spend some time in this exccellent hotel. It is worth evry penny You spent there. I will ceirtanly go there again, when I will stay in Tokyo. Peter R.

Room was very comfortable and priced right. We even lucked out with a spectacular view of Mt. Fuji one morning in the rainy season! Staff was very helpful and attentive. Only had the breakfast buffet one morning, and selection was great. Room amenities included yummy smelling bath toiletries, good coffee, and a fun toilet. Location was perfect for our needs - easy access to trains, within walking distance of the fish market and Ginza. I would definitely stay here again!

We did a two day stopover at the Park Hotel in July. It was excellent. We asked for a non-smoking room and were very pleased with the size of the room. It may have been an up-grade. The bed was king-size. The room was very well appointed and comfortable. The toilet was a delight. Never experienced anything like it. The hotel is close to Ginza and Shimbashi station. The hotel is very tastefully decorated. The lounge area is very quiet and pleasant. The jazz performance at night was a treat. The concierge was very helpful and efficient. The most impressive feature was that the staff were extremely courteous, helpful and well-trained. Do not miss a visit to the Tsukji Fish Market. It is amazing.Also, the limousine bus worked very well for us being airport to hotel door. Saved lugging suitcases around.Overall, we had an excellent stay at this lovely boutique hotel. It is highly recommended.

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 3 nights and thought it was great. It was in a very safe location which was just 5 mins walk away from the shops in Ginza. Our room was on the 29th floor and had great views. The room was a good size, considering it cost only £80 per night for a double room. The toiletries provided were great, as were the free toothbrush, hairbrush, razor, and also the tea/coffee. We did hear some faint noise from the train station but it didn't bother us.We found it quite easy to navigate our way from the room to the main streets. Simply take the lift to the Lobby, then walk across the Lobby, and take either one lift to the main entrance of the building or the other lift to the subway. Even jetlagged we were able to work it out. My only complaint was the breakfast we bought on our first morning in the Hotel Lobby restaurant. It cost 5000 Yen for 2 continental breakfasts, which was more expensive than any other meal we had in Japan! The next morning we went to the cheaper 'News Art Cafe' on the ground floor of the building, which cost 650 Yen for a coffee and croissant.We also appreciated the free internet access on 2 computers and didn't have any problem accessing them.Would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone planning a trip to Tokyo. It is a modern, well located and well priced hotel.

We had chosen this hotel because of the good reviews in tripadvisor and were not dissapointed.We had a twin room on 28th floor for 5 nights. It was very clean. Small in size but totally sufficient to our needs. The view was amazing. The only downside was the noise from the trains, but the traffic calms down for the night. The service was exellent and no complaints about the stylish puplic interiors.We found the hotel location perfect for exploring the Tokyo and it was also easily accessible by foot and several train and metro lines.

We (parents and 12 year old boy) stayed twice in the Park Hotel in July, for a total of 5 nights. We had a corner room and it was plenty big - from the other reviews, sound like these are a lot bigger than the regular rooms. The bathroom was good, with plenty of toiletries, tootbrushes, razors etc. First introduction to heated toilet seats... We stayed on the 30th and 33rd floors with no noise from the trains, even though we were above the train lines. The hotel was great, and we throughly recommend it. For a first visit, the Airport Limousine from Narita stops right outside making travel easy - if you're more confident, its easy enough to take JR to Shimbashi, and then follow the pedestrian walkways to the Shiodome tower (download the map from the hotel's web site first!). The walkway to the 3rd floor of the Shiodome are easy to follow - the basement tunnels are more complicated and we rarely used them. There is a Family Mart in the basement, useful for food and other items. As other reviewers have noted, the surrounding buildings are full of restaurants of all types. The location is also good - lots of metro lines close, easy to get to Tokyo Station (though the fastest way seemed to be the JR lines from Shimbashi, not the metro), right beside the Yurikamome monorail that goes to Teleport, and easy walking distance to Ginza.The only disappointment was that there is no WiFi network (there is cable access for laptops in the rooms however). Also, the hotel is not for those who dislike heights, as it extends from floor 25 to floor 34 of the media tower. Would definitely stay again.

The rooms here are beautiful, and the bathroom alone was half the size of many Japanese apartments. Add in the free internet service, free Herald Tribune under the door each morning, complementary coffee and tea, and the hotel deserves 4 stars. Now for the bad news. Our room faced the Shimbashi train station, and the noise was persistent and loud between 5 a.m. and midnight. A noise generating air purifier was cleverly left running to mask the noise, but did not help. Most frustrating for us was the location of the hotel, attached to the complex of buildings known as the Shiodome. This complex is reminiscent of one of those large hamster habitats, with a bewildering 5 level array of overhead and subterranean walkways. A planned stroll to the Palace gardens turned in to a 3 hour fitness program of stair climbing and many wrong turns. We seemed to always be on the wrong level and the numerous orientation maps placed at corners each have north pointing in different directions. Bono would love Tokyo, because it is a place where "the streets have no names". Your first challenge is to exit the building. You cannot simply hop in the elevator and go out the front door. You must first descend to the lobby level on floor 25 and parade across the lobby to the elevators on the other side of the room. Mercifully, this hotel does not employ a legion of service workers bowing and chanting pleasantries as you pass in front of them. Once at the next bank of elevators, you must choose between the ones on the left that take you to the overhead walkway and main entrance or the ones to your right that also go to the subway levels. Even at the subway level you will be descending and climbing stairs in order to get through the bottleneck of the Shimbashi station. Whatever you do, do not try to leave the hotel from the main door entrance. The surface roads are all but impassible to pedestrians. You will spend your day climbing and descending long staircases. And Heaven forbid you should try to enter the nearby Dentsu building to use the escalator. You will cause a great deal of stress to the security guard whose job it is to keep people like you out of there. Like caged rodents it will take you several days to learn the best pathway to food and entertainment from your room. Perhaps some people thrive on this sort of complexity, but if your knees and brain are aging you may prefer simpler surroundings.Some advantages to the location include:Fantastic Miyazaki designed mechanical clock on the pedestrian walkway level. Plays an enchanting tune several times per day. Arrive several minutes before the scheduled performance time. Some people have posted the performances on Youtube.comMany low cost, high quality restaurants in the surrounding buildings. The Shimbashi station is on the JR Yamonote line. Day pass for the JR Yamonote line is only 730 yen. It circles Tokyo and takes you to most of the interesting neighborhoods.

Agree with most opinions expressed about this hotel but with one big caveat. I stayed on the 32 floor of the hotel and yes I know its Tokyo but the noise of the trains down below was a real intrusion from early morning to late night. Guess it doesnt help that the trains are on an elevated track but if you stay here suggest that you insist on a room facing away from the train track. Think the Tokyo Tower side is much better and quieter !!

This is a lovely boutique hotel. Very sophisticated decor with an intimate atmosphere. There were no nonsmoking rooms of the type we needed available with city views so we went with smoking. The room did not smell and the view from our floor-to-ceiling window was breathtaking with the lit radio tower as a center piece. Despite the adult atmosphere -- low lights and jazz piano in the lobby in the evenings -- I was very comfortable staying at this hotel with my energetic 8 year-old daughter. And though the room was small and had little storage space, it was thoughtfully designed so we really didn't feel cramped or disorganized. It's also worth mentioning that when my jet-lagged daughter and I were up at 3 am, the all-night convenience store downstairs, with a reasonable selection of relatively healthy prepared foods, was a real blessing.The location is very convenient -- a few blocks from shopping and fabulous restaurants in Ginza (I'm not much of a shopper but the yen is weak and Japanese goods can be utterly irresistible) -- and easily accessible to trains.

Great location and great time! I would recommend exploring Shiodome as there are dozens of restaurants that can save you tons of money over the hotels. My girlfriend and I are both 25 and loved the local restaurants, you could get drunk and eat for under 40. loved this place great location great safe clean and amazing hotel.Jr PASS: Just a heads up for those trying to redeem a JR PASS. The ONLY place that knew what I was talking about was Tokyo station, you must go to the left hand side of the Tokyo station main entrance to a small gift shop looking place to redeem your JR PASS. It was a headache so don't bother trying at shinbashi etc go straight to tokyo station
Exceptionally clean, well situated, helpful staff. Really nice amenities!

I researched the best place to stay in Tokyo on Trip Advisor while planning our trip and booked the Park Hotel. It was perfect! A well priced Design Hotel within walking distance of Ginza and Shimbashi. I've stayed in two more expensive hotels in Tokyo, but this is the one I will go back to my next trip!

I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights in June 2007. Rooms are just standard in terms of interior design. The lobby is beautiful. Service is excellent (everyone greets you with nods and bows, like a king). The lady working at Concierge desk was extremely helpful, and copied me detailed maps from a street directory to make the process of finding places easier.Location is a bit hard to find for first time travellers to Japan (but same goes for most places in Japan).The price was exceptionally cheap at 14,500yen per night. For the 4.5 star standards of this hotel, this was fantastic value for money.If it's your first time to Japan, you will find it a challenge. The Japanese cannot speak English. Street signs are in Japanese. It's very tiring and difficult to find places. And the subway lines are a maze.In Tokyo most of the streets do not have names, and so the address is conveyed as area number, block number, building number eg. Shinjuku 2-1-9. I recommend you get a detailed map from a Street Directory (not a tourist guide), and then it makes it easier to navigate to places. Always find out the address in terms of area number, block number, building number of whereever you are going.This hotel is located above the ShioDoMe (pronounced She Oh Doh May) subway station. The easiest way from the airport is to take the Limosine Bus (a normal bus) to Tokyo City Air Terminal for 30000 yen and then catch a taxi which will cost 20000 yen to the hotel.If you are getting the subway around, I found it easiest to use the Shidome subway station. The Shimbashi station (which was recommended by the hotel) is a long walk and difficult to find in the maze of the underground subway lines. The Shidome station is just outside the entrance from the hotel on Basement level 2.While in Tokyo, I recommend a visit to the basement food court of the Isetan department store in Shinjuku, the array of food offerings are amazing! Also a must is shopping and dining in Ginza, which can be walked to from the hotel. On Saturdays and Sundays they close off the 8 blocks, and it is a pedestrian street. The shops, restaurants and atmosphere is wonderful.

I was really impressed with the hotel during my stay. I've stayed in lots of hotels in Tokyo before where I paid a lot more and got a lot less. The room was on the small side, but so thoughtfully designed that I really didn't notice. Bed was terrific - slept like a baby. Loved the Thann bath products from Thailand - will have to pick some up on my next trip to Bangkok. The adjoining Shiodome complex has lots of restaurants, Japanese and Western, and I tried one tonkatsu place that was really very good. Also, from the hotel as mentioned it is just a short 15-minute walk to Ginza (there is an excellent supermarket under Shimbashi station) where there is all the shopping and nightlife you'd want. It took me just 15 minutes to jog over to the Tsukiji fish market and I am not a fast runner. I loved how the Shiodome subway was right at my doorstep (that line could take you to Roppongi) and how convenient it was taking the airport limo bus. Two thumbs up for a great stay.

Based on the reviews from others on this site we stayed here in early June (07) - and were not disappointed. Not much to add that has not already been said - so I will offer some local pointers for those that would like to stay here: 1. The "Limousine Bus" from the airport stops and picks up at this hotel which is great. This bus is an excellent way to get to and from the airport - as cabs are very very expensive, and if you have a lot of bags, using the subway can be a challenge. You can easily find the ticket counters @ the airport when you arrive and the hotel will sell you a ticket at the front desk when you depart. 2. This hotel is two quick subway stops from the Tokyo (Tsukiji) Fish Market that is in many guide books. You need to get there very early but it is worth the trip in my mind. Unique and fun. But wear shoes that you are OK getting wet and mucking around in (It is an active fish market - not a tourist attraction). 3. For great sushi try Midori-zushi - remarkably reasonable prices given the quality. Note the sign is not in English but it we found it. It is in Ginza and very close to the Imperial Hotel. Address: Ginza 7-108, Ginza Korida-dori 1F. Open 11am-2, 5-9:30pm dailyWe would stay @ this hotel again on future trips.

Wonderful hotel! During our one week stay, we tried this hotel along with a ryokan. This hotel won by far for quality, view, experience and price. Getting to the hotel was a bit of a maze and found the outside walkway to be easier. Also liked the short walk to Ginza and the fish market.

This is a wonderful hotel in a great area. It is located in the upper levels of the Shiodome Media Tower, directly above the train station. It is also a stop on the airport limo service to Narita. There is an elevated walkway between the tower and surrounding buildiings which allows for a pleasant walk above the busy streets. There are many good restaurants in the area and an easy walk to the Ginza shopping district. The room was well appointed and quiet with comfortable beds and nice views. The staff was extemely helpful with all our needs. We booked it through Tablet Hotesl for a great rate.

PINK Glasses says it all comprehensively ! I would say I found the overhead walkways easier at first than beavering away underground. The Park is ideal for JRpass users accessing the Yamonote line (and others) at Shimbashi.The staff professionalism and attention, the cleanliness, the toiletries, the free guest internet access outweigh the fact that the lobby can get a little smoke-filled at times.We stayed 5 nights and will certainly use this hotel again.
We also loved the hotel and the Shiedome area. Nothing much to add to others reports.

I was wavering between this hotel and the Mitsui Garden in Ginza and ended up booking both of them for a few nights. While the other hotel was also very nice, this one wins!This is not just a place to rest your head; it's a place to come home to after a long day of walking around Tokyo and ooh & ahh over the brilliant architecture and atmosphere of the lobby, over the amazing skyscraper view you have from your room, over the friendliness of the staff. Truly, this is a gem. The rooms are spotless and very spacious for Tokyo. I booked on tablethotels.com and found the rates to be very reasonable for the quality of the hotel experience. The only possible negative is the location, but even that is a stretch. It's in Shiodome, a relatively new skyscraper/business district and the hotel is directly connected to a subway line and a monorail line (which runs to Odaiba). That said, it's not really walking distance to the big attractions like some other hotels are, but I think you'll find that you don't regret picking the Park! Very, very recommended.

Just got back from a seven night stay at Park Hotel Tokyo (May19-26, 2007). It’s located in the top floors of the Media Tower of Shiodome, an ultra-modern collection of high-rises on the southern edge of the Ginza neighborhood (and not to be confused with the Royal Park Hotel, which is in the Royal Park Shiodome building next door). We arrived via the Airport Limousine, tickets purchased at the airport for about $25 each way. A bellhop seemed to know we were coming and brought us to the 25th floor with our bags for check-in (and it felt very strange not to tip him). We stayed in a City Twin room, which their website says is about 280 square feet (26 meters sq), for about $225 per night. Our view was to the southwest, overlooking Hamarikyu Garden (which has a water bus to the Asakusa neighborhood with the Sensoji temple), Tokyo Bay and Tokyo Tower. My only complaint was that we could have used just a tiny bit more space so we could keep our bags out rather than tucking them away each day. Plenty of toiletries were provided (photo attached), as were terry cloth robes and cotton wrap gown pajamas. The minibar fridge had enough spare room that we were able to keep some of our own food and beverages chilled (purchased from a convenience store called Family Mart at the base of the building, or a larger store nearby called DonK). There are also vending machines on each floor with cool Japanese versions of bottled water and sodas for just over $1 each (fun souvenirs). We didn’t try any of the restaurants in our hotel building as there were dozens of others in surrounding Shiodome buildings, from Subway, McDonald’s and Nathan’s, to diners where you buy meal tickets from picture-button vending machines. And Chuo Dori street, the equivalent of Champs Elysees or Fifth Avenue, is a short walk and has plenty of high-end dining.The Shiodome area can be really disorienting. There’s an underground pedestrian passage that connects the Shiodome train station to the nearby Shimbashi station, and we found it much easier to navigate from that level than the elevated pedestrian walkways that wind around the skyscrapers. Our bags were stored for us on our last day while and brought down for the shuttle home, tickets this time charged to our room through the concierge.The staff was impeccable (the concierge was kind enough to go with us to an ATM-like kiosk in the Family Mart to buy tickets to a sumo match *highly recommended* since the screens were in Japanese only). The decor was stylish. The bed was firm with comfortable cotton bedding. The location was convenient to the Ginza neighborhood and two train lines. You always hear about how expensive Tokyo is, but I know I've paid more for lesser rooms in other cities. I would stay here again.

I stayed here with a friend for a few nights on vacation and it was wonderful. The staff is great, even by Japanese standards, and we luckily had a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower. The room design is sparse but attractive, using nice materials. The internet was speedy and the location was convenient enough. It's a good 10 minute walk from the station but as it's accessible from the JR and Metro lines that's excusable, especially since the entire walk can be done across an elevated promenade. The lobby/lounge is a bit pricey for food but features jazz nightly and is a chill way to end a day. A GREAT hotel at a GREAT price.

We stayed at the Park Hotel in Tokyo during a three night stay in May 2007. The hotel is located in the Shiodome complex and was a little tricky to locate initially, however we were extremely pleased once we found it. The hotel is clean, quiet and modern, we got a very good rate. It is centrally located for train/subway access. We never needed a taxi as we walked or took the trains everywhere without difficulty. We did not eat at the hotel, there were a few resturaunts that we in the Shiodome complex for a quick breakfast. We did enjoy martinis at night in their bar which has a great view of tokyo at night. I would definately stay there when in tokyo again for business or pleasure.

We've just stayed 3 nights at the Park Hotel in Tokyo and I couldn't be happier with my choice.The tone was perfectly set on arrival, we got there around 11pm due to a late connecting flight and were very tired, but the check-in lasted less than 90 seconds. The lobby is stunning. The room is nice and cozy, a bit on the small side but nothing of a shock if you're used to other Asian cities like Seoul and HK. Great views from the 32nd floor. Need to mention that the toiletries are simply incredible, and the matress very very comfy. Location is the tie-breaker, though. Walking distance from the Fish Market and Ginza area, 3 metro lines plus the JR Yamanote take you in 15mins to anywhere from Shibuya and Omotesando to Shinjuku. The last morning we wanted to book a restaurant for dinner and when we got back in the evening to change clothes not only did we have our reservation confirmed but also 4 pages printed in colour from a gourmet website with pics of the place, the menu in English, directions for the subway and even a map in Japanese to show the taxi driver.What a pleasant stay. And it's really excellent value for Tokyo.

Stayed in Park Hotel for 2 nights. This is a very clean, new, modern hotel located in the business area of tokyo. It is very near the Rainbow Bridge area, and is very convenient as there is metro located near the basement of the hotel.Friendly staffs, very nice lobby, the rooms are very new and clean and so is the bathroom...you can tell that they were very careful witht he decorations. You could have axcellent view from the room (facing the tokyo tower, but those rooms costs more).The area is not exactly like the Shinjuku, it is relatively quieter and less crowded, so depends on what you are looking for. BUT this hotel is definitely way better than those small and older ones in shinjuku ....is like our 7th tokyo visit....On other tokyo trips we also stayed at: B Ropongi, Nishi, and Prince Shinjuku, Washington Hotel in Shinjuku, the PARK hotel is by far the best one....while is the most expensive one.

Was there last week and must say it is a very nice. Just keep in mindif you don't get a corner or a premium room you will be in a shoe sized room. I had a corner twin and it was very good sized but we didpeek in the other rooms so and they seemed very small. I found the info on this site to be very accurate regarding this hotel.You will be dealing with 4 levels when you stay at the Park.1. Lobby level which is on the 25th floor2. Overpass level that connect the hotel to surrounding builds and is a raised walkway over the street.3. Street level, there is a little construction going on there.4. Subway/underground.Between all these levels you will find at least 50 or so places to eat for high and low budget meals. I suggest you take an hour or two to look around all the levels. If you don't find that many eateries keep looking cause they are definitely there and wil save you abunch of $$$ with infinite food choices.Also the view is stunning from the lobby and if you have a premium or corner room it is just as good. But after you seen that view for a few days I suggest you walk over to the Conrad hotel right across the street, go to the lounge which is first calss all the way and the water view is stunning definitely worth the walk.The fastest way there is to take the NEX (Narita Express) from the airport to Tokyo station 54 minutes then a ten minute cab ride from the station to the hotel. wait and take the hotel bus and you will get there almost an hour later or maybe longer.Most important tip is to print out the map from the hotel website with street names and hotel info in Japanese. Everytime I wanted to go to the Hotel I just showed it to the cab driver would get there without any problems whatsoever. Used that map at least ten times to get back problem free.

I want to chime in and reinforce all the good reviews that have been posted about this hotel. The hotel is very clean with an attentive staff. Although the rooms are relatively small, you don't feel cramped. And the floor-to-ceiling windows (we had an amazing view of Tokyo Tower and half of Tokyo) make them feel much larger. They are also unbelievably quiet. You never hear your neighbors or hall traffic; something I can not usually say for US hotels.The location is very convenient as it's only a 10-15 min walk to Ginza (tons of shops and restaurants) and only a 5 min walk to a shopping center (I recommend "Vie de France" as a bakery for those looking for European-style morning pastries).
