And there are 3 subway stops and 1 train station in the immediate area, so it's always easy to go where you want in Tokyo.We didn't try the restaurants due to cost, but the breakfast buffet was tempting just b/c of seeing it each morning in the beautiful lobby. On a side note, we exchanged a little bit of money at the hotel our first day to get us going, and the rate we got was within 1% of what we got at a bank the next morning. That might be something useful to know.Anyhow, trust the reviews. You can't go wrong staying here and you'll love it!

Stayed for almost a week in Tokyo on my honeymoon, and selected the Park Hotel based solely on the reviews posted at Trip Advisor.First off, this hotel is extremely hard to find. Our father-in-law, even with a native car and Japanese navigation system, couldn't seem to locate the hotel and had to ask multiple people in the area. In fact, we spent a good 30 minutes in the vicinity circling around until we found it. The reason was that the hotel is part of a skyscraper, and is located on the higher floors. So the only thing pointing out that there's a hotel there is a small sign that was hard to see from the construction-crowded road.Once there, we took the quick and quiet elevator to the spectacular lobby. The view from behind the check-in desk was expansive, and the lounge was in a very open and cozy area with modern furniture and smiling hotel staff everywhere. Everything reeks of upper-class service and quality. For some reason, the entire hotel seemed to be exceptionally quiet...muffled even. White noise perhaps?The room is typical Japanese...that is, small. For those used to living in large suite hotel rooms in the US, get ready for a shock. Needless to say, everything was spic and span clean, but the actual room was barely large enough to fit the furniture.The "TV" was really like a 21" flat panel monitor from a computer. What was mildly irritating to me was the fact that virtually all the channels were Japanese. The only English channels were CNN International, CNBC i think and some various ones here and there. To make matters worse, they didn't compensate by offering much pay-per-view choices, nothing like the ones in the US. On the bright side, you could get quick previews of Japanese Adult Videos before they asked you to pay.The bathroom was immaculate with a toilet that required a computer science degree to fully enjoy if jets of water is your thing. Room service was pricey as to be expected. The food was quite good.The restaurants in the hotel were top notch and pretty expensive.The bathrooms in the lobby/lounge were, to quote my wife, "the best bathrooms I've ever seen". For a germophobe like me, Japanese bathrooms are heaven.Part of the Shiodome complex, the building is actually one of a few towering modern skyscrapers in the area. The immediate vicinity are mostly businesses. If you go down to the subway level, there is a 24-hour convenience store with all manners of goodies...definitely not the 7/11s...we're talking pretty darn good food. On the subway level are some restaurants open only during business hours for some good quick cheap bites. Further along there's a Starbucks and a bookstore/stationary store.The subway system is quite complex and not for the faint of heart. However, everything is laid out with a logic that the Japanese are known for. The actual subway lines to get to attractions in the city is about a 10 minute walk that takes you through the Shiodome complex and down a subway area.All in all, I'd stay at the Park Hotel again in a heartbeat. And at the deal rate we got ($118 US), it was unbeatable.

Booked this hotel after reading reviews on this website & so glad we did - what a great place. We were on a 3 day stopover on the way to Oz with our 2 toddlers. Hotel lobby on the 25th floor of the Shiodomemedia tower in the Ginza district of the city. Booked a superior room& size was more than enough even with 2 cots, despite endless reviewsmentioning shoe boxed sized rooms. Also despite various reviewers having difficulty finding the place, we had no problem at all. We arrived at the airport too early for a limousine bus direct to the hotel so we got one to Tokyo station and then a short taxi ride to the hotel. I did give the taxi driver the map provided by the hotel website which is in english and japanese. Staff were very courteous and efficient. The views from the hotel lobby are amazing & we also had a fantastic review from our room on the 30th floor. There were lots of lovely toiletries and yes the biddet stye loo was an experience in itself! The local area does take some navigating & getting used to especiallyas there are lots of levels, i.e, underground trains, street level traffic, elevated pedestrian walkways. There is a 24hrs supermarket in the basement, easy to find, & the cafe on the 3rd floor of the tower is good for a quick bite. Lots of eateries in nearby towers & in the underground malls, best thing is just to explore & you will find.We visited Ueno park & saw lovely cherry blossom, easy to get there, public transport very efficient. A real gem of a find was a lovely garden about 10mins away from the hotel, begins with 'h....something rekki & can't remember name but lovely - reception will know it & a definite must for some peace & tranquility in such a busy place. Overall loved tokyo, loved the hotel, would DEFINITELY return.

This hotel is a very very nice hotel. I booked this through the hotel website (something I don't normally do, as I usually use one of the last-minute discount hotel websites) and stayed for four nights.The hotel is very new and everything is impeccably clean. It is very central, with a short walk to Ginza and the JR line a 4 minutes walk and two other lines at the side door of the hotel. The lobby is on the 25th floor and the rooms are above, with an atrium in the middle.The room is small (average by Asian room standards), but not squashed. The price is less than a comparable room in, say, Hong Kong, Sydney, New York or Paris and the hotel staff are perfect.

My wife and I stayed @ Park Hotel for 4 nights last week..The Park is an average 4-star property, stylish without being intimidating.Our room (a premium corner king bed, 29th floor) was good in size, very clean and had a fantastic view. The price was cheap in comparison to hotels of the same level in Italy, US or UK. The hotel is literally sorrounded by open air train and metro lines so it is almost impossible to find a 100% quiet room but I'm a very light sleeper and I could sleep very well.On the other hand the location is fantastic: you have direct access from the hotel to 3 metro lines and 2 train stations!Taxis and always available in front of the entrance and Tokyo station is a 10-minute ride.Breakfast: again, average in quality and price.Staff: helpful and very kind, like everybody in Tokyo. Check in/out took 3 minutes and went smooth.A good experience and I recommend this hotel.

With hours research, my husband and I decided to stay at Park Hotel Tokyo this time because it got really good reviews and we really enjoyed our stay at other design hotels. Our experience with Park Hotel Tokyo is totally a disaster. We checked in around 9pm and found out that they didn't have the room we requested with king size bed, and the rate we got is for their standard room with queen size bed. This is just the beginning of 9 nights nightmare. After second night, we were finally told that we could stay at their standard room with queen size bed) or we have the option to pay more to get the room we requested, or we can check out and check in other hotel. The difference between the rate for their standard room and the room we requested is over $100/ per night. We couldn't figure out how the room rate could increase so much upon check-in (it should not have, we have the print out of the confirmation!!! The rate and room type request are all on it) Hotel insisted it is our travel agent's mistake and they spoke with our travel agent, and our travel agent confirmed it's misunderstanding (between? Hotel never clarified) We decided to stay at Park Hotel Tokyo and in the standard room AND not to waste our time finding out who screwed up our reservation because we just wanted to enjoy our vacation and didn't want to waste our time to pack up and move.The night before we checked out, we found out that our room rate is higher than what shown on our reservation confirmation. We were told that the rate we got is for one person and the new rate is for two people. My husband and I got so furious. Hotel has a copy of our reservation confirmation and it clearly states in the reservation the confirmed room rate and the number of guests staying at the room is two. We decided that we couldn’t let the hotel get away from changing room rate, so we requested the hotel staff to call our travel agent in front of us. After 1 hour long international phone call, the hotel agreed with AE travel agent and honored the rate. Will we stay at this hotel again? No!! To be fair, the location is good. This is the only good thing we can say about this hotel. .

A truly amazing hotel, decorated with the lastest trends. The service is incredible and the Shiodome neighborhood where the hotel is located is possibly the most futuristic place i have been in my life.

Stayed for 6 nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo in April 2007. This is a new building and hotel, so everything is new and in mint condition. My room was fairly large and very comfortable, with air-conditioning, and a good sized bathroom. Everything was very clean and well maintained. The view from the 26th floor was excellent. Free tea and coffee was available. The staff were very helpful. Breakfast at the hotel was excellent. The lobby is very impressive. The hotel is very close to subway and train stations for travel within Tokyo, many sites can be reached without changing. For travel further afield Tokyo station is fairly close. There are also many restaurants and bars very close to the hotel. I would certainly stay again.

Park Hotel is a great hotel! It was our cheapest and best hotel in Tokyo and Kyoto. Its in a great location - although it is hard to figure out how to get out of the hotel area the first time like someone else mentioned - but once you figure that out its perfect! Shiodome building has a ton of food choices available and a starbucks :) Its a close walk to the Fish market and to ginza. We stayed here our first 3 days in tokyo and then stayed in Shibuya after coming back from Kyoto. I missed this hotel the whole time we were at the others! Definitely pick this hotel if you are staying on that side of Tokyo!

The Park hotel is a really amazing accomodation in tokyo, just 5 minutes from shinbashi JR and underground station, 10 minutes from Tsukiji Fish Market, Ginza's famous crossing is within walking distance, though the lobby is on the 25th floor and rooms are from 26th floor to 30th, so they have great views over tokyo skyline. All rooms have city view window and corridors overlook the void which spans from main lobby to the skylighted ceiling ( !!! )My room had LCD Tv, tea boiler, choice of pillows, armchair and obviously yukata! It is useless to speak about room cleanliness! It is really advisable to download the english map with direction from the unerground station to the hotel because it is not easy to understand at first glance where to go.We paid 130 euros taxes included (no breakfast) per night which is a quite good price considered the hotel level (it may be considered much more than standard four star accomodation). If you can afford 100 euros per night is is a good option to spend something more for having a lot more.

We stayed 4 days/3nights at the Park Hotel in November of 2006. It is a wonderful hotel and once you figure out your bearings it's very easy to get around by train or walking. There are great shops, bars and entertainment all around the Shiodome area. Getting around by train is very easy, just crowded during rush hour. The concierge were great, they spoke perfect english and did not laugh at our butchering of the Japanese language. Check in and out was a breeze and the prices for the mini bar were more than reasonable. The lounge/lobby area had wonderful jazz every night and the interior of the hotel is beautiful. I highly recommend the Park Hotel Tokyo, so much that we're going back in August of 2007 and we didn't even think twice about where to stay.

Great hotel in a perfect location! We stayed here 3 nights.The JR station is only about a 10 min walk, only the first time it's a little bit hard to find,but then it's easy. I disagree that the Tokyo metro is confusing. It's one of the easiest metro systems to use. We come from Helsinki with only 1 metro line and we didn't get lost one single time. Also we took a taxi from and to the Tokyo station (because of the luggage we had) and the bill was only about 1000 yen, which is really cheap. Overall we found Japanese taxi prices to be quite cheap in comparision to Finland. In general we haven't found Tokyo or Japan to be very expensive.There are many great restaurants near the hotel. The service was very good and the room perfect.We had a double room on the 34.floor (last floor) with a view of the Tokyo tower. The room was big enough and so was the bed (normal European size bed) and the bathroom (plenty of space for one person). Both hubby and I are medium built, and we had plenty of space in the bed. One would really need to be quite large to fall out of the bed or not to find enough space in the bathroom.Also the room wasnt noisy at all. The view is really spectacular and it's worth spending a few yen more to get a room with Tokyo tower view.Internet surfing is free. Also,all the hotel stuff spoke good English.Even using the hotel phone (which we had to do before our rented mobile arrived) wasn't too expensive.The area is within walking distance of Ginza.Ah yes,one receives also a free newspaper (in English) every morning. For those who like to watch tv even while on vacation, forget about it, everything is in Japanese. But there is plenty to see and do in Tokyo, so you won't have much time for it anyway.The Tokyo tower could be reached on foot from the hotel,it's only about 2-3 km away, but best is to get there with the metro.

This hotel was amazing. I normally stay at Starwood hotels, but the prices in Tokyo were just too outrageous this time. So we decided to try out this smaller hotel -- and we couldn't have been more pleased. The service was impeccable, the furnishings were great (rooms are small, but that's just Tokyo in general), and the location was amazing. It's a 5-minute walk to the fish market, so every morning we could have sushi for breakfast. So memorable! Plus the JR line and Metro lines are practically under the hotel.I would absolutely stay here again.

Good hotel in an excellent location. Very modern design in a triangular tower. Rooms relatively small but clean and adquate, and comparable to Japanese standards. Within 15-20mins walking distance to the Tsukji Fish Market where you can sample fresh sushi from the daily catch. Relatively easy access via either subway or JR rail to other places in Tokyo. I had a JP pass which allowed me unlimited free travel on JR rail. The JR station is slightly complicated to reach if you go underground. The best way is to use the pedestrian walkway on the third floor. About 10-15mins stroll. A map easily obtainable from the reception. Friendly staff and fully recommended.

The Park Hotel Tokyo is an oasis in the middle of Tokyo. The room was immaculate, modern and extremely comfortable. The location is excellent - about a 5 min walk to the JR Yamanote line Shimbashi station. The Tokyo subway system can be a little intimidating at first, and the JR Yamanote line was easy to use. We would definitely return.

This is the second year (Spring break) that we stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo. This time, I requested a West side room overlooking the Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fujii...It was beautiful!Staff was wonderful! Helpful and well informed! They helped we talk to Tsukiji fish vendor to arrange for sashimi to take home and took care of receiving a package on the last day while we went shopping. Room is clean and amenities very nice! They provide adapter for electrical connection. Hot water pot is nice for tea in the morning.Location is great...centrally located in Tokyo. hotel is right above the Oedo subway line so you just catch the elevator to the subway level...only 1 stop from Tsukiji Market...great place for breakfast. short walk to Shimbashi station. Roppongi, Shinjuku is on Oedo subway line...Saw some comments regarding noise, but I REALLy don't hear a thing!I highly recommend!

The Park Hotel Tokyo is a relatively new hotel, clean like everything else in central Tokyo, but with the added bonus of being far enough from the hustle and bustle that it's quiet at night times, yet still near enough to Shimbashi station that getting around Tokyo on the trains or Metro is as easy as pie. The rooms are a very generous size (for Tokyo), and because it's in what is essentially a business district most day trips are against the flow of humanity. The staff have (so far) been very friendly and accommodating, and we're looking forward to the rest of our stay. Two small things do stand out about this place as problematic, however. Firstly, breakfast and room service are very expensive. Secondly, there are few truly local eateries. We've spent our dinners so far going down to Odaiba or closer in to town. The convenience store down at the base of the tower is great in a pinch or for a light meal, but if you're in need of protein you might have to go further afield.

Shortcut:-very very clean-very very friendly staff-room size over average for Tokyo-nice location-nice surrounding-walking distance to fish market to get your daily sushi-felt like homeSpecials:-heated toilette with BD-very good communications skills for all staff-good breakfast for resonable priceRemarks:-sure it is not a five star but at least a 4++I will choose this place again and like to recommend it - great job and thanks again.

I have always stayed in Ginza area, which is close to the Shimbashi subway because I needed to travel out to Tokyo Big Sight. Since my usual hotel has increased in the room rates, I have decided to do some searching for some nearby hotels. Having read some great reviews of the hotel, I am amazed by the quality of the hotel service, it's family-friendly environment (we travelled in a group of 5 pax, including a boy of 12 years), especially the toiletries.... I have enclosed a snap shot of it. Trust me -- this is the first ever experience being pampered by a full range, including matching coloured bath salts.Well Done, Park Hotel. The best thing is, the hotel is located exactly outside the Shiodome Train Station, on Yurikamome line... which takes me directly to Tokyo Big Sight. Despite being so close to the train line, you can't hear anything (perhaps it's because the lobby is situated at the 25th floor of the Shiodome Media Tower). One impressive impression if you were to return from an evening outing... hang around at the lobby to check out the Tokyo Tower... whilst enjoying the live music on the weekends.Wonderful... just wonderful!

Park Hotel is located in Shimbasi,which reminds you of the Dockland,London but without the water.New area with high rise buildings and restaurants located at ground floors.Hotel was very easy to get to from Tokyo station, we took the JR line to Shimbasi and took the exit signposted Shimbasi exit.Walk across to an overground covered walkway (also lift available for those suitcases) and follow the walkway literally to the Hotel.It is a 7min walk.The walkway is safe,just like the rest of Tokyo.The hotel was very stylish and modern and you get complimentary pyjamas and slippers.The staff very courteous and friendly and reception area has a fine view of Mount Fuji on a clear day as its located on the 25th floor.Shimbasi is located next to Ginza which is the shopping district so we didn't find a 10 minute walk tedious at all.Not like some of the reviews.Would definitley stay there again.

What a great hotel! We stayed here the end of December while touring Japan for three days before heading south. After an eleven hour flights and a two hour shuttle bus ride to the hotel we got to the hotel late and when we got up the the lobby were immediately greeted with a beautiful view of Tokyo Tower and jazz music from the lounge. The staff were all very helpful and most spoke english fairly well. I have to say the shampoo they give you is some of the best I've used and had a very good hair day with it. So much so that I ordered more from Tokyo after I got back to the States. All in all the bed was comfortable, the drinks in the bar were excellent, everyone was friendly and courteous and the view was unbeatable.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for 3 nights en route to New Zealand and would highly recommend it. As others have noted, the location is excellent for public transport, including the Yurikomome monorail that goes out to the Odaiba waterfront area - a day ticket is well worth buying for 800 yen to hop on and off and explore this area (spectacular views back to the City at night, too).Many others have mentioned the 'small' rooms; we found our room perfectly adequate and, certainly, well designed - in fact, the whole hotel is stylish and comfortable. Breakfasts are easily bought from one of a number of coffee shops nearby and on our first night at the hotel, being pretty exhausted, we ate in the restaurant and did not consider our simple, but good, pasta dish too highly priced.As has been mentioned, the Limousine bus does not run to this hotel until around 2pm - on advice from the helpful staff at the Limousine counter, we took a bus to Tokyo Airport 'City' and then a taxi for the short distance to the hotel. The hotel concierge will book the return Limousine, store your luggage, if necessary, and deliver it to the bus for you. Typical of the superb service we encountered here.Finally, keep an eye on the view from the huge window behind the reception desk in the early morning - we were rewarded with a fantastic view of Mount Fuji glistening in the sunshine on two occasions.

It could have been an excellent hotel , design hotel ,reasonable price, good location, interesting restaurants , helpful staffs, close to transportation, unfortunately the windows sound proofing could be better and with the hotel surrounded by the railway lines (including yamanote line , yurikamome , the Osaka shinkansen, ..) , the noise is too present for people like me. I asked to change room because of the noise which did not seem to be a surprise for the staff. The new room did not improved the situation and when i asked a second time to change, the staff confessed that there was not much things to do due to the location of the hotel .What a pity I will not come back

Have just spent three nights at the Park Hotel on a stop-over on the way to New Zealand.Overall i was happy with our stay here. Getting to the hotel was a bit of a challenge since we arrived at Narita airport early morning and the bus to our hotel did not leave until 2pm. Instead we got another bus to a nearby hotel and had the name of the Park Hotel written down in Japenese to show the taxi driver - this did not prevent him from taking us to two 'other' park hotels first.The hotel itself is new and located in the modern Shiodome complex. The entrance is on the ground floor but the hotel lobby is actually about 20 floors further up. The lobby / bar and reception do indeed give great views across the city. The conceige was very helpful and spoke good English.The rooms are small but as expected for Tokyo and a little stuffy. They all have a city view. They are well furnished with plenty of complimentary toiletries.The best thing about this hotel is location - pretty much sat on the subway and 5 mins from a metro station and just a bit further to Ginza district for shops/food etc. There is also a nice park with a tea house about 10 mins from the hotel. There are a number of restaurants in the other Shiodome (City) Tower on the 42nd floor, in particular 'En'.What i would not recommend is eating or drinking at the hotel. Breakfast was 2,500 yen - so instead we went out of the hotel on the 3rd floor to Tully's coffee shop - coffee and a bagel for 500 yen. We didn't dare use either of the two restaurants in hotel.Overall this is a good hotel for a few days in Tokyo and well worth the money.

Stayed here for two nights, our first visit to Tokyo. The hotel is an excellent value for money, the room, although small, has everything you need (including free Internet) plus an excellent city view (guest floors start at 26th floor!). Location is good: 15 min walk to Ginza, 10 min walk to closest JR station and a subway station as you walk out the hotel. The area though is a brand new financial center, so don't expect too many dining options there, but again, Tokyo has an excellent subway network, so who cares. Speaking of dining options, these are endless in Tokyo. If you are looking for modern Japanese cuisine, head to Casita. Watch it, the address you'll find in most review websites (like Frommer's) is wrong. They've moved to La Porte Aoyama, in Aoyama St., check it in [--]. Excellent restaurant for a special dinner.All in all, we would definitely recommend this hotel to anybody traveling with his/her partner and looking for an upscale hotel.

The best thing about this hotel is its extremely convenient location. Some people in a few other reviews commented that it was a bit far from a JR line, but it can't be more than five underground minutes away walking leisurely. That's hard to beat, really. It's also even closer to the Toei Oedo line, monorail line, and also a tokyo metro ginza line. That, and you can walk to the fish markets, ginza, and shimbashi easily. We ate once at the hotel, for breakfast, and wouldn't recommend it. They only had pretty disgusting western buffet style stuff, no japanese breakfast, and it was overpriced. You don't need to rely on the hotel though because there are tons of restaurants within walking distance in all directions.There is nothing spectacular about the hotel itself, but for this price you wouldn't expect there to be. It was clean, the staff were polite, and the views were nice(but most tokyo hotels I've seen are high up in buildings, so views arn't that rare in tokyo hotels). If you want to luxuriate for a little bit walk next door to the conrad and have a drink in the bar, the Conrad is supposed to be one of the best hotels in Tokyo. Oh, one word of caution. We were in a double room with two very small beds, and both my brother and myself were pretty much hanging off the beds.I'd stay here again as the location is hard to beat, but if I was after super luxury or really hip, I'd go elsewhere. It depends why you're in tokyo and how much time you plan to spend in the hotel, and who's paying.

It was a bit confusing to find the lobby due to construction outside, but the room was great. Very comfortable, excellent service, reasonable price, and comfortable bed. I was just spending 1 night after a 2 week trip to northern Japan and hadn't slept well the whole time. Man, did I realize the difference a good bed could make. From waking up around 5-6am to dragging myself out of bed at 8. I'd definitely recommend it and stay there again. The only part I wasn't crazy about was that it was a bit farther from the train station than I was hoping (about 10 min. walk). Otherwise great.

My wife and I just returned from a long weekend in Tokyo and the Park Hotel proved to be a great base camp for setting out to see the city. Conveniently located on top of the Oedo subway line, and a stones throw (2 min walk) from the Shimbashi JR line, hotel guests can easily access mass transit to anywhere in Tokyo (which has the best mass transit of any city I've been to...)As far as the hotel: sleek, modern, subdued, tasteful.The view: stratospheric! The hotel is on the 25-34th floors of the Shidome Media Center (Kyodo News Building). The atrium design of the hotel allows for every guest room to have a city view...The staff was extremely helpful and friendly. No complaints. The room: a bit small - par for the course in Tokyo I'm told - but clean and comfortable. The price was rather inexpensive as well: $186.00 US per night (including fees and tax)Oh yeah, and the minibar prices were fairly inexpensive too...not the usual gouge rates...impressive.There is a Lawson (7-11) in the basement...very convenient.We didn't eat in any of the restaurants in the hotel...but did eat at a great Thai place in Shinjuku called Ban Thai (near the Prince Hotel)...great food.I'm giving it ***** since it met my expectations and fulfilled every need on this trip. It's a good city hotel at a great price. If you are looking for a resort, you might find it a bit sterile...but then, if you are looking for a resort, you should go to Amanpuri in Phuket!Give the Park a shot...it will not disappoint!

I guess my expectations were too high after all the Tripadvisor praise - my one night stay last summer at Park Hotel was ok, but nothing memorable. No complaints though - everything was spot on and smooth. Nice view over Tokyo from the lobby, also nice view from the room. The room was uninspiring but functional, obviously spotless and modern. The crowd was very touristy and mixed. I did not try the hotel restaurants - so many great places to eat in in Tokyo.Must say the five nights I stayded at a ryokan (old-fashioned japanese inn) in Tokyo were much preferred to this lukewarm hotel experience. Sure, unfair comparison, but still. :) Also compared to other same class hotels I've stayed in all over the world this was not a memorable stay. It's a fine hotel and gets the job done. Great Ginza location, but in my opinion nothing overly special if you've stayed in good hotels before.

I've been a user of TripAdvisor for a few years now and there is no doubt that Park Hotel Tokyo is one of the best in hotel iv'e stayed. Tokyo is not a cheap place to visit but booking at this hotel was a big savings for my friend and I. The staff were GREAT. Directions, recommendations, anything you wanted to ask, they'll help you. Location is great. Close to the subway and cheap food just around the corners. Note: For Americans, the ATM on the basement does not take US ATM card. There is an ATM on the next building that works -- ask the concierge which building.

After seeing all the positive reviews about the Park Hotel Tokyo here on TripAdvisor, I decided to try it for myself. I had a premium king room (see attached pictures). The only disappointment was that the king bed was actually two single beds pushed together to form one large one. Otherwise everthing was as expected for this designer business hotel. The staff were all very nice and helpful. The hotel is right above the Oedo subway line which gives direct access to Roppongi and Shinjuku. Shimbashi station is just a couple of minutes walk away with access to the Ginza subway line and JR lines. The hotel is located right next to the Tokyo Conrad Hotel.The is not a luxury hotel like the Mandarin Oriental, but then again the price is much more reasonable and you get a hip hotel in a convenient location. I would definitely stay again.

this is an amazing hotel I highly recommend it to all visitors to tokyo. we got a great deal through trip advisor and travelocity we paid almost half than the usual rate. the hotel is superb. they were wonderful in customer service and extremely accomodating. Tokyo is a spotlessly clean city and the same is of the hotel. usually i'm a bit nervous about restrooms in hotels but here it was so clean you could eat off of the floor. the free ammenities in the bathroom were great also. we took the advice from the past reviewer of not eating in the hotel cause it could drain your wallet fast so we walked around and found cheap eats all over. we especially love the lunch specials. and about the getting around the hotel, sure the first day it was allittle annoying because of construction but after that we found the above ground walkway which connects you to the subway and jr train it's was so simple. the hotel is located in ginza which we come to find out from other english speaking tokyo-ites that it's where stuffy salary men and snobs of tokyo live. but we didn't mind since the hotel was so great. we took the jr all over. easy easy. then again we are from brooklyn so we don't mind train rides and transfering. once again dont hessitate to book at the park hotel tokyo.

This is a gem! When we first stepped in we couldn't believe that we could afford such beauty, functionality and nature all combined together. If you like architecture you will love the lobby from where you can see Tokyo from the 25th floor and have drinks while listening to Jazz music most of the nights. It was excellent! Our room felt like home with all the modern amenities and great views of the city. The staff are extremely helpful and pleasant although I believe we were the only backpackers in the hotel. What amazed me was the art gallery in the lobby. There are amazing art items all around and a huge tree on the wall which matches wonderfully with the two live olive trees in the lobby . I would recommend it to all! This is the best hotel we have ever stayed.

The Park Hotel Tokyo was an excellent hotel that was suprisingly affordable.The Park Hotel Tokyo is a newer hotel that occupies the top floors of a building in the recently build Shidome complex which is located just below the popular Ginza neighbourhood in Tokyo. The hotel is directly connected to the Shidome Subway stop which is on the Toei Oedo Line which my girlfriend and I found was an excellent starting point to go to the various neighbourhoods in Tokyo. Most sights are a maximum of one transfer away. A little further walk can get you to the Shimbashi Station and another metro line that is useful for taking you to other areas of Tokyo directly.The hotel is very modern in design and had a truly boutique feel about it. The view from the hotel lobby on the 25th floor is stunning and features an excellent view of the Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji. The check-in process is effortless and the staff is very accommodating and always provided quick and useful advice on issues ranging from restaraunt suggests to directions to timetable information for the Narita Express trains.The rooms are an adequate size and well furnished with a flat screen TV, a mini bar and an in room safe. The entire hotel is spotlessly celan. The bathroom is effecient and supplied with nice amenities such as toothbrushes, razors and soaps and shampoo.We ate in the asian themed restaraunt and it was good but quite expensive, especially when compared to the countless local restaraunts that are scattered through many of Tokyo's neighbourhoods.There is a convenience store in the basement of the building on the way to the subway that is open 24 hours. There is also a Starbuck's coffee shop and a variety of restaraunts in the basement of the building which looked good but we didn't have a chance to eat there. It looks like their hours are mostly oriented towards catering to the office workers lunches and dinners.As for booking, I found that the best rate was avaiable through Tablet Hotels but there was a service fee added to our bill which could have made it on par with booking directly through the hotel's website (to be honest I didn't look into whether it would be added by hotel as well). Regardless, my average rate was $200 Canadian which I think is reasonable for the quality of the hotel in Tokyo.I would stongly recommend this hotel to people looking for a stylish hotel in Tokyo at a resonable price. It is particularly attractive if you are unintimidated by using the subway which is, in my opinion, the best way to get around and to see Tokyo. Those used to the London or New York subways will have no trouble using the Tokyo transit system. In fact, it is the best marked system I have ever experienced. This is particularly true when paired with the Tokyo Handy Guide that the concierge (the woman that works there is excellent) gave us.I would definitely stay again at the Park Hotel Tokyo when I return to further explore the amazing city of Tokyo.

Based on the excellent previous Tripadvisor reviews, I spent 2 nights in the Park Hotel in Tokyo. The hotel experience has even exceeded our expectations. The hotel is very modern and conveniently located near various subway stations and the Ginza shopping district. The staff is not only friendly but highly knowledgeable and professional. Two advices:1. If you are staying during winter-time, request an air-humidifier as the air in Tokyo is extremely dry.2. Try to ask for a room on one of the higher floors with a view on the Tokyo tower.

The Park Hotel is a really good value hotel and the service you receive is impeccable! The lobby area is stunning with amazing views over Tokyo to the tower and the bridge! Rooms are also well-equipped and comfortable.We ate in both of the restaurants too, both of which are really good - but there are far better restaurants in Tokyo so ask the concierge to recommend some. Restaurant called "Ukai-tei" highly recommended for the most amazing Japanese steak/teppanyaki! Finally, location is pretty good too. It's a short walk into the Ginza shopping district with loads of fabulous shops, bars and restaurants. Subway directly next to hotel too.Highly Recommended!

We chose to stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo based on the information from Trip Advisor and it was a great decision. The hotel is absolutely lovely and the staff was more than accomodating. Our room was small - but we didn't expect nor need a lot of space. It was sort of like being on a cruise ship - everything had a place and a purpose. The views from our room were fabulous - day and evening. It was very very quiet - hard to believe that anyone else was staying on our floor. We ate breakfast every morning in the lobby and it was quite good and we had dinner one night in the Japanese restaurant. It was incredibly good and the service was impeccable. The location was especially convenient. We couldn't have had a better experience and would recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo.

Myself and a friend stayed at the Park Hotel on our way back from Australia in July 06 (taken me a while to get round to writing this entry!). It was a great stay from start to finish. The staff are very friendly, speak almost fluent English and are willing to help with your every need. The view from the lobby is absolutely amazing and far outshines the views from Tokyo tower which we visited on one of our tours of the city. The rooms are clean and we felt more than large enough for a few nights stay. A large array of toiletries are provided as well as tea and coffee making facilities. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants, but there is ample choice of places to eat in the shopping mall which can be accessed from the ground floor of the hotel. Contrary to some other reviews on this hotel I would say that it is well placed for exploring Tokyo. We used the subway which was easy to find and navigate, although buying a ticket without the help of a friendly Japanese man who took pity on us would have proved difficult! I think the only small quibble we had was that we had problems getting to the hotel, as it was confused with the Tokyo Park hotel. However, after reading the reviews on this site before we left we were aware that this may happen and were eventually transported to the correct hotel! Something to bear in mind but not something that should deter you from visiting this brilliant hotel, which as far as we were concerned was quite reasonably priced for a city like Tokyo.

I spend half my time travelling on business in Asia and Europe, and have relied on this site to provide hotel insights so I thought it's time I give back to fellow travellers and readers :)I booked the hotel room on their site, which gave me a good idea of what the availabilities were, especially last minute bookings (I booked it about 4 days before arrival). I booked a small room (with double bed) for approximately 18,000 Yen (approximately US $160).Overall the rooms were very clean, excellent and cosy for one person (might be a tad cramp for two as the room is possibly the smallest I've every stayed in in Japan). View from hotel room is fantastic and a small bistro table is provided right next to the window so you get breathtaking view sipping coffee or having room service.In typical Japanese fashion, hotel staff were very helpful and friendly. The hotel is within a 10-minute walking distance to the Ginza line which takes you straight to Shibuya within 15 mins if you need to go shopping.Only catch was, when I arrived at 8:30 pm, I'd missed the last airport bus to hotel (last bus at 7 pm I think) as it's not considered one of the major hotels with high traffic. So I had to take the airport bus to Tokyo Station and transfer to the hotel, that costs an additional 1500 Yen.I would definitely stay there again should the rates stay reasonable as my last trip. I only spent about 15 hours in the hotel, and really wished I'd had more time to enjoy the room!

The two hotel mistakes a Tokyo tourist can make is (1) spend a not-so-small fortune and (2) stay in a hotel that isn't convenient to the invaluable and super-easy-to-use Tokyo subway/train system.A good Tokyo hotel can easily cost $300, $400, or more a night. I was really worried that at roughly $155 a night, the Park Hotel would be a dump. Boy, was I wrong. It is a sleek, modern, new, immaculately clean, trendy, and gorgeous hotel. Anything under $200 a night is a bargain in Tokyo and I can't imagine that there is a better bang for the buck anywhere in the entire city of Tokyo. The hotel is very close to one of the main subway lines and an easy 8-10 minute walk to Shimbashi station, which makes it a snap to get to all the other popular areas: Roppongi, Shinjuku, Meiji, Akihibara, Tokyo Station, and Shibuya. I can't emphasize enough how critical it is to choose a hotel that is close to a subway/train hub. This hotel is also within easy, easy walking distance to the Ginza and the Tsukiji fish market. Both of those are absolute must visits. By the way, the only reason to get to the Tsukiji fish market before 6:00 is if you want to see the actual auction process. I found the post-auction process the most interesting. Things like carving up the monster tunas, strolling the colorful seafood stalls, and watching the elaborate engine of sushi commerce in action. My advice is to sleep in a little and arrive around 7:00 AM instead. The only negative is the size of the room. They are indeed small. It was no problem for me because I was traveling by myself, but I the size would be a serious problem for anything more than 2 people. Don't bring a family here. The hotel restaurants are good but expensive. Take advantage of the Family Mart store in the basement. Family Mart is the 7-11 of Japan and has drinks, snacks, and cheap-but-delicious bento boxes to eat. Unless you're rich and have money to burn, this is the VERY, VERY, VERY best deal in all of Tokyo.

Stayed here for 6 nights in mid-November in a standard double room.The rooms may be small but they are so well laid out. Absolutely everything you could want, exactly where you need it. The lobby is awesome and the views aren't too bad, either.The location is fabulous. A short walk from the lifts to subway and train networks or just step out onto the streets of downtown Tokyo.This hotel is amazing value for money - although we didn't eat or drink in the hotel. You can eat with the Japanese under the railway tracks for a tiny fraction of the price.

Stayed at the Park Hotel Nov 21 to Nov 27, as indicated in previous reviews. Conceige was helpful. They gave maps of subways, directions and recommended routes with options. (we should have utilized them more.) Would I stay here again - Yes. And the lobby, yes is very quiet, dragging your stuff on the nice wooden floor is not adviseable. Not the hotel for your if you're looking for cultural ambience scene. And you want to smooze with the locals.Room size was was great - premium room with seating. (paid 3,000 yen for extra bed.) They converted the seating to a fold out bed. (for my 13 yr old dau and her 12 yr girlfriend.)Toiletries includes -shampoo, conditioner, body gel, soap, razors, bath salt, wash scrub, q-tips, makeup cloth and nail file, toothbrush and paste, body lotion and a hairbrush. They have a blow dryer, pajamas, terry cloth robes, slippers, tv, nice room lighting, radio, tv (and lan available.) Bed was comfy, no tower view, but thats ok. I was more pleased with the room size. I've stayed at Shinjiku Washington Hotel - now that is small.Didnt get the pillow fitter service as raved in other reviews.They have excellent complementary coffee and tea for your morning dose.We didnt eat at any of the hotel restaurants or used the other hotel services.Recommendations: Check your bearing. We probably should have checked out the Carretta Bulding - several reviews indicated that there are shops and restaurants on 1st and basement floor. Japan has great food. Wish we had more. I kinda feel like I didnt eat as much as I should have. I notice the Via La France (which isnt too bad of a walk about 5 minutes. Shibashi station is another 7 minutes from there. We took JR to Akihabara - and that was another 3 minute from there. (in route we found a great food store - grocery, bentos, fine candies, cakes, all kinds of food things you could picked up.) Fine Foods Fair (I think was the name) We even went back the morning of the day we left.In the same building as Via La France - 2nd floor they have around 12 restaurants all in a row. I was told by hotel that the restaurants areon the 41 and 42 floor of that building. Usually last order for restaurants are around 9:30 pm so had to eat at the English Pub twice - and do the prime-rib thing. Prices is not as cheap as you'd like it to be, but not bad.We found the am/pm store and went there the first three nights - finally found the Family Mart store (yes, the Family Store is very close (just right out side the hotel.) Hotel has two elevators. If going the subway and trains easier to switch elevators on the 1st floor - security guard will help you. (they look stiff but very helpful. (the elevator is hidden behind a wall. (but thats your ticket to get below ground level.Did a walk to Ginza from the Park Hotel. With baby and stroller. A test of endurance to walk through the constructed overpass. I'm sure it would have been a better walk without the staired overpass.

Overall, our experience with Park Hotel was very good. The hotel is very clean and modern. The lobby is on the 30-somethingth floor of an office building, which makes for some really awesome views of Tokyo, though lots of long elevator rides. The rooms, though VERY small, were incredibly clean and had large windows with great views (ours was looking out over the park). And though the room is small, you have everything you need - including filtered coffee, which very much impressed my boyfriend. One of the biggest reasons we booked the Park Hotel was for its location right over Shinjuku station on the JR loop line. And though it is connected via underground tunnels, they are very confusing at first and it is quite a trek to make a couple times a day. Probably about 20 minutes from station to hotel lobby. Also, don't try to use the tunnels late at night (after the last train) because we almost got locked in! Going above ground is not very easy to do either - our first morning when we ventured out to try to find the fish market, we couldn't even go a block without street construction or dead ends stopping us in our tracks. Eventually we discovered the extensive network of over-street passageways you had to use to get anywhere, but it was not easy to figure out in our jet-lagged state. We were always starving in the morning, so opted for the very pricey but filling buffet in the lobby. Basically we stuffed ourselves silly at 8 am and ate lightly on ramen, etc the rest of the day.The staff at the hotel was pretty helpful. They spoke English and tried to help us when we were lost a few times.The Park Hotel was one of the least expensive hotels we stayed at in our 2 week trip and also one of the best. I would recommed it based on the quality of the rooms and hotel overall, but the location leaves something to be desired.

Like the other reviewers here, we had a wonderful time for five nights at the ParkThe hotel is located in a new complex of skyscrapers at the southern tip of Ginza, with two railway stations within the complex:L an easy walk to the centre of of Ginza or easy access to anywhere in Tokyo via the trainsThe hotel itself is clean, modern, and chic with a great central atrium. It is slick -- some have said sterile but i diasagree -- and the staff are professional and courteous, with excellent EnglishThe rooms are not large but you are in Tokyo after all!Highly recommended

There is not really much to add to the other recent reviews on this hotel. Excellent value - where could you stay in London at the same price? I did not mind the room size - in Tokyo what do you expect? In every way this hotel far exceeded my expectations. They know how to do service without servility. I think the best thing is how relaxed and comfortable you are made to feel. The decor ( I am a bit of a minimalist, I confess) is an absolute delight and the quality of light and sense of space in the atrium is just superb.On top of all this, the location. In 2 days we were able to walk to most of the central sights (site?) and also take the train out of the city.Just great!

If you're looking for somewhere to stay in tokyo, that's modern, trendy, clean, accessible and not ridiculously expensive, this is it. The rooms are quite small (but that's tokyo) but they've got amazing views, comfy beds and are all newly decorated and modern. The communal areas of the hotel are great and there's a few shops in the basement too. You can walk to lots of places (incl, ginza) but for everywhere else, you are basically on top of a tube so you can go anywhere really easily)If you're planning to go anywhere to eat or sight see (we were going to football in yoykahama and on to kyoto) the guest services/concierge where just aobut the best I've ever coem across in man yyears of staying in much more expensive hotels all over the world. they're well worth using. Totally recommended.

Having read previous reviews we booked a superior room. It was well worth the extra - fantastic views, bags of room and a superb bathroom. The location was excellent. Near the park, walking distance to the Ginza district and many restaurants. We only had breakfast in the Hotel, which was very good and varied. All the staff were very friendly and obliging. Will certainly stay at the Park Hotel next time we visit Tokyo.

We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of October. I was happily impressed (after having read other reviews) with the size of the room. It was compact but comfortable and well designed and it had a fantastic view. The room and other facilities were spotless and the service was very good as well. The area is very convenient for central Tokyo. Good connections for trains and metro.Fantastic value for money. I would recommend this place and stay there if I go back to Tokyo.

Would thoroughly recommend the Park Hotel if you are looking for a hotel in Tokyo. We stayed in October for 2 days and had a really great time. The room was very well designed although not that big. The bathroom had one of the great Toto electric toilets, a real experience if you have not been to Japan before.The location is really good, there are a number of good sushi restaurants within walking distance or if you are loooking for something a bit smarter you have the great Gordon Ramsey restaurant at the Conrad over the road.

I agree with the general thrust of the latest batch of reviews- it's a bit of a stretch to compare the Park Hotel with some of the other luxury bracket hotels in Tokyo as it lacks both the room space and the level of facilities you might expect for hotels with the very best star ratings. This could prove a bit of a nuisance for business travellers. But, at the price, it is extremely good value, particularly for tourists to the city.The public spaces of the hotel are beautiful... all dark wood and understated lighting, although, as someone else has alluded to, this does mean it feels rather like an exhibition space to be crept around, rather than somewhere to drag trolley cases across or to drop umbrellas - a bit of a victory for form over functionThe standard room size is not particularly generous, but they do seem to have been laid-out to make the best possible use of the available space. The bed was extremely comfortable, which proved a great help in easing out the jet lag - the hotel is justly proud of its custom-made pillows! The lighting control also makes it easy to create a relaxing environment.There's certainly no danger of getting lost in the bathroom, but, again, the use of space has been well thought out and all the usual facilities were well up to scratch, plus everything you could need by way of complimentary toileteries. When booking, it's worth specifying that you'd like a room on the Tokyo Tower side. Given the hotel occupies the upper floors of a lofty office tower, the view is absolutely stunning, especially at night. There is some noise from the Shinkansen tracks that run by the base of the tower, but this is little more than a gentle rumble.The staff, while friendly and polite, are also refreshingly unobtrusive... none of the cloying over-attentiveness of the big hotel chains. While Shiodome could hardly be described as the most charming corner of Tokyo, it is very well connected - nearby Shimbashi station is on the JR Yamanote, which loops around the central areas of the city (and to Tokyo central station, in 4mins), plus there are a couple of subway lines that link up to some of the main tourist destinations. The third floor exit from the building takes you on to an elevated walkway where everything is clearly signposted in English. It's easy enough to reach places like Ginza by foot, and Tsukiji fish market is just 15mins walk away - great if you decide to make the early start to watch the auctions. The Hama Rikyu garden provides a counter to the steel-and-glass sterility of the rest of the area. All-in-all, a great value, good-looking hotel.

I stayed here for three nights on business in November 2006. Great hotel for the price - if I were to come back for a holiday I would choose to stay here again. English speaking staff greeted me the moment I walked into the lobby on the 25th floor and asked if I needed to check in, also offered to help with anything after they had showed me to my room. I really liked the atmosphere in the lobby with the bar/breakfast area. I stayed here on my own which sometimes as a woman can be a bit lonely and intimidating. But here I felt very at home - due to the helpful staff and mix of guests: some businessmen frantically preparing for tomorrow's presentation over a beer, some tourists, some Japanese (but not many). The French Restaurant, run by chef Teteru Yoshino, deserves a mention. I entertained 5 Japanese businessmen here and the staff were very helpful in setting it up, providing special menus, etc. The food is good french 'nouvelle cuisine' - beware, the portion sizes are quite small so I think my Japanese colleagues felt a bit short-changed and ate lots of bread. The food is good but not great - this restaurant would not get a Michelin star (although the chef's Paris restaurant Stella Maris has one). And my room had a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower - what more could you ask for?

From JR Shimbashi station it's a small trek. The hotel map is sort of confusing. When you get of JR Shimbashi station, follow the signs going to the "Yurikamome Station." This station is directly across from the entrance to the hotel building (triangular shaped skyskraper). The staff was very courteous and there was free internet access (this was helpful in looking up directions in english to places the staff may not know about - e.g. Parasite Museum in Meguro). It was walking distance to Tsukiji Fish Market and Ginza. The JR Shimbashi Stn is a little bit of a walk, but if you have a JR pass then this gives you all access to Tokyo (via JR Yamanote). The buffet breakfast was pricey (5200JPY for 2 people). However, the rooms were very clean, the amenities were very nice and there was a Family Mart close to get water, bento boxes, snacks etc... There is also a famous MOS Burger (limited menu) nearby (1st floor around the corner from Tully's Coffee). This hotel made our first stay in Tokyo, Japan very pleasant.

We stayed at the Park Hotel Shiodome October 27-30, 2006. We generally agree with the positive reviews. High quality room (not large but this is Japan), and we had great city views of the Tokyo Tower and surroundings from the 28th floor. Found a very high level of service from greeting us at ground level and taking us to check in on the 25th floor. Staff at desk had fluent English. The room has nice amenities, and as said by others nice to get an English newspaper (International Herald Tribune combined with English version of Asahi Shimbun.) We booked over the internet for 17500 yen per night, not particularly cheap but not bad for Tokyo.It is a bit confusing to find (especially at ground level) because of construction right now, and it is across from the somewhat similarly named Royal Park Hotel. Like others we had some trouble navigating at first until we found that if you exit at the 3rd floor, you can exit turning left to reach an upper level walkway that takes you past the Royal Park on your right, then you turn left to reach Shimbashi station which has the Yamanote rail and Ginza subway lines. If you take the escalator down near the Royal Park there are restaurants and shopping. Also on the 3rd level if you go right past the new yurakicho sky train station you reach the Pedi Shiodome which has some very nice restaurants and coffee shops which we frequented. We also ate in the underground by Shimbashi station. We did not eat in the hotel, though on the ground level there is nice cafe, Cafe Des Artes.We have stayed at Keio Plaza in Shinjuku previously and the ANA in Roppongi. While the ANA is a superior hotel, we found the Park to be good value for the money. Unlike another reviewer we did mind being a little out of the action, and having a bit of a quiet retreat in a smaller more boutique like hotel. We would happily stay there again.

I stayed in the Tokyo Park Hotel at Shiodome (not to be confused with several other "Park" hotels) for 6 nights on business. As other reviews note, it can be difficult to find if arriving by cab (the roads are very complex and under construction) or by train (the train station/office complex is huge). Best bet for arrival is by limousine bus from the airport.The entire hotel, from lobby to restaurants to guest rooms and bathrooms is beautiful and immaculately clean. It no doubt helps that the hotel is only 3 years old. The rooms are well designed and quiet, and have especially nice attention to amenities in the bathrooms. Beds were very comfortable and there is excellent attention to lighting control in the rooms.The location in the Shiodome area is very convenient for easy transportation to almost everything in Tokyo (or outside Tokyo, for that matter). The hotel connects directly to the Shiodome station for Toei (newer, private) subway line and the Yurikomome elevated train to Odaiba; and it is a 10 minute enclosed walk to the Shimbashi station for Tokyo Metro subway and JR station (Yamanote line as well as several other lines, e.g., to Kamakura). It's only a few minutes by train to Tokyo station for the bullet train. As others have mentioned, it's also about a 15 minute walk to Ginza, Tsukiji fish market, etc.The downside of the location is that taking a cab to the hotel is quite difficult. It's essential to pick up one of their map cards to show the driver. Also, the Shiodome complex is sterile -- full of office buildings and chain stores. Although the enclosed nature of it is convenient when hot or rainy, it can also be claustrophobic, like living in a shopping mall.You may be wondering: why is the hotel so much less expensive than other top hotels in Tokyo, especially since it is new and beautiful? I think there are two reasons: the rooms are relatively small for a luxury hotel, and the hotel provides relatively few services, compared to 5-star hotels. The regular rooms with king bed allow very little room apart from the bed. I stayed in an upgrade corner room which had a separate small sitting area, but it was still fairly crowded, even for just one person. It would be fine for two people, but would probably feel quite small if a child were added (and would be impossible for more than 3). On the other hand, you're likely not to spend a lot of time in the room anyway. One thing to remember, though, is that extra room is very nice when one or more family members suffers jet lag and wakes at 4:00am.As for services, there are many things the hotel does not have: a fitness center, a pool, business services (apart from a couple of computers), a variety of restaurants (only two), etc. Those things are probably of main concern to business travelers. For instance, I needed to make more business cards, which they could not do, unlike other hotels I've visited in Tokyo.Finally, the open atrium style architecture of the hotel (a 10-story high open central space) is dramatic and lovely, but it has a drawback -- one feels as if "on display". Eating at the main breakfast area in the lobby, one sits at the bottom of the open area. All sounds are magnified by the echo chamber effect and the hard wooden floors. I felt like I should not talk (it echoes all over) and must walk quietly. When I dropped an umbrella, it resounded loudly throughout the restaurant area. (FWIW, a better place to sit for breakfast is in one of the side rooms, which also have views). So it definitely could feel awkward coming or going through the lobby with boisterous children.In short, is it a good deal? Absolutely. Is it a good location? Yes, very much, as long as you get out of the Shiodome complex. If traveling alone, I'd be happy to stay there again. However, it is not really fair (or the intention of the hotel) to be compared against five star hotels with complete range of services and spacious rooms.

We only stayed for one night in the Park Hotel on a layover, but our short experience was great. As other reviews have stated, this hotel is located in a business area, but a short walk to Ginza, the fish market etc. The staff was exceptional, rooms were immaculate. We would definetely stay there again.

My husband and I spent our first 5 nights in Japan at the Park Hotel Tokyo as part of our 2 week trip in mid-October. We made the decision to stay here because of the reviews on this site plus the hotel's fabulous rate. We would absolutely stay here again without hesitation.Pros:*Great location- easy walking to Tsukiji Fish Market, Kabuki-za theater, Ginza shopping, JR line, subways, restaurants, convenience stores, area street scene*Easy access to major Tokyo attractions*Price- very reasonable compared to other hotels in its class*Urban/chic atmosphere- gorgeous views from the lobby and room, contemporary design, live jazz in the lobby lounge on weekend nights*Exceptionally clean, bright, pleasant room w/ very comfortable bed and pillows; immaculate bathroom w/ nice assortment of good quality bath amenities*In room minibar fridge offered extra space for cold storing personal goodies plus super speedy hot water heater for coffee and tea*Efficient, pleasant service- provided maps and directions, handled baggage forwarding for us, very hospitable staff without exception*The multi-level above ground walkway connecting the hotel to the subway, the street, shops and restaurants, other buildings, etc., was a lot of fun to learn how to navigateCons:*Road construction surrounding the hotel is a temporary nuisance only if you need to drive around the hotel; a multi-level walkway above ground will keep you out of the fray*Insufficient drawer space for clothes for two people*Small room compared to our other Tokyo accommodations at Akasaka Prince where we stayed at the end of our trip

We stayed in the Park Hotel, Tokyo for 3 nights at the beginning of October 2006. The hotel is in a great location in the center of Ginza with easy access to the metro, shops and restaurants. The hotel itself is located above the 23rd floor giving the rooms a great view of the city, our room had a spectacular view over the bay. The room was small but very clean, comfortable and modern (LCD TV, Toto, nice products). The staff were very friendly and helpful and there was a very nice looby bar which had live music most nights. Highly recommended.

This hotel is perhaps not the most central in Tokyo, situated in the business district of Shiodome, but we would strongly reccommend it. The lobby is located on the 25th floor of the media tower, allowing stunning views from the rooms and the lifts! The service was fantastic, as can be expected in many places in Japan. The staff were always keen to help and spoke good english, which helped us. The meals are a little pricey, but there is a good selection including French, English and Japanese. Rooms are a good size and kept immaculate - the heated toilet seat in the bathroom is a bonus. Most nights had live music in the atrium, mainly Jazz and Blues with a mixture of Japanese and Western muscians playing and singing to a very high standard. Just off the atrium is a cocktail bar and although there is a cover change (1000 Yen), for great views, fantastic service and a comprehensive cocktail list it is definatly reccomended. Overall this is a very nice hotel, and a very good price. Shimbashi station is just 5 minutes walk away.

Very nice hotel, but rooms are small and area is newer live/work type. Be sure to get the larger room and have breakfast included as it is $25 if you pay. Nice food due to the French Chef on staff, but pricey. Doesn't feel like Japan hotel, more like a contemporary Hilton. If you want to feel the city vibes and eat close by at more authentic restaurants, don't stay here. If you want out of the hustle more modern surroundings, this is your place.

We chose to stay at this hotel based on the reviews on tripadvisor.I was not disappointed. The hotel is in a great location, only a short walk to Ginza, a great shopping district. The shops were a little out of my league (Prada, Salavatore Ferragamo, Ralph Lauren) but most people just enjoying walking up and down the street.It's also very close to Shiodome and Shimbashi metro station which can easily be reached by an underground, very clean, well-lit walk way. The metro was quite easy to tackle as the ticket machines have an english function, so working out how much to pay for a day trip or single journey on the metro is quite easy.The room was fantastic, I was worried it would be small, but I would say it was average size for a western hotel room. There were fabulous shampoos, conditioners and body lotions provided - they smelt divine - and didn't leave skin dry like some hotel creams/shower gels can. The shower was great, bed was very comfy and they had fab toilet with all of the japanese mod cons!!! - It would wash your bum and heat the seat for you!!We had 3 great nights in Japan and I would love to stay at this hotel again. When I booked it, it did seem slightly on the pricey side, but We had a great time and I'm very glad I took the advice on trip advisor and stayed here , it really made my short stay in Japan memorable!!

The hotel is a real bargain. I booked directly through the hotel's website and paid around £80 a nights. The room was fairly large and had a great view of the water and surrounding skyscrapers. Decor was modern and everything was top quality and up to 4* standard.The transport links are also very good. Shimbashi station (on the Yamanote line is about 10 mins walk away through underground tunnels and Shiodome station is a few hundred metres away. The hotel is a short cab ride from Tokyo station with the Narita express out to the airport.The downside for me is that the hotel is in a characterless (although upmarket) business district. Reception is on the 25th floor of an office building. In the evening the ground level is totally deserted except for a roving security guard and did not feel at all welcoming. The lobby itself had no atmosphere and at 11pm on a saturday there were just 4 people in the lobby bar. Under the hotel are long spotlessly clean underground passages leading to the subway. Very few people around at night. It feels totally safe, but a bit isolated. If you want somewhere to escape all the hustle and bustle of Tokyo then this is fine. Personally, I think the crowds and energy are part of Tokyo's appeal and I'd rather stay closer to the action in somewhere like Shinjuku.

My husband and I stayed at Park Hotel Tokyo - which I'd chosen based on tripadvisor.com reviews - the first week in October while on holiday, and we couldn't have been more pleased. As I pen this using the complimentary Internet hook-up in my room, I am just wrapping up my second stay this month (this time on business). Excellent value for money. Shimbashi station is about a 10-minute walk (15 minutes when stopping at Starbucks ;), while the Oedo subway line - which I've used several times to get to such places as Roppongi - is accessible through the one hotel elevator that descends to B1 (basement 1). (The hotel has four elevators; the one on the right side, farthest from the reception desk, is the one to take to B1.) You exit into an underground hallway with restaurants; go straight out and through a revolving door, and you'll see a Family Mart convenience store on your right. Keep going, and you'll exit into an underground pedestrian walkway. Look for signs that will direct you to the Oedo line. One trick to get back to the hotel using the same underground access is to follow exits 7 and 8 from the Oedo line exit....you come out of the subway area, take a sharp right and go up an escalator. The Park Hotel Tokyo entrance is up ahead on your right (turn left and through the sliding glass doors for Starbuck's, Mailboxes Etc., convenience store with water, etc.)When my husband and I arrived for our first stay in early October, we were intent on walking to the hotel from Shimbashi station using the hotel's on-line map that I'd printed. We failed miserably - and we laughed when I remembered the one reviewer who said he is a savvy traveler (as are we) and his best advice was to take a taxi. We solved the problem later! When reading maps conveniently posted all around Japan, be sure to look for the symbol that denotes which direction is "north." Turns out that maps on display here are oriented in the direction you are facing! And the map we'd consulted in Shimbashi station had North pointing down.Incidentally, my colleague reports that the Business Center on the main floor by the reception has two computers connected to the Internet with free access and printing.We bought breakfast items in a convenience store instead of having the hotel breakfast. When we asked for bowls/spoons for our cereal, they were promptly delivered to our rooms.Also, if you like to exercise, this hotel doesn't have a fitness center. The front desk has a 1-mile-circuit jogging map, though. It's a simple, "rectangular" route. I would have preferred a fitness center, but the difference in room rates for another, untested hotel would likely not have been worth one.Also, when we asked the front desk personnel to help us plan how to arrive at our various meetings this week, they were more than helpful, showing us on a subway map which lines to use, etc.

My wife and I picked this hotel on the basis of the ratings and reviews on Tripadvisor, and we were NOT disappointed.Room: The room we had was smaller than the typical North American hotel room, but you quickly become accustomed to it; it is Tokyo after all! It was super-clean and had FREE high-speed Internet access. Also, the room and the hotel, in general, were super-quiet; even the elevators were silent.Friendly Staff: The hotel staff were some of the most friendly and helpful people we have ever encountered at a hotel anywhere. One evening I called housekeeping to request an ironing board; no sooner had I put down the phone, then the doorbell rang. The front desk and concierge made restaurant reservations for us, and provided us with maps. The hotel kept our bags over the weekend, when we took a side-trip outside of Tokyo. Everyone at the hotel understands and speaks English.Location: We thought the location was really convenient. I actually appreciated that the hotel was in an office district and was removed from the bustling shopping and entertainment districts; it was a nice refuge at the end of long day of shopping and sight-seeing. There is a convenient underground concourse that connects the hotel to the Shimbashi train/metro station; it is about a 15 minute walk from your room to the station, and you never have to go outside. From Shimbashi, you are just two stops from Tokyo Station, which is the main Japan-Rail hub for the bullet trains. Directly beneath the hotel is the Shiodome metro station. This stop is on the Oedo line, which also has stops at Roppongi and Shinjuku; you don’t even have to change trains.Getting to/from Narita: You can take the Japan Rail train from Narita to Tokyo station; then take the JR line to Shimbashi station. If you’re adventurous and don’t’ have a lot of luggage you can try to navigate the underground concourse to Shiodome Media Tower; just keep looking for the yellow and black English signs that will point you in the correct direction.Food: We took the advice of other reviewers and grabbed croissants and yoghurt for breakfast at the French-themed bakery (I can’t recall the name.) in one of the nearby office-tower concourses. There was also a Starbucks close by (I think it was in the same building.).Fish Market: You must visit the fish market, and you must do so before 7 a.m.! You can indeed walk to the fish market in about 15 minutes with a good map. I could on…but basically if you are looking for a clean, quiet and modern hotel that is close to transportation and has extremely friendly staff, then stay Park Hotel. Whenever we return to Tokyo we will only stay at Park Hotel.

I stayed this hotel for 4 days. It was a pleasant experience. Every morning I could read English newspaper .And complimentary tea and coffee was good.Staying in Japan for a English speaking traveler is tough experience sometimes. Even in hotel you may feel uncomfortable due to communication problem. But in this hotel all the staffs speak english very well. There was no communication problem. Besides the location was fantastic. Every kinds of subway including yurikamamoe close to this hotel.But for the first time it was really hard to find the right location of the hotel. It's near shimbashi station but only through subway passage you can find the Park hotel. On the street you couldn't find it if you were a new comer in this district. It took 30 minutes for me to find this hotel. One more thing about the Park hotel Tokyo.. breakfast was so simple and a little bit disappointing for me. You'd better go other building complex(such as Caretta Mall) to find restaurants .

Stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. Enjoyed my experience there and would go back. Location is excellent, beside Shimbashi train station and subway. The room was clean and decent size (had a superior room however, did not see standard rooms). I was a bit concerned about the noise from the trains that pass non stop but it wasn't a problem after all. The hotel is in a business area but the underground passage ways are convenient (restaurants, Starbucks, and linked to the subway).Buffet breakfast was good.

We stayed at the Park for 3 nights and had a brilliant time. It was our first visit to Japoan and from the moment we arrived the staff were helpful and went out of their way to assist - there were no language problems at all. The business suite was excellent - we were able to upload our holiday pics as we went along and write our blog so that friends and family at home could follow our trip.Ignore the reviews that say the Park is miles from the subway - it isn't - unless you think a 5 minute walk is miles! All signs were in english and we found it very easy to get around. We didn't eat in the hotel as the breakfasts/meals were quite expensive but there are loads of restaurants (Japanese, Italian and other) in the towers nearby. There is an excellent Starbucks in Shimbashi station.The rooms were quite small but very comfy and had everything you could possibly need (very hi tech toilets!) including slippers and robes.We would definitly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo for the first time or any time!

This hotel cannot be more perfect for our first trip to Tokyo. The hotel is beautiful; the room in the high floors have perfect views; and the staffs definitely go any possible way to help out. Not to mention the perfect location right above subway station. We got rained out one day with a really bad storm; but we did not even need umbrellas all day! The restaurant selections nearby are also very impressive. We'll be back again!

Based on prveious Tripadvisor reviews and our particular needs, we chose Park Hotel. Overall, we had an extremely satisfying four night stay.Some of the attributes of the hotel; Reception was great with an extra effort to ensure our bed request was available. We ended up with a breathtaking view of Tokyo Bay (with the Conrad on our left). We felt the cityscape around Tokyo Tower was somewhat lacking during the day, so we were glad that we endured our couple of days of jetlag appreciating the morning sunrise cast on the Bay. The hotel is high above city noise and bustle of downtown Tokyo. The tone and atmosphere of the hotel is dark, hushed tones, so the guest is inclined to speak softly. Hotel clientelle is well-travelled, informed, primarily business professionals with little evident overt "gaijin" behaviour. The live evening musical entertainment was extraordinary and different each night. A variety of food services and cheap breakfast (Y800) is avialable in the Shiodome complex. We walked to Tsukiji, the Ginza and being too ambitious our first day on Tokyo, the East Garden (meaning we passed out at 1800hours and woke up again at 0300hrs...so much for correcting jetlag our first day!)The attributes of the room; The bathroom had a dimmer switch, great and generously provided "Thann" amenities (very much like Molton Brown) and powerful shower pressure. Room temperature adjusted quickly, pillows were a mix of Barley-filled pillows and feather pillows, the bed was really comfortable although unlike other Japanese hotel stays, we received a hospital-style nightgown and not a Takata (we prefer Takatas).
