The Park was only hotel on our visit to Japan to provide complimentary coffee. Honor bar was reasonably priced and a morning English paper provided. I found the room size efficient and comfortable (size is much like staying in established classic European hotels), but I will say the design lends to business travel, so we had little drawer space for our folded clothes. Carpet was in great repair. Found slippers would be ideal for "smaller feet".Overall, an excellent selection and best hotel on our vacation. We would stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo again without question.

Stayed in September 2006 for 5 nights at the Park Hotel during a business trip and got a great deal from Travelocity of $117/night, supposedly unheard of in Tokyo.I have never visited Japan but the room size was small but very nice and comfortable and very new, 3 yr old hotel. Small TV and bathroom but they provide all toilettries, so you don't have to bring anything, including a razor, toothbrush, and lotion.The hotel walkable from the Shimbashi train station, where you can get trains to anywhere in Tokyo and beyond, and the Shiodome subway station. It was very convienent to shopping areas and food. There are elevated walkways and underground walkways from this hotel to the train, subway, food and shopping. If, like me, you need coffee to start in the morning, there is a Starbucks, Tullys, and Via La France in the underground walkway area.High recommendation for the Park Hotel. Ask for a room with the view of the Tokyo Tower and Mt Fuji on a clear day.

I would like to comment on some of the bad reviews below.Some people you can never please. I found the front desk to be very helpful. If you want a map of the city, you have to ask. What’s so hard about that? Also, the subway station is very close to the hotel. If you’re too lazy to walk 15 minutes, than maybe you should stay home. As with every city, you’ll have to walk a bit to get to the station. I’ve found this hotel to be great for the price. If you want a superb hotel, stay at the Hyatt.

It was our 3rd stay at Park. The biggest surprise was, we couldn't find the concierge who have helped us a lot during our previous stay. She have had the great knowledge of Tokyo, and always gave us the great information. Where have she been? Unfortunately we couldn't get as much information as we did the last 2 times. The location good. Is within 30 minutes to Shinjuku, Shibuya, and the other major tourist spots in central Tokyo, using subway. Once you memorize how the underground walkway is, it will be quite easy.The room pretty small, but should be the average size in Tokyo.If we be able to have great information again, we will stay here again. But if not, we look for the other place to stay.

I have lived in Japan for 13 years (not Tokyo) and I have stayed in everything from $5 campgrounds to $800 a night hotels. The Park Hotel is an excellent deal for Japan. I stayed in a single room for 3 nights in Sept. Despite other complaints of room size, the Park's room is ample for Japan. In other hotels you bang your knees on the desk getting off the bed! Yes, it is clean and modern. For those wanting more of a "Japan" feel then stay in ryokan. For people not used to walking then the 5 minute walk to Shimbashi station may seem like a lot. However, for Tokyo it is an excellent and close location. There are restaurants all around the hotel in the other buildings. I did not eat the breakfast at the hotel. I prefered simple sandwich from the Vie La France bakery a short walk away. There is also a delicious onigiri (rice ball) restaurant in the Caretta building. Also in the Caretta building there is a famous Taiwanese dumpling restaurant. The menu has pictures and it is easy to order. For the price and location in Tokyo the Park can't be beat! P.S. check out their website. It was in English and the price from them was cheaper than from other travel websites for the days I was going to be there. Japanese prices must include tax so you are looking at the total with the exception of a 200 yen or so hotel tax.

Horrible experience. Front desk was rude when we tried to check in early. They wouldnt let us check in early and at the same time they didnt offer to even store our bags temporarily while we went sightseeing. The concierge had very few recommendations and initially only gave us a map to get to the subway station from the hotel, we had to press her to get even a city map. Rooms were small, but fairly clean. There was lots of construction around the hotel, so it was difficult for taxis to get in and out. The subway station is actually about 15 mins walk, and then a 15-20min ride to shibuya, shinjuku, and other popular destinations, so it wasnt an ideal location (thought itd be closer to the action). Also thought the hotel being at top of tower would be interesting, but there are only a couple elevators so you have to wait to get into the hotel section (25 floors up), so there was some inconvience. Would never stay here again based on service and location.

Excellent location with good connection to all subways. Good value for money. And good service. Internet access is for free and so is the use of two PCs at the reception. As usual, beverages and food inside the hotel is quite expensive, so it's definitely worthwhile taking a few steps outside. The design of the lobby is stunning, that of the rooms average and simple. I don't think it deserves to be called a design hotel, but it's all new and fresh. Recommended!

This hotel is in an office building in the middle of an office complex. This is a strange location. The whole complex was in the middle of major road construction, therefore it was not easy to walk around. Ginza is about a 15-20 minute walk. The rails are under the complex therefore you have to do a lot of underground walking to get to the stations (even though they tell you it is right in the basement of the building). Our room was the size of my closet at home, I could not even lay out my suitcase. Yes the rooms are modern and clean. Also, the food is extremely expensive. We paid $37.00 for 2 coffees and three minuature pastries!!

Stayed here twice on my trip. The first few days I wasn't the happiest with the room as side of the bed was against the wall and the room was tiny. I really didn't see what the fuss was about that I'd read here on Trip Advisor. I then went to Kyoto for a few days and decided that when I returned to Tokyo I'd stay at the hotel again as they offered to keep my luggage so I would only have to bring a small bag to Kyoto with me. When I returned the room they gave me stank of fish (really strong) so when the bellman came to deliver the bags I asked him to step into the room and see if he got the smell. He immedately rang downstairs and came up with another room key. This room was gorgoeus and I'm gutted I didn't ask for a room like this the first time. There was more space and the bed was in the centre of the room and the view of the Tokyo tower was amazing. I have to say that staying in that room completely changed my opininon of the hotel. My advice....if you're booking a normal room then ask for the room I was in which was 3306. If they put you in a smaller room then ask to be changed. It's worth it.Of course I'll also say what everyone else is saying....it was great location because of the subway and trains underneath. Bit of a walk though to get to any of the lines so bring your walking shoes!

Our stay at the Park Hotel was for 4 nights (Sept 3-6 2006). As most of the other posts stated, the Shiodome area is a great base location. The Shiodome and Shinbashi stations are in the complex itself and can pretty much get you anywhere you need. A plethora of restaurants to choose from. We ate at a few in the Caretta and Pedi buildings and were quite pleased with all and wish we had more time to sample more!We thought the room was indeed a bit cozy, but nonetheless sufficiently sized for a few days stay. We had a great view on the 33rd floor overlooking Tokyo Tower and part of the Bay. The water pressure from the shower was excellent. The one minor negative observation we had about the hotel was the lack of warmth. Everytime we walked through the lobby, it felt as if we were in a library and had to keep our voices hushed. Service was fine, but not overly inviting. Regardless, we would stay here again in a minute.

We have just returned from a 1 week stay in Tokyo. It was our first trip to Japan, and therefore a little intimidating. We considered the twice as expensive Mandarin Oriental, or the Park Hyatt, but the reviews on Trip Advisor once again steered us in the right direction. We like something a little less opulent and flashy, yet we are very picky on hotels, and this met or exceeded our expectations in every way. I would request a room on a corner, since you get 5 windows instead of 2, and the views are amazing. One night we got a fireworks display thrown in, and what a spectacle it was. The staff were very attentive, and the rooms seemed to be made up as soon as you left , no matter whether you slept in or rose early. Simply, this was one of the best hotel values I have seen in the world, especially knowing how expensive Tokyo is. We booked ahead and paid around 20,000 yen per room per night including all taxes. I think that they upgraded us to the corner rooms because we were staying a week. Go and enjoy, you won't be disappointed. Lots of great restaurants in the vicinity, and well connected to all of Tokyo.

For me, the most important decision about a hotel is the location and this hotel has a superb one. Easy to travel all around Tokyo and within spitting distance of monorails, bullets and metros. On top of that a clean, friendly (they carried my bags!) and a superior hotel. The rooms were small but of adequate size - I mean, you're in Tokyo you're not spending 24/7 in the room anyway. More toiletries than my local supermarket and a computer controlled toilet which kept me amused for hours! The views were spectacular and the staff friendly and helpful. Would recommend for many reasons.Travellers tips - Check out the Imperial Palace on a Sunday - roads are closed and there's free bike hire!

We stayed at the Hotel in April, just after the Sakura (cherry blossom) season. We could not have had a better experience. Although the room wasn't very big (I don't know where you would find a big room in Tokyo), it was extremely comfortable, clean, and it provided everything we could ask for. The price of the room was very good, better than other comparable hotels. Our friends stayed at the much pricier Conrad Hotel next door, and although it was a good experience it was 4 times the price. We also loved the design of the hotel - it was very modern, without being cold. The best thing about the hotel is the location. It is close to a local subway, and more importantly it is close (3 minute walk) to the JR Yamanote Line. It is very important to be on the JR Yamamote line because it is the "express" train that runs in a circle around the heart of Tokyo stopping in all the best neighborhoods (Shibuya, Shinjuku). The Yamanote also gets you to the bigger train stations such as Tokyo Station, where you catch the bullet trains, etc. to quickly get in and out of the city. The best thing you can do for yourself during a visit to Tokyo is to stay near a Yamamote Line. Also, this hotel is walking distance to Ginza, arguably the ritziest shopping district in Tokyo.

I dont understand people's excitement about this hotel. My wife and I stayed for a week on our 5th trip to Tokyo, but were disappointed by the lack of service in this hotel compared to other Tokyo hotels. It seems that the staff here is trying very hard to imitate the style of New York hotels, in that they make you feel anonymous, and dont really extend a welcome feeling. No bows, no greetings, and no help with the bags. I guess many gaijin prefer this treatment, but why come to Japan if you want New York. The room was quiet with a nice view and lots of amenities typical of Tokyo hotels (toothbrush, hair brush, shampoo, razor, morning newspaper, minibar, tea and coffee). The furniture and rug were spotted with stains. The room safe was too small for a 12" laptop. It seemed the hotel guests were mostly foreigners. By comparison, we spent one week at the Takanawa Prince for half the price, and had much better treatment, same amenities, swimming pool, large room safe, larger room, nice view and felt like we were in Japan.

The Park Hotel is the second hotel we stayed in during our recent Tokyo holiday, and it matched the excellent experience we had at our first hotel (Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel) in virtually every respect. We stayed at two different hotels because we bookended Tokyo stays with a five-day trip to Osaka and Kyoto. Our bifurcated itinerary enabled us to visit sights near our hotels (Shibuya, Harajuku, and Shinjuku while at the Cerulean; and Asakusa, Imperial Palace and Tsukiji while at the Park) without spending time and money travelling around Tokyo. Even though Tokyo has an excellent transportation network, getting from Point A to Point B can still be quite time-consuming.As far as the Park Hotel is concerned, we had a lovely corner room with a stunning view of Tokyo Tower. Though not overly large, our room was very well-designed and fully-equiped with LCD-TV, mini-bar and, best of all, free high-speed internet. Our bath was spacious and was stocked with a full array of amenities. Service from every hotel employee was gracious and polite. And, location-wise, the hotel is about a seven-minute walk from the Shibuya station on the JR Yamanote line.One tip: We did not think the 2200 Yen cost for the Park Hotel's breakfast was worth the price (the Cerulean's breakfast offerings were far superior), so we decided to eat breakfast at the nearby Conrad. We agree with other posters that the Conrad is a spectacular hotel visually and will only add that its breakfast is also superb. Though the Conrad breakfast was not cheap (3400 Yen), the wide array and the excellent quality of the offerings lessened the sting on the wallet.

Great Hotel. Great location. 2 very important things. Don't be discouraged about the small space since this is standard in most Japan and European hotels. The staff is very helpful and everyone spoke English. The concierge desk can help you with anything. Housekeeping was wonderful and always willing to help/serve your needs. A must stay in Tokyo. The location to sites and subways is very convenient. I would definitely stay here again.

The staff is so awesome here! They all spoke great English and were so accommodating to our needs! A present I brought from the US got smashed, and they quickly re wrapped it for me. Also, internet is free, so that is a big plus. The rooms are pretty small, which is the only downside. Check out the spa; wonderful massages although expensive, well worth it! Would definately come back.

This is the second time I stayed in this hotel and it was as good an experience as the first time.Although rooms are on the small side the quality of mattress is excellent and the insonorisaion is faultless. Having stayed 2 weeks altogether I was never woken up by a toilet flush or a running bath.During Winter, you can enjoy spectular views and see FujiYama very clearly.This hotel is very central and is 10 mins walk to Ginza where all the best craftmen and luxury brands can be found. Even the old Tokyo Asakuza can be reached in 20 minutes by public transport: you never need a taxi when staying at this hotel.Although the breakfast is expensive at the hotel (~£12), the Shiodome will offer all the variety you may be craving for from Indian food to Cheese cake. Another bonus the monumental painting of Taro Akamoto about Hiroshima nuclear bombing is on display until end of August and literally 5 minutes walk from the hotel.To beat the jet lag on arrival, have a walk at Hanna Park ( just behind the hotel) a traditionnal Japanese park with a tea house on a small island in a middle of the lake. If you do wake up early in the next morning do go the fish market ( 15 minutes walk).On your way back to the airport, the hotel organises a limousine shuttle ( coach) stopping only at 2 other hotels in the immediate vincinity for just £15. If you have not checked out 1 hour before the time you booked, they will even wake you up to ensure you are not going to miss you flight: this is what I call service!

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. The lobby is on the 25th floor with the room above. The rooms are small but very well appointed. The view of the Sumida river and Tokyo is marvelous. It is clean, new and within walking distance to the fish market. We took a taxi to the fish market because it's a little complicated figuring out which road it was on. The staff is very helpful. There is an internet connection in the room (ask for a two prong adaptor, it's free). It's right near the subway and JR trains. We met a Tokyoite for lunch and ate in the restaurant which was very good but expensive.

Three of us (my husband, our 12-year old son, and I ) stayed here for a week. We loved the hotel. Our room was quite large with a wonderful view of the Tokyo skyline. It was clean, extremely quiet, and very comfortable. The service was impeccable. The location was great. Both the subway and JR were right underneath the building. There were also many restaurants easily within walking distance. If ever in Tokyo, we would definitely stay here again.

We stayed at the Park Hotel for two nights end of May. The lobby and rooms were amazing and the service was impeccable. We arrived at 10 in the morning and not only were they able to accomodate us, they gave us a room on the top floor with a beautiful view of Tokyo Tower. The location was very convenient to transportation and walking distance to Tsukiji Fish Market (a must visit). The staff spoke great English and very helpful, always providing directions and recommendations. We were going to try the spa for a massage but they were having staffing problems, so the conceirge directed us to Ooedo-Onsen-Monogatari, which was the most relaxing experience of my life. I would definately recommend this hotel.

The instructions to the hotel were good, but a fair traipse from Shinbashi station (about 15 min walk) not great after a long flight from England! However, easily found. The staff were very welcoming and luckily our room was ready on arrival (11am) although it was a smoking room and it did smell. We couldn’t be bothered to request a different room.. we just wanted bed! The room was on the small side as was the bathroom, however, it was very clean and had everything we needed for a comfortable stay. The hotel is situated in the Shiodome area, which seems quieter than the rest of Tokyo we had explored. We liked this, and it was a welcome relief from the hustle and bustle of the city. It was a 5/10 min walk from the action of Ginza. Ginza is a great place to explore and preferred this to the other area (Roppongi) we stayed. Overall, very pleasant all round stay in this Hotel

Our stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo was a most enjoyable one. We thought the lobby and lounge area were very beautiful, relaxing, and serene in its decor. Our room was comfortable, clean, with every ammenity provided. As for the service, we were spoiled yet very appreciative of the attention given us. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is visiting Tokyo for either business or pleasure.

I stayed for 4 days, and wish it could have been 2 weeks. The hotel is perfectly located in the cener of Tokyo. Every imaginable type of transportation is right in the immediate area.The hotel lobby on the 25th floor has an impressive view at night of the Toyko tower. My room on the 29th floor has a great view, and while not all that large, it was a perfect fit.Walking out of the hotel on the 3rd floor deck, it is almost like stepping into the Jetsons world. Futuristic skyscrapers with pedestrian walkways that take you every where without interacting with the street traffic below.This was my second trip to Tokyo, and I can hardly wait to return to both the city & the Park Hotel.

I had a wonderful stay (6 nights) at this hotel! Everything was clean, pleasant and comfortable, and the room had a nice, modern design. Free wireless was available, which is always nice, and the bathrooms were spotless, another important factor! As other reviewers have mentioned, the rooms are small, but not ridiculously so (I've been in smaller), and are nicely furnished so they feel clean and bright.Location: this hotel is in the SE quadrant of the city of Tokyo, within walking distance of Ginza. It's located in the Shiodome Media Tower, which is right above Shiodome Station (about a 5 minute walk); from this station you can access the Oedo line (which sort of does a loop around the city) and the new Yurikamome line, which offers a direct route to Odaiba (I recommend riding this route even if you don't plan on exploring Odaiba, just for the fabulous view you get while crossing the Rainbow Bridge). If you walk another 5 minutes from this station, you can get to Shimbashi Station, which serves the Asakusa and Ginza lines but also the JR Yamanote line, which is the one you can ride without buying a ticket if you've got one of those Japan Rail passes. Riding from here to the trendy areas of Shibuya/Harajuku/Shinjuku via JR takes about 20-30 minutes, though it never feels that long when there's so much to observe! Shimbashi Station is also just two stops away from Tokyo Station, which is the major hub for bullet trains or trains that take you on day trips to places such as Kamakura. I could go on but the main point here is that the hotel is conveniently located.There are places to eat in the hotel, of course, but there are also a bunch of restaurants in nearby Carretta Tower and also the tower right next door (the name escapes me at the moment). Numerous coffee shops are nearby (including Starbucks, if you need it! - one in the train station and one in the tower next door), as are convenience stores (including 7-11). Again, I highly recommend this great hotel. Just make sure you get the right one, because there are a few hotels with similar names in Tokyo!

I just returned from a 3 week vacation throgh out Asia, and the Park Hotel Tokyo was one of the best ones I stayed in. Considering prices in Tokyo, the Park Hotel provided by far the best value. The hotel is perfect, great view and beautifull decor. The location was really convenient, and they upgrated our room without any extra charge. Definetly one of the best hotels experiences I've had in every aspect. No wonder is #1 on this list.

This truly is a wonderful hotel in every aspect except for the filthy habit of people who smoke in the lobby and restaurant area. Location in perfect proximity to JR and subways. Ginza is a great shopping area and the department stores there put American ones to pathetic shame! The room is a little small, but with new, chic decor. You'd be hard pressed to find a better hotel. Paid about US$200 per night. If you're on a budget, go ahead and spend the extra money to stay here!

We stayed here for 3 days in April.Beware there are several hotels with "park" in their name including one opposite. This one being newish was not the first thought for taxi drivers etc., Make sure you have the Japanese language hotel card with you to show. Tell them Shidome and they are OK!The best way from the airport is the airport coach,which stops at the hotel (and others) but does not stop at this hotel in the mornings! Booking in at a lobby on the 25th floor seemed strange at first but this is offset by the fabulous overviews of the city.Rooms are adequate (small) but perfectly acceptable, bearing in mind the cost of land in central Tokyo. Service and facilities were A1and the very good western breakfast in the lobby which has an atrium 8 stories high!Well recommended!

Great views. Spotless room. Nice price. We were amazed to find out you could stay in such a nice place in Tokyo for this price. (We paid about $220 including tax). Rooms are small perhaps but for Tokyo it was fine. Bathroom was real nice. Location is convenient to the subway and the JR Line which connects you to pretty much to everything you want. It is close to the fish market (10 min walk) which we thought was one of the highlights of Tokyo.

I am sorry...but I went here on the ratings of Trip Advisor and I was very disappointed. First, the room I received was SO small. I have seen small rooms, but this one was awful. Second, my sheets were stained. This is unacceptable. Third, the room was sooooo hot.I nicely told the front desk after one night that I was going to check out. They offered to give me another room, but I decline and walked across the street to the CONRAD Tokyo, which although 12,000 more Yen a night, it was 3 times better!!Buyer beware.On the plus side...good views and nice lobby.

We loved our stay at this hotel, the staff are very helpful, the location is within walking distsnce of Ginza and the shiodome area possesses many restaurants. The hotel room had a great view of the tokyo tower which we gazed at a lot in the evening! The breakfast at the hotel was lovely, and transport very easy from this area of towm. Also within yards of the hotel you can get on the transit line to tokyo bay which was fun with lots of shopping and a small beach. Tokyo is very special, efficient and great people. The area we especially enjoyed was Harajuku and Omatesando, because of the lovely cafes and the museums. Walking in tokyo is very easy also. Shinjaku is as expected very crazy. I'd definitely recommend the day trip to kamakura. The Park hotel was the best city hotel we've stayed in.

I'm a seasoned expat living in Tokyo. Have been living in Japan for over 15 years. When my firm or a client is footing the bill and the budget is not a concern, I prefer the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku or the Grand Hyatt in Roppongi. When I'm footing the bill for a short-term stay, I like this hotel. It is clean, comfortable, stylish, relatively inexpensive (for Tokyo), and often has great views. The downsides are 1) everyone from taxi drivers to long-time Tokyo residents confuse it with the Royal Park Shiodome, located across the street, 2) the single rooms are a bit small, so it pays to upgrade to a slightly larger room if within your budget, and 3) shiodome has many great restaurants in the skyscraper buildings, but it is a bit outside the happening central areas of Tokyo. Unless you are comfortable taking the subway (Toei-oedo line is at your doorstep), you'll be taking cabs everywhere. Shiodome is not too far from Roppongi/Akasaka/Aoyama/Daikanyama to make this impractical, but it can be costly and time consuming. That said, this is one of my favorite hotels in Tokyo, and I give it the highest rating with the above provisos.

Understated hotel in Tokyo's Shidome district. Minimalist design and very hip. Room space is decent enough and comes with LCD TV sets. Although Tokyo action might be quite a distance, for it's very reasonable price compared to most Tokyo hotels, it's worth the stay. Getting around Tokyo from Park Hotel is quite easy as well. Park Hotel sits on the higher floors of the new Shiodome Media Center while below it lies the subway station to get you to most parts of Tokyo. Staff are very friendly and in the loop to most of Tokyo's happening places. They'll be more than happy to assist you in and around Tokyo. At night, don't forget to catch the jazz band in the lobby. For smokers, smoking in the lobby is permitted.

We stayed two nights at the Park Hotel and two nights at the B Roppongi (see review) and both were excellent hotels but obviously aimed at different markets.The Park Hotel is in a different league and so obviosuly the same criteria don't apply, you pay more and so your expectations are greater. We loved the Park Hotel, although as noted in other reviews, the Shidome area was a bit sterile after the lights and action of Roppongi. An easy walk to the Tsukigi fish markets, the Hamarikyu gardens and Ginza and an easy tube up to Ueno park, Akihabara and Asakusa. But the whole walkway above street level among the huge skyscrapers was a bit strange. Have you seen Bladerunner ? The monorail (Yurikamome) out to the Oedo Onsen Monogatori (hot baths) is worth doing as well - the station is just next to the hotel.As for the hotel, we had a standard double room and had no concerns with size (maybe that is a whole US pre-occupation). Very clean, robes, LCD TV with BBC in English, minibar, in-room safe, toiletries and everthing you could wish for. A heated toilet seat but unlike the B Roppongi, no beer dispensing machine on each floor !! The city view from our room on level 32 was simply spectacular. The staff were excellent, spoke better English than I did, and were extremely helpful. Very good knowledge of the local area which is important. They also allowed us to check-in early and had a room for us at 11am which was great.We didn't eat at any of the three restaurants in the Hotel, but there are plenty of good eating options in the nearby Cabretta Mall and for very reasonable prices. Nearby Ginza has plenty of more sophisticated restaurants and bars but be warned, we couldn't find a bar with a happy hour and had to get up and leave one jazz bar after finding out a single beer was going to cost Y2000.Would definately stay again and it was a very nice hotel. I would imagine you could pay a lot more for a similar standard at other hotels in Tokyo. Deserving of the praise received on this website.

The Park Hotel is a very hip hotel for a very good price. The lobby is impressive, as it is an open space that rises from the 25th floor, where the registration desk is, to the 35th floor. The morning breakfast buffet, which is served in the lobby, was good. The Japanese restaurant in the hotel was excellent. As for the room, the decor was nice, and the bed was comfortable, although a bit firm. The bathroom was small, but adequate. The location of the hotel is within walking distance of the Ginza shopping district and the fish market. It also sits above the subway station. The only downside to the hotel was the ventilation system, which filled with cigarette smoke from the other rooms.

My husband and I recently stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for 6 nights. The lobby was very nice and although we never sat to listen, they have jazz bands at night for entertainment. The staff was very helpful, although we had to wait a long time for the concierge one day. They finally had someone else help us, but her English was not very good. The manager did check on our way out that she had given us the correct directions to our destination. They made dinner reservations several times for us. We loved the free business center where there were two computers to check/send email. The view from behind the check in desk of Tokyo Tower and the city was truly amazing. We saw Mt. Fuji twice, which we couldn't believe. This hotel caters to westerners, more than Japanese it seemed. It is hard to find at first if you arrive on the train at Tokyo Station, but once you figure out where to go, it's very convenient. We loved the whole underground area that connects to Shimbashi Station on the JR Yamanote line and the Ginza subway line. We ate breakfast in the Vie de France bakery every day rather than paying the high prices for the hotel's breakfast buffet. The pastries were very good and I loved the kiwi banana soymilk smoothies. We thought having a subway station below the hotel would be convenient, but we never ended up using the Oedo line. It just didn't go to any of the areas we wanted to visit. The room was very clean and modern, and as everyone else has said, small. There was enough room for two of us though, and for the price (we booked on Expedia for $180 per night) it was well worth it. The water pressure was very strong and we loved the heated toilet seat. The provided toiletries were of high quality also. We had a wonderful view of Hama Rikyu gardens and the water. It was also a very quiet hotel, we never heard any noise when we were in our room. We liked the location of the hotel (I know there's been mixed reviews on this). It's proximity to the JR Yamanote line was perfect as we preferred to take that rather than the subway because it was free with our JR rail passes. It's also perfect if you plan to visit the Tsukiji fish market and Hama Rikyu Gardens, which we did on our first morning. The above ground walkways and underground malls and restaurants in all the surrounding buildings seemed exactly what this futuristic city should be like. If you wanted nightlife it's a short walk to Ginza or short train ride to any area in Tokyo. We never took a cab so we didn't have the trouble of the driver not being able to find it. Shiodome really is a whole city within the city. We would definitely stay here again.

I won't go over the ground covered by previous correspondents but, this hotel is good value. I paid slightly more than I would pay in a 4 star Hotel in either Hong Kong or Los Angeles, though the quality and service was far, far better.The room I had was small, but very comfortable, with a generous sized bed. Small flatscreen TV, a good bathroom with great toiletries, filter coffee, yukata etc.When i left this morning, the concierge took my bag, brought coffee down to the waiting area whilst I waited for the bus to Narita, and gave out umbrellas to a couple of tourists who were likely to get wet! Needless to say, both the level of service and indeed the level of english is quite good (for Japan).As for the location, it is a bit sterile, but i got used to it. The Shiodome site has coffee shops and eateries all around it. The Shimbashi/Shiodome station system seemed to have all the major lines go through that area which was a bonus.I would definately stay here again.

Just came back from 5 nights stay at the hotel.All have been already written by the previous reviewers so just little to add:The location is superb - very quiet location althoughabove train stations. The new Shiodome area is very interesting in its architecture aspects. There are so many good restaurants, coffee houses and supermarkets in the buildings complex around the hotel that you can dine in the area without being needed to go elsewhere.The staff in the hotel is superb - willing to help in any subject. The view from the room and the lobby is magnificent, in a clear morning you can see Fujiyama!The only minus is the room size: we stayed in a double room and we couldn't go around the bed withoutbumping into each other...

Just got back from stay in Tokyo. I read all the reviews for the hotel (that is why I chose it). I went to Tokyo by myself and this was my first trip to Japan. I would stay at this hotel again. Here is some pratical advise:Hotel is loacted at the end of Ginza's main shopping street (about 8 min walk). Perfect hotel for high end shopping and back to hotel again.Once you find the hotel it is easy to find your way around. (initially finding it was impossible for me.)If you choose this hotel here is the best way to find it:Take JR express to Tokyo Station. Take subway to Shimbashi station (only two stops away). Exit Shimbashi station and get a cab with the print out of directions from Park Hotel's website). The cab ride was only 660 yen (about six bucks and well worth it). I am a pretty sauvy travler and could not find the hotel on my own. Once you know where it is it is easy to head out and find your way back.If you don't only shop on Ginza it is a short and easy subway ride to anywhere else.Booking your room on their website is the cheapest option.

We stayed here for 4 nights and had an excellent time. Agree with other review - perfect location (with train lines to get you anywhere) although the rooms are a little on the small side. Ask for a City View.

Taking the advice and statistics from this website, I chose Park Hotel Tokyo for our 5 day trip with my toddler, 2 years old. It was a good choice. Shinjuku has always been our choice of area for Tokyo visits, this time I decided to try elsewhere. Not disappointed at all. Like most have said, the area is ultra modern, very clean, sleek, and Shiodome area is very business like, and like a small city itself.I found the location to be perfect. It was easy access to everywhere. It's actually next to Ginza. So how much more convenient can it get? going to the fish market for breakfast, and Starbucks just across the basement of the hotel.The staff is the best I have every encountered. Excellent english, and very helpful concierge. Each time we asked for directions to somewhere, they would print out the map, and exact directions for us. Subway map, hotel map provided. The most impressive was, when we got back from our trip to Nikko, we needed to repack our luggage before going to the airport. The Hotel was kind enough to give us a spare room to do this instead of having me to do it in the lobby. It was very generous of them. We already checked out the day before. They stored our luggage, and provided this service of bringing our stored luggage upstairs for us to reorganize, and then had a bellboy help us bring back all the luggage after we were finished.This was very helpful, especially because I was travelling with a toddler.The hotel is very catered to Business travellers, but we were treated with perfect service and attitude even with a young child.The Japanese restaurant was excellent.All in all, I was very happy with our choice. The rooms are small, but that's what Japan hotels are usually like.

Rooms: The room we had, though quite small, was clean and nicely furnished. The water in the bathroom gets hot immediately and the water pressure is fantastic. The views from the room--we had views towards the bay, not the city--were quite nice.Location: When you first arrive at the hotel, the area seems a bit corporate, a bit bleak. Once you get used to using the skybridge, which is connected to the hotel at the third floor, you realize that the area, Shiodome, is actually a little city, just three blocks above of the street. Not only that, once you venture from the hotel at ground level, you realize how well-located the Park Hotel actually is. It's a 10 minute walk from the Tsujiki Fish market, 5 minutes from the Hama Rikyu Gardens, 15 minutes from Ginza, and located on top of a subway line and 5 minutes from the JR line. All in all, the location was very, very good. We liked the Shiodome area itself because it looked like how we imagined Tokyo to be before arriving--clean, hyper-modern, and hyper-efficient.Service: The service here--with all the graciousness the Japanese are famous for--was really first class. Each staff member we encountered was very helpful--they assisted us in mailing letters, getting train reservations, and the like. The staff are everywhere and always willing to help.Overall: This is a new hotel in a developing, very modern area. If not for the small size of the room--we had bigger rooms elsewhere for the same price--I would give it a 5.

Impressed by the comments we'd read on Tripadvisor.com, we recently stayed at the Park Hotel in Tokyo for 4 nights in mid-March. While we were pleased with the hotel itself, we felt disappointed with its location and would not stay there again. The hotel is in a high-rise building which sits amidst a small cluster of skyscrapers in the relatively deserted Shiodome area of Tokyo. The area surrounding the skyscrapers is a gigantic construction site which has obliterated most all of the sidewalks. There is no street life whatsoever -- if you have the urge to walk around the neighborhood, get a bite to eat or people watch (as we wanted to do), there is nothing to see & nowhere to go except the confusing, identical underground passageways that link the buildings. On the positive side. the hotel is within walking distance (20-30 minutes) of the Ginza district, Tsjuki Fish Market and the beautiful Hama Rikyu Gardens. However, no taxi drivers or tour guides know about the hotel yet and it was difficult to find our way back when we took cabs. It also didn't help that right next door to the Park Hotel's location in the Shiodome Media Tower is the ROYAL Park Hotel located in the Shiodome Tower. Confusing! The hotel's rooms are well-appointed with a very modern, sleek style that is quite nice. The staff was helpful. But we would have preferred to be in a neighborhood like Aoyama or the upcoming Daikanyama with shops, restaurants and people around.

Spent two nights in a double room. The hotel staff was very friendly and spoke English well. There was always someone readily available to talk to if need be. Like other reviewers stated the location may be an issue but we didn't have any problems with using the nearby subway station. A couple taxi drivers had trouble finding the hotel for some reason though. In any event the view from the room was fantastic, Tokyo Tower was head on and the room was very clean and comfortable. The only downside is that the room wasn't large although I didn't mind the size especially considering the very reasonable price for this hotel. Also, there is a shuttle from Narita that is about 30 dollars.

I stayed at Park Hotel Tokyo for one week in early March. I have nothing but positive things to say about the accomodations (rooms were larger than expected), as well as the very friendly english-speaking staff. The location was exceptional, as were the views of Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji. The subway lines are very easy to access from the hotel. I feel the room rates are reasonable, I am sure it would be difficult to find a room like this in New York or London at this price. I will most certainly stay at Park Hotel Tokyo again when I am able to return to Tokyo (hopefully soon!).

First of all, I did'nt mind the location (which seems to be the largest issue most people have with the hotel). It is within walking distance to Ginza and Shimbashi... and a close station on the Yamamote line (Shimbashi) and a Metro stop (Shiodome -- once you learn how to get to each. The room I got was really small, even for Tokyo standards...having said that, I did book a standard double. The room was OK, but I would not call it a luxury hotel room (I also stayed at the Granvia in Kyoto which was). Check in was easy. My largest complaint was at check out, where at 6 in the morning there was a line of 3, and only one person behind the desk. I was asked to sit and wait. Soon the person behind the desk left. Finally someone from the back came out to deal with the next customer. He had an issue of thinking he pre-paid, and didnt want to pay again... so that went on and on. It wasnt until I complained to the Bell person that she fished someone else out of the office to check me out. Ahotel like this (which gets the #1 ranking) shouldnt let customers wait like that. We didnt try the hotel restaurants (there are plenty around the area) so I can't comment. All in all, it was OK, perhaps a decent value for the price.

We recently stayed at the Park and found it to be a pleasant stay. The location is good and the staff is excellent. They have custom pillow fitters which was interesting:) The rooms are small compared to american rooms. If you need space upgrade. We enjoyed the view very much due to the fact that the hotel is on the 25th floor. This hotel is within walking distance to Ginza. I would highly recommend going on a city tour if you are only there for a limited time. All in all it was a great place.

Believe all the positive Tripadvisor reviews, we're very happy that we did. My Wife and I spent 2 nights at the Park Hotel on the way to skiing at Hakuba (also highly recommeded). The panorama window behind reception on level 25 provides a fabulous view. Our room faced a different direction so we opted to pay extra (not much) for the view facing Tokyo Tower (Japan's answer to the Eifel Tower). In the morning, we were very pleased to be able to see Mount Fuji quite clearly.The rooms are efficiently laid out and very clean. The staff were all very happy to assist. Ask at the tour desk for their recommendation of a sushi restaurant down near the fish market. A short walk and worthwhile adventure. The temple beside Tokyo Tower was also well worth visiting. Whilst you're there, one of our favourite destinations was to have coffee and cakes on the 42nd floor of Mori Tower. Sit at the window and enjoy the view back towards Ginza. The hotel's website has location maps for the short walk from the neighbouring station. With direct service to Tokyo Station and on to Narita Airport, the trains are very a very efficient and safe travel option. Expect there to be too much in Tokyo to see and do. Just plan on going back, as we do. The Park will definitely be our first choice. Currently ranked #1 with good reason. Enjoy.

I think everything of this hotel is good, except location. If you go to Tokyo for shopping, choose another hotel in major shopping area - like Shinkuju. You know, you need to drop you bags sometime to hotel and rush out for shopping again. The hotel is close to Ginza, but it is very far from Shinkuji (the major shoppers paradise). It takes 30 minutes by JR from Shinkuju to Shimode! But have to say the hotel is very stylish and staff are warm and helpful.

I am still here waiting to go to airport and have had a fantastic 3 nights at this excellent hotel. Excellent service, location, furnishing, cleanliness 5 plus stars all round - although expensive like all Tokyo hotels.

I spent two nights at the Park Hotel with my girlfriend in December 2005. We were very pleased with this hotel. The connection to and from Narita was easy, and the hotel was very modern, clean, friendly and well located at Shidome Station, and a short walk to Shimbashi Station. You can expect to pay unavoidably high Tokyo prices.

My wife and I spent two nights at the Park Hotel Tokyo in a Double Room facing Tokyo Tower. We had such a great time! Even prior to our stay, the hotel's concierge assisted me with planning various events including dinner at Iron Chef Hiroyuki Sakai's restaurant. The room is definitely small, but cozy and clean. The view of the Tokyo Tower made up for the smallness of the room. The bed was very comfortable with a down comforter. Free internet access at the business center (with a great view) was a great perk. Using the subway to travel to various sites was very convenient as directions the station were in English. Be sure to bring your coat if your walking to the subway station during winter; the winds gust through the passageways. We would definitely stay here again the next time we are in Tokyo.

My wife and I stayed at the Park hotel for two nights on route to Sydney and found the location to be excellent, easy walking distance to Ginza. The room was spotless although a little small but from other reviews this seems to be common theme in Tokyo. I would recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo.If you arrive in the morning you will find that the only option to the city centre is via train or taxi as the hotel buses don't run until 13:00 ish so we left our large suitcases at the airport left luggage counter which made life much easier.

Just returned from a 5 night stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo. This is a first class hotel, very intimate with very attentive and accomadating staff. Most all speak english very well. Location was convienent to the Shimbashi train station, where you can take trains to almost all parts of Tokyo, the JR Yamonte line was our train line as it took us to most major destinations in Tokyo. The Shiodame subway line was also right there. Hotel was also connected to the Carretta Shiodame shopping center where there was restaurants. Expect to do alot of walking as the train stations are big and if you get lost alot more walking. Hotel was in walking distance of Ginza also. The view from the lobby was of the Tokyo Tower, very beautiful, especially during sunset. The lobby seemed a little "stuffy" for our taste but if that's what you want. Arrival at the hotel could have been easier as there is no one from the hotel at the bottom of the building to great or help you with bags when you arrive, since the front desk is up on the 25th floor. All in all would stay here again and recommend it to others.

We usually prefer a smaller hotel with charm but in Tokyo, this was perfect. The location is convenient enough to transportation, the staff amazingly helpful and eager to please. All the rooms have amazing views as the hotel is above the 25th floor of a large tower that houses Tokyo broadcasting below. The room wasn't large but was very comfortable, well heated and nicely appointed. Robes were provided and the moment you requested anything, they were there with a smile. The lobby and cocktail lounge are inviting. At something like $200 a night, this felt like a terrific deal, particularly since they have top speed internet, will store your bags and take care of any requests.

I traveled to Tokyo on my own for the first time in July and I booked a room at the Park hotel after reading some good reviews on various sites. The fact that there was a shuttle from Narita directly to the hotel was also a bonus. I was shocked to find that the hotel I found was just perfect for my stay. Clean, new, modern, affordable... you can't ask for more. The rooms are small, but it's Tokyo, that's expected. Easy access to the subway system was also very convenient (entrance is in the bottom floor of the hotel).If you liked the movie "Lost in Translation", this is the hotel for you, if you can't afford the Park Hyatt (which is almost double the cost).

We stayed here for two nights and were very impressed. We had a room on the top floor with an excellent view over Tokyo. The room was lovely as was the rest of the hotel. The hotel is located on the 25th floor and the reception area has great views over Tokyo. It is also very handy for travelling around and is right next to monorail etc.

Have stayed here and Kyoto during an October 2005 vacation. Great hotel and excellent staff. They arranged all trips for us and airport shuttle ($30 each person). Room with 2 twins was nice and all have a great view. Booked through Hotels and had no problems.

We were in Japan for two weeks and stayed in the Park Hotel twice during that time. We found the hotel to be stylish and whilst the rooms are not the largest we have seen they are clean, comfortable and well appointed particularly useful was the free 'always on' cable Internet access in the room. The staff were friendly and helpful and it was enjoyable sitting in the bar listening to the jazz trio of an evening. We also found the location of the hotel very useful. If arriving on the Narita Express, it is only a 1440 Yen taxi ride away from the Tokyo Station and the train links near the hotel make it very easy to get around. There are also shops nearby from a local convenience store in the basement to bars and restaurants in the Pedi Shiodome complex which is linked to the hotel by a walkway. Overall, we had a very enjoyable stay there and would be happy to go back and recommend the hotel to anyone going to Tokyo.

We stayed at the Park Hotel Tokyo for a week in September 2005, in a double room with Tokyo Tower view on the 33rd floor. I had previously stayed at the Akasaka Prince, and we also dropped in on the Park Hyatt to see what it was like. By comparison the Park Hotel is a great example of how to be classy without resorting to grandiose-ness or overstatement. Major plus points: the hotel design and atmosphere, the staff and the location; negative points: small bedroom size, and the 1000 yen cover charge in the bar.

We just returned from our trip to Tokyo for our honeymoon and thought that we should offer our opinion on the very popular Park Hotel. We chose this hotel because of all the good reviews on TripAdvisor. Unfortunately, we were not as pleased by our visit. First and foremost, I must admit that the hotel staff is wonderful. They are incredibly helpful, and they speak English very well.That said, there were certainly a few concerns that will prevent us from ever returning to this hotel. The hotel rooms were tiny, even by Tokyo standards. But that was not our main dilemma. Our biggest complaint was that the bathrooms smelled very strongly of urine! Although the rooms looked clean, the bathrooms always smelled bad. We thought perhaps this was a fluke, so we moved into another room. The bathroom smelled of urine there too. In fact, we stayed in 3 different rooms at this hotel and found that they all had stinky bathrooms. We were very unhappy.Otherwise, the hotel is in a very convenient location with access to both the Japan railway and the subways. The hotel lounge offers live jazz on some days of the week, which is also very nice. If not for the horrible smell of the bathrooms, I would have given this hotel a better review.

Fantastic hotel, brand new, in one word: luxurious! The comforts and the staff made our stay in Tokyo a one in a lifetime experience. Very central and it has a tube station very close from where you can easily travel around Tokyo.Will definitely stay there again when we will go back to Tokyo.

I enjoyed my stay at the Park Hotel Tokyo very much. It's within walking distance to both Shimbashi station (which is a major subway station) as well as the famous Tsukiji fish market. I commuted by subway to a conference every morning, and it was easy and efficient. On the last day, I went for a stroll to the fish market, and had sushi for breakfast, and then to Ginza for some last minute shopping before heading for the airport with the Limo Bus service that the hotel staff reserved for me. It was efficient, easy, and comfortable stay over all. The hotel is modern, with all the latest furnishings. Highly recommended!

This is a fantastic hotel. My partner and Ihave just visited Tokyo for the first time as part of our honeymoon trip and we trusted the reviews on tripadvisor and decided not to spend on the Park Hyatt but booked the Park Hotel. This was taking a chance as we are used to 5 star travelling and are very fussy when it comes to accommodation. We made the right decision. The hotel is directly cconnected to the skyrail and to the metro so it couldn't be easier to get around the city. Also, it is a 5 minute walk to Ginza which we think was one of the nicest parts of the city. Much better than Shinjuku which is covered with MacDonalds! The service in the hotel was freindly and very efficient. One night we ordered room service at 3am and it arrived within 5 minutes. The reception staff couldn't be more helpful (they made reservations, posted our mail, provided us with the best guides to the city). The hotel itself is very stylish and modern but the best thing about it is that it is very much Japanese. This is something that we were worried about missing if we booked with a big chain like the Hyatt which has very American style surroundings. The rooms are comfortable with great amenities (trea, coffee, nice cosmetics, etc.) and the views of the city are unbelievable. This hotel is very close to being a 5 star. If it had a gym and the bar opened past 12 it probably would be.We have stayed here for 3 nights and would recommend it to any traveller.

My husband and I stayed at the Park Hotel for 4 days at the end of February, 2005. We attemped to find a hotel that was somewhat nice, but would not break the bank.The Park Hotel did not let us down! We paid about $190 per night, and booked our room online, at Travelocity.com. Most of the other rooms we were interested in were well over $250 a night, so we were surprised to find such a bargain.The lobby of the hotel is located on the 25th floor of the tower, and immediately we were impressed with beautiful views of the city and Tokyo Tower. The lounge area and bar off of the lobby, were immaculate and uber-classy. This was a perfect place to have an evening cocktail, or to listen to the lounge singer that performs on Friday nights.The rooms were on the small side, as are most rooms in Japan! We had a queen-sized bed, that came equipped with a cozy down comforter. The toilet sported a seat-warmer and a bidet..something I could get used to at home! We each received a pair of slippers and a Japanese-style robe, which were nice for lounging around after a shower or bath. The hotel also offers a "Pillow Fitting Service", where a consultant finds the perfect pillow for you, to make sure you get a great night's sleep! Only in Japan!Before we would head out for the day, we took advantage of the hot water kettle, and made ourselves cups of complimentary tea and coffee. It sure beat having to pay for room service!We didn't try the restaurant or room service during our stay, but ate several great meals at the Caretta Mall, which is directly across the street. There is everything there from high-end dining to Mc Donald's and 7-11! The Shiodome area where the Park Hotel resides, is still being developed, and seems to be less crowded than other areas in Tokyo. It was a nice quiet place to return to after a long day of sightseeing. The JR Shimbashi station is a few minute walk from the hotel, so it was very for easy to use public transportation. It is also in walking-distance from the Tsukiji fish market, which is a definite highlight in Tokyo. If you visit, you MUST GO TO TSUKIJI!All in all, our stay was wonderful, and the staff was friendly and courteous. They made us feel welcome from the moment we entered to the minute we checked out. When we finally make it back to Tokyo, this is where we'll be staying!

I would love to give this place 5-stars, but I had just come from a stay at the Park Hyatt, a hotel truly in a class of its own. The service here was especially gracious, even by Tokyo standards. A trainee bellboy, Nobuna, went out of his way to make sure we were comfortable in our room and repeatedly brought us various panphlets and maps full of activitiy and restaurant suggestions. He made our initial impression of the hotel that much better.The hotel's location is quite convenient, in Shiodome, a modern, up and coming area of Tokyo. We took the Yurikamome monorail line to Shiodome and wondered if we would need to take a taxi to the hotel. Much to our surprise, as soon as we stepped on the very convenient elevated pedestrian walkway, there were signs for the Park Hotel. There is also convenient underground access (about 7-10 min walking) to JR Shimbashi station and the Ginza and Hibya Metro lines.I am usually not a fan of open atrium style hotels, but the Park Hotel's design is very striking. The atrium gives one a sense of space that is hard to come by in Tokyo. Also, the lobby doubles as a lounge area and gives the hotel a sense of intimacy and activity while still maintaining that spacious feeling.Check-in was no problem and our room, while not large, was very attractively furnished with a full view of the Tokyo Tower. The 28th floor offered a perfect view of the Tokyo cityscape, perhaps even better than our 45th floor view from the Park Hyatt. Being at that level allowed one to look out to the cityscape, rather than down to it.

You cannot pick a better location, especially if this is your first time in Tokyo. We were in walking distance or easy cab ride from Ginza, Kabuki-za, the fish market, Shimbashi Station ( making coming into Tokyo from many train lines a breeze) as well as user friendly ( though not the best) restaurants via the walkways. Also, perfect area for someone who is handicapped, since so much of Japan is hard to get around. We also we able to connect easily with many subway lines from all of the stations right next to the hotel.Another thing that we liked was this hotel rounded out our stay in different types of Japanese hotels- this was the modern one- we also stayed in Historic traditional and business hotels.On the downside, the hallways seem to be slightly threadbare ( SLIGHTLY!) and we had a view of buildings from our room- not the " on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji" that so many other hotels claim. Had an in room massage- not the best I have had.Airport Shuttle bus comes to the hotel and the staff took care of every need- and of course, no tipping. Will stay here again next summer.

I have stayed at the Hilton, Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt, Century Hyatt, the Palace and a couple others. The Park Hotel has clean, quiet, modern rooms. The rooms are smallish but incredibly well designed. The location is walking distance to Ginza district and right above a huge shopping center. This is now my favorite hotel in Tokyo. When I checked out I needed a place to change into my street clothes. The manager gave me HIS OFFICE to change in!

Firstly - this place is so new that many cabbies don't know about it. Ask them to take you to Shidome and then look through the construction for the . Warning: The Royal Park Hotel is next door, and a not-so-easy walk across the construction.So perhaps it was because we stayed here the days preceeding Golden Week - but this place was quiet. Very quiet. And that just added to the funky/cool/mysterious/quirky feel of the place.However, I absolutely loved this place. The lobby was gorgeous, the staff extremely sharp, and everything was in place. If you're looking to hit the Tsukiji market first thing, this hotel is an easy walk to the auctions.I would definitely say that this hotel is a rising star in Tokyo - once the Shiodome area comes into it's own and the construction is done. Top notch, on par with the Imperial, ANA, Keio, New Otani - and just maybe one day the Park Hyatt.

My wife (30yo) and I (36yo) were both first-time visitors to Tokyo and plumped for this hotel after the positive comments we read on here. Without doubt we can add to those as this was a superb place to stay and we would recommend it to anyone. It benefits from being very modern and chic and at around £120 was definite value for money. True, the room wasn't that big but as long as you go there expecting that, it's not a problem at all. The fancy toilet (two levels of seat warmth!), flat-screen TV and wonderful views more than compensate. We paid an extra £5 a night for a view of Tokyo Tower and it was worth the extra for those "this was the view from our hotel room window" camera shots.The Shiodome area (full of modern skyscrapers) takes a few walkings to fully get your bearings but all the towers are worth a visit - especially for cheap eating. We eat in respectable places for under £30 a night (between us that is!) which certainly exploded the myth that Tokyo is the most expensive place in the world. Quite simply, it is not.Shiodome also has its own train station which is good for taking the underground to other parts of the City. You can also get the monorail from there to Odaiba, crossing the elegant Rainbow Bridge and getting a good look back to the City.Shinbashi station is also a 5-10min walk and that serves plenty of destinations on the overground JR Train. You can also take the train from here to Tokyo station (just two stops away) and catch the Shinkansen (Bullet Train). We did that when we had a day-trip to Kyoto.It definitely pays to carry a map of the train lines with you (the hotel will sort you out with one if you haven't got a guidebook) as at some stations the maps are only printed in Japanese. When this happened to us we just asked one of the staff who were all very helpful, taking us to the ticket machine, telling us how much to pay and even wishing us a "nice day!"We had breakfast in the hotel a couple of times (a tad expensive for £12.50 each) and it was a good way to start the day - cereals, fruit, bread, egg, bacon etc (there's plenty of time to eat Japanese food later in the day!).Finally, the staff were all overwhelmingly polite, spoke good English and made our stay a memorable one.For the same money, I'd be amazed if you could find anywhere as good as this!!!!!

We stayed at the Park hotel twice whilst in Tokyo for a total of nine nights. The location is exceptional, Ginza, Tskujii and shimbashi station all within convenient walking distance. We only had breakfast at the hotel once and found ample other options for western style breakfast in the immeadiate vicinity of the hotel (important after several japanese breakfasts).The convenience of Shimbashi station cannot be stressed highly enough. If you are not in tokyo on business and wish to do day trips the proximaty to Tokyo station (two stops) is extremely convenient. We used both the Ginza metro line and the Yamonote Train line extensively. The Shiodome area is modern and fascinating but the area around shimbashi station is terrific also and not mentioned in any guide books. We spent many nights in the restaurants and bars around Shimbashi station and met many Japanese who would later become friends.The hotel is well designed and offers all the modern amenities you would expect. The staff are courteous and could not be more helpful. The views from reception are remarkable. Would not hesitate to reccomend it and would stay again.

Park Hotel near the Shio Dome metro station is definitely "boutique hotel" hip. GREAT lobby atrium and stylish restaurant. BUT the windows don't open and it's a *little* out of the way. Close to the fish market and just a few minutes from the metro stop, but in an area of mostly business towers. Staff speaks excellent English and is really excited to suggest restaurants etc. Joggers: out-and-back 3 mile loop around the park where Tokyo Tower is situated, which is good since there isn't a gym on site.

I travelled to Tokyo with 4 of my male friends and we were all in our mid 20's. This hotel is just a couple years old and you can definetly tell with how trendy everything is. The lobby is on the 26th floor and it overlooks much of the city. On a clear day you can see Mt.Fuji from the hotel cause it is so high up. No matter what room you have, you will have some incredible view of Tokyo from way up. The concierges there speak perfect english. They have great knowldge of good tourist trips that can be taken. The hotel is next to 2 different train lines so you will have easy access to any part of Tokyo. The rooms arent the biggest that you will find in Tokyo hotels but if you are planning to be out and about a lot, it wont matter. I highly highly recommend this hotel. Ask them about their Mt. Fuji day trip too if you go.
this is the best hotel we had stayed in japan. it was mordern and simple, clean and convienet. it is a nice hotel and i would like to go back again
It's beautiful, stylish and the service is amazing (as with most places in Japan). We had a great time, and considered it a steal for the price.

This was my first visit to Tokyo and didn't expect to get a lot of hotel for my money based on what I had heard from colleagues who had been to Tokyo. But I was very pleasantly surprised by the Park Hotel. This is a VERY modern, new hotel centrally located near Ginza and many other attractions. Located right at the Shimbashi train station, it is easily accessible from Narita Aiport (take train to Tokyo station and then transfer and go two stops to Shimbashi), and within walking distance of many good sights. The Tsukiji fish market is a must-see and is just a short walk away. But back to the hotel. Free high speed internet in the room is something which I always appreciate. The room was very modernly decorated and fairly spacious for Tokyo. And at about US$200 per night, it is a very good deal. Also, guest rooms start on the 26th floor and go up to the 34th floor, so every room has a fantastic view of the city as this is one of the taller buildings in the immediate area. I will certainly stay here on my next visit. I spent 7 nights and enjoyed every one!

There is nothing to fault with the Park Hotel. It gives you Park Hyatt style service and location but at a much more affordable price. Its staff were incredibly friendly and its location was superb - the metro right at its basement and a short walk through nice shops to Shimbushi and Ginza. The rooms were very contemporary and the view of the city at night was to die for. Take a Limo Bus from Narita and back - it's the easiest, or take the Narita Express to Tokyo station and, if you have little luggage transfer, get on the metro to Shimbushi, or grab a cab. It restaurants also have wonderful views so set a night aside to dine there. We spent 2 nights on the way home from London here and would go back tomorrow if we could.

My boyfriend and I spent 4 nights here in June 2004. We stayed in a room on the 34th floor (the highest as I recall).The window in the room was enormous - basically the whole wall was a window (surprisingly not vertigo-inducing from that height)... views from our room were fantastic, from the vast foggy expanse of Tokyo during the day to the twinkling cityscape at night, with a great view of the Tokyo tower. I imagine that as the lowest floor of the hotel is half way up the Shiodome media tower, all rooms are likely to have pretty good views.The bathroom was small but beautiful, bright, spotlessly clean, and well eqipped with loads of goodies. The shower was wickedly powerful. The toilet warmed your bum and had inbuilt bidet - amusing... (on a toilet note, DO try the toilets downstairs in the lobby on the same level as the bar - seriously, you will see why). The flat screen TV in our room was a welcome surprise. Even the coffee and tea making facilities were really nice - you could make a green tea, filter coffee etc. -the attention to detail was formidable. The decor was bright and modern - our room was mostly red and white. The bed was sooo beautifully comfy and BIG.The bar is lovely, with attentive waiters, big comfy sofas, and jazz music playing live most nights, or at least gentle background music.Room service menu looked impressive but very expensive, so we didn't try any of the meals in the hotel apart from breakfast.Reception has a breathtaking view and the staff could not have been more courteous and helpful. My poor boyfriend was on crutches at the time and they were so kind to him, and so helpful, we were really touched.Internet access is free to all guests in the lobby for an hour each day of your stay. The staff will change the Windows settings from Japanese to English for you as necessary.The concierge were great, helping us to organise our transfer to the airport, and even helped me find an english speaking doctor when I fell ill that week.Breakfast buffet was extensive and yummy, and included in our package (booked through hotel directly) - not sure how much it costs separately though.As you can tell, although our trip was 6 months ago I remember so much of our stay here - it really is that memorable. We were so happy here and were sad to leave. Also the hotel really does look like the pictures on its website - modern, stylish and elegant.If we ever have to opportunity to return to Tokyo we will certainly stay here - very highly recommended.(the only (tiny) downside was getting a taxi driver to find it with my minimal Japanese speaking, as it was such a new hotel - perhaps that has changed now???)

This is a wonderful hotel. We have a room facing the Tokyo Tower. It's an amazing sight through the extra large windows. On clear mornings we can actually see Mt Fuji at a distance. The atmosphere is top notch. Very chic. The service is very good too, exceeding my expectation. I would not hesitant to recommend.The only issue is it's not very easy to find if you are coming out of JR Shimbashi. It's quite complicated, so have a hotel map with you. But at least it's close to a JR station. A must in Tokyo.

This is a relatively new luxury hotel in Tokyo and word about its greatness has not yet reached very far. Right now, staying here is one of the true bargains in Tokyo. The style and elegance is equal to that of the Park Hyatt in Roppongi Hills but at a fraction of the price.The location is terrific, only a short distance to the Ginza (a 15 minute walk or 5 minute cab ride). It is located in Shiodome (pronounced, she-Oh-doh-may), which is a huge office and shopping complex that is straight out of Bladerunner. One can navigate the vast Shiodome complex via walkways perched high above the underground shopping areas and well below an airy monorail and skyscrapers, while being surrounded by the gigantic electronic billboards that made Tokyo so famous -- a jarring but eye-opening experience that makes one want to redifine "urban".The hotel itself is on the top half of one of the Shiodome highrises, with the lobby way, way up in the sky. Once there, there is a central atrium, lined with bars and restaurants. The bar is terrific, has great jazz nightly and features an oustanding collection of single malts. Room size varies in size, depending on price, but even the smallest are very comfortable and feature the famed, high tech toilets that do just about everything imaginable and then some. There's a business center with three Internet stations in the lobby. Outstanding value for the money in this increadibly high priced city.

I stayed here for the first time past month, and I have to say - this is the BEST hotel I've ever stayed in. This is a small but luxurious boutique hotel that's not overly expensive. Every room here has a great view (no joke!!) and the staff are the friendliest I've encountered in all my visits to Japan. The restuarants have great view and are yummy. It's close to both the subway and the JR. Very convenient location! It's close to Tsukiji fish market and there's a convenient store as well near the 1st of the building. Really great place to stay, and the staff all speak good English. Words cannot explain how great this hotel is - please go to their website - the rooms all look just like the website promised. Highly recommened, and I'd love to come back!

I have stayed twice in this hotel - the first time for 3 nights and the second for 4 nights. Each time the service was fantastic (what else would you expect in Japan!). The twin room was a little on the compact size, however the design and room amenities were first class. The hotel is conveniently located in the new Shiodome district and is a short walk to the Shimbashi JR station. I would not hestitate to stay at this hotel again when I make future visits to Tokyo.
